fields.headline: Golding standard
fields.body:
Nicci Gerrard's brilliant article, Lost for an Answer (Comment, last week), sadly and accurately described the nature of life for significant numbers of children. It's as if they are marooned in islands of deprivation. But there is nothing new in the concept. In the Fifties the man who was teaching me English, William Golding, wrote a novel about it.
Ivor Annetts
Tiverton
Devon

webTitle: Leader: The honours list is imperfect

fields.headline: Cleaner than most
fields.standfirst: But there is still a lot wrong with honours
fields.trailText: But there is still a lot wrong with honours.
fields.body:
The honours list published this morning is perhaps best described as innocuous. Given some of those which preceded it, that is a term of approval. It is broad at the base and thin on top, which helps.

Few would begrudge the unknown citizens rewarded here for years of service, diligent but obscure: the caretaker in Harpenden; the street cleaner in Llandaff; the couple honoured for their work in the Shropshire cheese industry; the man who restored the organ of Glasgow Cathedral and the couple who raised the money to pay for it.

Higher up too, there is not a lot to cavil at. Though soap operas are far from forgotten, the names in entertainment and the arts are not quite as abjectly crowd-pleasing as sometimes before. The composer Harrison Birtwistle, who becomes a companion of honour, is not most voters' idea of a barrel of laughs. Paul Scofield gets the same honour; the playwright Peter Shaffer is knighted, along with the historian Norman Davies. And Spike Milligan gets a knighthood too, though since he is Irish, he cannot become Sir Spike. Many will flinch at the name of Jim Davidson, comedian and devoted Tory supporter: at least the accolade cites service to charity rather than to public morality.

The list's great virtue is the absence of that kind of life peerage which, however dressed up, is all too plainly a reward for services rendered and purse strings opened at a party leader's behest. That this occurred so often through the Conservative years was one reason why they got their reputation for sleaze, but it has happened too often too since Labour came in.

There are no such life peers this time; but that is largely because there are no life peers at all. A batch of "people's peers", selected from a list of those who applied, will come later. And after that, there may or may not be a list of political honours before the election. If that proves to be innocuous too, we shall be gratified. And very surprised.

webTitle: Sir Steve adds knighthood to Olympic glory

fields.headline: Sir Steve adds knighthood to Olympic glory
fields.trailText: Olympic gold medal winners, elderly comedians, soap stars and an array of hitherto unsung postmen and charity workers feature in a relentlessly populist New Year Honours List published last night.
fields.body:
Olympic gold medal winners, elderly comedians, soap stars and an array of hitherto unsung postmen and charity workers feature in a relentlessly populist New Year Honours List published last night.

All 22 British Olympic gold medallists (including those in team competitions) are recognised, mainly with MBEs, while rower Steve Redgrave, five times a gold medal winner, is knighted.

Comedian Spike Milligan, 82, is awarded an honorary knighthood - honorary because he is an Irish citizen. Astronomer Patrick Moore, 77, also becomes a knight.

Despite his active backing for the Conservatives and his at times sexist and homophobic repertoire, comedian Jim Davidson is awarded an OBE for charity work. TV presenter Beadle, who is reputed to have raised £10m for charity, gets an MBE.

In theatreland there are honours for Patrick Stewart, Paul Scofield, Tom Courtenay, Zoe Wanamaker and the Coronation Street star Bill Roache, alias Ken Barlow. Playwright Peter Shaffer, the author of Amadeus, is knighted.

Charlotte Rampling is given an OBE in the diplomatic list "for services to acting and UK-French cultural relations". The star of Visconti's The Damned moved to France some 25 years ago.

Overall the emphasis in the 990 awards is on public service with a strong showing for teachers, crimefighters and nurses. Some 10% of the awards are given in the field of education, 15% in health and social services and 24% in police and local government.

Three chief constables are knighted, including Charles Pollard of Thames Valley, a critic of zero tolerance.

In probably the last full honour's list before the election there are no peerages or explicitly political honours. However, as many as eight new cross-bench peers will be announced in the spring.

Downing Street praised the sacrifice and dedication of the British Olympians, promising a special reception for the entire team in the new year. It is also the first time that the paralympics team has been properly recognised for its extraordinary success, with five MBEs for gold medal winners.

Other sportsmen honoured include jockey Frankie Dettori and former Manchester United goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel.

Professor Grahame Bulfield, the director and chief executive of the Roslin Institute which cloned Dolly the sheep, receives a CBE for services to animal genetics. Scientists given knighthoods include Christopher Evans, the entrepreneur biotechnologist, and John Sulton, cited as a seminal figure in the field of genome research.

Intellectuals honoured in clude the historians MRD Foot and Professor Norman Davies.

Elsewhere in showbusiness the presenter of Desert Island Discs, Sue Lawley, and Trevor Harrison, better known as Eddy Grundy from the Archers, are honoured.

Pioneering disc jockey Annie Nightingale, folk singer Maddy Prior and veteran clarinet player Acker Bilk all receive MBEs. Sir Harrison Birtwistle, modern classical composer, is made a Companion of Honour.

fields.headline: Pressures build for rich and poor alike in the new boom towns
fields.standfirst: Following MPs' warnings that prosperity creates problems, Guardian reporters investigate two cases
fields.trailText: Following MPs' warnings that prosperity creates problems, Guardian reporters investigate two cases.
fields.body:
The town of Reading is booming. From the enormous Oracle shopping mall in the centre, heaving with sale bargain hunters, to the 180 acre GreenPark development in sight of the M4, where new offices are rising, it is impossible to avoid the signs of success. Unemployment is nil, wages are high and life, it seems, is sweet.

In the last 10 years the Thames Valley corridor has become Britain's own silicon valley with Reading at its heart. Formerly famous for its jail, the town is now home to IT giants such as Compaq, Microsoft, and shortly Cisco Systems.

Every silver lining has a cloud, however. According to concerned local MPs the Berkshire town is facing a "crisis of prosperity", an unforeseen flipside to the growth of the last 10 years. Reading is facing recruitment problems among nurses, police officers, teachers and bus drivers. Its infrastructure is sagging under the weight of traffic and, crucially, a housing shortage is pricing the low paid out of town.

The pattern, now familiar in London, where demand for housing has driven the cost of living beyond the salaries of those in the public sector, is being repeated to the west.

The prosperity problem is seen as so severe that the town's MPs are lobbying against new jobs. The imminent arrival of Cisco has caused disquiet, with Jane Griffiths, MP for Reading East, questioning whether there are the people to fill the jobs. A one bedroom flat in Reading starts at £80,000, with two bedroom houses closer to £130,000. These prices may be affordable for an IT graduate on a salary of £25,000, but they are beyond the reach of a nurse on a salary of £16,000.

James Walthall, 30, is a charge nurse at the Royal Berkshire hospital. With a degree and 11 years' experience, his salary is at the top end of the nursing scale - £26,000 - yet it is impossible for him to live within 15 miles of the hospital. Instead he commutes from Didcot, Oxfordshire, a 50 mile round trip.

"It costs around £200 to get to work each month, but there's no choice," he said. "My wife and I bought a three bedroom house in Didcot three years ago for £87,500. A similar property in Reading would cost around £160,000. We wouldn't get the mortgage."

Mr Walthall estimates that 55% of his nurses face a similar predicament, a problem which is causing a shortage of nurses.

"They try to make up the shortfall with overseas recruits - we recently recruited in India - but unless there's some sort of weighting we just won't get the staff."

The problem is more marked among the town's firefighters. While there is no shortage of potential recruits few of them live near their station. Of the six members of red watch at Whitley Wood station, less than a mile from Green Park, only one lives in Reading.

David Wilson, the watch commander, commutes daily from Alresford near Winchester, Hampshire, an 80 mile round trip, and his deputy travels from the Isle of Wight for the four days out of eight he works.

Mr Wilson said: "There's a couple of lads from Portsmouth, one from Barnstaple, and I've heard of lads coming down from Northampton and Lincoln and crashing with their mates. It is impossible to live here on a firefighter's wage."

With national pay deals failing to take into account differences in the cost of living, said Mr Wilson, public sector workers suffered from a topsy-turvy version of the north-south divide in which those from prosperous regions were penalised.

The phenomenon is repeated across the public sector. Reading schools are testing a scheme to offer teachers from south Wales accommodation with local teachers, subsidising their travel and rent. Thames Valley police have had to deal with new recruits leaving for another force as soon as they have qualified. Meanwhile, 120 bus services have suffered cancellations in the past year because of a lack of drivers.

But according to Manda Rigby, director of marketing for Cisco, Reading will continue to appeal to companies looking to expand away from London.

"The area has fabulous transport links with the M4 and the railway and it is not far from Heathrow. It may bring problems at the moment, but it is an investment in Reading's future. If there was not full employment I don't imagine that MPs would be complaining."

Related story: Prosperous old capital strains against its boundaries

webTitle: Wayne Sleep: Echinacea | Family photos | A silver Dutch doll

fields.headline: Wayne Sleep never travels without...
fields.trailText: Echinacea | Family photos | A silver Dutch doll
fields.body:
A necessity: Echinacea, a herbal remedy, which keeps me going when I'm exhausted. It keeps your system healthy.

A luxury: Photographs of my family. A luxury I don't always have is a good bed. Because I am a dancer, I need a very hard mattress, so half the time I end up sleeping on the mattress on the floor.

A good luck charm: A silver Dutch doll I have had since I was a baby and I keep by my bed.

If only: I could have a portable home, which would have the perfect mattress inside.

 Wayne Sleep is appearing in Jack and the Beanstalk at the Hall for Cornwall,Truro, until January 14. Box office: 01872 262466.

fields.headline: Ask a fellow traveller
fields.standfirst: Mike Harrison wants to know if it is possible to see America by delivering other people's cars
fields.trailText: Mike Harrison wants to know if it is possible to see America by delivering other people's cars
fields.body:
I have done "driveaways" across America twice, totalling over 10,000 miles. The main company is Auto Driveaway, 310 S Michigan Ave, Chicago, Illinois (www.autodriveaway.com). All you need to do is phone their nearest office (from a choice of 60) to find out where they have cars going to.

It is without doubt the cheapest way to get around America, as it doesn't cost anything. There are however, some downsides:

1 You don't get very long to complete the journey - you are expected to cover approx 150-200 miles daily (you may get a day or two extra for longer journeys).

2 Once you arrive, you have to hand the car back - when you may need it the most.

3 Your route is laid out for you, for insurance reasons - which will invariably mean travelling mostly by the Interstate Highways.

Richard Pavey

We did a driveaway coast to coast in 1990, from a company called Dependable in New Jersey. We'd found it impossible to organise from home; you just turn up and look in Yellow Pages - there are lots of driveaway agencies in each city.

You pay a deposit ($200 for us) refundable by the owners and make sure you have adequate insurance. If you want to go more than a few hundred miles, there must be two drivers each over 25 with a clean full UK licence. Take the contact details and address of the car's owners and get in touch a few days before you want to drop the car off. Ours offered to let us use it for the rest of our holiday!

Tess Guilding

www.driveaway.com provides office contacts and an idea of destinations available from some offices, as well as a lot of general information. We drove a van from Milwaukee to Seattle paying only petrol (approx $150) and motel fees ($30 a double). This is a great way to see America, especially if you can link up two or more deliveries, as long as you are flexible with time and destination! If you are lucky, you can get very nice cars too! Be aware that you will be driving to strict time and mileage limits (five to nine hours a day), must return the car in pristine condition to avoid fines, and delivery locations are often in out of the way places! Also, arrangements are last minute, so deals can disappear as well as appear quickly. Otherwise I highly recommend it.

Richard Lyon

In addition to holding an international driver's licence and being at least 21 (preferably 25), you need to be happy driving around 350 miles a day, leaving a cash deposit, not driving off the agreed route or at night and paying for all the petrol you use. One major drawback of the scheme is that there is no guarantee that there will be a car going anywhere you want to visit, but if you are willing to be flexible about your destination it's a marvellous way to explore the US.

Geraldine Fawcett

This week's question

What are the best, easiest and cheapest ways to see the Aurora Borealis, preferably in Britain?

TP Cooper

 If you have questions or advice, please write to: Ask a fellow traveller, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: ask.a.fellow.traveller@theguardian.com .

fields.headline: What Christmas presents
fields.trailText: On Christmas morning, I heard on the BBC a claim, made by a dame of the British Empire no less, so inherently preposterous, yet so chilling in its implications, that my senses have been reeling ever since.
fields.body:
On Christmas morning, I heard on the BBC a claim, made by a dame of the British Empire no less, so inherently preposterous, yet so chilling in its implications, that my senses have been reeling ever since. Given its capacity for inculcating greed in young people, I'm amazed and shocked that the BBC should have been willing to publish it.

The claim had to do with gifts alleged by Dame Joan Sutherland to have been showered on her over Christmas by her true love - identity unspecified, but presumably her husband of many years, Richard Bonynge, the distinguished conductor. Since the 12 days of Christmas had at this stage yet to begin (purists tell me they start with Boxing Day, making today the fifth of them), the events she described must have happened last year. The process, as she recalled it, began unobjectionably, as Dame Joan took delivery of a partridge in a pear tree. Subsequent days brought, in modest numbers, various species of bird: turtle doves, French hens and calling birds - all listed by Dame Joan in a tripping, insouciant manner. At this point, however, her manner changed. The next line was delivered more slowly, and much more portentously. The reason, I thought, was clear: the flow of birds had at that point dried up, and five gold rings had arrived. The calculation was clear. "Whoopee," the Dame must have told herself. "At last he's out of the aviary and into the jeweller's."

But here she was wrong. On day six - New Year's Eve, and a day when last year much of the world was busy mistakenly hailing the imminent dawn of a new millennium - the supply of jewellery ceased and the flow of birds resumed with six geese a-laying, followed by seven swans swimming on New Year's Day. From here on, the arrival of presents assumed quite alarming dimensions, with eight maids a milking on Sunday, nine ladies dancing on Monday, 10 lords a-leaping (unlikely under this Labour government to have been hereditary peers) on Tuesday, 11 pipers piping on Wednesday, and finally 12 drummers drumming on Thursday, January 6.

Similar claims, of course, have been made before, but never in my experiences with the authority of a dame of the British Empire. And never before had I realised the magnitude of what was alleged. For each item in the consignment was delivered not once but daily from its inception: the partridges, complete with their pear trees, on 12 successive days, the turtle doves on 11 and the French hens on 10. As figure one shows, the total of presents delivered had by the end reached 364: one for every day of the year except Christmas Day.

A little further analysis revealed one of those arithmetical pleasures which cause serious mathematicians to find such tear-jerking beauty in their profession. The sequence of these deliveries takes the form of what we bookish folk call a palindrome, though I guess you might also call it a perfect parabola. The first and last arrivals will in each case have contributed 12 to the final total (that is, 12x1 partridge-in-pear-tree, 1x12 drumming drummers.) The second and the penultimate category muster 22 each (11x2 turtle doves, 2x11 pipers). The acme is reached with the geese and the swans, of whom at the end there are 42 in each case (ie 6x7 swans a swimming, and 7x6 geese a laying.)

But that was only the start of it. As I contemplated the enormity of what Mr Bonynge had done, I began to assess its dire implications for public health and animal welfare. It is clear when you study the make-up of Dame Joan's gifts that other deliveries too must have taken place. The turtle doves will have needed a dovecote, and so on. One can easily imagine the crisis which must have occurred on day eight when the milking maids appeared on the scene. Note that Dame Joan specifies that the maids were not just milkmaids on their day off but were maids a -milking: ergo, they must have brought cows. Just how many cows is beyond my powers of computation. Ideally, there would have been eight, one for each maid. By the end of the process, though, a further 32 maids would have arrived, each presumably with a cow. A congregation like that would have needed a byre, and one very much hopes one was built to Maff specifications.

But worse still, the maids would have needed somewhere to sleep, as would the next day's contingent, the lords; and anyone even mildly familiar with the wicked ways of the aristocracy would hope the two groups were not billeted too close together. Perhaps rooms were found for these people down the road at the Dove and Drummer; but there may at a season like this have been no room at the inn. The problem would have grown even graver when the pipers arrived. What kind of pipes they were piping is nowhere specified: we must hope that they were not bagpipes, for bagpipers have to practise, and had they insisted on doing so close to the spot where the maids and the lords were attempting to sleep (preferably, as I say, not together), the standard of performance in the milking parlour and the leaping arena next day might have left Dame Joan disappointed. Since drummers are, if anything, even noisier than pipers, it is just as well the drummers were only there for one day.

And yet, were they? What happened to this gallimaufry of people and birds once the 12 days of Christmas were over is something of which Dame Joan neither sang nor spoke. Were they all paid off and sent home on January 7? Or do they continue to cluster around her home? And if so, are they now being joined by a further Christmas collection marshalled at the behest of Dame Joan's loving spouse? She published an autobiography in 1997, I see. Perhaps the time has come to update it.
fields.bodyText: On Christmas morning, I heard on the BBC a claim, made by a dame of the British Empire no less, so inherently preposterous, yet so chilling in its implications, that my senses have been reeling ever since. Given its capacity for inculcating greed in young people, I'm amazed and shocked that the BBC should have been willing to publish it. The claim had to do with gifts alleged by Dame Joan Sutherland to have been showered on her over Christmas by her true love - identity unspecified, but presumably her husband of many years, Richard Bonynge, the distinguished conductor. Since the 12 days of Christmas had at this stage yet to begin (purists tell me they start with Boxing Day, making today the fifth of them), the events she described must have happened last year. The process, as she recalled it, began unobjectionably, as Dame Joan took delivery of a partridge in a pear tree. Subsequent days brought, in modest numbers, various species of bird: turtle doves, French hens and calling birds - all listed by Dame Joan in a tripping, insouciant manner. At this point, however, her manner changed. The next line was delivered more slowly, and much more portentously. The reason, I thought, was clear: the flow of birds had at that point dried up, and five gold rings had arrived. The calculation was clear. "Whoopee," the Dame must have told herself. "At last he's out of the aviary and into the jeweller's." But here she was wrong. On day six - New Year's Eve, and a day when last year much of the world was busy mistakenly hailing the imminent dawn of a new millennium - the supply of jewellery ceased and the flow of birds resumed with six geese a-laying, followed by seven swans swimming on New Year's Day. From here on, the arrival of presents assumed quite alarming dimensions, with eight maids a milking on Sunday, nine ladies dancing on Monday, 10 lords a-leaping (unlikely under this Labour government to have been hereditary peers) on Tuesday, 11 pipers piping on Wednesday, and finally 12 drummers drumming on Thursday, January 6. Similar claims, of course, have been made before, but never in my experiences with the authority of a dame of the British Empire. And never before had I realised the magnitude of what was alleged. For each item in the consignment was delivered not once but daily from its inception: the partridges, complete with their pear trees, on 12 successive days, the turtle doves on 11 and the French hens on 10. As figure one shows, the total of presents delivered had by the end reached 364: one for every day of the year except Christmas Day. A little further analysis revealed one of those arithmetical pleasures which cause serious mathematicians to find such tear-jerking beauty in their profession. The sequence of these deliveries takes the form of what we bookish folk call a palindrome, though I guess you might also call it a perfect parabola. The first and last arrivals will in each case have contributed 12 to the final total (that is, 12x1 partridge-in-pear-tree, 1x12 drumming drummers.) The second and the penultimate category muster 22 each (11x2 turtle doves, 2x11 pipers). The acme is reached with the geese and the swans, of whom at the end there are 42 in each case (ie 6x7 swans a swimming, and 7x6 geese a laying.) But that was only the start of it. As I contemplated the enormity of what Mr Bonynge had done, I began to assess its dire implications for public health and animal welfare. It is clear when you study the make-up of Dame Joan's gifts that other deliveries too must have taken place. The turtle doves will have needed a dovecote, and so on. One can easily imagine the crisis which must have occurred on day eight when the milking maids appeared on the scene. Note that Dame Joan specifies that the maids were not just milkmaids on their day off but were maids a -milking: ergo, they must have brought cows. Just how many cows is beyond my powers of computation. Ideally, there would have been eight, one for each maid. By the end of the process, though, a further 32 maids would have arrived, each presumably with a cow. A congregation like that would have needed a byre, and one very much hopes one was built to Maff specifications. But worse still, the maids would have needed somewhere to sleep, as would the next day's contingent, the lords; and anyone even mildly familiar with the wicked ways of the aristocracy would hope the two groups were not billeted too close together. Perhaps rooms were found for these people down the road at the Dove and Drummer; but there may at a season like this have been no room at the inn. The problem would have grown even graver when the pipers arrived. What kind of pipes they were piping is nowhere specified: we must hope that they were not bagpipes, for bagpipers have to practise, and had they insisted on doing so close to the spot where the maids and the lords were attempting to sleep (preferably, as I say, not together), the standard of performance in the milking parlour and the leaping arena next day might have left Dame Joan disappointed. Since drummers are, if anything, even noisier than pipers, it is just as well the drummers were only there for one day. And yet, were they? What happened to this gallimaufry of people and birds once the 12 days of Christmas were over is something of which Dame Joan neither sang nor spoke. Were they all paid off and sent home on January 7? Or do they continue to cluster around her home? And if so, are they now being joined by a further Christmas collection marshalled at the behest of Dame Joan's loving spouse? She published an autobiography in 1997, I see. Perhaps the time has come to update it.

fields.body:

British Airways from Gatwick. Must be booked by Jan 29. Full payment required when booking. Valid for departures until Feb 28. Minimum stay one Saturday night, maximum one month. Airline Network (0800 727747).

Lauda Air from Manchester via Vienna. Must be booked by Dec 31. Valid for departures Jan 15 - March 23. Minimum stay seven nights. All travel must be completed by March 30. Going Places Direct (0161-908 7967).

fields.headline: Your private Tokyo
fields.standfirst: Phil Goddard  uncovers the weird, the psychedelic, the beautiful and the truly bizarre
fields.trailText: Phil Goddard uncovers the weird, the psychedelic, the beautiful and the truly bizarre
fields.body:
1 Replicate the Blade Runner experience

Ridley Scott's film is set in a highly Asianised Los Angeles in 2019, inspired by present-day Tokyo. One of the best ways to throw yourself in at the deep end of Japanese culture, and enjoy a thoroughly hallucinogenic experience into the bargain, is to travel straight from the airport to Shibuya station.

Walk out into Hachiko Plaza, and you're immediately swallowed up by a teeming mass of people. Your eyes and ears are assaulted by a welter of neon and an array of vast video screens, some of them six storeys high and all with hi-fi sound, pumping out a cacophony of adverts, music videos and film trailers.

The dog after whom the plaza is named used to turn up at the subway station every afternoon to greet his master, a university professor. In 1925 the professor died while at work, but in a moving display of loyalty (or perhaps stupidity) Hachiko continued making daily appearances for some 10 years afterwards.

2 Play pachinko

There are pachinko parlours everywhere you look in Tokyo; you can't miss them, because they make such a din. This is the country's national game, a vertical version of pinball. Rows of besuited, chain-smoking men and the occasional woman spend hours in total absorption, while white-gloved assistants move up and down the aisles, bowing to the oblivious customers like churchwardens to an altar.

3 Sample conveyor-belt sushi...

Yes, I know these restaurants are starting to catch on here, but there's no substitute for doing it in authentic Japanese style. The staff greet you like an old friend, shouting in unison as you enter. These restaurants also solve the eternal problem of how to order if you don't speak the language: here you just help yourself from the conveyor belt. And they're cheap: each dish costs between £1 and £2.50.

Widespread throughout the city; £10-£12 per person.

4 ...and an all-garlic menu

When the Queen visits foreign countries, her hosts are instructed to go easy on the garlic. She'd get short shrift from the Spicy Cafe in the city's Roppongi district, where all the dishes contain this love-it-or-hate-it ingredient - though it hasn't found its way on to the dessert menu yet. The food was a pleasant surprise: a fusion of Italian and Far Eastern, with dishes such as fried garlic cloves, grilled garlic beefsteak, spiced minced scallop wrapped in a small pancake with steamed garlic ... you get the idea.

Spicy Café, 5th floor, Roppongi Plaza, 3-12-6, Roppongi, Minato-ku (5771 7500). About £40 for two including wine.

5 See a kabuki performance

Performances of Japan's colourful popular theatre can last many hours, but the Kabuki-za theatre in Ginza has adopted the Capital FM bite-size approach to this centuries-old art form, by allowing you to walk in off the street and sample just one act. Covent Garden take note?

Kabuki-za, 4-12-15 Ginza, Chuo-ku (5565 6000). One-act tickets go on sale 10 minutes before each performance.

6 Visit the parasite museum

The star of the show at the Meguro Parasitological museum is arguably Tokyo's most famous animal after Hachiko and the pandas at the zoo. It is a neatly-coiled 8.8-metre tapeworm, with a white ribbon hanging from the wall beside it to give you an idea of what it looks like full-length. Don't buy any postcards or souvenirs until you've been here.

4-1-1 Shimo-Meguro, Meguro-ku (3716 1264). Entrance free; open 10am to 5pm; closed Mondays.

7 Stay in a love hotel...

Instantly recognisable by their Las Vegas-style exteriors, love hotels can be rented for two-hour periods or all night. Inside, they are smart and completely unsleazy, offering a cheaper alternative to the city's often painfully expensive mainstream hotels. A board inside the door has photographs of all the rooms, with the vacant ones lit. Choose yours from the range of jazzy designs on offer, press a button to de-illuminate it on the board, and then collect your keys through a hole from a cashier hidden behind a screen. Some love hotels are not keen on foreigners, but keep trying and you'll get in. Our room had imitation Louis XIV furniture, a mirrored ceiling, a Jacuzzi, and a karaoke machine.

One of the main concentrations of love hotels is in the triangle between two streets near Shibuya station, Dogenzaka and Bunkamura-dori; another is in the Kabuki-cho district. £60-£100 per night for a double room. If you want to stay the night, you'll have to wait until about 10pm to check in.

8 ...and a capsule hotel

A claustrophobic form of accommodation in a claustrophobic city, but also another novel way of cutting down on hotel bills. Outside, they look like any other hotel. Inside, the rooms are lined with what look like rows of oversized tumbledriers, stacked two high and just big enough for one person. Each is around two metres long, with a mattress, TV, radio, light and not much else.

Capsule Hotel Riverside, 2-20-4 Kaminarimon (3844 1155); both sexes welcome. Asakusa Station.

9 Rent a karaoke booth

This is much better than the British version, because you don't have to wait for your local pub to organise a session, or make a fool of yourself in front of a crowd of strangers. Just wander in off the street, pay a few pounds per person per hour, and shut yourself in a soundproof booth - on your own, if you like.

10 Go for a long weekend

Many flights are non-stop, taking only 12 hours, so it would be feasible to leave work Thursday lunchtime, spend three full days there, and arrive back on Tuesday.

The practicals

The standard London-Tokyo economy return fare on Japan Airlines (0845 7747700) is £3,447, but www.expedia.co.uk has Alitalia flights starting at £481, and Bridge The World (020-7911 0900) has a special £400 fare for under-30s on Korean Airlines.

Some recommended hotels: Roppongi Prince Hotel (expensive), 2-7, Roppongi 3-chome, Minato-ku (tel: 3587 1111, fax 3587 0770; www.princehotels.co.jp/english/); Ryokan Shigetsu (midrange), 1-31-11 Asakusa, Taito-ku (tel: 3843 2345, fax: 3843 2348; shigetsu.com); Tokyo International Youth Hostel (cheap), 18th floor, Central Plaza Building, 1-1 Kaguragashi, Shinjuku-ku; (tel: 3235 1107).

fields.headline: Best of the net
fields.trailText: Sports sites
fields.body:
It should be an exciting year for sports fans. Many tickets are sold so far in advance that you may only be able to book tickets for 2002. But you can sometimes register an interest in returned tickets online.

Finding an event

Whatsonwhen.com

Lists forthcoming events all over the world and - most usefully - links to their official sites.

Buying tickets

Ticketmaster

A long-established ticket broker specialising in rugby and football. Sadly, little outside the UK.

Golf

The Ryder Cup

England will host next year's Cup at The Belfry. Play begins on September 28. Tickets went on sale as long ago as last March, so you may well be too late to secure one - but this is the place to keep track of the preparations.

Football

The World Cup

Yes, it won't take place until 2002 - but the qualifying matches will be held in November, and they include Germany v England, Scotland v Croatia, Northern Ireland v Denmark and Wales v Armenia.

Tennis

Wimbledon

The public ticket ballot for 2001 closes tomorrow, so unless you're exceptionally quick off the mark, you may be too late. Play begins on June 25 and the site already has plenty of useful information on rain refunds, ground opening times and ticket prices. The US Open (www.usopen.org) or the rather poor Roland Garros site (www.frenchopen.org) may still have tickets available.

Cycling

Tour de France

Last year's site was impressive, and this year's looks as though it will be just as good. Visitors can inspect the 2001 route in Flash and search for details of every rider since 1903.

Cricket

English Cricket Board

England "A" are in the West Indies in January and February, England tour Sri Lanka between January and March, while Pakistan and Australia visit in the summer. The ECB has contact details for ticket offices at all the major grounds; those wanting to buy Lord's tickets for big matches need to register for an application form.

fields.headline: Somewhere for later
fields.trailText: Make a resolution to get away
fields.body:
Europe

Channel Islands: Until the end of February, a three-night weekend break in Jersey with Modern Hotels (01534 735511) costs £99 per person including return catamaran crossing from Weymouth, transfers and B&B accommodation at the Mayfair Hotel, St Helier. Four-night midweek breaks with ferry from Portsmouth cost £109pp.

Spain: Barcelona's Palau de La Musica Catalan concert season runs until May 25, with visiting orchestras including the New York and Vienna Philharmonics. Kirker Holidays (020-7231 3333) is offering three-night breaks from £354pp (based on two sharing), staying at the two-star superior Meson Castilla in the centre of the city, five minutes from the Placa de Catalunya venue. The price includes return flights, car transfers and B&B accommodation. Concert tickets can be arranged on request.

Italy: Until the end of February, three nights in Venice costs £246 from Travellers Cities (01959 540700). The price, based on two sharing, includes return scheduled flights from London Gatwick and B&B accommodation in a family-run three-star hotel five minutes' walk from St Mark's Square and the Rialto Bridge.

Greece: First Choice (0870 7500001) has halved the price of seven nights' self-catering at the Ionian View apartments in Corfu. The new price, £128 per person, includes return flights from London Gatwick between May 1-7 and transfers, and is based on four adults sharing a one-bedroom apartment.

North America

Florida: Until March 30, America As You Like It (020-8742 8299, www. americaasyou likeit.com) has cut the price of three-bedroom homes with private pools in the Orlando area from £344 per home per week to £265.

Caribbean

British Virgin Islands: Toad Hall Caribbean (01548 852407) has cut the cost of some new apartments overlooking Cane Garden Bay, Tortola, from £700 per week to £500 until the end of February. The apartments sleep two and the price includes maid service and all linen. Flights to Tortola can be arranged from £400.

South America

Ecuador: Visit the Andes, the Galapagos archipelago and the Amazon rainforest on an 11-night tour with Voyages Jules Verne (020-7616 1000, www.vjv.com April 24, May 8 and May 22 departures cost £1,295 per person; July 24 and August 21 £1,495; September 4 and 18, October 16 and November 13 £1,395. Single supplement £295. Price includes return scheduled flights from London Heathrow, four nights' B&B at the Hotel Quito, three nights' full-board at La Casa del Suizo in Ecuador's Amazonian district and three nights' full-board cruise round the Galapagos on the MV Santa Cruz.

fields.headline: Snow show
fields.trailText: Where can you find the white powder?
fields.body:
New snow has fallen across the Alps and the Pyrenees, refreshing the slopes, but many Austrian resorts are still waiting for a big dump to create a reliable base. Most European resorts are now open, many fully operational.

Fantastic conditions in the US and Canada, where new snow and fresh powder make perfect skiing. But temperatures are still extremely cold so thermals are essential.

Austria

Soll (*) has finally opened with snow conditions being described as "wet". Best ski conditions in St Anton (* *) are above the mid-station. Saalbach Hinterglemm (*) has some patchy, rocky condi tions, but temperatures are lower than they have been and what snow exists is likely to be retained. Kaprun (* * *) and Obergurgl (* * *) are still the best resorts.

France

Isola 2000 (* * *) has had up to 20cm of new snow, with excellent skiing and all its lifts open. Tignes (* * *), Val d'Isère (* * *), Risoul (* * *) and Montgenevre (* * *) are all good, although best conditions are at high altitude.

Switzerland

The Jungfrau area needs more snow although Grindelwald (* *) and Wengen (* *) have more than half their lifts open. Some of the best skiing can be found in Pontresina (* * *), St Moritz (* * *) and Saas Fee (* * *), all now fully operational.

Italy

Madonna di Campiglio (* * *) has over half its lifts open and offers some good skiing. Cervinia (* * *) is best above the mid-station although a huge ski area is available there. Sestriere (* * *) and Sauze d'Oulx (* * *) have good piste conditions.

Andorra

Most resorts are almost fully open. The best is Arcalis (* *).

North America

Breckenridge (* * * *) has had 18cm of new snow, and Killington (* * * *) up to 25cm with more forecast. All US resorts offer excellent skiing on fresh, new snow with most lifts open. In Canada, Lake Louise (* * * *) and Fernie (* * * *) have both had up to 10cm of new snow, with brilliant skiing. Whistler (* * * *) also looks very good.

 Liz Russell, The Ski Club of Great Britain

Key to conditions: No stars = a serious lack of snow - no lifts open. * = poor snow conditions, very few lifts open. * * = conditions reasonable, some slopes in poor condition. * * * = plenty of good skiing. * * * * = good conditions. * * * * * = fantastic conditions on and off piste. For the latest snow conditions in more than 250 resorts, check out www.skiclub.co.uk

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: January sales | Priced to go | Moving museum | Coasting
fields.body:
January sales

British Airways has more than 140 discounted destinations on offer and savings of up to £284 in its January sale. Prices for a round-trip ticket including all taxes, start from £79 to Amsterdam, £197 to New York, £326 to the Caribbean, £399 to South Africa and £621 to Australia. The fares, advertised under the banner Make Your Money Go Further, are on sale until January 29 2001 and are valid for travel from January 4 until June 30 2001. British Airways Holidays is also offering a range of discounted holidays: for example, a two-night city break to Paris starts from £99 (two-star hotel with breakfast). For details and reservations, call: British Airways on 0845 7733377, British Airways Holidays on 0870 6000500, visit www.britishairways.co.uk/value , British Airways Travel Shops, and IATA and ABTA travel agents.

Priced to go

The battle for the 2001 holiday trade is about to begin, with travel agents offering all sorts of discounts to entice early bookings for next summer. But, according to a survey commissioned by independent travel agency group Travelcare, holidaymakers are fed up with the confusing price practices of tour operators, and aren't confident that the holiday they've booked won't be on sale for less later. As a result, Travelcare is launching a brochure with Cosmos featuring prices guaranteed until March.

Moving museum

San Francisco airport, the new $970m international terminal that became fully operational this month, has been accredited as a museum. It has four galleries, open 24 hours a day, which will showcase the work of local artists as well as cultures of the world. The new International Terminal will also feature its own rapid transit service into downtown San Francisco in 2002.

Coasting

An exhibition celebrating the British coastline opens on February 21 at the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, south-east London. Views From the Edge - The Great British Coast draws on a collection of newly-commissioned photography, from the National Trust Photographic Library, to take visitors on a tour of places such as the White Cliffs of Dover and the Giant's Causeway. Each year, around 10 million people visit stretches of the 600 miles of coastline protected by the National Trust. Views From the Edge: February 21-October 1, 10am-5pm seven days a week. Adults £7.50, concessions £6, children and OAPs free.

fields.headline: The borders of history
fields.standfirst: Why would the much-travelled Michael Palin want to visit two obscure towns, one in Poland and the other in Italy? To put faces to either end of the Iron Curtain for a Radio 4 travel show
fields.trailText: Why would the much-travelled Michael Palin want to visit two obscure towns, one in Poland and the other in Italy? To put faces to either end of the Iron Curtain for a Radio 4 travel show
fields.body:
"Rolex?" "No, thank you. Just some coffee and a glass of orange juice." "No Rolex?" "No." "Any other ex?" "Oh! Eggs." "Yes! Rolled eggs. My grandmother makes them. She is from Danzig. It is very old recipe."

I was in Poland for the first time in my life and was already struggling with the language. Such are the delicate nuances of pronunciation that even my attempts to learn "Hello" in Polish had surreal results. "You keep saying 'father-in-law'," explained my guide politely.

I was in Szczecin because of Winston Churchill, who had no trouble with the pronunciation when, in a speech in Fulton, Missouri, in March 1946, he uttered the prophetic words: "From Stettin in the Baltic to Trieste in the Adriatic an Iron Curtain has descended across the continent."

He used the German name Stettin because the city had been part of Prussia for 225 years. As a result of the Potsdam Treaty, it was taken from them after the second world war and handed over to Poland. Most of the German population fled and more than 100,000 dispossessed Poles from all over the country moved into their homes.

The existence of the Iron Curtain shaped international politics for most of my life, and its almost shockingly swift destruction in 1989 only made me want to know more about it, and more particularly to put a face to the two cities Churchill chose as the limits of the new East and West. Which is why I'm here in this surprisingly handsome city on the banks of the Odra saying "father-in-law" to the conductor as I hop on one of the well-worn, ad-plastered, tram-cars that run through the centre of Szczecin.

Whenever possible I prefer to approach cities by land, so I had taken a northbound express out of Berlin Ostbahnhof, which dropped me at Angermunde, where I joined a local service that ran, in disorientating November darkness, across the Mecklenburg plain and into Poland.

Szczecin station had a neglected end-of-the-line feel to it. Its ornate old iron canopy and lovingly detailed stone work cried out for some of the money that had been lavished on the restoration of the Ostbahnhof in Berlin.

I was put up at one of the city's newest hotels, open only three weeks. The Rondo was small, welcoming, family-run and, like almost everywhere in Szczecin, laced with recent history. Until 10 years ago, this solid German villa had been the library of the Central Party committee and the six rooms consisted of pointlessly large suites, still clearly built for committee meetings. The hotel also doubled as a language school and, as I was to find at breakfast next morning, everyone did their best to speak English.

I was quite unprepared for the appearance of the city by daylight. As I waited for my rolled eggs, I looked out on an orderly network of tree-lined boulevards, radiating from roundabouts and flanked by four- or five-storied terraces with wrought-iron balconies and Teutonic motifs. After reaching Paris in the war of 1871, the Prussians decided they liked it very much and imported French architects and builders to re-create Paris in their own cities.

Much of the elegance is faded and though neon signs give a surface glitter, there is no Gap and Starbucks tidiness here. There is instead the faint unease that comes from a dysfunctional recent history. As I admire the solid red granite slabs of the pavements off Grunwaldski Place, my guide Richard Jasinski points out that they were re-laid in the 1960s, sometimes with gravestones of Germans and Jews from the cemetery.

One long, bland modern office-building, down towards the river, seems to embody all the dramatic twists and turns of Szczecin's post-war history. This was by turns Nazi, then Communist Party headquarters and in 1970 Jasinski remembers seeing it stormed and set alight by shipyard workers, protesting against food shortages.

The insecurity of those post-war years is only slowly fading from the city. It has, after all, been little more than a decade since an unlikely alliance of workers, intellectuals and the Catholic church finally saw the communist government collapse.

Now Szczecin is intent on putting the past behind it. The deputy mayor meets me in a bar, hands over some prints of old Stettin and regales me with news of economic progress - new roads, bridges, a regional airport.

The great Gothic buildings high on the west bank of the Odra precede 20th century troubles. They are impressive reminders of the mercantile traditions of a city that grew rich on Baltic trade, and it is from the sea that Szczecin still makes a living. A visit to the shipyards in the north-east of the city is bittersweet for one brought up in the industrial heart of Britain. Here heavy industry survives and seems to be thriving. There are five or six huge tankers and container ships under construction, ships we in Britain can no longer afford to build. In sheds several hundred metres long welding sparks fly as steel plates are being cut like strips of cloth. Work is still hard here and wages low. The only difference now is that the yard is privately owned.

Perhaps because of its traumatic history, I found welcome eccentricity and self-expression in Szczecin. After all, Catherine the Great, raunchiest of the tsarinas, was born here. I enjoyed a visit to one of the city's most famous poets, who is also a gynaecologist. He received me dressed like Wagner in velvet jacket, neck-scarf and floppy beret and offered me sausages and champagne while two friends sang arias from his latest opera.

Later, at dinner in a basement restaurant called Chate Plac, they served a meat dish translated on the menu as "pork chop of village administrator".

Trieste

My Churchillian researches next took me some 530 miles south to Italy. At Venice Mestre station, I turned my back on the Serenissima and boarded the well-graffitied 14.32 electric train service which ran across the remorselessly flat fields of the Veneto before turning south and east along the limestone ridge at whose base is spread Italy's most easterly and easily forgotten city, Trieste.

The proximity of Venice makes for invidious comparisons. Trieste is no feather-light lagoon city. The buildings I passed on the way to my hotel were big and bulky and several lanes of noisy highway separated me from the seafront. I made out tall functional buildings and stone jetties empty save for a Greek ferry looming higher than the buildings on shore, into which a seemingly endless line of trucks was being loaded. Trieste's only canal, the Canale Grande, runs for about 300 yards and could well be challenged under the Trades Descriptions Act.

I passed a lot of people heading for the station. These were not your average commuters, more like figures from classical legend, staggering out of the gloom bearing huge loads, suitcases straining at the seams, black bags filled to bursting and piled one on top of the other on groaning trolleys.

With some relief, I turned off the waterfront and made my way around a mighty square signposted as the Piazza Unita d'Italia. It was undergoing extensive renovation, but will be unwrapped from its protective green plastic by the summer of 2001.

One side looks out clear toward the Adriatic. The flamboyant and imposing buildings on the three other sides have recently been cleaned. In the centre is the town hall, a rich mix of styles from mannerist to neo-classical to Venetian, and a grand art-nouveau facade on one side is matched by the neo-renaissance style of the Rossetti theatre on the other.

No wonder people forget that Trieste is part of Italy. Its looks and style are all middle European, heavy and dripping with ornament. If Szczecin is a Polish city living in a Prussian body, then Trieste is Italian living inside an Austrian. Empress Maria Theresa plucked it from relative obscurity to make it one of a triumvirate of great cities of the Austro-Hungarian empire - Vienna was the court, Prague the administration and Trieste the seaport. Her architects built the neo-classical terraces that line the grid plan streets of the old town - the Borgo Theresiano. Impressive, but not cosy.

Walking out next morning, I found welcome gaps in the Theresian uniformity. Turning away from the sea and heading east towards the steep slopes behind the city centre, I passed a Greek Orthodox church on my way to the old Jewish ghetto, where tall, crumbling facades confronted each other across narrow alleyways which converged on a square that reminded me briefly of the theatricality of Venice. There was a preponderance of antique shops, not the smart, intimidating kind, but full of bric-a-brac - German army helmets from the first world war, letters, diaries, collections of old newspapers. A rich social record of a cosmopolitan city.

Walking up the hill to the plateau on which stands the 14th-century Cathedral of San Giusto and the ramparts of the castle, I paused for breath outside the Baroque church of Santa Maria Maggiore, which is cheek by jowl with the small, finely-proportioned Romanesque church of San Silvestre, from which organ music resounded. In many cities, this would be a coach-tour stop, but I was the only person there.

Trieste is so overlaid with accretions of foreign culture that it's hard to detect any single national influence. It is as close to the rest of Italy as it is to Croatia and Slovenia. The Austrian border is 65 miles north, and a local told me that most of those I saw with bulging suitcases making their way to the station were Hungarians drawn here by the abundance and cheapness of the goods.

Trieste's famous cafés are grand and Viennese. The most celebrated, the Caffe San Marco, had tall ceilings, art-nouveau decoration and a collection of clichéd café characters: chess players, anxious students shuffling essay papers, lovers, novelists, poets. There seemed to be room for the whole world in there and no one was hurried on.

The diverse cultural influences and congenial pace of life have always made Trieste attractive to writers. In addition to Rilke and Italo Svevo, it was, on and off between 1904 and 1920, home to James Joyce. Exiled from narrow-minded Dublin, he found little difficulty re-creating it in Trieste. Much of his essential work on Dubliners, Portrait of the Artist and Ulysses was completed here. The city is proud of the association and there is an extensive and well-signposted Joyce trail to be followed.

Trieste seemed optimistic, as if it were finally waking from the deep sleep into which it fell after the city was taken from the dismembered Austrian empire in 1918. It is still home to world-class writers such as Claudio Magris and Joyce expert John McCourt, while remaining the catchily-named "insurance centre of Italy". The mayor is the head of the Illy coffee company and his product is one of Trieste's most lucrative.

As for the Iron Curtain, well, it was full of holes down here. Neighbouring Yugoslavia, though communist, was much less paranoid than the hardliners of the Warsaw Pact and though there were fences and barbed wire, there was also largely unrestricted movement of local people across the border.

This perhaps accounts for why Trieste felt sleepier, more laid back than Szczecin. With less in its past to hide, it lacked the abrasive, everything-to-prove energy of the Poles.

These two cities that Churchill plucked from relative obscurity do have considerable similarities. Both have a heavy legacy of Germanic taste and style, both have changed national identities in the last 80 years, and both have bright futures.

Churchill foresaw the ideological partition of Europe after the second world war, and he pretty correctly judged that Szczecin and Trieste would mark the north and south extremes of this new dividing line, torn between East and West, between the free world and communism.

Now, with the Cold War over and the Iron Curtain gone, Szczecin and Trieste are no longer at the edges of a divided continent but, potentially, at the centre of a new, united Europe.

So, hurry. See them now, before they become like everywhere else.

Where to eat and drink

Szczecin

Restaurants:

Chate Plac
(Holdu Pruskiego 8, 70 -550, Tel/fax: 091 488 73 70)
Jolly, slightly touristy but none the worse for it really. Folksy music,but great game, and excellent northern fare such as bread and dripping and black pudding - Polish style, of course.

Admiral
(Monte Cassini 37 432 28 15)
Best fish restaurant in Poland - and we agreed having eaten in no other fish restaurant in Poland.

Trieste

Cafés are a big feature of the city, and the two most famous are the Caffe San Marco (Via Battisiti) and Antico Café Tommaseo (Piazza Tommaseo), which is more Viennese in style.

Restaurants:

Osteria da Marino
(Via del Ponte 5, tel: 040 366596)
Try the Tokay wine and lunches of mushrooms, cheese and ham which you never want to end.


Enoteca Nanut
(Via Genova)
Stuffed with bottles of Italian wine. Ask the man behind the counter to recommend glasses for you to try or head out the back again for lunch and supper at wooden tables.

How to find the Iron Curtain

You have to go to the border of former East and West Germany, which is a five-hour drive from Szczecin. The nearest airport is Hamburg. The nearest city is Lübeck, and the border is about 10km away - the small border post will be converted into a museum next year. A good place to stay at is the Hotel Jensen am Holstentor (tel: 00 49 451 702 490/fax: 00 49 451 733 86), which costs DM160-DM 210 (£50-£67) for a double room. For further information on Lübeck, visit www.luebeck-tourismus.de

 Michael Palin's Iron Curtain, two programmes for Excess Baggage on Radio 4, can be heard at 10am this morning and on Saturday January 6

Trieste's famous cafés are grand and Viennese. The most celebrated, the Caffe San Marco, had tall ceilings, art-nouveau decoration and a collection of clichéd café characters: chess players, anxious students shuffling essay papers, lovers, novelists, poets. There seemed to be room for the whole world in there and no one was hurried on. The diverse cultural influences and congenial pace of life have always made Trieste attractive to writers. In addition to Rilke and Italo Svevo, it was, on and off between 1904 and 1920, home to James Joyce. Exiled from narrow-minded Dublin, he found little difficulty re-creating it in Trieste. Much of his essential work on Dubliners, Portrait of the Artist and Ulysses was completed here. The city is proud of the association and there is an extensive and well-signposted Joyce trail to be followed. Trieste seemed optimistic, as if it were finally waking from the deep sleep into which it fell after the city was taken from the dismembered Austrian empire in 1918. It is still home to world-class writers such as Claudio Magris and Joyce expert John McCourt, while remaining the catchily-named "insurance centre of Italy". The mayor is the head of the Illy coffee company and his product is one of Trieste's most lucrative. As for the Iron Curtain, well, it was full of holes down here. Neighbouring Yugoslavia, though communist, was much less paranoid than the hardliners of the Warsaw Pact and though there were fences and barbed wire, there was also largely unrestricted movement of local people across the border. This perhaps accounts for why Trieste felt sleepier, more laid back than Szczecin. With less in its past to hide, it lacked the abrasive, everything-to-prove energy of the Poles. These two cities that Churchill plucked from relative obscurity do have considerable similarities. Both have a heavy legacy of Germanic taste and style, both have changed national identities in the last 80 years, and both have bright futures. Churchill foresaw the ideological partition of Europe after the second world war, and he pretty correctly judged that Szczecin and Trieste would mark the north and south extremes of this new dividing line, torn between East and West, between the free world and communism. Now, with the Cold War over and the Iron Curtain gone, Szczecin and Trieste are no longer at the edges of a divided continent but, potentially, at the centre of a new, united Europe. So, hurry. See them now, before they become like everywhere else. Where to eat and drink Szczecin Restaurants: Chate Plac (Holdu Pruskiego 8, 70 -550, Tel/fax: 091 488 73 70) Jolly, slightly touristy but none the worse for it really. Folksy music,but great game, and excellent northern fare such as bread and dripping and black pudding - Polish style, of course. Admiral (Monte Cassini 37 432 28 15) Best fish restaurant in Poland - and we agreed having eaten in no other fish restaurant in Poland. Trieste Cafés are a big feature of the city, and the two most famous are the Caffe San Marco (Via Battisiti) and Antico Café Tommaseo (Piazza Tommaseo), which is more Viennese in style. Restaurants: Osteria da Marino (Via del Ponte 5, tel: 040 366596) Try the Tokay wine and lunches of mushrooms, cheese and ham which you never want to end. Enoteca Nanut (Via Genova) Stuffed with bottles of Italian wine. Ask the man behind the counter to recommend glasses for you to try or head out the back again for lunch and supper at wooden tables. How to find the Iron Curtain You have to go to the border of former East and West Germany, which is a five-hour drive from Szczecin. The nearest airport is Hamburg. The nearest city is Lübeck, and the border is about 10km away - the small border post will be converted into a museum next year. A good place to stay at is the Hotel Jensen am Holstentor (tel: 00 49 451 702 490/fax: 00 49 451 733 86), which costs DM160-DM 210 (£50-£67) for a double room. For further information on Lübeck, visit www.luebeck-tourismus.de  Michael Palin's Iron Curtain, two programmes for Excess Baggage on Radio 4, can be heard at 10am this morning and on Saturday January 6

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Lorraine
fields.trailText: In 1992 (my 50th year, and my daughter's 25th) we decided we really had to do something memorable together, so we hopped on a plane to India. I see that you're going there too. We spent six weeks exploring Rajesthan and I believe, despite many visits to other parts of India, that this state holds the most adventure, romance and excitement.
fields.body:
Hello Sue,
In 1992 (my 50th year, and my daughter's 25th) we decided we really had to do something memorable together, so we hopped on a plane to India. I see that you're going there too, but having checked your itinerary you miss the places we visited. We spent six weeks exploring Rajesthan and for me, despite many visits to other parts of India, this state holds the most adventure, romance and excitement. Turn around and spend some time there if you can alter your schedule. We went to Jaipur, Udaipur, Jodhpur, Jaiselmere, Bikanir, Shekesvatir and the most - no word to discribe it - wonderful village in the the desert called Khuri. Rajesthan has exciting people, customs, clothes and jewellery - it is all colour.

Now, after five years in Indonesia, I have packed a lifetime's goods and chattels - all of which tell a story - and have moved to the Cameroons, so if you double back to Africa any time the spare room is all yours.

Good luck, and may wonderful memories and adventures be yours.

fields.headline: Somewhere for now
fields.trailText: Start the new year with a bang
fields.body:
Europe

Ireland: Recover from Christmas with a two-night de-stress package at the four-star Inchydoney Island Lodge and Spa. The price of £332 includes half-board accommodation, return flights, transfers and treatment. Thermalia Travel (020-7483 1898, www.thermalia.co.uk).

Belgium: Two-night breaks to Brussels cost from £189 per person from VFB Holidays (01242 240310, www.vfbholidays.co.uk). Prices include return travel on Eurostar, B&B accommodation at the four-star Jolly Htel du Grand Sablon, 10 minutes' walk from the Grand Place, and full travel insurance.

France: Ski Esprit (01252 618 300, www.ski-esprit.co.uk) is cutting a minimum of £240 from the price of holidays departing January 7 for Courcheval, Chamonix, Morzine, La Plagne, La Rosière and Verbier. Adult prices now start at £350 per person including flights from Manchester or London Stansted, airport tax and transfers, seven nights' half-board chalet accommodation and one night's babysitting per week.

Sweden: The biggest snow festival in Europe runs January 23-27 in Kiruna in Swedish Lapland. There's snow sculpture competitions, dog sledge and reindeer racing and the Northern Lights. SAS (0845 607 27727) flies from London to Kiruna from £240 return. For accommodation, contact the Swedish Travel & Tourism Council (020-7870 5600, brochure line 01476 578811, www.visit-sweden.com).

Egypt: Libra Holidays (020-8275 5500) has cut its prices for January and early February departures to the Red Sea. Seven nights' B&B at Hurghada with flights from London Gatwick on January 5 and 12 cost £169pp, down from £419, February 2 £289 (£375). A similar deal to Sharm el-Sheikh on January 7 costs £179 (£369), on January 14 £189 (£385), and February 4 £259 (£385). Seven nights in Sharm el-Sheikh departing Manchester on February 1 costs £269, down from £404.

Canada: Ski Independence (0870 5550555, www.ski-independence.co.uk) is cutting up to £70 per person on chalet bookings for departures on January 6, 13 and 20. Seven nights' full-board at the ski-in Mountainside Chalet in Fernie, British Columbia, now costs £639pp, £829 pp for 14 nights, including flights and car hire. In January, a six-day lift pass costs £98, a saving of £32, and a 13-day pass costs £213, down £71.

Asia

Cambodia, Laos, Thailand: Explore Phnom Penh and Angkor Wat before heading for a tropical beach on a 15-day fully-escorted small group tour departing January 6. The price of £1,300 includes flights from Heathrow, all accommodation, food, activities and transport. No single supplement. Gecko Travel (023 92376799, www.geckotravel.co.uk).

fields.headline: Wonders of the world
fields.standfirst: If you take next year off, here's what you can see and do - starting on Monday.  Annie Mills of whatsonwhen.com reports
fields.trailText: If you take next year off, here's what you can see and do - starting on Monday. Annie Mills of whatsonwhen.com reports
fields.body:
1 January 1 Kiribati Dawn Millennium Island

It's 5.45am. You're standing on a beach looking east as the sun rises out of the Pacific ocean. Before retiring to your hammock for the first pina colada of what promises to be an incredible year, you might reflect that Millennium Island, Kiribati, will not likely be there for ever. Rising sea levels may mean that, by 2045, only the fish will enjoy the beach where you now stand.

2 January 5-26 Sydney Festival Sydney

Australia celebrates the centenary of its Federation on January 1, and the annual Sydney Arts Festival promises to be bigger and better than ever. Highlights include The Tale of the Rainbow Serpent, a fantastic parade of inflatable animals including a 15-metre snake; and, of course, the Sydney Fringe, which is as unorthodox as its Edinburgh cousin - but better because you're on the beach.

3 January 19-21 Ati-Atihan Kalibo

In Australian terms, it's a short hop to Panay Island in the Philippines, where every year they hold a monumental street party called Ati-Atihan. This involves blackening your face with paint, downing plenty of rice wine and dancing for three days through the streets of Kalibo.

4 January 9 - February 21 Kumbha Mela Allahabad

According to the Guinness Book of Records, Kumbha Mela in India is "the largest number of human beings ever to assemble with a common purpose". (This might explain why it only happens every 12 years.) Long ago, the story goes, the gods fought over a "kumbh" (pitcher) containing immortality. Four drops were spilled, which landed in Alla habad, Haridwar, Nasik and Ujjain. As a consequence, 15 million pilgrims come to bathe in the Ganges.

5 February 22-26 Sri Lanka v England First Test Galle

It's just a short plane ride to Galle, Sri Lanka, for a celebration of another religion widely revered on the subcontinent - cricket.

6 March 1-14 Omitzutori Nara

For the past 1,200 years or so, the Todaji Temple has been the home of the Omitzutori festival, in which the monks celebrate the coming of spring by sprinting round the temple's balcony in the middle of the night, brandishing flaming torches. Considering the torches weigh 80kg and the temple is the largest wooden structure in the world, this is no mean feat.

7 March 24 Dubai World Cup

Before heading over to Europe, you've just got time to stop over in Dubai to place a bet on the world's richest horse race. The race coincides with Dubai's annual month-long shopping festival which offers top designer clothes at knock-down prices. So you can arrive in the Old World looking your very best.

8 April 1-7 Feria de Abril Seville

Seville's April fair sees the area south of the river taken over by a canvas city known as the Real de la Feria, where more than a thousand brightly-coloured marquees are filled with flamenco dancers day and night.

9 April 15 Scoppio del Carro Florence

At Easter, two shards of the Holy Sepulchre brought to Florence in 1099 are used to start a fire. This lights a dove-shaped rocket known as the Colombina, which spins along a wire from the Duomo to a cart in the square below. The cart is heavily laden with fireworks; when it explodes, the city is guaranteed another year's prosperity.

10 April 20-30 Keukenhof Spring Bulbs, Lisse

Each spring also sees an explosion of colour at the leading showcase for Dutch bulb-growers - the Keukenhof Gardens in Lisse. Throughout the 70 acres of wooded parkland, some seven million flowers come into bloom - tulips, daffodils, hyacinths, Japanese cherry trees, azaleas and more.

11 May 1 May Day 'Obby 'Oss Celebrations Padstow

Every year, Padstow hails the coming of summer with a pagan procession of ale-quaffing locals accompanying a hobbyhorse who, for reasons unknown, draws hapless women under his cloak and daubs them with coal. Conveniently, and perhaps not coincidentally, the whole thing starts off in a local pub, the Golden Lion Inn.

12 May 1-31 Maison du Vin Bordeaux

The exquisite 18th-century Hotel Gobineau is home to France's Bordeaux wine school. If you ever confuse your Pomerol with your Sauternes, it might be best to take a Maison du Vin wine course to get your olfactory memory in good working order before touring the Bordeaux wine region.

13 May 9-20 Cannes Film Festival

Still the most glamorous film festival in the world. The Palais des Festivals itself is hard to get into, and your best bet for successful star-spotting is to get drinking at some of the posher bars and hotels. Cannes is notoriously expensive, though, so remember to pack a fat wallet.

14 June 10-30 White Nights St Petersburg

After the over-indulgence of Cannes, it's time to take stock in Russia's most beautiful city. June's White Nights (it never gets dark) are legendary. During the festival, locals come out to play, heading for the Marinsky theatre when the Kirov Ballet and Opera companies are at home.

15 Anytime. Zero Gravity Flight, Star City, Russia

Have you ever wanted to be an astronaut? Well now you can. A brief 10-minute zero-gravity flight awaits you at the Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Centre in Star City, a brief hop from St Petersburg. For a price, you can pretend you've just stepped into the rolling credits of 2001: A Space Odyssey. Well, it is 2001 after all.

16 July 14 Love Parade Berlin

You've come for the trucks of speakers blasting every kind of big beat music and to join the crowds who party in various states of undress. The great monuments of Berlin roll on by as your dancing feet propel you round Germany's nonconformist capital.

17 July 10-29 Lincoln Center Festival, New York City

You're just in time to catch the Lincoln Center's celebration of global artistic talent. It's innovative, funky and guaranteed to inspire.

18 August 27- September 3 Burning Man Nevada Desert

Take your own body weight in water and leave your inhibitions at home. You're joining 20,000 of California's most spun-out souls to camp in the desert of Nevada. The finale is the burning of an enormous wicker man. By that time, you'll have seen naked people driving around on sofas, built kinetic sculptures, experienced an Inipi sweat lodge workshop and partied - hard.

19 September 22-23 San Francisco Blues Festival

Take some time out to discover the joys of California, but before you go south, don't miss one of the great jazz festivals. The San Francisco Blues Festival has seen anyone who's anyone make an appearance over the past three decades.

20 Late September Dunes of Utah Kanab

Just before you leave the US for good, get back to nature with a trip to the 3,730-acre, vehicle-free Coral Pink Sand Dune State Park.

21 September 16 - October 17 Cayman Madness Diving Festival Grand Cayman

From the desert to the deep blue sea. At this time of year visibility is at its best, so dive all day (and night, too) before heading to one of many beach parties.

22 October 26-28 World Creole Music Festival, Roseau

One of the top annual Caribbean shindigs, this festival in Dominica celebrates the Caribbean Creole musical heritage. Artists play zydeco (France via Louisiana), zouk (France via Guadaloupe), soukous (Zaire via Dominica), compas (direct from Haiti) and salsa (hailing from Cuba).

23 October 31- November 2 Day of the Dead Mexico City

You might be of the opinion that hanging around in cemeteries is not cool. You'll find you're mistaken when you rock up in Mexico City's largest cemetery on the night of October 31. For the graves of the dead will be covered by picnicking relatives, children will be eating skull candy and the tequila will be flowing. The next day, amazing parades of skeletons and coffins take to the streets.

24 November 17 Leonids meteor shower

You can be anywhere in South America to see this, as long as the sky is clear and your gaze is directed into space. The shower occurs when the earth passes near the orbit of the comet Tempel-Tuttle and the dusty debris of its path hits the earth's atmosphere. Be sure to get your hands on a telescope.

25 Early November Galapagos Islands

Although the waters are not at their warmest, with a decent wet suit you may strap on your snorkelling gear and prepare for some close encounters with friendly sealions, not so friendly hammerhead sharks and what will feel like a billion fish. What's more, experience the bliss of being separated from your fellow man by a thousand miles in any direction.

26 Late November Machu Picchu Cuzco

The mountain-top city of Machu Picchu was built by the Incas. If you want to earn your view, trek for three days to the 4,200m-high pass along the 1,000-year-old Inca roads. Be sure to arrive at the Puerta del Sol in time for sunrise and when the mist clears, the sacred city will appear 1,000ft below you wrapped by a loop of the Urubamba river and backed by snowy mountains.

27 December Los Glaciares National Park

The largest ice mantle outside the Antarctic stretches across the Patagonian ice field hiding 47 glaciers in a series of rugged mountains and glacial lakes. The Perito Moreno is a sheer wall of ice rising 200ft out of the water. Over a cycle of four years, its contours and size fluctuate (at times it's three miles wide and 22 miles long).

28 New Year's Eve Copacabana Rio de Janeiro

You've covered every continent except Africa, heard some of the best music, watched the most talented performers, tasted the finest wines, seen some wonders of the world and danced your socks off. It's time to reflect on your year - oops no, you're off to Rio to see in the year 2002 in your samba shorts on Copacabana beach, under the stars with the Atlantic ocean lapping at your feet. Perhaps it's time to fly to Kiribati again.

 Annie Mills is head of content at whatsonwhen.com. For more details of all the happenings above, check out www.whatsonwhen.com/globetrotter

fields.headline: Fight with us, says Ken
fields.trailText: Hywel Williams (Capital offence December 27) is wrong to claim that London stands in the way of English regionalism. The establishment of a mayor and assembly for London is a major step forward for devolution.
fields.body:
Hywel Williams (Capital offence December 27) is wrong to claim that London stands in the way of English regionalism. The establishment of a mayor and assembly for London is a major step forward for devolution.

Far from being a European disaster, London is a European success story. There are only a handful of genuine world cities and London is one of them. For many of the major international investors, the choice is not between London and Birmingham, Manchester or Glasgow, but between London and New York, Frankfurt or Tokyo. Cities like Paris, Berlin and Frankfurt are queuing up to challenge London for its global status, its financial and cultural strength, for the wealth of creativity and skills it offers, for its dynamism and the pull it has on businesses and individuals the world over. It would do the UK economy no good for London to lose that status.

London is a city of great diversity and massively enriches the life of the country as a whole. But it also faces huge problems. Hywel Williams does not appear to have noticed the poverty, the massive infrastructural problems nor the fact that London's population is rising while its police numbers fall.

London subsidises the rest of the economy. In its October 2000 report, the National Institute of Economic and Social Research shows that London contributes £18bn per year to the rest of the UK. Much of that goes to the English regions. The government receives a net £1,000 per annum from each Londoner. Across the rest of the UK, it spends more than it receives.

The problem facing the English regions is lack of powers and representation. Tony Blair's commitment to returning regional government for Greater London is the first step to increased devolution to the English regions. Lobbying for more devolution at local and regional level is where the regions should concentrate their efforts, and they stand a better chance fighting alongside London, not against it.
Ken Livingstone Mayor of London
