webTitle: Scouting the world for 2001's hot spots

fields.headline: 2001 odyssey
fields.standfirst: Roger Bray scouts the world for 2001's likely hot spots
fields.trailText: Roger Bray scouts the world for next year's likely hot spots.
fields.body:
As New Year hangovers fade and a bleak January bites, thoughts turn to travel. The summer holiday booking season is about to reach its peak, and from Exmoor to North Korea, West Africa to South America, here is a sprinkling of the many new options on offer for 2001.

Brazil

Earlier attempts to launch charters to Rio bit the dust, partly because customers were deterred by fears of street crime. But tour operators reckon they have cracked the Brazil nut with beach packages on the north coast combined with city tours and visits to sights such as the Amazon rain forest.

Unijet (08705 336336), for example, is offering holidays between May and October to three main resort areas - Natal in Rio Grande do Norte, Recife in Penambuco and Salvador in Bahia - with prices from £799 for two weeks and seat-only deals from £399.

SuperClubs has opened a new all-inclusive resort called Brisas Costa do Sauipe . An hour from Salvador Bahia airport, it has 350 rooms, a six-mile stretch of beach, an 18-hole golf course and 15 tennis courts. Funway (020-8466 0222) is offering holidays there and Airtours has also included the resort in a new dedicated brochure.

Emerging destinations

Expect increased interest in North Korea following the thaw in relations with the south and the establishment of diplomatic links with Britain. Regent Holidays (0117 9211711) is ahead of the game, already offering five-day tours there from Beijing for £849. That covers flights to the capital Pyongyang and visits to Kaesong, the Myohyang mountains and Panmunjom for a look across the demarcation line. It also takes in the International Friendship exhibition, which includes gifts to the former leader Kim Il Sung such as a bullet-proof Zil limo from Stalin. The price does not include flights from the UK to Beijing.

And, as relative calm descends on the Balkans, Montenegro looks likely to stage a comeback. Though its future status remains in doubt, the Foreign Office has withdrawn its advice not to go unless you have essential business. Among the tour operators tentatively venturing there is Steppes East (01285 651010), which hopes to send customers on tailor-made holidays.

The FO has similarly softened its advice on Serbia following the demise of ex-president Milosevic, but persuading tour firms that customers are ready to return there may take a little longer.

Islands

The Mediterranean, you may think, has few secrets left to offer but Sunvil (020-8568 4499) believes it has found one in the shape of Ikaria, which was once difficult to reach but is now linked by hydrofoil with the much better known Samos. It attracts few outsiders, says the firm, but its forests, mountains and lakes make it an excellent choice for walkers, and its bucolic panyiris - religious festivals - are something to behold. Prices start at £427 for a week's B&B, £491 for two weeks, including flights from Gatwick. It costs £25 extra to fly from Manchester.

Trailfinders (020-7938 5400) has introduced Catalina Island, California, in its tailor-made North America brochure. Two days and one night cost from £65pp in a double room. Twenty minutes by ferry from Long Beach, San Pedro or Dana Point. Hire a bike, go snorkelling, relax on the beach. Summer is very busy, so book well ahead.

And Explore Worldwide (01252 760000) has introduced the Cape Verde Islands, 275 miles off the coast of West Africa. They formed a colony of Portugal until 1975 and the Portuguese influence remains strong there, in architecture, food and wine. Explore points to deserted beaches, volcanic mountains and spectacular scenery. It is offering a 14-day trip, taking in five islands, for £1,055 - including flights from Heathrow and accommodation in hotels and a couple of village houses, mostly on a B&B basis.

Britain

Expect crowds to descend on north Devon following the BBC's adaptation of RD Blackmore's novel Lorna Doone. Costumes from the Christmas TV production will be on show from April to October at Lynton town hall. And a Doone Valley trail has been mapped out, so visitors can follow in Lorna's footsteps past Badgworthy Water, through Hoccombe Combe and Yealscombe Wood to St Mary's Church at Oare, where she was shot. For a leaflet on the trail, call Lynton tourist information centre (01598 752225) or drop in at similar centres around Exmoor.

Stand by for big changes at Jorvik, the recreated Viking city in York. The centre is being expanded at a cost of £5m to represent the settlement as it looked in 975AD. Visitors will now arrive by river and "fly over the city in a time capsule". (www.jorvik-viking-centre.co.uk).

Cod may soon be in short supply but Kingston Upon Hull, also in Yorkshire, plans a fishy antidote to quotas. Later this year The Deep will open there, incorporating what is claimed to be Europe's deepest aquarium tunnel, a viewing lift that will travel through tanks containing sharks and coral and an interactive representation of an ocean floor research station (www.thedeep.co.uk).

Safaris

June 21 sees a total eclipse of the sun over southern Africa. Holidays have been selling like hot cakes, but among those with a handful left is Okavango Tours and Safaris (020-8343 3283), which is offering a 10-day trip to Madagascar for £2,124, with flights from Heathrow via Paris. Customers will watch the eclipse while camping in Isalo National Park.

It's not only the Aussies who have flying doctors. Cedarberg Southern African Travel (020-8941 1717) is offering a one-week safari in Maputaland, in northern KwaZulu Natal, which, as well as rhino tracking and elephant watching, includes the option of flying to rural clinics and a local hospital. It costs from £1,385, which includes flights from Heathrow and full-board at the Pongola Game Reserve. A portion of the holiday cost goes to support local health care.

At least two operators have launched safaris specifically aimed at families. Dragoman (01728 861133) has put together two, 14-night East African tours departing Nairobi on July 28 and December 22. It says groups will consist only of families. As well as game drives and a visit to Elsamere, former home of the Born Free Adamsons, it includes camping by Lake Nakuru and finishes with three days in Zanzibar. The trips cost £605 for adults and £490 for 8-15 year olds - plus a kitty of £305 to cover food and camping fees.

Guerba World Travel (01373 826611) is offering a two-week tour for parents with children aged eight or over, for example, taking in Namibia's Namib-Naukluft, Waterberg and Etosha National Parks and including two days at Victoria Falls. Prices start at £830 for adults (17 and over) plus a £125 kitty contribution for food and camping fees - or £415 for 8-11 year olds and £695 for 12-16 year olds, each with a £110 kitty. These prices do not cover airfares from Britain, which will cost around £730 return for adults or roughly £450 for under 12s.

Trekking

Mountaineer Eric Shipton's son John will lead an intriguing new trek in China from Himalayan Kingdoms (01453 844 400). The 21-day Plant Hunters of Yunnan trip, from June 9-29 takes travellers in search of flora in remote areas near the Tibetan border. It takes in Napha Lake and the Baima Mountain and Reserve. The cost is £3,425 and flights are via Hong Kong or Bangkok.

Planes, trains & cruise ships

British Midland (0870 6070555) plans to launch scheduled services between Manchester and the US next spring, promising big savings against other carriers' economy business-class prices. It will operate daily flights to Washington Dulles airport from April 30 and Chicago O'Hare from May 21. Fares start from approximately £329 and £362 respectively, including tax.

The first section of Tasmania's restored Abt Railway, which closed in 1960, is due to open early in the new year. Steam-hauled trains will run through rain forest between the former mining boom towns of Strahan and Queenstown.

And no fewer than 17 new cruise ships are scheduled to make their debuts in 2001. They include the biggest in the Mediterranean, the 109,000-tonne, 2,600-passenger Golden Princess, operated by Princess Cruises (020-7800 2468) on which a 12-night cruise from Barcelona to Istanbul starts at £2,225.

Camping

Keycamp (0845 1457000) is encouraging customers to go walking and cycling. It has introduced notes suggesting suitable routes at 43 of its campsites around Europe. And families can pre-book trailer bikes at £3.50 a day for children aged 4-7. Parents take their own bikes and fix the trailers on the back. Prices start at £432 a head for a 12-night holiday in Normandy. That covers two adults and up to four children under 18 in a fixed tent.

Offbeat

The stained glass of Gothic France is the theme of a tour on offer from Martin Randall Travel (020-8742 3355). Accompanied by lecturer Professor Nigel Morgan, it runs from June 24 for a week and costs £990 for each of two sharing (£110 single supplement). Cities include Troyes, Chartres and Auxerre.

Underwater photography courses at Hurghada on the Red Sea are on offer from Regal Diving (0870 2201777). A package price of £629 includes tuition, processing for the first three films and use of dive equipment.

In Washington DC, General Oleg Kalugin, a former head of KGB operations there, is among counter-intelligence experts who take visitors to locations used for spying during the Cold War. Tours cost $35

And in California Airliners of America (001 805 444 2257/www.airliners.org) is offering Sunset Champagne flights in a 1952 Martin 404 - one of five converted in the 1960s to carry the rich and famous.

webTitle: Health advisers head new year's honours list

fields.headline: Health advisers head new year's honours list
fields.standfirst: A raft of key ministerial advisers who helped draw up the NHS plan are among those public sector workers to be rewarded in the new year's honours list.
fields.trailText: A raft of key ministerial advisers who helped draw up the NHS plan are among those public sector workers to be rewarded in the new year's honours list, writes Patrick Butler.
fields.body:
The head of the Audit Commission, and a raft of key ministerial advisers who helped draw up the NHS plan are among those public sector workers to be rewarded in the new year's honours list.

Andrew Foster, Audit Commission controller, and a former top manager in both the NHS and social services, was made a knight. Also receiving a knighthood is Barry Jackson, president of the Royal College of surgeons, and a member of the NHS modernisation board, which has been set up to implement the NHS plan. NHS cancer "tsar" Mike Richards is made a CBE.

Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of Unison, the UK's biggest public sector union, reportedly turned down a life peerage because it would "betray his socialist beliefs".

Other members of the NHS modernisation board to receive honours are: Professor Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of GPs (MBE); Harry Cayton, chief executive of the Alzheimer's Society (OBE); and Barbara Hakin, chief executive of south and west Bradford primary care group (OBE).

Sue Page, chief executive of Northumbria healthcare NHS trust, another modernisation board member, receives a CBE.

Local government figures receiving gongs include: Sally Powell, deputy executive mayor, at the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham (DBE); Robert Wynne Jones, chair of the East Midlands regional assembly; Barry Quirk, chief executive of the London Borough of Lewisham; Richard Leese, leader of Manchester City council; and Douglas Sinclair, chief executive of Fife Council (all CBE).

Somerset County council director of social services John Davies is made a CBE. Geraldine Peacock, chair of the Association of chief executives of voluntary organisations, is made a CBE.

Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, is made a privy counsellor and there is a CBE for Mahbubuddin Ahmad, chair of the Millat Asian Housing Association in south London.

Sue Page, chief executive of Northumbria healthcare NHS trust, another modernisation board member, receives a CBE. Local government figures receiving gongs include: Sally Powell, deputy executive mayor, at the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham (DBE); Robert Wynne Jones, chair of the East Midlands regional assembly; Barry Quirk, chief executive of the London Borough of Lewisham; Richard Leese, leader of Manchester City council; and Douglas Sinclair, chief executive of Fife Council (all CBE). Somerset County council director of social services John Davies is made a CBE. Geraldine Peacock, chair of the Association of chief executives of voluntary organisations, is made a CBE. Nick Raynsford, the housing minister, is made a privy counsellor and there is a CBE for Mahbubuddin Ahmad, chair of the Millat Asian Housing Association in south London.

webTitle: Comment: How the Queen got zapped

fields.headline: How the Queen got zapped
fields.standfirst:
Poor ratings for her TV speech should cause panic at the palace

Special report: future of the monarchy
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Poor ratings for her TV speech should cause panic at the palace.
fields.body:
There is occasionally a moment in election campaigns when a battered candidate not only expects to lose but secretly welcomes defeat, having had enough. This was probably true of John Major in 1997 and of George Bush the elder in 1992. But you now have to wonder if the impulse for self-destruction has spread to our non-elected leaders.

The Princess Royal's imputation of stupidity to a royalist who had risen at dawn to bring a hand-crafted basket of flowers to her heroes at Sandringham church is the rough equivalent of a candidate's wife telephoning a local newspaper to reveal that he does it with sheep.

A million republican pamphlets could not equal the damage done to the Windsors by the curious decision of the Queen's daughter to diss the monarchists. And yet the monarch herself is in no position to issue a rebuke. For the Queen's own performance this Christmas suggested that, psychologically, she has one-way tickets to Monaco in her handbag.

In this season of quizzes, let's consider the question of what HM the Queen and Noel Edmonds have in common? The answer lies not in boorish sidekicks who go around upsetting everyone (Blobby/ Edinburgh) but in presiding over once top-rating TV shows which suddenly halved their audience. This year's Queen's speech suffered a startling switch-off even in a period of poor figures for holiday viewing.

When Noel's House Party suffered such a loss of popularity, it was cancelled by the BBC. That isn't going to happen to Lizzie's Castle Party because, against the usual rules of broadcasting, the corporation has no power over the Queen's speech and simply screens what it is given. Even so, family or advisers would be sensible to suggest that the performer makes some urgent changes to her act before December 25 2001.

Like music hall and Noel Edmonds, the Queen is in part the helpless victim of shifts in the definition of entertainment. Carol Thatcher revealed in a recent article that her family not only wolfs lunch in order to be in front of the TV by 3pm but that they all stand up for the anthem at the end. There are, though, ever fewer Britons like that and, whatever broadcasting innovations the monarch makes, a British tradition of never missing the Queen is inexorably being replaced by a tradition of putting on a video or video-game instead.

Yet, despite these defences, the content of this year's address - My Life As a Christian - actively encouraged switch-off. It was as if a regional theatre, noticing a dip in the subscriptions for Ayckbourn, responds by staging a season of late Ibsen. In running the Pope close for devotion, the Queen was being true to the constitution - she is supreme head of the Church of England - and to her own psychology. Although it tends to go unnoticed in a secular world, biographies suggest that Elizabeth II probably isn't very different from Elizabeth I in her definition of the monarchy as divinely given and inspired.

Admittedly there's a certain thrill in hearing a speech by a public figure which involves no spin or tactics, consists of the deeply held beliefs which they wanted to speak at that time and is the opposite of what most of the audience expects or wants to hear.

Yet, again, you have to question the Queen's instincts and advisers. As a survival and modernisation strategy for monarchy, playing the God card (and the even lower suit of the Anglican card) can only be regarded - in a largely godless culture in which any surviving belief divides between many faiths - as lese-majeste in a rare inwards application.

The Republican party in America, which responded to crisis by playing to the religious minority, was unelectable for a decade. And the Queen's heir has sensibly suggested that a future monarch should seek to be a defender of faiths rather than of a single church.

Following this miscalculated address, HM's advisers should be on their knees. More accurately than any opinion poll - because it draws on a massive national sample and offers comparisons over 50 years - the ratings for the Christmas address have become a measure of the monarchy's popularity. Smart people in the Buck House press and marketing teams must realise that it is necessary for them to ascend next year.

There is only one solution, which I propose from historical interest rather than mischief. The Queen must accede to her first ever media interview. If any lackey ever dared put this proposal to her, she would quote in refusal her late daughter-in-law's Panorama, but the point of this encounter will not be confession or scandal.

The interviewers - David Dimbleby and Trevor McDonald jointly for BBC and ITV, I would guess - will so feel the weight of the occasion and her status that the questions are unlikely to be tough. Television executives are so terrified of the royals that there would be as few or as many Diana or Camilla posers as she indicated she was prepared to take.

The point is novelty: the constitutional equivalent of that moment in a movie theatre when the audience first heard the stars talk. The result would be record ratings and a necessary impression of modernity. Without such a move, the televised speech serves as a clock on the monarchy, ticking down loudly each year. Noel Edmonds used to be on telly every Christmas too.

webTitle: Creator of the Goon Show is knighted

fields.headline: Comic eccentric joins establishment
fields.standfirst:
Creator of the Goon Show is knighted

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Creator of the Goon Show is knighted
fields.body:
Spike Milligan - one of the rare undisputed geniuses of British humour - was at last formally honoured by the British establishment, nearly 50 years after his Goon Show sketches inspired a new kind of comedy.

At 82, he received his distinction in a typically indirect way; his knighthood is honorary because he is an Irish citizen.

Milligan began his career in the radio series with sketches such as The Dreaded Batter Pudding Hurler of Bexhill on Sea. He continued it with Hitler: My Part in His Downfall and only four years ago penned Frankenstein, According to Spike Milligan.

He has enjoyed a long friendship with the Prince of Wales, whom he once called "a little grovelling bastard". When the prince urged him to qualify for a British passport by swearing the allegiance oath, Milligan said, "Yes, but it's your mother, isn't it? You don't get board and lodging at Buckingham Palace if you don't swear an oath."

Paul Scofield , 78, is another who could have been honoured at any time since the 1950s. He has long been recognised as a great actor in the line of John Gielgud and Laurence Olivier, though his stage work has been less frequent.

However Scofield, a reticent man, is said to dislike titles. He became only the third actor, after Gielgud and Alec Guinness, to be appointed a Companion of Honour. A theatrical knighthood went to Tom Courtenay, 63, once projected as the northern working class face of a new wave of British cinema and theatre in the early 1960s.

A stage star in Billy Liar in his early twenties, he later played leads in films including The Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner, Private Potter, King and Country and Dr Zhivago, before returning to theatre and television.

His fellow actor Joss Ackland, 72, received a CBE after a 55-year career which included a spell as a tea planter in Malawi. His admired range of work stretches from restoration comedy to the BBC television role of the writer CS Lewis in Shadowlands to a Mafia don in the film The Sicilian.

Another CBE went to the influential, risk-taking West End theatre producer and impresario Bill Kenwright. Kenwright's first job until 1969 was in the part of Gordon Clegg in Coronation Street.

William Roache, who plays Ken Barlow in the Street, got an MBE. So did Trevor Harrison, Eddie Grundy in the Archers; the television prankster Jeremy Beadle; the veteran cartoonist Bill Tidy; and one of the fathers of the postwar trad jazz boom, the clarinettist Acker Bilk. His Stranger on the Shore in 1962 was the first British song to top the US charts, paving the way for the Beatles a year later.

The TV entertainer Jim Davidson received an OBE. In the diplomatic and overseas honours lists, the classical and Star Trek star Patrick Stewart gets an OBE, along with the actress Charlotte Rampling.

The TV and stage actress Zoe Wanamaker became an honorary CBE.

fields.headline: Two-minute fight for BA2069
fields.standfirst:
Jumbo dives 10,000ft to within seconds of disaster as captain and crew wrestle with passenger

I could see the ground. It was very, very close
Training tells as pilots face the unexpected
fields.trailText: Jumbo dives 10,000ft to within seconds of disaster as captain and crew wrestle with passenger.
fields.byline: Jeevan Vasagar, Vikram Dodd  and  Liz Stuart  in Nairobi
fields.body:
A packed British Airways jumbo came within seconds of disaster yesterday when a mentally unstable passenger stormed the cockpit and attempted to seize the controls.

The Nairobi-bound Boeing 747, with 379 passengers on board, plunged 10,000ft as the captain and one of his first officers wrestled with the intruder on the flight deck for two minutes.

BA flight 2069 had left Gatwick six hours earlier and was cruising 35,000ft above Sudan when one of the struggling men accidentally disengaged the autopilot.

Passengers screamed in terror and prayed for their lives as the plane dived steeply down then, witnesses said, banked left at a sharp angle heading for the ground.

Oxygen masks dropped from their hatches as bags flew through the cabins and passengers who were not strapped in bumped their heads on the backs of seats.

A flight attendant was thrown to the ground, breaking her ankle, as Captain William Hagan struggled with the intruder, poking his fingers into the man's eyes.

In the scuffle the intruder bit one of the pilot's fingers and his ear but, aided by one of his first officers, Capt Hagan succeeded in dragging him out of the cockpit and into the club class cabin. There passengers rushed to help, including a 6ft 6in tall American who helped bundle the man to the ground.

Phil Watson, 38, the co-pilot, who had been sitting at the controls throughout, pulled the plane out of its dive and ended the two-minute crisis, which took place just before 5am.

Among those on board were Lady Annabel Goldsmith, widow of the businessman Sir James, her daughter Jemima Khan and her son Benjamin.

Mrs Khan was travelling to Kenya with her children, Kasim, aged 18 months, and Sulaiman, four, for a two-week holiday.

Also on board were the singer Bryan Ferry and his wife Lucy Helmore, en route to Zanzibar for a family break. "I'm relieved to get here in one piece," he said on his eventual safe arrival in Nairobi.

Capt Hagan, 53, whose wife and two children were on board, said: "It all happened very quickly. My first thought was for the safety of the aircraft and the passengers. We just did what we are trained to do.

"In the struggle the intruder bit my ear but my first officer Richard Webb and I managed to get him out of the cockpit while my other first officer Phil Watson flew the aircraft. With the help of some passengers we managed to restrain the intruder.

"Thanks to the quick thinking of my colleagues and the passengers, this incident was brought to a swift conclusion. I'm very proud of my two first officers and cabin crew and I'm very grateful for the assistance from our passengers," added Capt Hagan, who is from Glasgow and and has 30 years of flying experience.

The intruder was arrested when the flight arrived in Nairobi. Police described the 27-year-old man, a Kenyan, as a suspected mental patient and said he was under sedation in hospital.

Benjamin Goldsmith said Capt Hagan later told passengers that if the drama had lasted four or five seconds longer, the co-pilot would not have been able to regain control because the jet was about to flip upside down.

"I don't think there was a single person on the plane who didn't think we were going to crash. Everyone was asleep at the time when the plane went into a violent dive and started to shudder.

"There were grown men screaming. It was quite a violent situation when the plane stopped diving and went into another dive to the left. One of the engines cut out. This was a scene of an aeroplane about to crash," Mr Goldsmith said.

"The lights went out and the oxygen masks came down and the plane sort of regained control after what must have been about 20 or 30 seconds.

"The pilot then came straight on to the loudspeaker and said, 'A very nasty man just tried to kill us all,' and that's what he said."

"Every single person on that airplane was absolutely terrified, there were people praying aloud. The pilot came down to see his wife who was in the club class cabin and said to his wife and to all of us four or five seconds more and the co-pilot wouldn't have been able to regain control because the thing was about to go on to its back."

webTitle: Training tells as pilots face the unexpected

fields.headline: Training tells as pilots face the unexpected
fields.standfirst:
Two-minute fight for BA2069
I could see the ground. It was very, very close
fields.trailText: When first officer Phil Watson yesterday found that the Boeing 747-400 aircraft he was flying was going into a steep descent after the cockpit was stormed, it would not have been the first time he had faced such a situation.
fields.body:
When first officer Phil Watson yesterday found that the Boeing 747-400 aircraft he was flying was going into a steep descent after the cockpit was stormed, it would not have been the first time he had faced such a situation.

Every six months, British Airways pilots spend two days in a hi-tech simulator at Cranebank, near Heathrow, experiencing dangerous circumstances.

Yesterday's was one of the worst a pilot could face, and the crew of flight BA 2069 were said to have handled the situation brilliantly.

It was the temporary loss of the autopilot system that was believed to have caused the plane's sudden drop in altitude.

Before the cockpit was invaded, Mr Watson had engaged one of three autopilot systems on the jet, to fly it on a steady course. While there is only one way to switch the system on, there are three ways of switching it off.

Ian Hibberd, a BA pilot, said it was unlikely the intruder would have deliberately disengaged the autopilot, as he would not have known where the switches were. But if the control column, which steers the jet, were grabbed, the autopilot would automatically disengage.

"I would imagine someone made a grab for the control column, or it got knocked quite hard," Mr Hibberd said.

It is little wonder that the passengers noticed the drop of 10,000ft in a few seconds. A plane usually descends at 800-900ft a minute. "It's a big aircraft; you don't go throwing it around the sky like an aerobatic aircraft," said Mr Hibberd.

BA said control was recovered at least seven minutes before the aircraft was in danger of hitting the ground.

There were two more immediate dangers. One was that the plane would flip over, making it extremely difficult to regain control. "The pilot has literally to pull it out of its dive using the control column, which is power assisted," said Doug Birch, editor of the aircraft industry journal Maintenance, Repair and Overhaul.

The second danger came from stemming the rapid descent and returning the plane to a proper course. This could have put enormous stress on its superstructure. Damage to the tail, wings or airframe could have made the aircraft permanently uncontrollable, said Mr Birch.

Yesterday's flight "pitched up and down" as Mr Watson struggled to regain control. For a time is was "banked", or inclined at an angle of more than 45 degrees.

Mr Hibberd said: "If it did bank at over 45 degrees, that is worrying to pilots because it is bloody uncomfortable. You imagine 300 tonnes of aircraft doing 500 mph: it is a massive amount of momentum."

The incident raises the issue of whether the flight deck door should be kept locked, as on US airlines, some of which also have armed "sky marshals".

Kieran Daly, editor of the in ternet news service Air Transport Intelligence, said: "It is almost impossible to guarantee 100% security during the flight. There is a lot of coming and going from the main cabin, and attackers are going to find a way through."

A locked cockpit door could also leave cabin staff more vulnerable to attack from passengers.

Mr Hibberd, of the security committee of the airline pilots union, Balpa, said: "A determined villain will be able to gain entry anywhere. By keeping the flight deck door locked you're not benefiting safety. It can be locked in an emergency, but as an emergency exit for the crew it is breakable."

Terror in the air
Sally James Gregory

 In July a 28-year-old passenger on a Japanese jumbo jet stabbed the pilot to death and took over the controls. He claimed he wanted to fly the plane under a bridge in Tokyo. He was overpowered by cabin staff.

 A man claiming to be an asylum seeker threatened to blow up a BA flight from Zurich to Gatwick in July. He held a large pair of scissors to a stewardess's throat. The pilot persuaded him to let her go while the co-pilot landed.

 A drunken bodybuilder burst into the cockpit of a Boeing 737 flying from Tenerife to Germany in March and grabbed the controls, shouting: "I'm bringing you all down." He was overpowered.

 In May on a Philippine Airlines flight to Manila a man wielding a gun and a primed grenade ordered a cabin attendant to push him from the plane. He was found embedded in the ground.

There is a lot of coming and going from the main cabin, and attackers are going to find a way through." A locked cockpit door could also leave cabin staff more vulnerable to attack from passengers. Mr Hibberd, of the security committee of the airline pilots union, Balpa, said: "A determined villain will be able to gain entry anywhere. By keeping the flight deck door locked you're not benefiting safety. It can be locked in an emergency, but as an emergency exit for the crew it is breakable." He claimed he wanted to fly the plane under a bridge in Tokyo. He was overpowered by cabin staff.  A man claiming to be an asylum seeker threatened to blow up a BA flight from Zurich to Gatwick in July. He held a large pair of scissors to a stewardess's throat. The pilot persuaded him to let her go while the co-pilot landed.  A drunken bodybuilder burst into the cockpit of a Boeing 737 flying from Tenerife to Germany in March and grabbed the controls, shouting: "I'm bringing you all down." He was overpowered.  In May on a Philippine Airlines flight to Manila a man wielding a gun and a primed grenade ordered a cabin attendant to push him from the plane. He was found embedded in the ground.

webTitle: Guardian reporter's eyewitness account of Flight BA2069

fields.headline: I could see the ground. It was very, very close
fields.standfirst:
Guardian reporter Liz Stuart who was on board Flight BA2069

Two-minute fight for BA2069
Training tells as pilots face the unexpected
fields.trailText: Guardian reporter Liz Stuart who was on board Flight BA2069.
fields.body:
It had just started getting light when the plane jolted massively. There was no warning, just this terrible shuddering.

I thought it was turbulence, that we were going through a storm because I looked out the window and saw black. Then I realised I was looking at the ground. The plane was tilting left to right so one minute I could see the clouds, and the next minute the sun. Then I could see the ground, which looked very, very close.

People didn't seem to panic, but when a man stood up, one of the flight attendants screamed at him to sit down.

I didn't hear any of the passengers screaming, but I don't know whether I just cut out. Passengers in other parts of the plane said people were screaming all around them.

There was a family in front of us whose 12-year-old son was in the loo at the time, and they didn't know what was happening to him. The father just kept saying to his children: "It's OK, it's OK."

There was another massive jolt downwards and the emergency oxygen masks were released from above us.

It didn't feel like a nose dive. It felt like being in a fast lift when the floor falls away.

The flight attendants were screaming at people to sit down, and I realised that something was seriously wrong.

I was holding on to my partner's hand for dear life. I remember having this really sweaty palm and telling him not to look out of the window. I could feel the plane shaking all around me.

Then the alarm bells rang three times, which must have been a signal for all the cabin crew to get to the front as fast as possible because all the staff just ran to the cockpit.

Then the captain's voice came on. He was out of breath, and he said: "Ladies and gentlemen, it is all under control now but a madman has just tried to crash the plane."

He seemed really panicked and the plane still wasn't steady. I felt utter disbelief.

I was told by a flight attendant that this guy had entered the cockpit and and tried to strangle the captain.

People had heard screams coming from the cockpit and two passengers went and wrestled him to the ground.

He was sedated, blindfolded and restrained. A passenger who saw him being taken off the plane said he had very swollen eyes and looked drowsy.

One of the attendants broke her ankle. She was standing up and fell when the plane jolted. Another stewardess said it was the most frightening thing that had ever happened to her.

People were crying. It was then that I went into shock and started shaking.

The attendants were fantastic. They were trying to give us as much information as possible, and they served us tea and coffee, but they had a panic in their eyes that I have never seen before.

It was bloody scary.

fields.headline: Dome troubleshooter eyes up Railtrack
fields.standfirst:
'Beancounter' sees troubled network as tougher challenge

Special report: the Millennium Dome
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: 'Beancounter' sees troubled network as tougher challenge.
fields.body:
David James, the corporate troubleshooter brought in by the government to save the dome from premature closure, would be prepared to take on an even tougher challenge - as head of Railtrack.

The chairmanship of the rail operator falls vacant when Sir Philip Beck retires next year. Mr James, whose crisis management credits range from Dan Air to Eagle Trust, indicated yesterday that he was attracted to Railtrack. "It's big, it's national and it is a crisis," he said in an interview with the Guardian.

Mr James, now overseeing the winding down of the dome, said his interest was conditional on a clear job definition and on the backing of the Railtrack board.

"I would need to know what needs to be done, but it is a sovereign board and I would not be shifted into any board against its wishes. And I would need to know where the finishing post is.

"But if I was approached, then I would consider it."

The prospect of Mr James taking over the helm of one of Britain's most controversial companies would be a welcome lift to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott.

As head of a department that includes transport, Mr Prescott has sought to keep a hold on the growing crisis in the railways, where accidents have led to hold-ups, mass cancellations and plummeting public confidence.

He would appreciate Mr James' strong financial background (he describes himself as a "beancounter") that would enable him to get to grips with the complexities of financing of the rail network.

Mr James' experience of stepping into controversies gives him a solid platform from which to conduct the public relations campaign that Railtrack will need to restore its image.

However there is some concern that he has no direct operational experience of running a railway, a criticism also levelled at Railtrack's chief executive Steven Marshall, who stepped up from finance director when Gerald Corbett resigned as chief.

One industry source said, "The company is clearly lacking in high level input from professional railway people.

"It has become too far removed from what it should be, which is basically an engineering business."

The crisis was underlined again yesterday when Mr Prescott indicated that a recovery of the network would probably take until Easter.

On Radio 4's Today programme he accused rail firms of showing "indifference" to passengers by increasing fares while the network faced chaos. It showed a lack of judgment, he said, and he agreed that the private operators would have to "watch out" in the future.

"I'm sure the public are fed up with this poor quality production.

"The companies will say they are losing income but it's not fair to put the burden on the passenger," he said.

Some train operators had not passed on the costs to passengers, and they should be an example to the rest, he said.

Mr Prescott also hit out at those responsible for leaving hundreds stranded at Stansted airport after trains terminated before the last flights arrived on Boxing Day, saying it had been "absolutely stupid". It was time the culture of the railways, which failed to put the passenger first, was changed dramatically, he said.

Railtrack yesterday found itself involved in a controversy over its forecasts for passenger growth.

Earlier this year the company said it was working on passengers rising by 47% over the decade. Yesterday, however, it emerged that Railtrack had reduced the figure to 37% as a result of the government's decision to scrap the fuel escalator.

With investment in the railways linked to growth rates, and with the new forecast taking no account of any reductions in passengers in the wake of the post-Hatfield crash problems, there had been concern about the impact on the government's transport policy - which supposes investment from 50% growth.

However Railtrack yesterday insisted that its revision would have no effect on investment. "We are all agreed we are going for growth," said a Railtrack spokesman; the actual differences between its forecasts and the government's were much smaller than they appeared, because the two used different forecasting models.

webTitle: Briton among 20 killed in ambush by Burundi rebels

fields.headline: Briton among 20 killed in ambush by Burundi rebels
fields.standfirst: 30 December 2000: Passionate teacher who was doing something special
fields.trailText: At least 20 people, including a British aid worker, were killed yesterday when an armed gang ambushed a bus travelling on the main road linking the Burundian capital, Bujumbura, with Rwanda's capital, Kigali.
fields.body:
At least 20 people, including a British aid worker, were killed yesterday when an armed gang ambushed a bus travelling on the main road linking the Burundian capital, Bujumbura, with Rwanda's capital, Kigali.

Nine passengers escaped as the attackers killed the others one by one, according to survivors.

The ambush happened in broad daylight 30 miles northwest of Bujumbura. An ambush on the same road a few miles away left three people dead, including a former interior minister, two weeks ago.

The Briton who died was named as Charlotte Wilson, 27. Colleagues in Kigali said she was a primary school teacher who went to Rwanda on behalf of Voluntary Service Overseas to work in a local school.

The bus overturned after being fired on and was surrounded by a gang who started taking valuables and clothes from the terrified passengers, a Rwandan woman, identified only as Cadeau, said.

"We were asked to lie down on the concrete road. When they voiced their intention to kill us, I began begging them to spare my life and my child's," she said. "Everyone was crying for mercy, but I looked their chief directly into his eyes and said, 'My brother, please, let us go.' He said, 'Get up and go, and tell the military we'll kill everyone and they will not be able to do anything.' I promised to pass that on."

She said two other women escaped death by saying they were her sisters but the other hostages were forced to line up in the road and were shot as the survivors ran to an army post two miles away, hearing gunfire as they fled.

Apart from Ms Wilson, the passengers were Rwandans and Burundians. The bus, called Titanic, is a regular shuttle between Kigali and Bujumbura. "The driver was shot and the bus crashed into the ditch, then the rebels ordered passengers to come out and executed them one by one," one witness said.

Ms Wilson was one of 56 VSO volunteers working in the country. Penny Lawrence, VSO's director of overseas operations, said colleagues and friends were devastated.

"Charlotte was an exceptional volunteer - very bright, caring and committed to rebuilding Rwanda's education system. Her students responded to her infectious enthusiasm, but her talent was also recognised at the highest level." She had recently been asked by the Rwandan education minister to help develop a science curriculum for the country's secondary school system.

The attackers were probably a small freelance group of rebels motivated mainly by banditry rather than members of the two main Hutu factions which operate in the south of the country.

webTitle: Falconer insists dome buyer will not make excessive profits

fields.headline: Falconer insists dome buyer will not make excessive profits
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Millennium Dome
fields.trailText: The government last night hit back at claims that it was selling the taxpayer short by offering the Millennium Dome complex for £125m, even though the purchasers planned to make as much as £200m from disposing of land for new luxury homes.
fields.body:
The government last night hit back at claims that it was selling the taxpayer short by offering the Millennium Dome complex for £125m, even though the purchasers planned to make as much as £200m from disposing of land for new luxury homes.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said the sell-off stank, and added that one of the key figures in Legacy, the bidding consortium, was a Labour party donor. Mr Ainsworth was referring to Robert Bourne, a friend of the culture secretary, Chris Smith.

The Cabinet Office minister, Lord Falconer, said the allegations of sleaze were bizarre since the initial preferred government bidder for the site had been the Japanese firm Nomura, not Legacy. The contract had been awarded to Legacy only after Nomura pulled out.

He also insisted the government would negotiate clawback deals so that if Legacy made "an excess profit" from putting housing on the site the taxpayer would benefit. During the competition it had been clear that bidders could make a bid on the basis of purchasing the dome and some property.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, pointed out that Legacy had not yet secured planning permission for any extra homes, and in the long term any planning permission deal could be called in by his department.

Earlier Mr Ainsworth had demanded that profits from selling the dome should be ploughed back into the national lottery and regeneration of the Greenwich peninsula. "The government is in danger of making as much of a mess of selling the dome as it has of operating it," he claimed.

Legacy, which is expected to take over the dome at the end of February, plans a hi-tech business city within the giant structure. The venture could create 14,000 jobs within three years.

Greenwich council also said that it would not allow Legacy simply to build highly profitable luxury homes.

It said that it would require a "significant proportion" of any development on the site to be made available for affordable rented housing on the site.

The suggestion that Legacy could make as much as £200m from the housing development rests on the assumption that the proposed apartments would be sold for up to £1m each, with the average home costing about £200,000.

Only Legacy remains as a potential buyer for the dome, which will close as a visitor attraction on New Year's Eve.

The government yesterday confirmed that the life of the millennium commission will be extended by two years to oversee building projects that have not yet been completed.

fields.headline: The multi-billion dollar retailer that could not deliver
fields.standfirst:
eToys would have had to take total US market to succeed

Net news
fields.trailText: eToys would have had to take total US market to succeed.
fields.body:
The story of eToys, the online retailer, is a prime example of how the mighty have fallen in this year of the dot.com crash.

Founded by a Disney theme park veteran four years ago, the company became one of the world's best known etailers. Its well designed website offered thousands of products to be bought from home rather than among the bustle of noisy children. It was launched on the stock market in the heady days of May 1999, and was valued at its peak at more than $80 a share, or about $10bn (£7bn).

The company, which fashionably called its founder "Uncle" Toby Lenk, appeared to flourish while rivals such asToysMart and KBkids either shut down or struggled.

Reports of unfulfilled orders and dissatisfied customers provided some warning signs last Christmas, typically a time when toy retailers make half their annual revenues.

The real bombshell came 10 days before this Christmas when eToys issued a dire warning about the state of its financial health. The Californian company slashed its sales forecast for this quarter by 50% and said its operating loss as a percentage of revenue could more than double. It also admitted that it would soon run out of money, perhaps by spring, and called for "additional, substantial capital infusion".

A company which was once seen as a threat to some of the biggest retailers in the world has appointed Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, to look at strategic options such as a merger with one of those rivals. The price should no longer be too onerous for them. Soon after the profits warning, shares in eToys plummeted to 25 cents, valuing the group at $31m.

Ken Cassar, retail analyst at Jupiter Communications, the internet research group, said: "eToys is probably the best example of the early euphoria and the subsequent crash. To have justified its earlier valuations, it would have had to capture 100% of the US toy market as well as a few others."

Following the sales warning, Standard & Poor's, the credit agency, cut the company's credit rating to junk level and expressed "serious doubt" that it would survive.

eToys is now one of many former multi-billion dollar businesses in danger of being kicked off the Nasdaq stock market because its shares are trading below a minimum bid price of $1.

A new name has been created to describe the huge number of companies trading at a fraction of their previous highs because of the slump in US stock market valuations. The so-called 90% club includes dot.com firms such as Priceline, the online ticketing company, as well as Drkoop, the health information website co-founded by a former US surgeon general. The latter has sacked more than half of its staff and is now worth only $13m.

Internet analysts believe that the shake-out has a lot further to go in America, where many more companies will close or merge. Mr Cassar says a supermarket group such as Wal-Mart, which has enjoyed limited success with its online offering, could do worse than buy eToys. "eToys clearly has to seek an acquirer," he said. "Its advantage is that it has tangible assets and a strong brand."

Even at the current low prices, few traditional businesses have stepped in to buy loss-making online counterparts. Few are sure whether their erstwhile rivals are now cheap or simply worthless.

webTitle: The year dot.com turned into dot.bomb

fields.headline: The year dot.com turned into dot.bomb
fields.standfirst:
Iron laws of the market bring a sharp dose of reality to the virtual business world

Net news
Letsbuyit problems add to dot.com gloom
Start-up backers suffer flagging fortunes
fields.trailText: Iron laws of the market bring a sharp dose of reality to the virtual business world.
fields.body:
First it was tulips, then it was shares in the South Sea Company. Now the dot.coms have been added to that dubious hall of fame - the roll call of speculative bubbles that have punctuated the history of financial markets.

Yesterday yet another high profile dot.com business - Letsbuyit - announced it had run into difficulties.

The mania for technology stocks in 2000 had all the ingredients for a roller-coaster ride from boom to bust - glamorous sounding products that investors knew little about, avarice, an economy firing on all cylinders, some dashing young entrepreneurs, a small army of cheerleaders in brokerage houses and in the media peddling the line that the rules of business had been rewritten.

Yet what it did not have was the ability to rewrite the rules of economics. When the historians come to write the story of the dot.com bubble their epitaph will be the same as that penned after the madness ended in 17th century Holland, London in 1720 or Wall Street in 1929: it wasn't different this time.

In vain did the Cassandras prophesy that it would all end in tears, that there were simply too many companies chasing too little revenue, and that for the stock market valuations of the dot.coms to be justified every person on earth would have to be surfing the net 24 hours a day with a mobile phone clamped to each ear.

The iron laws of markets have now reasserted themselves. The ratcheting up of interest rates by the Federal Reserve has not not helped, leading to weaker consumer demand and higher business costs. But there were also structural factors at play. Over the medium term, share prices are linked to profits with a fairly stable relationship between share prices and earnings, the price-earnings ratio. If the price-earnings ratio is much higher than normal, one of two things can happen - either the company will eventually justify its share price by making higher profits or its share price will come down to earth with a bump.

Most dot.coms were involved in sectors where profits - assuming there were any - were destined to be squeezed by cut-throat competition. Reality has now set in. Shares in dot.com start-ups that were changing hands for hundreds of dollars each at the height of the speculative fever are now virtually worthless. Did anybody know or care what Engage Inc was actually involved in, let alone have any idea of its likely earnings potential when it was trading at $95 a share earlier this year. They probably took a closer look as the shares fell to just over $1 this month.

However, there was little analysis of this sort as the year dawned with the US economy booming, fears of a millennium bug meltdown for the markets dispelled and the merger between America Online, the world's biggest internet services provider, and Time Warner, one of biggest traditional media companies, symbolising the unstoppable force of the "new paradigm".

The combination appeared to mark the coming of age of online upstarts as AOL had all the glitz and all the potential, but Time Warner was making all the money. With the benefit of hindsight, the merger presaged the crest of the stock market wave rather than the start of an avalanche of deals.

Having risen a record-breaking 88% in 1999, the Nasdaq composite index of technology companies rallied even higher in the first three months of 2000. On March 10, the index reached a record high of 5048. In the dying weeks of the year, it is trading at less than half this level. With the bubble burst and investor confidence in tatters, the index has recorded its worst ever annual performance in its 29-year history. The previous low of a 35% decline was recorded during the oil crisis of 1974.

This year's bear market began in April, when the Nasdaq suffered four of its worst ever points losses in quick succession. Within 51 trading days, $2,400bn (£1,700bn) had been wiped from the technology-driven stock market.

The amount of paper money made and lost in the US hi-tech sector has been astonishing. Microsoft has halved in value since the beginning of the year with about $240bn cut from its market capitalisation. Bill Gates, the company's founder, is still the world's richest man in spite of losing about $40bn as a result of his company's misfortunes.

Others to have lost several billion dollars over the past year include Jeff Bezos, founder of Amazon.com who saw the value of his stake in the company fall by $1bn one day this summer, and Jerry Yang, the chief of Yahoo whose stake in the web search group is worth about $7bn less than it once was.

Cassandra-in-chief for the bubble proved to be a shy economics professor from Yale, Robert Shiller, whose book Irrational Exuberance was published just as the market peaked in March. Shiller is unable to identify a precise explanation for why the bubble burst when it did, however. "It seems to me that something happened to let the sceptical advice sink in," is all he will say. After years out of the spotlight, Shiller is rather uncomfortable with some aspects of his role as a naysayer. "It felt funny," he said of the tours publicising the book, where many readers were concerned about their own plummeting fortunes. "It seems as though all doctors, whether economic or medical, are meant to be reassuring."

The Nasdaq has declined by about 50% since Shiller's book was launched. Yet, still he is bearish about the future direction of share prices. "I don't think we're at the bottom of the overall market," he said, adding that on a trailing 12-month basis, the S&P 500 index is still trading at a price-earnings multiple of 25 times, about twice the historic average.

The rate of company closures is still accelerating, according to a report published by Webmergers, an online consultancy. In the first 11 months of the year, 130 internet companies folded with about 8,000 job losses.

In spite of signs that the stock market mania has come to an end, most analysts believe the internet will make a lasting impact on business and the economy.

Andy Grove, chairman of Intel, confidently predicted last year: "There won't be any internet companies [within a few years]. All companies will be internet companies, or they will be dead."

This is almost certainly true. The Wall Street crash of 1929 did not mean the end of radio or prevent the spread of the motor car. But a word of warning. In real terms, the S&P composite index did not regain its level of September 1929 until December 1958.

fields.bylineHtml: Jane Martinson and Larry Elliott

fields.headline: Start-up backers suffer flagging fortunes
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Letsbuyit problems add to dot.com gloom
The year dot.com turned into dot.bomb
fields.trailText: The year 2000 was always supposed to be about crashes.
fields.body:
The year 2000 was always supposed to be about crashes.

The millennium bug threatened to derail the world's computer networks from the moment the clocks struck midnight on January 31, 1999 because of the machine's inability to compute the new number.

In the end the disasters that the doom-mongers had predicted failed to materialise.

Then in March the crash that the financial world appeared to have turned a blind eye to happened and the pandemonium really started. Over the period of a single week in March more than $100bn (£70bn) was wiped off the value of the world's leading technology stocks as the entire sector went into a tailspin.

Victims of the sell-off included several of the highest profile internet start-ups and their founders' multi-million pound paper fortunes.

The highest profile casualty was Boo, the trendy online fashion store run by a former model and her poetry writing partner. In little over a year they and their 400 strong staff managed to burn through £85m of cash put up by investors including the billionaire luxury goods magnate Bernard Arnault and blue-chip investment banks such as Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan.

Consumption within the firm had become the stuff of legend as junior staff flew on Concorde to meetings in New York and company credit cards took a hammering behind the bars near Boo's Regent Street headquarters.

Just edging them out in the publicity stakes was the British internet sector's First Couple: Brent Hoberman and Martha Lane Fox of Lastminute, the late bookings specialist. Investors and journalists alike could not get enough of the photogenic couple who graced magazine covers, pontificated with politicians on Radio 4's Today programme and preached the mantra of the net at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

The frenzy helped them to raise £120m from a controversial stock market flotation - just as investors fell out of love with business-to-consumer companies. At its peak the firm was valued at about £900m. Today is is worth £130m.

Lastminute shareholders were not alone. Steve Bennett, founder of etailer Jungle, saw the value of his firm fall from £700m to £37m in a matter of months before it was sold to Argos owner, Great Universal Stores.

Freeserve shares crashed from £9bn to £1.6bn and the company was taken over by a subsidiary of a former state run telephone monopoly in France. Oxygen, the internet incubator with a management and advisory team made up of celebrity investors, a father and daughter and a former professional footballer, slumped from 57.5p to just above its 2p issue price.

Yet at least they did not go the way of Clickmango, Boxman - the internet music store - and Thestreet.co.uk, just a few high profile casualties of the return to reality by investors later in the year.

They were not helped by the poor reception that greeted WAP, the technology that allows people to access the internet through their mobile phones, or the farce surrounding internet service providers' botched attempts to introduce unmetered access.

Despite the gloom, some emerged from the mire with credit. Companies such as ARM Holdings and Autonomy - the makers of the picks and shovels for the goldrush, as they put it - are still profitable players on a global stage. Only someone still suffering from a bad case of millennium bug would try to put a number on the amount of British technology firms we will be able to say that about next Christmas.

webTitle: Letsbuyit problems add to dot.com gloom

fields.headline: Letsbuyit problems add to dot.com gloom
fields.standfirst:
Net news
Start-up backers suffer flagging fortunes
The year dot.com turned into dot.bomb
fields.trailText: The gloom over the dot.com world deepened further yesterday when another high-profile internet company plunged into trouble.
fields.body:
The gloom over the dot.com world deepened further yesterday when another high-profile internet company plunged into trouble.

Letsbuyit, best known for its advertising campaign featuring ants supposedly illustrating strength in numbers, sought and won court protection from its creditors after running into financial difficulties.

The company, which specialises in arranging for consumers to pool their buying and bargaining power for goods, had applied to a Dutch court to delay making repayments on its debts while it sought an extra £50m of funding.

The company's website gave no indication yesterday that anything was amiss, but a spokesman said it would be closing to new orders in the near future. Existing customers would receive their goods or a full refund.

Martin Coles, the chief executive said: "While we still have cash and strong sales growth, we don't have any prospects of receiving funding in the short term, so we felt it was prudent to take this stand."

The group, whose holding company is Dutch but whose website is based in London, is the latest in a series of online ventures to run into trouble in a sector that is seeing about one dot.com business go under every day. Breathe and thestreet.co.uk closed their doors last month. On top of that, ready2shop scaled back its ambitions for its website after failing to attract enough venture capital. The industry has been hit by falling share prices and the high costs of winning customers.

The problems at Letsbuyit came to a head when it asked for trading in its shares to be halted in Frankfurt after announcing the plan to delay debt repayments.

Stephen Cox, a spokesman for the company, said yesterday an early rescue deal was not in sight. "We're talking to people but it takes time for these deals to conclude. There is no expectation that a deal will be done quickly."

Analysts said Letsbuyit's move was a strategic plan to extend its life. The deferral of debt repayments would allow the company to use its cash for other priorities and to increase the amount of time it has to operate. "Its not a good sign if a company can't meet its debt repayments. It suggests it has severe cash restraints," one said.

Last month the company said it was looking for a partner to provide funding until it reached profitability at the end of 2002, but said it has enough cash, £48m, to take it to the middle of next year.

Mr Coles said last month: "We definitely will be looking for cash, we're talking to people right now about the potential for investment. We'd be looking around the €80m [£50m] mark."

The company's cash pile has dwindled since it went public in July, when it raised half the amount it was hoping for. The flotation had been postponed twice because of negative market sentiment on technology stocks. It said it was not possible to say how much money it had left at this stage.

Letsbuyit's shares closed at €1.25 on Thursday, 81% below its peak of €6.45 on July 21.

webTitle: Comment: Be bold, Tony. It's the new way

fields.headline: Be bold, Tony. It's the new way
fields.standfirst:
John O'Farrell calls for renationalisation of the railways and a tax on Pringle jumpers

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Let's have renationalisation of the railways and a tax on Pringle jumpers.
fields.body:
Tomorrow night the Pedants' Society will be celebrating the dawning of the new millennium. "Technically the new century doesn't start until 2001; this should have been the night there were parties in all the parks and sports stadiums," the leader of the pedants will proclaim. "Actually Brian, it's 'stadia', not 'stadiums'."

For the rest of us, the new year means something far more significant: general election time is upon us once again. When Stanley Kubrick envisaged the year 2001, he erroneously foresaw the wonders of interplanetary travel and the meeting of time and space.

There was not one scene featuring Peter Mandelson speaking to prospective candidates in the key marginals on New Labour's priorities for a second term. Though I do remember a load of scary looking sub-humans smashing each other over the head, so at least the present Conservative party got a look in. 2001 will be a crucial year partly because the country will have to decide between Labour and Tory, but mainly because in the months beforehand the real choice between radical and conservative will have to be made by those drawing up Labour's manifesto. The discussion is already under way as to how bold Labour dares to be.

"Comrades, Labour is at a crossroads in its history; what are we to do?"

"Erm, change it into a mini-roundabout?"

First, the manifesto will need a sprinkling of populism. One trick might be a promise to legalise the things that everyone does all the time anyway. Under the next Labour government it will be legal to feed your toddler grapes in the supermarket before they have been weighed and paid for. It will be legal to go the wrong way up a one-way street as long as you do it in reverse. Throwing an empty tin can on to the ground will still be a littering offence, but if the can is placed carefully on top of a post, then that's all right.

Of course some new offences will have to be created. Fox-hunting looks set to be one of them; there may be many crueller things that happen to animals in Britain, but they are not done by such outrageously posh people, so hunting has to go.

The populist persecution of the upper classes should then be taken to the next stage with punitive taxes on Pringle jumpers and the wearing of cravats to the pub on Sunday. The City of London should be incorporated into the borough of Tower Hamlets and there should be an extra tax for people with too many names. And if the trend towards building high-security private housing estates is to continue, then the maintenance of the electric gates should be handed over to Railtrack. That should keep a few cars off the road for a while.

One of the lessons of Labour's first term was that the rich or rightwing were never going to vote Labour and that there was never any point in trying to keep them on board. Nothing would have stopped the WI's slow hand-clap, short of Tony Blair walking up to the lectern and singing: "If you're happy and you know it, clap your hands."

The real danger comes from Labour's natural supporters being too uninspired to vote this time round. A radical manifesto is not only necessary but politically expedient. For example, a Newsnight poll last week revealed that there would be overwhelming support for the renationalisation of the railways. For Labour to fight the next election on this policy would not only be the best thing for our transport system, it would also reinforce the public perception that the chaos on the railways was the fault of the Tories.

Labour could also commit to taking British Telecom back under state control with the massively popular promise that every home would get free unlimited access to the internet. Imagine if every telephone account was permitted just one phone number that you could call free at any time; this would totally transform access to the world wide web and stave off bankruptcy for families with teenage daughters. There are few votes to be had in keeping taxation of high earners lower than it was under Thatcher's first two terms, but plenty to be had from using all that extra money to help people at the bottom of the pile.

Electorally speaking, it is vital that the government looks fresh in 2001 and this will take more than the PM buying an anti-perspirant before his next conference speech. The chance for Labour to really get to grips with the great inequalities in our society only comes along once every generation and the time is now.

As Clinton ends his second term as president, the most memorable thing about his eight years in office turns out to be a sordid affair with a young intern. If Labour's manifesto for its second term is no more radical than its last, then I'm writing a letter to Washington. "Dear Monica, a vacancy will shortly be coming up in Downing Street..."

webTitle: BT begins to let its rivals in

fields.headline: BT begins to let its rivals in
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Greater access to high-speed internet connections moved a step closer yesterday after the regulator concluded that most of the terms under which British Telecom holds a monopoly over the local network will soon be ended.
fields.body:
Greater access to high-speed internet connections moved a step closer yesterday after the regulator concluded that most of the terms under which British Telecom holds a monopoly over the local network will soon be ended.

Oftel, the telecoms regulator, said BT had taken the first tentative steps to open up local exchanges, handing over access to two trial exchanges and making another two available early in the new year. By July 2001, the former state-owned telecoms company will have to make 600 local exchanges available to its rivals.

Telecoms companies, such as Energis and Cable & Wireless, have complained that delays by BT in the "unbundling of the local loop" was hindering their competitive plans to introduce access to faster, more modern telephone lines.

Shares in BT, which is under pressure from shareholders to hive off its businesses, fell to their lowest levels in almost three years yesterday before recovering to end at 572p, up 2p.

By opening access to exchanges controlled by BT, it is hoped that new high-bandwidth services will be introduced. To provide access to the "local loop" BT will be paid rental fees and connection charges by rivals who will then be free to set their own charges to consumers.

This has taken months of wrangling between BT, its rivals and the regulator and the terms under which customers will be able to receive separate lines for voice calls and the high-speed lines, known as ADSL, are to be finalised next year.

BT said the terms announced yesterday were broadly in line with those suggested by the regulator last month. BT is to receive £122 a year from each of its rivals when they sign up customers, on top of a £88 one-off connection charge. In November, Oftel suggested £118 and £95 respectively.

Companies will pay charges for installing equipment in local exchanges to connect BT's cables to their own. This will be set at £21 a year for every 100 lines plus an on-off charge of £863, some £500 lower than the amount suggested by Oftel last month.

The regulator, David Edmonds, director general of telecommunications, said the charges and terms announced yesterday would provide BT's rivals as well as consumers with a wider choice.

"Progress is accelerating in unbundling BT's local loop," said Mr Edmonds, who has been on the receiving end of much of the criticism associated with the intricate business of opening up access to local exchanges.

Separately, BT announced yesterday that it would take full control of German mobile phone operator Viag Interkom by buying the stake owned by Telenor of Norway.

BT said the cost of the stake at £1bn had been included in its plans last month to reduce its £30bn of debt.

fields.headline: ... and now you can't even trust the wine
fields.trailText: Police said yesterday they had arrested 10 people from the prestigious Burgundy wine-producing capital of Beaune in what experts fear may turn into one of France's biggest and most costly wine scandals of recent years.
fields.body:
Police said yesterday they had arrested 10 people from the prestigious Burgundy wine-producing capital of Beaune in what experts fear may turn into one of France's biggest and most costly wine scandals of recent years.

Tens, possibly hundreds of thousands of bottles of some of the country's top wines could be affected by the scam, which police said involved grands crus being "cut" with low-grade plonk and inferior wines being labelled as high-quality.

A Dijon fraud squad spokesman said most of the major wines of Burgundy's sought-after Côte d'Or region were concerned, including Beaune premier cru, Pommard premier cru, Volnay, Gevrey-Chambertin, Meursault premier cru and Nuits-Saint-Georges.

"It is a very serious matter indeed," the spokesman said. "Some very classy wines that can change hands even when young for over £100 a bottle have been cut with up to 30% of rubbish from the Midi or Languedoc, and generic Burgundy table wine has been sold as premier cru."

The men arrested, who include several leading Burgundy wholesalers and wine merchants as well as the managing director of the region's main bottling company, have been placed under formal examination for fraud and forgery. Police say they suspect more may be involved and other arrests may follow.

One Beaune-based company, Goichot, is suspected of adding quantities of vin ordinaire to stocks of undrinkable waste wine that were meant to be turned into vinegar, and passing the result off as a middle of the range Burgundy.

The scale of the swindle has staggered experts and local officials and could prove highly damaging to the region's growers, who last year produced 161m bottles of Burgundy worth some £600m.

"I'm afraid these are very far from being glad tidings of seasonal good cheer," said Hubert Camus, the vice-president of the Burgundy wine board. "Our fathers and grandfathers have laboured since the 1930s to bring Burgundy wines the renown they enjoy today. This destroys their efforts."

The affair may only concern four Beaune merchants who are "more unscrupulous businessmen out to make money than genuine wine lovers", Mr Camus said, "but they are sizable players and Burgundy in its entirety risks being affected by their actions".

Traditionally, two-thirds of Burgundy's production is exported to countries such as Britain. Producers, already worried by several years of what they see as unhealthy inflation in Burgundy prices compared with those fetched by rival Bordeaux wines, fear the scam may trigger a collapse in foreign sales.

Louis-Marc Chevignard, a leading French wine taster, said: "At first we thought this was an isolated case, but it appears to go much further. International wine reputations are very fragile things. When certain professionals are without conscience, it is all Burgundy that suffers."

Fraud is by no means new in the French wine business. Two years ago it emerged that 177,000 bottles of 1995 Château Giscours, a Margaux noted for years as one of Bordeaux's top Médoc wines, had been doctored with sugar, water, acids and even milk as part of an attempt to ruin its new owner, a Dutchman.

But as Bordeaux wines are sold by the châteaux that make them, the subsequent slump in sales affected only Château Giscours. Burgundy wines are traditionally produced by individual growers but sold by wine merchants based mainly in Beaune - meaning the slightest whiff of wine tampering can harm the whole region.

webTitle: Oxford rower feared dead on Spanish river

fields.headline: Oxford rower feared dead on Spanish river
fields.trailText: Rowing club officials at Oxford University face questioning after an oarsman was feared drowned yesterday on a turbulent river in Spain where warnings of strong winds had been issued by the regional government.
fields.body:
Rowing club officials at Oxford University face questioning after an oarsman was feared drowned yesterday on a turbulent river in Spain where warnings of strong winds had been issued by the regional government.

A member of Oxford's lightweight rowing club was swept away after two boats capsized near the south-eastern city of Tarragona on the river Ebro, which is currently swollen by heavy rain and melted snow.

He was named last night as Leo Blockley, 21, a maths postgraduate, one of two crews of oarsmen and women who were racing across the river at Amposta, Oxford's winter training base. Seventeen other people were rescued and nine people - seven men and two women - were treated for hypothermia after they had been thrown from the two coxed eights when waves were whipped up by gusts of wind.

The lightweight team - distinct from the main university eight which rows the annual Boat Race against Cambridge - had gone ahead with its scheduled training when the Ebro appeared calm, in spite of a series of official warnings of 100kph (60mph) winds.

Catalonia's regional emergency services said last night that the possibility of dangerous gusts had not been left in any doubt by a series of warnings after Christmas.

The lightweight club team, which was training for a series of races against Cambridge crews in March, was involved in controversy in Amposta last year, when 24 oarsmen were arrested for allegedly damaging a pizza restaurant during post-training celebrations. They were held briefly in the local jail but a judge ordered the dropping of all charges.

Yesterday's training, for which the rowers do not wear lifejackets, required the three delicate "shell" boats to cross 300 metres of the Ebro after two earlier sessions had gone smoothly. Axel Muller, a coach of Spain's national rowing team who is working with the club, said: "We had had two normal training sessions and when we went out, there was just a light breeze." Violent gusts then struck the area when the crews were in mid-river, causing chaos and conflicting accounts of precisely what happened next. The Foreign Office said that one boat had capsized at 10.40am, and waves from the accident appeared to have swamped the second craft nearby.

Steve Royle, director of rowing at Oxford, said Mr Blockley was one of two crew members who had tried to swim for the Ebro bank while the others stayed with the waterlogged boat. He said: "The tragedy is that Leo swam to the bank and got into difficulties. These guys are pretty shell-shocked. It's a close community, they go through a lot together."
