webTitle: French bons vivants take a battering as superchef takes meat off the menu ...

fields.headline: French bons vivants take a battering as superchef takes meat off the menu ...
fields.trailText: Battered by revelations about mad cows, chickens tainted with dioxins, calves fed on sewage and sausages infected with listeria, France's gourmet pride suffered another blow yesterday when a three-star chef said he was banning all meat except poultry from his menus.
fields.body:
Battered by revelations about mad cows, chickens tainted with dioxins, calves fed on sewage and sausages infected with listeria, France's gourmet pride suffered another blow yesterday when a three-star chef said he was banning all meat except poultry from his menus.

Alain Passard, whose £100 a head Arpège restaurant in Paris's seventh arrondissement was awarded the Michelin guide's ultimate accolade in 1996, said he was concerned by "the turn our food is taking" and would devote his menu to vegetables, with the odd bit of poultry, from next spring.

Mr Passard's announcement - an almost unimaginable leap in a country where vegetarians are considered either not quite normal, or German, or both - coincided with yet another EU report criticising French methods, this time in pork production.

Slaughterhouses, farms and laboratories visited by a team of EU vets earlier this summer suffered from severe hygiene problems, a worrying lack of veterinary controls and major lapses in animal welfare, the report said, echoing a similar EU study of French meat products such as sausages, pate and mince, released just before Christmas.

"Personally, it is many years since I have eaten meat," admitted Mr Passard, 44. "And it has been some time since I have been able to find any culinary inspiration in animal products. I want to become the first three-star chef to use only vegetables, a driving force in the field of vegetable and flower cuisine."

One of France's least flashy and most admired chefs, Mr Passard began his kitchen career as a 14-year-old apprentice and won two Michelin stars at the Casino restaurant in Enghien, Belgium, at 26. He then repeated the feat at Le Carlton in Brussels, and again at l'Arpège a mere two years after opening in 1987.

Admiring chefs say he can tell whether something is properly salted simply by sniffing it.

Culinary demi-god

He withdrew beef from his menus earlier this year and has been followed by several other leading culinary lights. "Even if the risk is only one in a million, we do not have the right to make our customers run it," said Guy Martin of Grand Véfour, a three-star restaurant in Palais Royal, central Paris.

But no other culinary demi-god has so far dared to remove meat from the menu altogether. While he admitted there were "some excellent producers of beef and lamb", Mr Passard said his decision was motivated as much by personal choice as by safety concerns.

"I can no longer stand the idea that we humans have turned herbivore ruminants into carnivores," he said. "But also, I can't get excited about a lump of barbecue meat. Vegetables are so much more colourful, more perfumed. You can play with the harmony of colours, everything is luminous."

He said he would keep poultry on the menu because he was "too much of a cook to do away with poultry", but would be very selective with seafood, offering it on a day-by-day basis according to the quality available.

"I won't put fish or shellfish on my menu in the future," he said. "I don't want to be constrained by what's on my menu to have to offer lobster from Rungis [the central French food wholesale market outside Paris]. If you had seen some of the stuff on sale there, you'd understand."

Those diners who can afford l'Arpège's prices and happen to have read yesterday's EU report will doubtless be relieved by the imminent absence of pork. At one abattoir inspectors found that hygiene conditions were atrocious and saw "animals that were obviously not fit for transport or human consumption".

"The animals were stabbed on a conveyor belt and blood was collected in an open system with high risk of contamination from unclean skin," the report said. "Not all workers had easy access to washing facilities. Hand-held hoses were frequently used for rinsing hands and tools, leading to a high risk of contaminating carcasses."

The year of eating dangerously

January: Oysters and other shellfish withdrawn after oil spill off Brittany coast; 23 cases of listeria including seven deaths from contaminated jellied tongue.

April: Eighteen cases of mad cow disease in first three months of year compared with 30 in all 1999.

July: 16,000 tonnes of doctored butter discovered.

October: Cow intestines, traditionally used to make sausages and other charcuterie, banned over BSE fears.

October: BSE-infected meat reaches three major hypermarket chains, sparking 40pct fall in consumption.

November: Meat-and-bone meal banned in all animal feeds; beef ribs outlawed unless cut differently; 1,800 kg of rotting duck meat products found just before hitting shops.

December: Two tonnes of out-of-date beef seized by Normandy farmers.

webTitle: Sleet and bitter frost to greet the new year

fields.headline: Sleet and bitter frost to greet the new year
fields.standfirst:
As Britain struggles to return to normal after heavy snow and freezing conditions, forecasters warn of strong winds and rain to come

Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: As Britain struggles to return to normal after heavy snow and freezing conditions, forecasters warn of strong winds and rain to come.
fields.byline: Tania Branigan, Gerard Seenan, Geoffrey Gibbs  and Helen Carter
fields.body:
Britain will greet the new year with further sleet and bitter frost, a met office forecaster warned yesterday as the country struggled to return to normal after heavy snows.

He predicted the freeze would continue well into the weekend with few areas seeing temperatures above zero, and further snow showers in coastal areas.

"Sunday will see a slight change as it clouds over and gets very windy with rain coming in to the far south-west and turning to sleet," he added. "Following that it may turn a little less cold."

The news brought little cheer to Britons yesterday as fresh snow blanketed north-east and south-west England, East Anglia, northern Scotland and Northern Ireland. Other regions faced freezing fog, sleet and black ice on the roads.

Temperatures plunged as low as -13C (9F) on Thursday night in areas including Birmingham, Hereford and Glasgow, and were predicted to fall to -5C (23F) in the south, and -10C (14F) in the north-west last night. At Whitehaven, Cumbria, the harbour remained frozen.

Extensive gritting and speed restrictions cut the number of road accidents yesterday from the heights seen on Thursday, but police urged drivers not to venture out unless necessary and the AA called in 700 extra patrols to deal with its busiest day all year. A spokesman said it had received up to 3,500 calls an hour and would have dealt with 20,000 breakdowns by nightfall.

In Scotland, the worst hit area, a spokesman for Lothian and Borders police said all roads had been affected by snow and ice. In Fife and in Dumfries and Galloway, main roads were "passable with care" and parts of the A93 and A90 were closed in Aberdeenshire.

ScotRail said services were subject to disruption and advised passengers not to travel. "Many of our trains have become affected by very severe frost. As a result only a very limited service is operating," a spokesman said.

Virgin reported delays and cancellations on the west coast mainline, while GNER reported problems on the east coast.

In the north-east, between two and four inches of snow fell in parts of Northumberland, Co Durham, Tyneside and Cleveland overnight. A three vehicle accident on the A1 near the Angel of the North statue, Gateshead, delayed traffic. Main roads were down to a single lane while many untreated side roads were said to be impassable.

In the midlands, the M40 was closed near Oxford and the M5 was partly blocked, while in Wales the M4 was again down to two lanes and some minor roads remained impassable. Dense fog caused severe delays on the M6 in Cheshire.

Cornwall had further snow falls and in the west country, Devon and Cornwall police urged snow seekers to steer clear of the moors after motorists caused chaos by abandoning cars on ungritted roads.

At Peters Marland, near Great Torrington, Devon, a farmer out shooting with his father shot himself in the foot after slipping on ice. He was wounded in his left foot and ankle and was taken by air ambulance to hospital in Exeter.

In Northern Ireland freezing weather brought fresh havoc and thick fog compounded the hazardous conditions. Disruption to transport was widespread as buses, trains and airlines struggled to cope. The Irish republic was just as badly hit, with many bus services cancelled or delayed.

Air travel began to return to normal, but passengers at Luton airport faced delays of up to two hours as staff struggled to catch up following a 14-hour shutdown on Thursday in which 63 flights were cancelled due to snow. Departures were also running late at Belfast International and Belfast City airports. Most other airports were back to normal, although a spokesman for Liverpool warned that fog could cause problems.

Railtrack said it still hoped to finish its week-long programme of track and signalling work in time for the new year return to work next week.

Sports events took a knock as all four race meetings in Britain were cancelled and football matches were scrapped. Postal services were affected as around 70 workers at Liverpool's West Derby sorting office walked out claiming the weather was too bad to deliver mail.

At Peters Marland, near Great Torrington, Devon, a farmer out shooting with his father shot himself in the foot after slipping on ice. He was wounded in his left foot and ankle and was taken by air ambulance to hospital in Exeter. In Northern Ireland freezing weather brought fresh havoc and thick fog compounded the hazardous conditions. Disruption to transport was widespread as buses, trains and airlines struggled to cope. The Irish republic was just as badly hit, with many bus services cancelled or delayed. Air travel began to return to normal, but passengers at Luton airport faced delays of up to two hours as staff struggled to catch up following a 14-hour shutdown on Thursday in which 63 flights were cancelled due to snow. Departures were also running late at Belfast International and Belfast City airports. Most other airports were back to normal, although a spokesman for Liverpool warned that fog could cause problems. Railtrack said it still hoped to finish its week-long programme of track and signalling work in time for the new year return to work next week. Sports events took a knock as all four race meetings in Britain were cancelled and football matches were scrapped. Postal services were affected as around 70 workers at Liverpool's West Derby sorting office walked out claiming the weather was too bad to deliver mail.

fields.headline: Crackdown on fat cat professions
fields.standfirst: Ministers plan challenge after OFT accuses lawyers, accountants and architects of restrictive practices
fields.trailText: Ministers plan challenge after OFT accuses lawyers, accountants and architects of restrictive practices.
fields.body:
Ministers are to mount a pre-election challenge to fat cat lawyers, accountants and architects, after the office of fair trading found evidence of restrictive practices.

The OFT is due to submit to ministers next month the results of a nine-month inquiry on restrictive practices and hidden cartels in these professions. It was handed the task by the chancellor, Gordon Brown, in the spring budget. Mr Brown is an advocate of extending competition in the interests of the consumer.

Industry sources said the OFT inquiry, to be submitted to trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers, found evidence of fee-setting by architects and lawyers. It is expected to find against some of the training and qualification rules set out by leading professional bodies.

The OFT has been studying a fee guide for clients published annually by the Royal Institute of British Architects. It suggests that specialist partners be paid a standard rate of £180 an hour, decreasing to £55 an hour for an architect undertaking general work.

The OFT is expected to recommend that single professional services companies, including auditors and lawyers, should operate under one roof. Restrictions on mixed practice firms currently apply across the professions.

An earlier OFT inquiry into law firms in Scotland found the ban on mixed partnerships to be a restrictive practice. Lifting it should allow lawyers and accountants to set up larger chains, with resultant economies of scale.

The Law Society is to produce a consultation paper on the proposal in an attempt to pre-empt OFT recommendations. Traditionally solicitors have argued that they would face conflicts of interest in advice to clients if they worked alongside other professions.

The OFT is also expected to argue that the length of training required for some professions is not based on preserving the quality and integrity of the professions but on restricting labour supply and so raising market prices.

Similarly, the OFT inquiry is expected to challenge the way so many barristers are restricted from working despite qualifications. Only two thirds of bar vocational course graduates obtain pupillage in chambers; the remainder often face debts of up to £20,000, with bleak prospects of a career at the bar.

The OFT has also looked at whether the QC system should be continued. More than 100 backbench Labour MPs have called for the post of QC to be abolished on the grounds that it is a licence to charge amounts to a quota system.

But there has been stiff resistance from the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, who regards the system as a kitemark of quality, and the Bar Council, representing barristers, which denies that QCs automatically charge higher fees.

The Bar Council maintains that it now restricts the number of times a client is required to hire two or more barristers.

The OFT has investigated whether an informal price fixing network operates between barristers through their clerks. The Bar Council has responded that even though some clerks earn well in excess of £100,000, their fees are falling as chambers bring in directors on fixed salaries rather than on a percentage of a barristers' earnings.

The OFT study has not found evidence of price collusion between the big city accountancy firms. Their huge fees for auditing company accounts appear to be obtainable despite genuine competition.

The OFT is also expected to call for greater use of advertising by auditors and accountants.

webTitle: Leader: Jubilee 2000 needs to be built on

fields.headline: In the shadow of debt
fields.standfirst:
Now Jubilee 2000 needs to be built on

Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Now Jubilee 2000 needs to be built on.
fields.body:
In the run-up to Christmas, World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) officials worked round the clock to speed debt relief to the nations which were promised it in Prague. Why the rush? Because a tiny London-based campaign of just 15 staff has managed in four years to turn debt relief into a cause célèbre. Millions of postcards, petitions and letter-writing campaigns have forced it on to the international political agenda. World Bank and IMF officials, long used to deals behind closed doors, find themselves in the glare of the media spotlight.

The Jubilee 2000 campaign, which officially ends this week, has been an extraordinary achievement. Its budget of only £3m is dwarfed by most of the major aid agencies, but its impact over the past couple of years has been huge. It has turned a complex subject into a mainstream campaign issue and in the process has educated thousands of activists in churches, trade unions and community organisations on the complexities of the global financial system. It has exploited the internet to pioneer a model of global activism.

The aim was a twin-pronged approach: applying pressure on decision-makers in northern countries and at the same time providing Jubilee movements in developing countries with accurate, up-to-date information on the commitments their own governments are making to borrow money and pay back debt. The key aim has been to demand accountability from both debtors and creditors. The result has been the first bold experiment in creating a global political culture.

But ultimately, for all its achievements, the campaign has fallen well short of its goal of relieving the burden of unsustainable debt on the poorest countries. Of the 41 countries deemed eligible, only 22 will receive some relief and 16 of these will still be spending more each year on debt than on health. After all the conditions and hurdles imposed on debtor countries by the World Bank and IMF, debt relief still amounts to only a 29% reduction in debt service payments, leaving highly indebted poor countries paying $2bn a year to foreign creditors.

The plight of such countries is graphically illustrated by Zambia, which is struggling to deal with a devastating Aids epidemic. One in five of the population are HIV positive. A country which should be spending at least $25 a head per year on health care is actually spending less than $3. Part of the reason for this is that even after debt relief, it will still be paying $168m a year to its creditors out of a total budget of around $800m. This is a country where progress has meant nothing; economic decline in the past three decades has actually seen living standards drop by 30%.

Such evidence arouses profound unease amongst a broad section of people that the process of globalisation is being managed by powerful economic interests with scant regard for human development. The conclusion of Jubilee 2000's director, Ann Pettifor, is that significant debt relief simply cannot be achieved under the current system because it is so heavily stacked against debtors.

There are attempts at reform; last September the UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, made a sensible proposal for an independent panel of experts to mediate between creditors and debtors. Jubilee 2000's great achievement was to inspire the outrage of millions by exposing the powerlessness of developing countries within the global economic system. Now, an even harder task lies ahead: to reform the structures of trade and finance which trap poor countries in a vicious cycle of poverty and underdevelopment.

fields.headline: Love-hate relationship with Woodhead
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead yesterday proved that he still has legions of both enemies and admirers in the education world.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead yesterday proved that he still has legions of both enemies and admirers in the education world.

The title of Villain of the Year was bestowed on the former chief inspector of schools by listeners of BBC Radio 4's Today programme, but the same listeners also made him runner-up in the voting for Hero of the Year.

However, there was no doubt about Steve Redgrave's hero status. The Olympic rower came top in the Hero of the Year voting, adding to his long list of achievements on the same day as his knighthood was announced in the New Year Honours list.

The five-times Olympic gold medallist follows such global figures as Margaret Thatcher, Mikhael Gorbachev and Pope John Paul II.

Runner-up as Villain of the Year went to Brian Souter, chairman of coach and train operators Stagecoach, who caused controversy with his campaign in Scotland to retain the Section 28 legislation barring the promotion of homosexuality.

This year's poll of Today listeners is an attempt to revive its personality of the year award, which was axed in 1997 after Labour and Conservative supporters tried to fix the results. The programme's editor, Rod Liddle, decreed that no politicians would be eligible, in an attempt to stop such cheating. He said yesterday: "Congratulations to both our hero and villain - they have certainly struck a chord with the listeners. Chris Woodhead, in particular, has scored well in both lists."

More than 40,000 listeners cast votes by phone, email and fax.

Mr Liddle also said that it had been decided that politicians would be allowed back in next year's voting - there were accusations of dumbing down when Today announced a shortlist for this year featuring such figures as West Ham United striker Paolo di Canio and Big Brother contestant "Nasty" Nick Bateman.

webTitle: Israel: Clinton works phones to salvage peace

fields.headline: Clinton works phones to salvage peace
fields.standfirst:
President in weekend diplomatic battle to sell US plans to Palestinians as tension rises in Gaza and West Bank

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: President in weekend diplomatic battle to sell US plans to Palestinians as tension rises in Gaza and West Bank.
fields.body:
President Bill Clinton will spend the weekend telephoning Arab leaders in an attempt to salvage the Middle East peace process before a decisive meeting planned for Cairo next week.

Arab foreign ministers are to meet in the Egyptian capital at the request of the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, to discuss the US president's plans for a settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

A Lebanese government source said the Arab League summit, originally scheduled for Monday, would be put back to Thursday to allow more time for consideration.

Washington hopes that wider Arab support for the proposals will persuade Mr Arafat to give a positive response. But events on the ground yesterday conspired against a settlement. An Israeli shell killed a Palestinian policeman on the Israel-Gaza border in the biggest gun battle for more than a week.

The exchange began after the Israelis bulldozed trees near a Palestinian military position, claiming that the foliage could provide cover for gunmen. An Israeli defence spokesman said a tank shell was fired after the Israeli troops came under heavy gunfire.

An Israeli commander earlier spoke despairingly of the "Lebanisation" of the border with Gaza.

At the end of a week in which progress on the peace front suddenly seemed possible, only to be snatched away, 15 Palestinians were wounded in incidents on the West Bank.

Tension has been heightened in both the West Bank and the Gaza Strip by Israel's decision to seal off both borders after two bomb blasts by Palestinian militants on Thursday.

About 10,000 supporters of the militant Palestinian group Hamas, which is thought to be responsible for one of the bomb attacks, held a rally in the West Bank city of Nablus yesterday and cheered as organisers burned a replica of the Israeli bus bombed in Tel Aviv on Thursday.

The Hizbullah guerrilla leader, Sheikh Hassan Nasrallah, urged them in an address by telephone from Lebanon to continue their uprising until Israel was destroyed.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, was presented yesterday with evidence of increasing Israeli disillusionment with his handling of the peace process.

Opinion polls in two Israeli papers, Yedioth Ahronoth and Ma'ariv, showed majorities opposed to the US proposals. In the poll in Yedioth Ahronoth, 51% opposed reaching an accord and only 44% were in favour. The polls are the first test of opinion since the shape of the proposed peace agreement became public.

Mr Barak also received his lowest popularity rating since he came to power last year. One of the polls suggested that support for him had dropped to 30%, and put the opposition candidate for prime minister, Ariel Sharon, on 53%.

The polls suggest that even if Mr Barak does secure a peace deal with the Palestinians, he will still lose the prime ministerial election on February 6 to Mr Sharon, the Likud leader. Mr Sharon, the hardliner responsible for the Israeli invasion of Lebanon in 1982, and for the recent flare-up of Palestinian violence, has said he will not abide by any settlement negotiated by Mr Barak.

The Palestinians continued to refuse to either back or reject Mr Clinton's plans yesterday. Israelis, from the cabinet down to the streets, are divided on whether Mr Arafat is playing a tactical delaying game to squeeze more concessions in the dying days of Mr Clinton's presidency or the peace process is effectively over for the time being.

Nabil Shaath, the Palestinian foreign minister, said yesterday that Mr Arafat was still prepared to meet Mr Barak, but that wide differences remained on the key issues: the fate of Palestinian refugees, the division of Jerusalem, including the disputed holy sites, and the territorial boundaries of a future Palestinian state.

He said Mr Clinton's proposals needed "to be clarified and developed in order to really go forward with them as the basis for future negotiations and we are in the process of trying very positively to do that". The Palestinians asked the US to provide a detailed map showing the proposed territorial changes.

Mr Arafat identified the refugees as one of the main stumbling blocks during a telephone conversation with a member of the Israeli parliament, Sallah Tarif, who had phoned him at Mr Barak's request.

Mr Arafat complained to him that Mr Barak was stubborn. "Even when Ben Gurion established the state of Israel, he allowed more Palestinian refugees to return than Barak is now," he said.

In a package that would form the basis for peace talks, the Israeli government has tentatively agreed to force at least 20% of the Jewish settlers on the West Bank and Gaza to leave. But yesterday the government extended until 2001 the rights of such settlers to a formidable array of incentives, including housing grants, a 7% income tax break, subsidised mortgages and free schooling.

Professor Galia Golan, speaking on behalf of the campaign group Peace Now, said this could lead to more bloodshed and make a peace agreement even more difficult.

"Because we believe Barak is intent on achieving peace, we find it difficult to understand how a decision like this could have been made at this critical juncture," he said.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Warning as genuine cheer circulates at Christmas blight
fields.trailText: Bad news - I fear that the relentless campaign against circular Christmas letters is beginning to work, and the perpetrators are raising their game.
fields.body:
Bad news - I fear that the relentless campaign against circular Christmas letters is beginning to work, and the perpetrators are raising their game.

Some now include genuinely interesting information (we had two from friends who had moved abroad this year and who sent fascinating letters); others now employ humour instead of the usual selection of boasting or moaning.

For example, we had a circular from friends whom we've not seen for years. It seemed to be devoted to dreary DIY projects, but just as I was about to tear the thing to shreds with a welkin-shattering scream it turned out to be a subtle shaggy dog story, which cheered me up a lot but which was no use for this column.

Murdo Culver of Twickenham has produced an excellent postcard which can save the recipient much time and anguish. There's a small map of the world ("a cross indicates locations visited"), a section on children (tick marital state, salary and progeny), two body outlines, "indicate areas of affliction suffered this year", plust wo inches for a personal message.

Some readers, bridling, have sent in their own letters, asking in effect if these aren't exceptions. My message to them is, don't push your luck.

The new irony is affecting many once magnificently unselfconscious letters. "We know people hate reading about how perfect one's children are ... Seth is a typical teenager, monosyllabic vocabulary, smokes, hates school etc. We came home to find him surrounded by an armed police response unit."

Brits in the States seem to have an especially hard time with their kids: "Midge has run up $6,000 on my credit card, which seems neither just nor fair."

People often seem obliged to put in little jokes these days - not necessarily very funny but acting as a sort of apology: look, at least we're trying not to bore you. "Oh, flux! Things keep changing!"

Or, from Northumberland, "another sudden blackout allowed me to reacquaint myself with the splendid parquet flooring in our new conservatory", which combines misery and vanity in a pleasantly humorous way.

New trends include yet more dramatic showing off. Too many rich people seem unaware of how annoying their casual references are. "It has been an eventful year seeing my parents going for a short holiday to Palm Beach, Florida ... and buying a condo on the polo grounds. In August we spent a glorious time in Italy and Sicily, hiring a rather fast Alfa Romeo and zooming round exploring remote parts.

"Jacqui manages to train as a surgeon while fitting in diving trips to Thailand, Caymans, Cuba and the Red Sea. Tor is mad about polo, and in summer was playing at least four matches a week. At number 3 in the world, she is not doing badly!"

Another disturbing new practice is listing the films you've been to. ("We went to see American Beauty on the 16th"; "films enjoyed this year include Chicken Run and Toy Story 2" - yeah, you and half the population.)

Also cars. Please, unless it's a 1911 Rolls Royce we have no interest in your car, and very little even then. "Jonty sold the 214 Rover to Nanette, who is the cook at the village school, with a comprehensive three month guarantee"; "Tom now has a VW Polo GT 1991, dark grey in colour, with new alloy wheels and a large bore stainless steel exhaust".

For some people no detail is too tiny to go unmentioned. "Last December, I was late with this letter ... I forgot to take my licking machine to London, so had to lick 80 stamps and envelopes myself, and the glue tasted so awful I had to keep making myself cups of hot Ribena." The same author spends a quarter-page of an eight-page newsletter describing the difficulties of buying an air ticket from Birmingham to Brussels last May.

I'm always delighted by the utter rage some of these letters evoke. "The upstairs shower and suite were completed just prior to Christmas 1999 (as promised in the last letter). We now have plans to tile the dining room fireplace by February 01." The reader who sent this in adds: "I am tempted to write to them in March, 'I shall be visiting next week to inspect the new tiling which you have promised to install.'"

Others scrawl in the margin, "Too much information"; "I don't want to know this"; and sometimes "No, no, no!"

Some interweave events in their lives with the wider world. From Rotherham: "many moles were caught in the next field, and the Air France Concorde crashed".

Religious people tend to see the letters as a chance to spread The Word. A tragic news event may be followed by, "'In the kingdom of Light, God will wipe every tear away. He will make all things new.' We need that promise when we look around us."

Others are involved with strange sects and anxious to let us know about them. An otherwise normal sounding woman from Cambridge writes: "I put out the intent, through the Huna Prayer way of praying, that my Reiki Teaching and Healing practice would grow. It has!! The Angel of Flexibility was the quality I needed." It is probably a mistake to let this kind of thing wind up in the hands of sane people.

Illness dominates so many letters. "Prolapsed lumbar disc, osteoporosis, crumbling vertebrae, bronchitis, colonoscopy, endoscopy (under anaethesia), low blood count, low iron levels" - all from a chap living in Australia, who pulls what's left of himself together to add, "nationally the outstanding events of the year have included the introduction of a 10% goods and services tax, equivalent to VAT." It's awful, but when sympathy is put under too much strain by someone you hardly know, it can easily become hilarity. A passing reference to "poor health" is probably enough.

Other letters contain horrid little shocks, like razor blades in the Christmas pudding. One letter is mainly about embroidery, theology classes and other middle class pursuits, but goes on: "Roger is in Wymot, but I haven't visited him lately because I hate the visiting conditions." My informant tells me that Wymot is a prison, and Roger is in for murder.

And music. What is it about this blameless activity which obliges its practioners to brag to everyone they know or once have met? Children who are at grade XI in seven instruments, or who sing in choirs which tour Russia?

From Cheltenham: "I kept my hand in on the harpsichord by venturing to Malvern now and again. An ad hoc group of curtal players meets in Bristol, crumhorns have been heard in a village near Bath ... and that's without mentioned Stroud choir!"

fields.bodyText: Bad news - I fear that the relentless campaign against circular Christmas letters is beginning to work, and the perpetrators are raising their game. Some now include genuinely interesting information (we had two from friends who had moved abroad this year and who sent fascinating letters); others now employ humour instead of the usual selection of boasting or moaning. For example, we had a circular from friends whom we've not seen for years. Murdo Culver of Twickenham has produced an excellent postcard which can save the recipient much time and anguish. There's a small map of the world ("a cross indicates locations visited"), a section on children (tick marital state, salary and progeny), two body outlines, "indicate areas of affliction suffered this year", plust wo inches for a personal message. Some readers, bridling, have sent in their own letters, asking in effect if these aren't exceptions. My message to them is, don't push your luck. The new irony is affecting many once magnificently unselfconscious letters. "We know people hate reading about how perfect one's children are ... Brits in the States seem to have an especially hard time with their kids: "Midge has run up $6,000 on my credit card, which seems neither just nor fair." Please, unless it's a 1911 Rolls Royce we have no interest in your car, and very little even then. "Jonty sold the 214 Rover to Nanette, who is the cook at the village school, with a comprehensive three month guarantee"; "Tom now has a VW Polo GT 1991, dark grey in colour, with new alloy wheels and a large bore stainless steel exhaust". The same author spends a quarter-page of an eight-page newsletter describing the difficulties of buying an air ticket from Birmingham to Brussels last May. The reader who sent this in adds: "I am tempted to write to them in March, 'I shall be visiting next week to inspect the new tiling which you have promised to install.'" Others scrawl in the margin, "Too much information"; "I don't want to know this"; and sometimes "No, no, no!" Some interweave events in their lives with the wider world. webTitle: 'Cold' father ordered to pay school fees

fields.headline: 'Cold' father ordered to pay school fees
fields.trailText: A teenager yesterday won a legal battle to force her estranged father to pay for her to attend a school that allowed her to be with her mother.
fields.body:
A teenager yesterday won a legal battle to force her estranged father to pay for her to attend a school that allowed her to be with her mother.

Nicole Lavelle, 16, took Callum Lavelle, 46, to court under the Family Law (Scotland) Act after he refused to pay her £6,600 annual fees. He had been happy to pay £12,000 a year for her to attend an exclusive school of his choosing, but not for her to go to a cheaper private school closer to her mother's home.

Sheriff Wyllie Robertson ruled Mr Lavelle must pay the fees and all incidental expenses for the next two years. He also branded him a "cold and unfeeling individual" who sought to control those around him.

Miss Lavelle was unavailable for comment yesterday but her mother's partner, Jim Whitehurst, said she was delighted by the ruling. "We're very relieved but also very annoyed Mr Lavelle forced Nicole and her mother through all this."

When the case was heard at Stirling sheriff court last month, Miss Lavelle, originally from Dunblane, told the court she could see no reason for her father to withdraw his support other than the feud between him and her mother.

Mr Lavelle, vice president of a US software company, and Miss Lavelle's mother, Belinda, 43, separated in 1996. Miss Lavelle stayed with her father, but sought to keep an equal footing with both parents.

Initially she and her father lived in a rented flat in Dunblane but, after the pressures in his job increased, he decided to send her to boarding school.

For a time, she attended Harrogate Ladies' College in Yorkshire. But, as she watched the day girls return home each evening, she came to believe she was missing family life.

She decided to enrol in Cheltenham Ladies' College so she could spend weekends with her mother and sister, Stephanie, who lived in Peopleton, near Worcester, and longer breaks with her father.

The court heard, however, that Mr Lavelle gave his daughter an ultimatum: stay at Harrogate and keep her relationship with him alive, or move school, form improved relations with her mother, and never see him again.

Miss Lavelle chose to move in with her mother and attend King's School, Worcester.

She said her father refused to pay her fees, claiming he could not afford them since his bank had told him to curtail his spending and he was being pursued by the child support agency.

Mr Lavelle, who earns around £112,000 a year and was said to live a lavish lifestyle, is alleged to have told his daughter of how men were forced into suicide by the actions of the agency.

In his written judgment, Sheriff Robertson said: "He impressed as a cold and unfeeling individual who did not speak of his daughter with any affection whatsoever. It seems to me Mr Lavelle is driven by the need to be in control of those around him such as his daughter. He is in receipt of a substantial income and, taking into account his expenditure and the contribution from his wife, he is well able to afford to pay."

Mr Lavelle was unavailable for comment yesterday - neighbours said he was on holiday to escape the publicity. It is expected he will appeal.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Elderly sisters found dead | 'Gruesome' death of boy | Wanted father arrested
fields.body:
Elderly sisters found dead

Police who broke into a bungalow in Dormansland in Surrey found Yvonne Warman lying dead in the lounge, and her sister, Hilda Warman, huddled beside her suffering from shock and hypothermia. Detectives think the younger of the elderly spinsters had a heart attack on Christmas day, and accidentally knocked out her sister as she tumbled.

'Gruesome' death of boy

A two-year-old boy lay dead in his cot for two weeks over Christmas before being found by police, who described the discovery as "sad and gruesome". A couple living at the flat in Hastings in East Sussex are in custody.

Wanted father arrested

Police in Blackpool in Lancashire have arrested a man aged 48 after saying they wanted to interview the father of Tony Bangs, 12, found dead at a house in the resort. Two other boys have been taken into care.

Timber circle can return

Archeologists have finished analysing a Bronze Age timber circle removed from a beach in Norfolk a year ago, English Heritage has said. Villagers in Holme, who opposed uprooting the 50 or so timbers, have voted overwhelmingly for them to be reburied.

Checkout sums fail to add up

A survey for The Grocer magazine found at least one mistake in 23 out of 26 supermarket trips by undercover shoppers. It also found that overcharging, undercharging and missing out items completely had more than doubled in six months. Errors were worst for fruit and vegetables.

webTitle: Referendum in Bristol may test council tax views

fields.headline: Referendum in Bristol may test council tax views
fields.trailText: Bristolians are to have a direct say in setting their council tax under a radical scheme being drawn up by the city council.
fields.body:
Bristolians are to have a direct say in setting their council tax under a radical scheme being drawn up by the city council.

Faced with the choice of raising the council tax by 5% or cutting next year's education budget, councillors plan to ask the city's 300,000 voters to express their view in a referendum.

The vote, expected to be endorsed at a meeting of the Labour-run council on January 16, would be the first in a UK city and will be watched closely by government ministers and by local authorities elsewhere.

There is widespread concern across local government about apathy on the part of the voters who use council services, and such referendums are expected to spread as a way of getting people involved in making decisions.

Bristol can draw on its experience of conducting a smaller referendum on a separate local issue as it finalises the £120,000 council tax ballot.

In what has proved to be a useful dry run for the city vote, 30,000 residents of the Hengrove area of the city were asked if they would be happy to see a football and sports stadium built in their neighbourhood.

On a turnout of just over 10,000 they rejected the proposal by almost two to one.

To encourage as big a response as possible in next month's referendum, voters will be able to register their preference either by post, by phone or via the internet.

Council taxes in Bristol have been frozen for two years. The authority is keen to continue holding them down, but the government's financial settlement for next year means they would have to rise by 4% to 5% if spending on services were to be protected.

Bristol's spending on education is said to be among the highest in the country. Council members say that, if the council tax were to stay frozen, next year's budget would have to be cut by £4.5m, and they warn that the cut to balance the budget would in effect have to come from education, as that is the only area in which Bristol is spending above the government's guidelines.

Council leader George Micklewright said that holding a referendum would be an important step for local democracy in Britain: "We have been looking for ways to give Bristol people more say over important council decisions."

If it goes ahead, voters are expected to chose between four options:

 no increase in tax and a £4.5m cut in education - equivalent to the loss of 180 teachers;

 a 2% council tax rise, with £2.2m cut from the schools budget;

 a 4% increase with a standstill in council spending;

 a 6% increase, allowing an extra £2.2m to be spent on education.

The council hopes to get at least a 50% response compared with the 33% turnout in the last council elections in Bristol. It plans to issue ballot papers within days of a go-ahead. Voters will also be provided with supporting documents explaining the implications of the options before them.

The referendum is likely to use a transferable vote (a first choice, and second choice if that is knocked out, etc), and will be conducted by the Electoral Reform Society. The result is expected in February.

A combination of ballot paper numbers and personal PIN numbers is being used to maintain security, but the council says it will not know how individuals have cast their votes.

fields.headline: Arts: 40 years after his West End debut, Shaffer is part of the theatrical nobility
fields.trailText: Peter Shaffer, 74, the playwright once denounced as middlebrow but now recognised for the ambition and enduring power of his work, received a knighthood in the honours list.
fields.body:
Peter Shaffer, 74, the playwright once denounced as middlebrow but now recognised for the ambition and enduring power of his work, received a knighthood in the honours list.

Shaffer found West End fame with his family-at-war play Five Finger Exercise in 1958, but his name rests on the epic Royal Hunt of the Sun - about Pisarro's conquest of the Incas - and Amadeus, with its sometimes foul-mouthed Mozart, both of which were filmed by Hollywood.

Fay Weldon , 69, the author of The Life and Loves of a She-Devil said was awarded a CBE in the list. She has written 35 books and 10 plays.

Harrison Birtwhistle, 66, who has been in the forefront of modern music for 20 years was made a Companion of Honour in the list. Birtwhistle was chosen to write fanfares for the Queen's opening of Tate Modern earlier this year.

The astronomer Patrick Moore, 77, said of his knighthood: "I was astounded because there are many other people who deserve a knighthood far more.

Broadcaster Sue Lawley, 54, was awarded an OBE as was Floella Benjamin, 51, the children's TV presenter.

fields.headline: City figures join new knights
fields.trailText: Knighthoods were bestowed on half a dozen City figures, including the biotechnology entrepreneur Chris Evans.
fields.body:
Knighthoods were bestowed on half a dozen City figures, including the biotechnology entrepreneur Chris Evans.

Mr Evans, 43, took the first steps towards acquiring his £120m fortune in 1992 when he sold his first company Enzymatix and invested in firms including Chiroscience and Merlin Biosciences, where he is chairman. Last night he said he would be known as Sir Christopher, adding: "The disc jockey can keep the Chris Evans name now."

Another entrepreneur, David McMurtry, chief executive of Renishaw, the Gloucester-based technology company, was knighted for services to design and innovation.

Venture capitalist Ronald Cohen was also knighted. He is the architect of the government's community tax credit to encourage investment in poor areas of the country.

The other new knights are Clive Martin, former Lord Mayor of London; Thomas Parker, chairman of Babcock, who was honoured for services to the defence and shipbuilding industries; and Treasury official Robert Culpin.

Rosalind Wright, head of the Serious Fraud Office, was awarded a KCB as was Jonathan Cunliffe, director of monetary policy at the Treasury. Grahame Bulfield, director of the Roslin Institute which cloned Dolly the sheep, received a CBE.

fields.headline: President-elect fills cabinet
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: A Republican party star and welfare-reform pioneer who favours a Harley-Davidson motorcycle as his mode of transport was selected yesterday by president-elect George W Bush as secretary of health and human services.
fields.body:
A Republican party star and welfare-reform pioneer who favours a Harley-Davidson motorcycle as his mode of transport was selected yesterday by president-elect George W Bush as secretary of health and human services.

Tommy Thompson, America's longest-serving governor, is credited with huge cuts in the number of Wisconsin families on welfare since he took office 14 years ago.

His methods included cutting public assistance to parents whose children fail to attend school; making fathers take part in work schemes if they do not pay child support; and finding more cash for teenage parents if they marry.

But critics say that a buoyant economy has had more to do with his success in cutting families on welfare from 98,000 to just over 16,000.

Mr Thompson will head one of the government's biggest departments, with health insurance programmes and financial assistance for low-income families among the areas under its remit.

The 59-year-old governor is joined in the president-elect's inner circle by Gale Norton, the controversial former Colorado attorney general.

Ms Norton, 46, named as interior secretary with responsibility for the environment, has already made herself unpopular with the green lobby because of her support for oil exploration in the Arctic national wildlife refuge.

Yesterday's nominations - the education and veterans' affairs jobs were also filled - leave only three cabinet slots vacant, still with no sign of the Democrat Mr Bush said he wanted to appoint as a balancing factor after the election.

George Tenet, the CIA director appointed by Bill Clinton's administration, is expected to keep his job.

Rod Paige, the superintendent of schools in Houston, Texas, and an advocate of vouchers to move pupils from public to private schools, was named education secretary. He becomes the second black cabinet member, following Colin Powell, who has been designated secretary of state.

Anthony Principi, a former deputy secretary of the department of veterans' affairs, now gets the department's top job.

Mr Thompson is a conservative populist who has moved closer to the centre and likes to identify himself with every perceived success during his four terms as Wisconsin governor: he takes credit for everything from falling welfare rolls and job creation to sporting victories and better toilets in parks.

"He can't stand not to be somewhere where things are happening," said Mark Bugher, a long-time aide. "He has to be everywhere because he's afraid to be nowhere, in some ways. He's afraid to be forgotten."

The issue that made him a national figure was W-2, or Wisconsin Works, a scheme based on the premise that everyone must do some sort of job as a condition of receiving childcare, transportation or healthcare benefits. Opponents say that the scheme is unfair to minorities and the poor, and that it ended up costing more than the welfare system it replaced.

 Hillary Clinton is thought to have settled on a new home in Washington, a six-bedroomed mansion with a $3.5m (£2.3m) price tag near the British embassy.

Mrs Clinton needs a home in the capital to do her new job as a senator, in the same way that she needed one in New York to qualify to run for a seat representing the state.

Her last plunge into the property market, just over a year ago, produced a $1.7m house about 45 minutes north of Manhattan. The Clintons are thought to owe law firms at least $4m, but the first lady has signed a deal for an $8m advance on her memoirs.

"He can't stand not to be somewhere where things are happening," said Mark Bugher, a long-time aide. "He has to be everywhere because he's afraid to be nowhere, in some ways. He's afraid to be forgotten." The issue that made him a national figure was W-2, or Wisconsin Works, a scheme based on the premise that everyone must do some sort of job as a condition of receiving childcare, transportation or healthcare benefits. Opponents say that the scheme is unfair to minorities and the poor, and that it ended up costing more than the welfare system it replaced.  Hillary Clinton is thought to have settled on a new home in Washington, a six-bedroomed mansion with a $3.5m (£2.3m) price tag near the British embassy. Mrs Clinton needs a home in the capital to do her new job as a senator, in the same way that she needed one in New York to qualify to run for a seat representing the state. Her last plunge into the property market, just over a year ago, produced a $1.7m house about 45 minutes north of Manhattan. The Clintons are thought to owe law firms at least $4m, but the first lady has signed a deal for an $8m advance on her memoirs. fields.headline: School heads' roles hailed
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A headteacher who has turned around an inner city school which once had the worst truancy rate in the country has been awarded a DBE.
fields.body:
A headteacher who has turned around an inner city school which once had the worst truancy rate in the country has been awarded a DBE.

In the new year honours list where education accounts for 10% of awards, Jean Else, 49, has been chosen for transforming Whalley Range high school for girls in Manchester. Attendance rates were just 73% when she arrived in 1994; now they are at 95%. The pupil roll has soared from 766 to 1,500. Now 35% of pupils get five good GCSEs, compared with 16% four years ago.

She reintroduced uniform, installed a school radio station and painted vast swaths of the school in purple, its official colour."It's down to a combination of old fashioned rules - regulations which are clear and precise - and innovative exciting ideas," she said.

Also honoured were Mary Richardson, former principal of the Convent of Jesus and Mary Language College, a specialist school in Brent; Janet Trotter, who led Cheltenham and Gloucester College of higher education from its formation in 1990; and Sharon Hollows, whose Calverton primary school in Newham, east London, had the most improved national test results between 1996 and 1999.

fields.headline: Montenegro warned against split
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The Serbian prime minister-designate, Zoran Djindjic, said yesterday that he opposed the current Montenegrin proposal to separate the two republics which form the Yugoslav federation and bring them together again in a looser alliance.
fields.body:
The Serbian prime minister-designate, Zoran Djindjic, said yesterday that he opposed the current Montenegrin proposal to separate the two republics which form the Yugoslav federation and bring them together again in a looser alliance.

But Serbia would not stand in the way of a legal attempt to secede, he added.

Mr Djindjic said Montenegro and Serbia should stay in one state. "Everything else is a risk ... and will be like [Slobodan] Milosevic's ghost taking its revenge," he said in Belgrade.

A divorce would be acrimonious, harming the climate for investment and representing a victory for the ousted Yugoslav president and his policies of division, he said.

President Milo Djukanovic of Montenegro outlined a hardline stand on independence on Thursday, jettisoning Yugoslavia as it is now constituted. His proposal prompted the People's party to leave the coalition government, but he can for the moment continue with a minority government.

Mr Djukanovic has called for Montenegro and Serbia to be two internationally recognised separate states, each with its own UN seat, separate diplomatic offices and armies but sharing a common currency, market and customs area.

The proposal envisages joint bodies in charge of defence, security and foreign policy.

It calls for a single chamber parliament based on the principle of parity, a president of the alliance, and a council of ministers.

A referendum on Montenegrin independence is planned next year. Analysts say Montenegrins are polarised and a referendum could produce a virtually 50-50 result.

That might provide a technical mandate for independence but would give Mr Djukanovic a weak hand with which to negotiate.

fields.headline: Gongs for stars of Sydney Olympics
fields.standfirst:
Steve Redgrave knighted after fifth gold medal

Special report: Sydney 2000
fields.trailText: Steve Redgrave knighted after fifth gold medal.
fields.body:
The Five times Olympic rowing champion Steve Redgrave rounded off a victorious year by being knighted in the new year's honours list.

Redgrave is one of several members of the British Olympic team who were awarded honours after their success at the Sydney games, where Britain secured 11 gold medals.

Denise Lewis, who won the heptathlon gold medal was awarded an MBE as was the gold medal-winning rowing men's eight.

Several other Olympians also received MBEs including Jason Queally, who won gold in the cycling 1km time-trial and Audley Harrison who won gold in the boxing super heavyweight category.

Redgrave, who has pledged not to go for a sixth Olympic title, celebrated his knighthood at home with his family in Marlow, Buckinghamshire".

He said: "No one starts sport for fame or fortune, they do it because they stumble across it and get a lot of pleasure from it and from there things lead on. Having gone through the heights of the Olympic games five times and picking up honours along the way, it's now finished with a knighthood - it's unbelievable. It's not something I dreamt about."

Sir Steve who was also named BBC Sports Personality of the Year added: "I hope with the profile of the knighthood that I can try to raise some serious money for charity. Perhaps my title will make people a little more prepared to listen to me and the ideas I put forward. It won't change me as a person."

The success of British athletes at the Paralympics in Sydney was also recognised. There were MBEs for Caroline Innes, who won two gold medals in the 200 and 400 metres; Kenny Cairns, who won silver in the 200 metres freestyle swimming and Isabel Newstead who won gold in the 10 metres air rifle.

Two foreign sports stars who have become increasingly popular within British fans over the past few years have also been recognised.

The former Manchester United and Denmark goalkeeper Peter Schmeichel and the leading Italian jockey Frankie Dettori, who earlier this year survived a plane crash in which the pilot died, were awarded honorary MBEs.

Ted Dexter, the former England cricketer was awarded a CBE.

There was also an MBE for one British world champion who does not usually receive a great deal of national acclaim. Phil Taylor, known to his fans as "the Power" and described as the best darts player in history, is currently defending his world title. He said he was delighted to receive the honour.

In football, the Portsmouth player Alan Knight, who made more than 800 appearances as goalkeeper for the team, received an MBE.

The former West Bromwich Albion player Brendon Batson, one of the first black players to break into mainstream football, also received an MBE.

One of the leading names from women's golf was also recognised for her contribution to the sport. Dale Reid, the Scottish captain of the Europe golf team which beat the USA in the Solheim Cup, received an OBE for services to women's golf.

webTitle: Jim White's Old Year's dishonours list

fields.headline: Jim White's Old Year's dishonours list
fields.standfirst: Old masters in the gallery of sporting self-destruction
fields.trailText: Old masters in the gallery of sporting self-destruction.
fields.body:
Glory, gold, graciousness in defeat: none of these things need concern us here in the annual round-up of the year's most self-destructive sporting moments. Ordinary cock-ups involving nothing more than a dodgy back pass, say, or an embarrassing mis-translation at a post-match press conference are not enough. These are the humdingers, the self-important and the laughable that make the cynical observer glow.

The award for golfing pomposity

As always, the contenders for this title stretch round the clubhouse, from Mark James and Nick Faldo bickering over the final resting place of a note of encouragement at last year's Ryder Cup, to an official at the Belfry club disqualifying Padraig Harrington from the winner's podium at the Masters because he forgot to sign his scorecard.

The committee at St Andrews, as always, gets an honourable mention, this time for suspending a poor member called Yuille Bayley after accusing him of carrying several extra balls in his bag ready when required to be dropped into a more strategic lie than the ball he had actually hit (doesn't everyone?).

But the award goes to the members of a club in the North-east (anonymity is only fair) who reacted with magnificent bluster to what can only be described as a local hazard. Two crows have been enjoying rich pickings these last couple of months swooping down and stealing balls off the 17th green. It seems the birds mistake the balls for eggs, but instead of a snack of ante-natal plover or pigeon, they get several kilometres of coiled string inside a Wilson or Callaway.

The aggrieved members, watching their balls fly away, are demanding that their club remove the birds by whatever means is necessary. Including shooting. These spluttering plus-fours would have displayed enough unnatural cruelty to carry off the award, were it not for their lack of awareness of the rules of the game. They should know every possible hazard is covered in the Royal & Ancient's bible-like rule book and they should not be demanding action beyond established precedent. For instance, animal intervention is already a fact of life on one course in Florida, where a player is entitled to a drop shot if a salamander should remove his ball from the fairway. Although there is not the same leniency, curiously, if it is a pelican which is doing the scavenging.

The Railtrack award for outstanding achievement in public relations

Manchester United led from the front for this one, elbowing aside the striking England rugby players and everyone involved in snooker. Their year began with an appalling press release warning fans not to travel to Rio de Janeiro for the ill-conceived World Club Championship last January.

A festering hell-hole populated entirely by muggers and HIV-positive transvestite prostitutes was the gist of the warning. Imagine how well that one went down with their hosts. As a piece of ill-informed nonsense, it was like officials of teams visiting Manchester alerting their fans to the fact that the city is alive with gun-toting, crack-headed drug runners. No, hang on, that sounds accurate enough to me.

Anyway, in order to ensure there would be no more repeats of the blunder, the club hired a public relations director. The only problem was Alison Ryan, the director in question, turned out to have an approach to the truth to match that of Jeffrey Archer. It transpired she had made up her qualifications so she was sacked, leaving faces all round Old Trafford smeared with egg.

But despite their best efforts, United were pipped at the last by their neighbours City. In the programme for the final Maine Road match of 2000, a reference was made to United's nickname in blue parts: the Munichs. "Human error," was the official City line to explain how the term made its way into officially sanctioned print. Which as a euphemism for ugly, offensive reference to the victims of tragedy is about as award-winningly shabby as they come.

The Goran Ivanisevic Award for services to tennis racket manufacturers

Goran wins the award yet again, after his heroic display at an ATP tournament in Bournemouth last month. Angered by the deficiencies of his own performance, he smashed not one but three rackets, a tantrum which culminated in the discovery that he had none left intact in his kit bag with which to proceed. He was thus forced to concede defeat, and was obliged to hobble off court with at least a dozen metaphorical gunshot wounds peppering his own feet. The rules for this category state that after three wins, the winner is entitled to keep the award in perpetuity. So Ivanisevic can take it home with him. And will no doubt smash it into several small pieces on his kitchen floor.

Most self-destructive team of the year

The Football Association was in pole position for this one, as indeed would be any organisation which made Kevin Keegan head coach. The award looked to be in the bag after things sunk to depths of comedy unplumbed even by England football teams: Keegan retreating after woeful defeat by Germany, chucking control of his team towards the butter-fingered hands of Howard Wilkinson. But then the blousons of Soho Square (as the modernised new FA must now be termed) made an enlightened appointment. Sven-Goran Eriksson may not, as his critics have suggested, be the best in Italy, he may not even be the best in Sweden, but he is several heads and half a dozen pairs of shoulders above anyone else willing to do the job.

With the field clear, Bradford City made their stab at the award for self-destruction when Benito Carbone and Stan Collymore were united in the same dressing room. But at least Bradford have won the occasional game, unlike the clear winners of this category. Normally in such circumstances, we would say: "Step forward Oxford United." Except with Oxford, the side with the worst record in English football, one step forward is generally followed by two steps back.

Not for United a succession of thrashings this season. No, they have sunk to the basement of the Second Division after a magnificently self-destructive run, losing nine of their last 15 games by a single goal. Five times they have lost by three goals to two. Five times they have managed to go down after taking the lead.

"I have never come across a team who can find so many new and unusual ways of throwing away a game," said one canny observer this week. Unfortunately he is Dave Kemp, the team's manager. Which, as a prognosis for the rest of the season, won't fill many supporters' hearts with confidence.

The Ken Bates award

As always, there is only one winner in the category reserved for the man whose actions seem designed to inflict maximum damage on his own interests. Who else but our winner would sack the most successful manager in his club's history five weeks into the season? Who else would seek to impose a business model on the national stadium which is looking distinctly unprofitable when applied to the reconstruction of his own club's ground?

Yes, Ken Bates has been at it again, though it would be remiss to suggest that the restaurants at the new Stamford Bridge do not offer a unique service. After all, nowhere else in the locale, when booking for dinner, are patrons offered a choice of 50 tables. But there is more to Ken Bates than simply sacking good managers and attempting to blag through grandiose building schemes at the public expense.

This was the year in which his past business dealings in Lancashire and the Caribbean were ruthlessly exposed by the brilliant Radio 5 investigative series, On The Line. After that, and after Wembley, and after the black hole that is Chelsea's finances, there may not be much more room for manoeuvre.

Make the most of it Ken: this might be the last occasion when you receive our Sports Poisonality of the Year award.

fields.headline: At this price?  Psion
fields.trailText: Top of last year's Christmas wish list for many City stalwarts was a handheld computer to replace the ageing Filofax bought back in 1985.
fields.body:
Top of last year's Christmas wish list for many City stalwarts was a handheld computer to replace the ageing Filofax bought back in 1985.

Among those to benefit from this silent revolution was Psion, for many years a pioneer in a field which has only recently become so fiercely competitive.

Although the company brought out its first electronic organiser in 1984, four years after it was founded, it took a while to persuade devotees of the pen and pencil to give new technology a chance.

But for a company whose shares peaked this year at £15 the past few months have been trying times.

Not only has it been facing intense rivalry from the likes of Palm, Handspring and Compaq, but its own performance has fallen well short of scintillating, which resulted in a profits warning back in October.

Shares have been sinking fast ever since, with more than £4bn being taken off the company's value since the spring.

And life looks set to get even more difficult with reports that Psion has found problems with its new Revo model which cause the screen to blank out soon after it has been recharged, preventing users from accessing phone numbers.

Psion is refusing to comment on the numbers of machines being returned, but the problem is not thought to be affecting all the units, up to 30,000, that are sold each month.

Despite initially dropping 10% as news of the problem leaked out, combined with a bout of profit taking, shares were not too badly hit yesterday and bounced back as the London markets closed at lunchtime.

Psion's stock ended the session up 3.4%, or 9.5p, to 286.5p, some way ahead of the 209.5p year low but still way off the £15 high.

This year won't go down as a classic in Psion's 20-year history but it is hard to see how much lower the share price can fall. Hold.

webTitle: FI ends its £1,000 incentive to fire a freelance

fields.headline: FI ends its £1,000 incentive to fire a freelance
fields.trailText: Computer services FI yesterday abandoned a controversial scheme that offered staff a £1,000 bonus if they named freelance colleagues who could be replaced by cheaper staff from India.
fields.body:
Computer services FI yesterday abandoned a controversial scheme that offered staff a £1,000 bonus if they named freelance colleagues who could be replaced by cheaper staff from India.

Chairperson Hilary Cropper was said to have been highly offended by the scheme. A spokesman for the company said the idea had been sent in an email on December 18 from one of the company's subsidiaries and had not been approved at board level.

At a meeting on Wednesday the scheme was scrapped. Ms Cropper told staff in a memo the plan was "ill-advised".

According to financial website Sharecast, Ms Cropper's memo said: "I apologise on behalf of the company to all employees who feel embarrassed by this communication, and confirm that the offer is withdrawn immediately."

FI has been trying to reduce the number of freelance contractors it employs and replace them with full-time staff, who can cost a quarter as much.

Part of the strategy is to bring over full time staff from its Indian subsidiary to replace freelance contractors.

fields.headline: The biology of success
fields.trailText: Cambridge Antibody Technology was the market's best performer during 2000 with a year-on-year share price rise of 557.41%, according to a survey by Thomson Financial Datastream.
fields.body:
Cambridge Antibody Technology was the market's best performer during 2000 with a year-on-year share price rise of 557.41%, according to a survey by Thomson Financial Datastream.

It was followed by two other biotech firms, International Biotechnology, the investment trust, with an almost 200% rise, and Oxford Glycosciences, which went up 194.2% over the 12 months.

Aberdeen Asset Management came in next with a rise of 126.76%.

Celltech, yet another biotech company, was the leading performer in the FTSE with a 106.64% jump while Telewest Communications was at the other end of the scale with a 68% loss.

Cambridge also took the honours among the technology companies on the Techmark index.

Globally, Israel was the best performing equity market, with a 29% rise; UK markets were down 12%.

fields.headline: Footsie skids on oil slick
fields.trailText: Despite a surging performance by there was scant consolation for the FTSE 100, which ended a poor year on a lacklustre note yesterday lunchtime.
fields.body:
Despite a surging performance by Vodafone there was scant consolation for the FTSE 100, which ended a poor year on a lacklustre note yesterday lunchtime.

The telecoms company rose 5.4% to 245.5p, singlehandedly adding 34 points to the index, as it shrugged off recent reports that a US firm in which it has a stake may face lawsuits from brain tumour victims.

But good performances elsewhere were in very short supply as traders began switching off their screens and winding down in preparation for their New Year's Eve celebrations.

As the London markets finally crawled to a halt, the benchmark index had slipped a further 0.7 points to end the session at 6222.5 with analysts saying it was indicative of a year which had been "lacklustre" and "disappointing".

Even the technology sector, which has had a tempestuous love-hate relationship with the market all year, went out with a whisper. Despite the Techmark creeping up 4.59 points to 2564.05 on the day, it was down just over 30% on the year.

Filtronic was among the best performers on the index with a 9% rise to 455p, while Cambridge Antibody went up by a shade under 3%, or 110p, to close the day at £38.

Oil, which has spent so many months on the front pages, was a prime reason behind the FTSE 100's woes as the industry's leading players suffered post-Christmas blues thanks to a drop in crude oil prices.

The London Brent blend futures had dipped 61 cents to $23.10-a-barrel by late morning, but the tumble was sparked by dealers taking the view that petroleum stocks would be enough to see the west safely through a harsh winter, despite the fact snow has already started to sweep across the country.

BP Amoco alone accounted for six of the oil and gas sector's nine point loss as it fell 6.5p to 540p, with Shell slipping 2.5p at 549p, while the BG Group sunk 10p to end the session at 262p.

Pharmaceuticals gave a mixed performance as did the banks, both sectors suffering erratic movements.

Shire Pharmaceutical shed 45p, over 4%, to £10.55, while the newly amalgamated Glaxo SmithKline fell 30p to £18.90. AstraZeneca did not enjoy the best of times, dropping 42p to £33.75, while Celltech gave the sector something to cheer with an almost 4% gain of 45p to £11.83.

In the banking world, Barclays lost 20p at £20.72, Alliance & Leicester was down 14p at 680p, while Bank of Scotland slipped 9.5p to end the morning at 700.5p.

On the upside, Abbey National put on 24p, or 2%, at £12.19, while HSBC and Royal Bank of Scotland both added 4p to close at 985p and £15.82 respectively.

The limited activity in the City was reflected in the fact that only 575m shares were traded during the half day with losers outnumbering gainers by two to one. The market had shut before trading began on Wall Street.

British racecourse owner Arena Leisure, part of the Go Racing consortium chasing a lucrative contract for UK horse racing media rights, said trading was in line with expectations but saw its shares slip 1.5p to close at 104.5p.

Shares in Spring Group, the training and recruitment consultantancy, rose 13% to 90p after the company announced it was selling Spring Education and Spring Skills businesses to Protocol Associates for £71.9m as part of its restructuring.

Elsewhere the FTSE 250 index was up 0.53% at 6547.5 points with the Small Cap managing a 0.38% increase at 3183.3.

Among other losers were Spirent, the telecoms test equipment company, which lost 5% to 610p and Helphire, the insurance claim management firm, which sunk 12.7% to 72.5p.

But British Telecom, which touched a three year low during the mid-morning, recovered to close up 2p at 572p.

fields.headline: Galloping away
fields.standfirst: Arena's profits up
fields.trailText: Arena's profits up
fields.body:
British racecourse owner Arena Leisure, part of the Go Racing consortium in line to win the media rights contract to British horse racing, yesterday unveiled an upbeat trading statement, writes Rob Griffin.

The company's operations include Windsor racetrack, above, and the three all-weather courses at Lingfield Park, Southwell and Wolverhampton. It reported a rise of 118% in operating profit to £931,000 for the six months to September 30, 2000.

It said trading for the first nine weeks of the second half was "in line", but admitted it would not be paying an interim dividend as it was the "company's priority" to invest in the business.

In a statement to the stock market, the company said it hoped contract negotiations on the Go Racing venture would be concluded by January 17, 2001.

Arena announced in October the formation of a joint venture with British Sky Broadcasting and Channel 4 Television for the media rights.

The Go Racing consortium looked as if it had beaten off a rival bid from Carlton Communications when the Racecourse Association agreed to hold exclusive rights over the 10-year contract.

But the deal still has not been signed, as the RCA an nounced that it was launching an inquiry into the bidding process.

Shares in Arena slipped slightly yesterday as the London markets closed for the final time this year, dropping 1.5p to 104.5p. This is just ahead of the 103p year low and well below the 267p high.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Textile group Coats Viyella, urged by 12% shareholder Guinness Peat to tackle its ailing share price, yesterday named three new non-executive directors, including GP's Blake Nixon.
fields.body:
Coats hires non-executives

Textile group Coats Viyella, urged by 12% shareholder Guinness Peat to tackle its ailing share price, yesterday named three new non-executive directors, including GP's Blake Nixon. Guinness Peat had called for an extraordinary general meeting to seek the appointment of the trio.

Coats Viyella said it was pleased to avoid having to call an EGM, and looked forward to working with the new board members.

"Arriving at a sensible agreement in discussion is most preferable to the considerable cost and distraction of convening an EGM," Coats, chairman, Harry Djanogly, said.

Coats Viyella announced almost 2,000 job losses in September after a steep slide in half-year profits.

Ward seeks chapter 11

US retailer Montgomery Ward said it has filed for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after 128 years in business, with about 28,000 staff to lose their jobs. The company, purchased by GE Capital in Aug 1999, said its 250 stores and 10 distribution centres would cease operations in the coming months.

The filing for protection from creditors was made "after an exhaustive exploration of options for continuing the business," said Roger Goddu, Ward's chairman and chief executive officer.

HSBC quits Thai talks

HSBC yesterday withdrew from a deal to buy a controlling stake in Bangkok Metropolitan Bank. HSBC had agreed in principle in May to pay $940m to take a 75% stake in the 177-branch Thai bank, which was taken over by the Thai government in August 1998 after becoming a casualty of the Asian financial crisis.

Assistant Thai central bank governor Chaktip Nitibhon said one reason for the failure of the deal was how much tax HSBC would pay.

Sega to retreat from Dreamcast

Sega's Dreamcast video-game machine may be its last pure game console as the company seeks to push its technology into other devices such as mobile phones, reports indicated yesterday.

"I think Sega is going to get out of the hardware business in the long run," Kazuhiko Nishi, an associate of Sega chairman Isao Okawa, said. Sega's business plan which was announced last month does not commit the company to producing a successor to Dreamcast.

Insiders say a number of companies have considered buying Sega and have taken a look at the business.

Lucent piles up bad debts

Lucent Technologies, battered recently by poor earnings and an accounting error, ended its fiscal year with nearly twice as much money set aside for bad customer debt as a year ago.

In its annual report, filed with the US securities and exchange commission, Murray Hill, Lucent said it set aside an additional $252m in the year to September 30 for what it termed "doubtful" accounts. It began the year with $318m set aside but wrote off only $69m this year, less than the $112m wrote off in 1999. With the new additions, it ended fiscal year 2000 with a $501m cushion.
