fields.headline: Footsie ends in the red
fields.standfirst: Telecom and hi-tech turbulence send market into decline
fields.trailText: Telecom and hi-tech turbulence send market into decline.
fields.body:
A depressing year in the City finally came to a close yesterday lunchtime with the bluechip FTSE 100 recording only the third annual decline in its 17-year history.

Over the course of a turbulent 12 months, in which the market fell spectacularly out of love with telecoms and technology, the benchmark index dropped 10% to 6222.5 points.

Its fall also brought to an end five years of double-digit gains that had culminated in the record high of 6930.2 at the end of last year.

The index, regarded as the barometer of corporate Britain, had only previously suffered annual falls in 1990 and 1994 when it sank 12% and 10% respectively.

But yesterday's performance clearly illustrated the mood in the Square Mile with many having become depressed with the seemingly endless stream of earnings worries and profits warnings being issued.

The half-day session, the last one of the year, saw the index dropping slightly down by 0.7 points - 707.7 points adrift of its position as the millennium celebrations were in full swing.

Dealers said last night that expectations of interest rate cuts in 2001 were likely to be the principle factors in deciding how strongly the market was likely to perform over the next few months.

But they warned trading may be further hit if the expected cut fails to materialise until the second half of the year.

The year 2000 will always be remembered for the derating which swept through the telecoms and technology sectors that had been responsible for dragging the FTSE to its 1999 highs.

Telewest Communications, British Telecom and Colt Telecom all had a nightmare year in which they lost more than 50% of their value.

Thus, a telecoms company which was a member of the index in the early months before being relegated, failed to escape the downward spiral and had lost around 85% of its value by yesterday.

Baltimore Technologies and Bookham, formerly the blue-eyed boys of the 100, lost their positions in the year's final shake-up of the index.

But it was not all bad news and, excluding telecoms and technology, the market actually rose year on year. While investors ran shy of IT firms as the internet bubble began to burst early in 2000, the biotech sector became the chief beneficiary of their affections.

The Celltech Group, which only gained promotion to the index at the end of March, watched its share price surge ahead to end the year up 121% with analysts impressed by the growth prospects of its cancer, arthritis and asthma treatments.

Shire Pharmaceutical was another celebrating with a 70% rise over the period.

Defensive stocks generally found themselves in favour as investors searched for ways of minimising the risks of the economic cycle.

British American Tobacco, along with others in its sector, started the year under a cloud with concerns over an inquiry into their past conduct by MPs on the House of Commons health select committee.

But despite the resulting launch of a Department of Trade and Industry investigation into its alleged links with smuggling, BAT enjoyed a 45% rise amid hopes of a more lenient legal environment in the US under George W Bush.

Analysts are expecting the FTSE 100 to rebound by the end of 2001, with some predicting it could bounce up to the 7,000 point mark, especially if there are lower interest rates in Britain and the US, which would sharpen the appetite of investors.

webTitle: Business: John Lewis sets new record

fields.headline: Still spending
fields.standfirst: John Lewis sets new record
fields.trailText: John Lewis sets new record.
fields.body:
A difficult end to a tough trading year for leading retailers was predicted yesterday after the John Lewis department store chain revealed that sales had risen just 1% this month.

During what is traditionally a crucial trading period for retailers, John Lewis said that although its sales had risen just slightly on the corresponding pe riod last year, they had still set a record.

Retail experts said the performance of the partnership did not augur well for other retailers, such as Marks & Spencer.

Richard Hyman, chairman of the Verdict Research retail consultancy, warned that big high street names were likely to report some "pretty tough" trading statements in the early part of the new year ahead of their profits figures.

Gareth Thomas, director of selling and customer service at John Lewis said: "I have a feeling that a lot of our competitors will not have traded very successfully this December."

His views were echoed by Mr Hyman who described 2000 as one of the toughest in recent years.

"You would expect John Lewis to be at the top end of the performance spectrum," said Mr Hyman.

Those retailers which are likely to have performed best are Next and Dixons, he said. Marks & Spencer, which has promised staff a £75-a-month bonus if they meet sales targets during the period, was always going to have a difficult Christmas period, Mr Hyman said, as its autumn and winter collection had not been enthusiastically received.

John Lewis admitted that the blanket of snow which covered the country on Thursday had led to a slow start to its two week sales period.

Mr Thomas, however, described December as a "buoyant month".

In the week to December 16, the group achieved new record sales of £72m, which were almost matched by £71m of sales in the week before Christmas. The figures were even greater than the huge sales recorded during last year's end-of-the-millennium rush, Mr Thomas said.

Meanwhile, the John Lewis partnership's supermarket chain, Waitrose, announced Christmas sales figures up 23% on last year's pre-Christmas week.

fields.headline: US slowdown 'a threat'
fields.standfirst: If America sneezes we all catch cold, says governor
fields.trailText: If America sneezes we all catch cold, says governor.
fields.body:
Sir Eddie George, the governor of the Bank of England, warned yesterday of the dangers for the UK if the US economy suffered a hard landing.

Though the governor said it was too soon to be seriously concerned, he noted recent evidence suggested the US economy could be slowing more sharply than had been expected.

"Some slowdown we needed to see, but I think the latest data suggests that it might be sharper than we need and sharper than would be desirable for the global economy - and I think one of the big uncertainties affecting the UK as a result," he told the BBC's Today programme.

The US economy has been growing for the best part of the last decade and has provided the motor that has kept the global economy on track even through crises such as the South-east Asian currencies crash and the Russian debt default. However there are now mounting concerns that it may slide back into recession in the second half of next year.

The governor acknowledged that "if America really sneezes we all catch cold", and that slower global growth would affect the UK but added "its not a nightmare scenario".

Sir Eddie urged moderation in the rate of growth of private sector spending to allow for accelerating public sector demand but said the UK "should be able to sustain overall growth around the recent level or perhaps a little less".

"I must say we have had a very good run and I tell my people here to enjoy it while it lasts because one can't expect it always to be as good as it's been but, on the whole, looking forward, I'm pretty optimistic."

He refused to be drawn on the likely outlook for UK interest rates, saying the object of policy was to allow the economy to grow at its sustainable rate. "I honestly couldn't predict, at this stage, whether that will require lower interest rates. It may even require higher interest rates still."

Sir Eddie welcomed the signs that the euro was recovering but was cautious about the implications for possible UK membership of the single currency club.

"I don't think the question can immediately arise but if the euro continues to recover then it comes back on to the agenda."

And he stressed that membership was " a political decision not an economic one".

"I must say we have had a very good run and I tell my people here to enjoy it while it lasts because one can't expect it always to be as good as it's been but, on the whole, looking forward, I'm pretty optimistic." He refused to be drawn on the likely outlook for UK interest rates, saying the object of policy was to allow the economy to grow at its sustainable rate. "I honestly couldn't predict, at this stage, whether that will require lower interest rates. It may even require higher interest rates still." Sir Eddie welcomed the signs that the euro was recovering but was cautious about the implications for possible UK membership of the single currency club. "I don't think the question can immediately arise but if the euro continues to recover then it comes back on to the agenda." And he stressed that membership was " a political decision not an economic one".

webTitle: House price surge takes average home to £82,188

fields.headline: House price surge takes average home to £82,188
fields.trailText: House prices have risen sharply this month, coinciding with an end-of-year surge in mortgage lending, according to new figures issued yesterday.
fields.body:
House prices have risen sharply this month, coinciding with an end-of-year surge in mortgage lending, according to new figures issued yesterday. Nationwide building society said its data showed the housing market was moving forward at a "steady, sustainable pace".

House prices rose by 1.2% during December - the largest monthly rise since April - which means the average property is now worth £82,188, said Nationwide. This is 9.3% higher than a year ago, when the typical price was £75,219.

And new figures show that November saw the largest amount of mortgage lending by the banks since the late summer, with remortgaging reaching record levels as growing numbers of people became aware of the savings they could make by moving their home loan to another lender.

Nationwide said this month's rise was further proof that the summer slowdown was only a pause for breath. A spokesman added that a stable 2001 was in sight, with pay rises and City bonuses likely to give a further boost to an already recovering market. It expects the Bank of England base rate to remain at around 6% for a few months, which should underpin a sustainable market outlook.

Nevertheless, annual house price growth is only forecast to reach 7% in 2001 compared with 9.3% this year and 13.3% in 1999. In London, the region which enjoyed the biggest gains this year, the average home notched up a 13% increase in value in 2000, though the prediction is for a single-digit increase next year.

This year saw the emergence of a number of property "hot spots," and locations where prices surged more than 25% in a year that include Castlereagh, near Belfast (33.3% annual house price inflation), Epping Forest, north-east London (32.8%), and Eastleigh, Hants (27.2%).

Nationwide's predicted hot spots for the next few years include Windsor and Maidenhead, Woking, Cherwell, North Oxfordshire, Stratford-on-Avon, and Winchester and the New Forest, both in Hampshire.

webTitle: Letters: No butter on my parsnips

fields.headline: No butter on my parsnips
fields.trailText: I too suspect that chemicals are not beneficial to the imbiber (Hangovers 'down to wine additives', December 23).
fields.body:
I too suspect that chemicals are not beneficial to the imbiber (Hangovers 'down to wine additives', December 23). I have been making my own wine for nearly 40 years and, apart from a degree of drowsiness, they seem to have no after-effects whatsoever.

After some horrific starts I have now managed to produce what I think is a tolerable wine. It is based on parsnips with the addition of a few grapes, with a couple of oranges and lemons. The sweetness or dryness can be adjusted by the amount of sugar added. I suspect this will horrify your wine critic, but nobody I have given it to has complained so far. In fact, a few of them have asked for the recipe and are happily making it themselves. Unfortunately, I now have to get the yeast from Ireland as chemists in this area do not seem to stock it.
F Abercrombie
Weston-super-Mare, Somerset

fields.headline: Key player
fields.trailText: Your obituary (December 27) rightly celebrates many of the achievements of Sir Jimmy Shand and his band, but does not do justice to three of his great personal contributions.
fields.body:
Your obituary (December 27) rightly celebrates many of the achievements of Sir Jimmy Shand and his band, but does not do justice to three of his great personal contributions. First, Jimmy's own playing - especially his use of grace notes (similar to the ornaments in bagpiping) - was unique. This was musicianship of the highest calibre and it can be heard to stunning effect on certain solo recordings.

Second, Shand's creative work as a composer. His output was phenomenal and many of his tunes are standards for Scottish dancing throughout the world. This is one reason why his portrait hangs in the Scottish National Portrait Gallery in Edinburgh.

Even more remarkable was Shand's achievement in redesigning the three-row button-key accordion. Good instruments were available when this shy, unemployed miner began his career in the early 30s, but he felt that there was room for improvement. Not only that. Shand went to the well-established Hohner company in Germany and persuaded them to take up his ideas. The outcome, the Shand Morino, became the gold standard against which other accordions were judged.
Dr Bernard Dixon
Ruislip, Middx

webTitle: Letters: BBC is Doone and out

fields.headline: BBC is Doone and out
fields.trailText: Once recognised as the best producer of costume drama in the world, the BBC's production of RD Blackmore's Lorna Doone (TV review, December 27) demonstrates just how far it has sunk.
fields.body:
Once recognised as the best producer of costume drama in the world, the BBC's production of RD Blackmore's Lorna Doone (TV review, December 27) demonstrates just how far it has sunk.

The corporation cobbled together a script from every 30th page or so which gave us the gist of the story without ever giving us the heart or spirit of it.

Nobody need claim this novel as great literature. It is, however, a fine romance, which has a sound moral purpose, a love and understanding of the common people and a descriptive power which captures the beauty of the rural English scene of its period.

Where was any of that in this thin version? We were given innumerable pre-transmission tales of period longhorn cattle and of an endless sea of mud and grime. I think most viewers would sacrifice an entire herd of longhorn cattle for a handful of characters bearing even a passing resemblance to those so lovingly drawn by the author.

Whatever happened to the gentle giant John Ridd, as high and as wide as a barn? Every time anyone hit him, he fell over! Production values didn't run to telling a coherent tale either. Without the vital opening scenes, most of what followed was nonsense

Surely the guiding principle when adapting a book for the small screen must be a genuine attempt to portray the characters of the original with truth and integrity, to use as much of the author's dialogue as possible (rather than none of it whatsoever), to tell the tale he wrote and not something vaguely similar, and to try and capture, with imagination and fidelity, the spirit of the book. This principle was simply, in Mark Twain's memorable phrase, flung down and danced upon.
Trevor Walter
Nottingham

fields.headline: A poor start to 2001
fields.trailText: Professor Watt is seriously misguided if he really believes that an improvement in funding for our health services will result in a reversal of the dreadful poverty-related illness that continues to worsen in the west of Scotland (Healing Scotland's deadly health divide, December 29).
fields.body:
Professor Watt is seriously misguided if he really believes that an improvement in funding for our health services will result in a reversal of the dreadful poverty-related illness that continues to worsen in the west of Scotland (Healing Scotland's deadly health divide, December 29).

He is almost right when he calls for a cultural shift, but it is not the people who need shifting but politicians and their advisers. I have worked as a GP in Glasgow for 17 years and I realise the limitations of what our health service can do.

The vast majority of illness in Glasgow is due to socioeconomic causes. Addiction, terrible housing, unemployment and poor early life experience are all beyond the control of poor people. The health education board for Scotland continues, however, with a "rub their noses in it" advertising campaign extolling the virtues of not smoking and healthy eating, concluding with the crassly insensitive: "There is a life you can save - your own."

This is merely a way of saying: "Tough luck Jimmy, your addiction, your obesity, your poor health is all your own fault and nothing to do with the Scottish executive."

The time has long since passed for us to realise that it is not the people who do not understand, it is the politicians and medical establishment. I haul my patients daily out of the socio- economic river of illness before applying the used plasters carefully rationed by unseen and uncaring politicians, twisting one arm up behind my back as some oily broker lobbies to ensure that formula one motor racing will escape the smoking ban.

Their party coffers swell as the tumours run amok among my patients and nobody really cares. Wealth for the few still comes before health for all. I used to think my patients fell into this river, but now I know that they are pushed by an immoral political system, indivisible from corporations concerned only with profits.

We desperately need a voice of reason to champion the health needs of poor people. This is supposed to be provided by Professor Watt's speciality, public health, but it has been neutered by successive governments. We now desperately need an independent body with teeth to ensure that government decisions in all departments are made with due regard for the health of all and not simply for the wealth of a few.

We don't need vast amounts of extra money thrown at ill health. We all know that medicine has its limits. Extra consulting times and some clean plasters will help my patients a bit, but what they need most is that rarest of currencies, political courage and honesty. It is not the poor people who must change their behaviour but the politicians who must change their policies.
Dr Colin Guthrie
Glasgow grey_triker@hotmail.com

 So, an NOP poll says Britons are disappointed that they do not own flying cars and that a cure for the common cold still proves elusive (Back to the future, December 23). Well, imagine the disappointment for over 600m of the world's poorest people in the burgeoning cities of the developing world.

For them, adequate and safe housing, and the provision of water, sanitation and waste disposal also remain fantastic visions of the future. The glass and steel world of Dan Dare could not be further from the daily realities of life in shanty towns made of little more than salvaged wood, plastic sheeting and string. The year 2001 has not crept up on them.
Antony Robbins
Care International UK robbins@uk.care.org

webTitle: Letters: Last chance to whinge about the dome

fields.headline: Last chance to whinge
fields.trailText: Hugo Young has a lot to answer for (Comment, December 28). With amazing prescience he predicted the dome disaster two years ago. Prescience or prejudice?
fields.body:
Hugo Young has a lot to answer for (Comment, December 28). With amazing prescience he predicted the dome disaster two years ago. Prescience or prejudice?

My experience is limited to a coach trip from our village in Suffolk, when 53 people, aged from 5 to 75, visited the dome in June. Without exception, all of us enjoyed the day and felt that it was well worth the time and cost.

The same is true for the many other people I have spoken to. The dome and its exhibits are not perfect - there are a few fairly naff areas - but on the whole it is excellent. I am sure that the same feelings are held by the other 6m visitors. The 6m who did not go missed that treat because of you, Hugo Young - you and your ilk who condemned the dome from the start. Why? I'm told that one reason was the fact that journalists did not get sufficient VIP treatment on the opening day. It was either that or your dislike of New Labour and your determination to vilify it at every chance.
John Christie
Woolpit, Suffolk jgchristie@cwcom.net

 We went to the dome on Christmas Eve, tempted by the £1 admission (which we prebooked). I am disabled and had booked a car space, but found when arriving at 9.45am that anyone could drive in and park, therefore there were no dedicated spaces available.

We then queued for 30 minutes to get through the turnstiles. Like Judy Jones (Letters, December 29), we hardly saw anything because of the huge queues and the general crush, and a real failure in accessibility.

When I got the lift down to the ground floor, I was told by the charming hostess operating the lift that they should never have sold tickets to people like me (in wheelchairs/buggies/ scooters) and we "got what we paid for". She went on to say, at great length, that if we'd paid £20 we could have had a better day, but as cheapskates what did we expect? My only consolation was that she was about to lose her job.
Lindsay J Rough
Watford, Herts

fields.headline: Perfect sized people
fields.trailText: This campaign (Poster's lesbian embrace breaks advertising taboo, December 28) does not do anything out of the ordinary. Mainstream companies have always used images of young, white, middle class, "perfect sized" people to to promote their products to consumers.
fields.body:
This campaign (Poster's lesbian embrace breaks advertising taboo, December 28) does not do anything out of the ordinary. Mainstream companies have always used images of young, white, middle class, "perfect sized" people to to promote their products to consumers. Peter Tatchell, step into the real world, people come in all sizes, colours and classes.
Irene O'Malley
Loughborough, Leics

 While I support Helen Weeks's views on fox hunting (Letters, December 27), I take issue with her allowing her cats in her garden, where they will tear apart the indigenous wildlife (blackbirds, robins etc). Surely these harmless creatures deserve the same protection as the fox?
John Wilson
Nottingham

 No one in Norfolk would recognise the song titles Hev Yew Gotta Loight, Boy? Or Moind Yer Hid, Boy (Obituary, December 27) The correct form of address is "bor", not boy. The Singing Postman's songs also live on in a number of film clips preserved by the East Anglian Film Archive and given regular showings throughout the region.
Michael Smith
Swaffham, Norfolk

 Re the recent "discovery" of the sites in the Egyptian eastern desert (The rock art from 6,000 years ago, December 27). I would suggest you refer to David Rohl's excellent book Legend, the Genesis of Civilisation published in 1998.
Richard Golding
Langley, Bucks

 M&S must hold all records for selling hot X buns (Letters, December 23 and 27). They sell them all year round.
Marie Blundell
Wigan, Lancs

 No smartarse letters (Letters, December 29)? Can't I go away for just two days without everyone noticing?
Julian Dunn
Great Haseley, Oxon

webTitle: Drug massacre: Seven shot dead in Philadelphia

fields.headline: Drug massacre
fields.standfirst:
Seven shot dead in Philadelphia

Special report: gun violence in America
fields.trailText: Seven shot dead in Philadelphia.
fields.body:
Seven people have been shot dead in an abandoned house in Philadelphia, in what appears to have been a drug-related attack.

Four masked men burst into the house in a run-down area of the city and killed six men and a woman. Three others were wounded. A small amount of crack cocaine was found on the scene, along with drug paraphernalia.

The killers are still on the run. Derrick Long, whose 18-year-old nephew died, said: "One sad thing is that the shooters might be right here among us. The family is trying to be strong."

The killings took place as a memorial service was held in Massachusetts for seven people killed at work on Boxing Day.

Michael McDermott, a 42-year-old software tester, has been charged with murdering his colleagues, supposedly because he was angered at his salary being docked to repay a tax debt.

fields.headline: Too close for comfort
fields.standfirst: Watchdogs should be independent
fields.trailText: Watchdogs should be independent.
fields.body:
One of the first responsibilities which the national health service placed on ministers' shoulders was to oversee the introduction and use of new medicines. Few medicines were effective in 1948 and only a dozen or so from that era - among them aspirin, insulin, morphine and penicillin - are still used today.

But there have been more medical breakthroughs in the past 50 years than in the previous 2,500. Medicines have multiplied. About 90% in use in the early 1990s were unknown 30 years before; 50% were unknown six years previously. Yet the regulation of this market continues to create unease, as yesterday's report from our health editor on the new director of drugs licensing at the medicines control agency (MCA) confirms.

The new director, Dr Ian Hudson, is a former top executive at SmithKline Beecham, which with its merger this week with Glaxo Wellcome, is now the world's biggest pharmaceutical company. fields.headline: Willard Van Orman Quine
fields.standfirst: Philosopher whose revolutionary ideas challenged the accepted way we look at ourselves and our universe
fields.trailText: Philosopher whose revolutionary ideas challenged the accepted way we look at ourselves and our universe.
fields.body:
Willard Van Orman Quine, who has died aged 92, was arguably the greatest American philosopher of the second half of the 20th century. He revolutionised developments in epistemology, metaphysics, logic, philosophy of language and philosophy of maths.

In 1951, his article Two Dogmas Of Empiricism caused a furore in the philosophical world. It challenged received notions of knowledge, meaning and truth, and exceeded even the extreme empiricism of logical positivism by arguing that logic and maths, like factual statements, are open to revision in the light of experience.

Experience, added Quine, does not confirm or falsify individual statements, but instead confronts an interlocking theory-laden system of statements, which has to be adjusted as a whole. And there cannot be any universally-held system of beliefs, he argued in his major work Word And Object (1960), since the way any theory describes the world is relative to that theory's linguistic background.

Quine revised and clarified such theses in more than 20 books and numerous articles, all written in a distinctive crisp, witty style. He taught at Harvard from 1936 - becoming a full professor in 1948 - until his retirement in 1978, and lectured all over the world.

The youngest son of an engineer, Quine was born in "a modest frame house" in Akron, Ohio. He chose scientific courses at his local high school. An ardent stamp collector and list-maker, he was fascinated by etymology, and obsessed with maps and faraway places. His interest in philosophy began when, aged nine, he became worried by the absurdity of heaven and hell, and only stopped being worried about the dangerousness of his doubts when he realised that they might be justified.

Late in high school his brother, already a student at Oberlin College, gave him William James's Pragmatism, which he read compulsively, along with Swami Vivekananda's Raja Yoga. But he always said it was reading Eureka, a short story by Edgar Allen Poe, when aged 14, that first filled him with a desire to understand the universe.

When he went to Oberlin, a fellow poker-player told him about a philosopher of mathematics called Bertrand Russell, and he decided to major in maths, with philosophy of mathematics as a supplement. Quine's years at Oberlin were idyllic. His rooming house, full of kindred spirits, was "an ideal setting in which to wax articulate". His "appetite for cosmic understanding" was sharpened by reading Russell.

In the summer of 1928 he and two friends crossed the continent, jumping on to moving boxcars, and spending nights on benches or in prisons. He also found time, somewhat reluctantly, to marry a fellow-student.

Quine was awarded a scholarship to Harvard, where he did a PhD in only two years. During his first year, Bertrand Russell gave a lecture, and afterwards Alfred Whitehead (who had co-written Principia Mathematica with him) introduced Russell to the young philosopher, leading to an exchange of books and letters. The following year, Quine visited Europe on a travelling fellowship, and met members of the Vienna Circle (the anti-metaphysical Logical Positivists), their British disciple AJ Ayer, and the young Kurt Gödel, who had just produced his renowned incompleteness theorem.

The next three months were "intellectually the most rewarding" of his life - six weeks in Warsaw with Alfred Tarski and other innovatory Polish logicians, and six in Prague, where, taken up by the prime logical positivist Rudolf Carnap, Quine discovered what it was to be "intellectually fired by a living teacher rather than by a dead book". They conducted endless discussions together in German, and Quine was lent the typescript of the book Carnap was writing, handed to him sheaf by sheaf from the typewriter as Carnap's wife Ina typed it. He became Carnap's "ardent disciple", and although they were to become increasingly combative philosophically, they remained firm friends.

Quine returned to a junior fellowship at Harvard and to the publication of his thesis - his first book, A System Of Logistics. During the 1930s he developed his ideas in many articles, mainly on logic and set theory (most distinctively propounded in New Foundations Of Mathematics, 1937, and Mathematical Logic, 1940), and on existence and ontology. On What There Is (1948) contained his famous typically succinct formula: "To be is to be the value of a variable."

When Carnap visited Harvard in 1940, Quine and Tarski (also visiting) challenged him on the view crucial to logical positivism that, while most of what we say is verified or falsified by experience, there are some statements (in logic and mathematics) that are necessarily true come what may, by virtue of the meaning of their terms. (This was the only way the positivists could cater for the fact that the latter sort of statements are so obviously incapable of being tested by experience.)

In his seminal Two Dogmas Of Empiricism, however, Quine declared it "folly to seek a boundary between synthetic statements, which hold contingently on experience, and analytic statements, which hold come what may". By denying the analytic-synthetic distinction, Quine made even the "truths" of logic and mathematics empirical. No longer the central planks around which our beliefs are arrayed, logical and mathematical statements can (in principle) be modified, even abandoned, in the light of experience, as factual statements are.

This was heresy in all philosophical camps. What experience, it might be asked, could lead anyone remotely to query the apparently adamantine logical law of excluded middle (that every proposition is necessarily either true or not true, and each thing either has or lacks any given property)?

Even that law might, said Quine, be revisable as a means of simplifying quantum mechanics, and so might the principle of causality. "Any statement can be held true come what may, if we make drastic enough adjustments elsewhere in the system [of our beliefs]." For the "totality of our so-called knowledge or beliefs, from the most causal matters of geography and history to the profoundest laws of atomic physics or even of pure mathematics and logic, is a manmade fabric which impinges on experience only along the edges", so that "a conflict with experience at the periphery occasions readjustments in the interior of the field".

But, said Quine, "no particular experiences are linked with any particular statements in the interior of the field", contrary to what empiricists had dogmatically assumed. Locke and Hume had held that the basic ingredients of our knowledge are sensory impressions (or the terms for them). For Bentham and later Frege, and the logical positivists, it was the individual statement, not the individual term, that was to be matched against experience.

Quine argued that "our statements about the external world face the tribunal of sense experience not individually but only as a corporate body". Since any observation sentence is theory-laden, the "unit of empirical significance is the whole of science".

Later, Quine would argue for a more "moderate holism" in which not the whole of science, but sizeable chunks of it, were the units for empirical revision. And he urged the "maxim of minimum mutilation" in revising. But he always declared that philosophy and science were in the same boat, a boat which, as in Neurath's simile, we are forced to rebuild plank by plank while staying afloat in it. For "there is no external vantage point, no first philosophy" by which to remodel it from outside - it is never docked and crewless on dry land.

Two Dogmas Of Empiricism established his reputation universally. It was published with other articles in From A Logical Point Of View (the title being suggested by a calypso number of Harry Belafonte's) in 1953, while Quine was Eastman professor at Oxford.

Word And Object (1960) attacked prevailing philosophical theories which see meanings as objects in a museum of ideas, with verbal expressions as their arbitrary, interchangeable labels. Quine agreed with Wittgenstein and with the pragmatist John Dewey that language is a form of behaviour. He introduced the concept of an utterance's "stimulus meaning" - the set of stimulations which would prompt a person to assent to that utterance.

But, he said, whereas assent and dissent are ascertainable in kindred or culturally similar languages, there is no guarantee that just because the speaker of a radically foreign language ("Jungle") always says "Gavagai" when a rabbit runs past, he means "Rabbit" or "Lo, a rabbit". The word could equally well mean "undetached rabbit-part" or "rabbithood", and a Jungle-speaker's assent or dissent in the presence of assorted stimulations proves inconclusive.

The usual checks against other parts of a language are impossible, since they involve the use of parts of speech, identity concepts, and "if thens", which are also all up for grabs when translating Jungle into English. In such cases of "radical translation", different translators, working independently on Jungle, could thus produce quite divergent manuals of translation, each compatible with the totality of the native-speakers' verbal behaviour, but incompatible with one another. And furthermore, Quine argued, the reason for this is not that we can never know which of these translations is correct.

The "indeterminacy of translation" he had diagnosed also involves "the inscrutability of reference". Since there is no language-independent meaning of "Gavagai" or any other expression, there is no determinate classification of what exists, only ontological relativity: what a theory says exists is relative to the manual of translation it uses.

Quine's prolific output and obsession with travelling continued up to and beyond his retirement. He preferred to learn his audience's German, Spanish, Portuguese or whatever, and lecture in that rather than English. He was distinguished by his openness and generosity to students, acknowledging the "close collaboration" on Word and Object of Donald Davidson, then a Harvard classics student, later to be a renowned philosopher.

Quine is often considered a behaviourist (someone who sees all mental life as nothing more than observable behaviour). Certainly he claimed that behaviourism is essential in linguistics, but he eventually adopted Davidson's anomalous monism, which holds that, although there is nothing over and above the physical, our mental states cannot neatly be identified with our brain states, or subsumed under physical laws.

As for the immemorial problem of how we can know about the world around us, his "naturalised epistemology" relocated the problem as that of how we learn to talk about things. If there is any dualistic split, it is not that between mind and body, but between physical objects, including humans, and the concepts that refer to them.

"I have been accused of denying consciousness," Quine said, "but I am not conscious of having done so." Indicatively, however, his 1985 autobiography, The Time Of My Life, is little more than a travel itinerary, so devoid of emotion and internality as almost to suggest not only that he had neither, but hardly even knew what they might be.

Quine had many friends, a very happy second marriage, loved Dixieland jazz and played the banjo in jazz groups. He is survived by two daughters from his first marriage, and a son and daughter from his second, and several grandchildren.

webTitle: Courts make Bush confront race issue

fields.headline: Courts make Bush confront race issue
fields.standfirst:
Affirmative action cases pave way for showdown

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Affirmative action cases pave way for showdown.
fields.body:
Does a student benefit intellectually from studying at a university that is racially diverse? That question and the wider issue of affirmative action in education may be one of the first big issues to confront George W Bush when he becomes president next month.

A court case due to start in January and another just completed set the stage for a confrontation between those who believe in taking action to ensure that universities are culturally diverse and those who say the policy discriminates against white people.

Last week a US district court in Detroit upheld the right of the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor to promote a racially diverse student body by its admissions policy. The court dismissed the action brought by the Centre for Individual Rights, a conservative group in Washington, which argued that whites were being discriminated.

Judge Patrick Duggan said the university had presented "solid evidence regarding the educational benefits that flow from a racially and ethnically diverse student body".

On January 15 a different judge is due to hear a similar action against the university's law school. The cases highlight an issue that featured only briefly in the presidential election campaign when Al Gore reaffirmed his support for the policy in one of the televised debates and Mr Bush said he believed only in "affirmative access".

The case was brought on behalf of Jennifer Gratz and Patrick Hamacher, described in the submissions as "Caucasian residents of the state of Michigan" who had applied unsuccessfully for admission between 1995 and 1997.

The current admissions policy gives black, Latino and Native American students, students from poor backgrounds, and outstanding athletes, a 20-point bonus on a 150-point scale.

At present 8% of the university's 38,000 students are black, 4% Latino and just under 1% Native American. This is double the number of minority students in 1988. The university justifies the policy on the grounds that all students benefit intellectually because heterogeneity promotes sharper critical thinking.

Affirmative action, introduced in the wake of the civil rights movement to offset discrimination in education andemployment, has become a rallying point for conservative politicians.

In 1996 the US court of appeals ruled against the University of Texas law school, which had implemented the policy.

Other US universities then changed their admissions policies.

But the University of Michigan, under its liberal president Lee Bollinger, continued with the policy, on the grounds stated in its defence submission, that diversity increased the intellectual vitality of its education, scholarship, service, and communal life.

The policy was only examined in detail when a university professor of philosophy, Carl Cohen, discovered it and publicised it.

People who felt they had been discriminated against were asked to identify themselves, and the centre began its action.

Prof Cohen was backed by the conservative right while the university was supported by 20 of the world's best-known corporations, including Dow Chemicals, Procter and Gamble, Microsoft, Kelloggs, Eastman Kodak and Texaco.

The latest decision and the one in January will almost certainly be taken to appeal, probably as far as the supreme court.

The litigation has been given an added frisson by the playing-out of the presidential election, which led many to conclude that the supreme court's decisions on such matters may be motivated as much by political allegiances as strict interpretation of the law.

Related stories
Florida moves to hand Bush victory
Jonathan Freedland: a nation divided

fields.headline: Europe and the media
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: It would be sad indeed if large swathes of the newspaper reading public found their appetite for European Union news undiminished over the Christmas holiday. In the main the politicians have kept their heads down on this topic, and the newspapers have allowed them to do so. But there have been chinks...
fields.body:
It would be sad indeed if large swathes of the newspaper reading public found their appetite for European Union news undiminished over the Christmas holiday. In the main the politicians have kept their heads down on this topic, and the newspapers have allowed them to do so. But there have been chinks, moments when a fearless page-planner, weary of white hell and Railtrack, has let those two capital letters, E and U, creep into a headline.

It would have been surprising if the Brits missed an opportunity to say "Good riddance" to the French presidency of the EU, but in fact only two papers, both of them among the more Euro-supportive and less Francophobe, paid much attention to this baton change. The Financial Times published a cool but savage critique of France's six months in charge, culminating in "Mr Chirac's mishandling of the Nice summit" which meant that "Gerhard Schroeder, the German chancellor, looks set to be the dominant figure in the EU in 2001."

To the FT the French presidency could mark a turning point in EU affairs, after which France will no longer be able to assume power and influence greater than its status. "By overplaying France's hand, Mr Chirac managed to antagonise the EU's 10 smaller member states, the Commission and its president Romano Prodi, Germany, the EU's biggest power, and the candidate countries of eastern and central Europe." Somehow Britain doesn't seem so isolated after that indictment of the French from the FT, bringing the authority of a paper with a reputation throughout Europe and a consistent sympathy for the European project.

The Guardian, too, bid the French presidency adieu, but in its case leaned heavily on views from within France. Who needs to lob in grenades when there is plenty of insurrection within? The Guardian referred to even the French media describing the presidency as a "six month political fiasco", and quoted the daily Liberation as saying: "The treaty of Nice is a failure ... and the way France conducted the inter-governmental conference that produced it has led to an unprecedented avalanche of criticism."

The Guardian also quoted a diplomat from one of the smaller member states saying, "This has been perhaps the worst EU presidency ever. France has acted like a bull in a china shop."

The one Nice issue that won't go away is the European rapid reaction force (RRF) or "army" to its critics. Here there has been much partial reporting, and as has gradually become clear not all of it has been from those critical of the concept. Tony Blair, Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, and Lord Robertson, secretary general of Nato, formed a strong alliance to assure the public Nato had no worries about the RRF. The Daily Mail and the Daily Telegraph, in particular, paraded numerous spokesman, military and political, to assert that the opposite was true.

This week the Mail reported that President-elect Bush's choice as defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, was "known to be suspicious about plans for a European Army." And the Daily Telegraph published a letter from two senior right wing US senators, Jesse Helms and Gordon Smith, describing the RRF as "a dangerous and divisive dynamic within Nato."

The Financial Times, however, in an editorial this week argued in favour of the European defence dimension, as a way of securing more defence spending in Europe and making troops more rapidly deployable. "George W Bush should not listen to those in Britain who portray the EU initiative as a French plot to create an alternative security umbrella to Nato," said the FT. "The alliance has managed for a long time to cope with France's aspirations, and will probably continue to do so. It is in the best interests of all Nato's members that the EU force succeeds."

The turn-of-the-year mood in the newspapers gives more emphasis to the domestic than the European, because they expect a general election in May. But the two are linked, and they are linked through the Tory leader William Hague whose anti-European stance is central to his election platform.

The Times provided some support through extensive coverage of the views of Lord Blackwell, billed on page one and two as a 'key advisor' and 'policy guru' to John Major when he was prime minister, and under an article on page 16 by Blackwell himself as chairman of the Centre for Policy Studies, the well-known Thatcherite policy group. Blackwell advises Hague to free Britain from "the centralist ratchet imposed by the continental ambition for an integrated social market European state." He prefers a relationship with the EU such as that enjoyed by Mexico or Switzerland.

One new year prediction that requires little insight is that the Euro-debate will provide much election noise, even if the public still rank it low in any list of key issues. And lest William Hague is tempted to relax in the knowledge that at least he has his party behind him over this issue, The Times sent a message this week in the form of this headline: "Rifkind emerges as future Tory leader." He is, said The Times, "a pragmatist who would be able to keep the party together on the key European question."

webTitle: Coal makes Oslo king of the isles

fields.headline: Coal makes Oslo king of the isles
fields.standfirst: Norway believes mining is the key to keeping Svalbard out of the hands of foreigners  hands
fields.trailText: Norway believes mining is the key to keeping Svalbard out of the hands of foreigners hands.
fields.body:
The world's most northerly bust of Lenin gazes down past the empty kindergarten towards the block of flats which gulls now use as a nesting site. On the side of the mountain is the huge scar of a coal mine - a clue to this deserted settlement of Pyramiden.

The mountain, shot through with coal seams, once supported a community of 1,000 Russians in this model town only 550 miles from the north pole.

But this desolate spot is not in Russia. It is in Norway, on the group of islands called Svalbard, known in Britain as Spitsbergen after the largest of them. In the post-cold-war economy Russia cannot afford to keep alive this excuse for a presence in a Nato country.

Fifty Russians are mining the site for scrap. They return in the spring when the light comes back after four months of darkness. This summer they were loading spare parts for their other settlement on Svalbard, the more southerly town of Barentsburg, where coal is still dug out and shipped to Russia.

No one on Svalbard or in Norway knows whether the Barentsburg mine makes money. Only someone deep in the Kremlin has the answers. The axe could fall at any time.

Norway is concerned about its future. If coalmining ceases how can Svalbard be kept going as a year-round settlement and maintained as Norwegian territory?

It was coal that changed Svalbard from a whaling and sealing outpost to a proper settlement. Once there were seven Norwegian mines to underpin Oslo's claim to the place; now there is one, and that is kept open mainly for the one coal-burning power station, which supplies the capital, Longyearbyen.

Maintaining a coal industry in a country with huge oil exports and plenty of gas, hydropower and untapped wind energy, the idea of keeping seems unnecessary, particularly when the Norwegian government is potentially embarrassed by its contribution to global warming.

But the Norwegians are intent on keeping Svalbard alive and, to make sure there are no rival claims to sovereignty, continuously occupied by more Norwegians than Russians or any other nationality.

Consequently there is a proposal to open a new mine on Spitsbergen to exploit vast recently discovered reserves. Coal seams five metres thick could produce 700,000 tonnes of high calorific value coal a year and make a profit without subsidies, even in a country whose labour costs are among the highest in the world.

The business case is important, because Norway needs to avoid the embarrassment of subsidising a polluting industry, when, for political reasons, it decides to go ahead with the mine.

Its fear of losing sovereignty of its most northerly settlement runs deep, because Iceland, Russia and even the Dutch and British have claimed Svalbard as their own in recent history.

After the first world war Norway was given control of the islands under the Svalbard Treaty. Any country that acknowledged the islands as Norwegian soil and signed the treaty was allowed to mine and conduct scientific experiments on Svalbard, provided it accepted local jurisdiction. To date 39 countries have accepted the deal.

Spying post

In the cold war this continued to suit everyone, because Svalbard was an important spying post for both sides. As the most northerly ice-free area of any significance, easily accessible by air, and commanding the route the Russian northern fleet needed to reach its base, it was occupied by many a listening post disguised as a coal mine or scientific station.

Ten years after the cold war the Norwegians are anxious to secure the future of the area. They have encouraged tourism: in summer Longyearbyen is a favourite calling place for cruise ships, and young people come to snowmobile, ski and trek across the wilderness. A gun is a must, to ward off hungry polar bears.

Their second strategy to maintain the population is to make Svalbard a centre for science. In 1993 the four Norwegian universities established a campus for 300 staff and students. There are more than 20 scientific stations from foreign countries, including two from Britain, which study everything from outer space to the tiniest Arctic plants, and such problems as upper atmospheric ozone loss and global climate change.

Although some of these activities keep people on Svalbard all the year round, the population plunges in winter. Without the coal industry, which demands continuous production to make it viable, the islands would be deserted in the winter months.

Carl Kilander, head of the Svalbard governor's environment section, said: "This is the largest area of pristine wilderness in Europe, but our population came from coal, and a stable family community is what we need. We have the only power plant driven by coal in Norway. We would be pushed to stay a proper year-round capital without a mine."

That is why the proposed new mine has assumed such political importance, despite the apparent contradiction of a country with no need for coal exploiting new reserves.

Robert Hermansen, the managing director of the mining company, said: "To keep control of Svalbard we have to have a community here. If we left the Russians would immediately claim it. I am under no illusions.

"For our part, we realised we could not continue with the subsidies that we got without question in the cold war, so we have shown we can have a new mine which makes money.

"The rest is up to the government, but I am confident than we will win a future for coal in Svalbard, and keep the islands Norwegian as a result."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Turkish denial | Fugitive returns | Sudanese polls
fields.body:
Turkish denial
The Turkish justice ministry has denied that the security forces killed and tortured prisoners during raids on prisons last week in which at least 31 people died. A statement published by the semi-official Anatolian news agency answers accusations by prisoners freed under a mass amnesty. Reuters
Istanbul

Fugitive returns
A man still wanted for hijacking an Indian Airlines plane in 1971 surrendered to police yesterday on arriving in New Delhi from Europe.

Hashim Qureshi, a founder of the separatist Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, who has spent nine years in a Pakistan jail and 14 years in the Netherlands.
Reuters
New Delhi

Sudanese polls

General Omar el-Bashir has been re-elected president of Sudan, winning 86.5% of the vote in polls marred by an opposition boycott, the authorities said yesterday.

The nearest challenger was former president Gaafar Nimeiri, who won 9.6%. Civil war prevented voting in three of the 26 provinces of Sudan.
AP
Khartoum

webTitle: Rory Carroll on strolling in Rome

fields.headline: Walking the walk - with the baggage
fields.trailText: Dictionaries translate  passeggiata as a walk, stroll or promenade, but that is because the people who compile them do not live on my street. They do not experience the richness the word embodies.
fields.body:
Dictionaries translate passeggiata as a walk, stroll or promenade, but that is because the people who compile them do not live on my street. They do not experience the richness the word embodies.

It is a noun which demands adjectives: glossy, ironed, polished, tight, taut, bare, expensive, luscious, sleek. It is a catwalk of thousands competing for attention. It is a phenomenon.

From early evening the Via del Corso fills and swarms until the pedestrians become phalanxes blocking the road to cars and scooters. True, the pedestrians are putting one foot in front of the other, but to describe that as walking is like calling Ernest Hemingway a typist.

The nightly ritual is an expression, a declaration of self performed by rich and poor, young and old, couples and groups, individuals and families, and me.

The rules are these: clothed and groomed to maximum sexiness, you sashay past shops, ogle the talent, exchange gossip, flirt, admire the successfully coordinated, disdain the unsuccessful, and exude a sense of being on stage.

Break the rules, as I do every Saturday, and there is a price to pay. Returning from the supermarket, I have no choice but to trudge up the street laden with grocery bags, exuding nothing but a desire to get home.

Hard stares remind me that cornflakes, apples, toilet rolls and washing-up liquid are precisely the sort of banal intrusions which risk breaking the passeggiata's spell.

More imaginative souls regard my bags as daring deviations guaranteed to grab attention, and thus props worthy of inspection. And they do inspect, so brazenly that I'm tempted to place the more exotic purchases at the top of the pile.

All Italian villages, towns and cities do the passeggiata, but few manage it with the brio of Rome's Via del Corso.

It is a road which has always been about spectacle. Stretching for almost a mile from Piazza del Popolo to Piazza Venezia, in past centuries it hosted horse races and festival parades.

Now the spectators are the show. Jewellery-encrusted women accompany ageing beaux resplendent in knee-length wool coats. Teenage girls flash brown tummies and brown lipstick at young bucks with enhanced bulges.

That you may be unemployed with zero prospects matters not, as long as your shirt is clean, your shoes polished, and your one pair of Levi 501s fits perfectly. With enough effort even the broke can look a million dollars.

But the so-called coatti, kids from grim suburbs who stream into the centre to chew gum and swagger, have decided they no longer want to glide up the social scale to match the wealthy.

"Coattismo is the cultivation of the vulgar, the cheeky, the sexual, the aggressive, and has its roots in a distinctly Roman kind of machismo," the historian Anthony Majanlahti says.

Celebrating this change is a hugely successful rap song, Supercafone (Supertrash).

A girl in a skirt is the cue for staring, lip-smacking and whistling. Boorish? Certainly, but during the passeggiata it would be rude not to.

fields.headline: Czech TV journalists battle on
fields.trailText: Journalists continued to occupy the studios of Czech state television in Prague yesterday in defiance of its new director general: a dispute which puts the future of public broadcasting and the government itself in doubt.
fields.body:
Journalists continued to occupy the studios of Czech state television in Prague yesterday in defiance of its new director general: a dispute which puts the future of public broadcasting and the government itself in doubt.

President Vaclav Havel has backed the journalists, who have been putting out their own programmes on cable and satellite channels since the director general pulled the plug on them. Thousands of Czechs have braved the cold each night to demonstrate outside the television building in support of the journalists.

The dispute began just before Christmas after the new director general, Jiri Hodac, appointed a news editor who had been an adviser to Vaclav Klaus, the parliamentary opposition leader and a longstanding rival of Mr Havel.

Since then journalists have barricaded themselves in the studios and refused Mr Hodac entry.

He threatened to evict them, and the tension was increased by a bomb scare on Thursday. The journalists refused to leave the building and the police went in to investigate, but found no bomb.

Mr Hodac controls the transmitters, and for several nights during the peak Christmas period Czechs watched news programmes put together by his supporters in outside studios. On Wednesday these were replaced by a message saying that normal service would not resume until the parliamentary council decided which side was right.

Mr Hodac himself is regarded as close to Mr Klaus. Earlier this year he resigned as head of the station's news department after journalists protested at his sacking of an anchorman, allegedly because Mr Klaus complained about the way the man had interviewed him.

His appointment as director infuriated the professional staff. His choice of a Klaus adviser as news editor was the last straw.

Mr Klaus's complaints of discourtesy by interviewers were reportedly backed by Milos Zeman, prime minister in the Social Democratic party minority government, which is "tolerated" by Mr Klaus: he has agreed not to vote against it in return for jointly approved legislation.

Many Czechs are unhappy about the deal, which has resulted in jobs going to cronies of both the big parties.

The wider issue is whether the republic can maintain a real public broadcasting system independent of the big parties and the commercial tycoons who have built up the private television sector and taken over most of the country's newspapers.

In most of the former Soviet Union and eastern Europe state television is still dominated by the government. Until this year the Czech Republic had managed to do better.

Mr Havel said he accepted that Mr Hodac was legally the director, but he accused him of "violating the spirit of the law". The issue is unlikely to be resolved until January 5, when parliament holds a special session to consider it.

webTitle: After 13 years, Enniskillen claims another victim

fields.headline: After 13 years, Enniskillen claims another victim
fields.standfirst:
Headmaster Ronnie Hill, in a coma since the IRA's Poppy Day bombing, was lovingly nursed by his wife Noreen

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Headmaster Ronnie Hill, in a coma since the IRA's Poppy Day bombing, was lovingly nursed by his wife Noreen.
fields.body:
For 13 years, Ronnie Hill's every breath, cough or sigh held special meaning for his wife Noreen.

She devoted almost all her waking hours to nursing him since he lapsed into a coma after sustaining horrific injuries in the Enniskillen IRA bombing which killed 11 people on November 8 1987.

Supported by her family and her faith, Noreen bore an immense burden with strength and patience. "I am a weak woman but I have a strong God," is her disarmingly simple explanation.

Now that the Poppy Day atrocity has finally claimed his life, she admitted a sense of relief that his suffering was over. But there is also loneliness at the death of the man she was married to for 44 years.

"It was no life for a man who was so active in the past," she said. "But I know he was aware of what was going on around him these past 13 years and I feel his loss.

"He couldn't speak or even smile, but, sitting at his side for hours on end, I know he heard and understood what was said to him. You learned to listen to the sound of his breathing, any movement. You knew if he was peaceful or in pain.

"We read to him every day, often from the Scriptures, although we didn't talk for long spells as we didn't know how good his concentration was."

Ronnie, who was 69 when he died, was Enniskillen high school's headteacher. He was at the Cenotaph with his bible class when the bomb exploded. A wall collapsed, burying him alive and he was rescued only when someone spotted his gloved hand sticking out of the rubble.

His injuries included a smashed pelvis and jawbone, Two days later he was in a coma.

At first, Noreen prayed for a miracle. But gradually she realised he would never recover. "We hoped the Lord would heal him, but it wasn't to be and we had to accept that."

She has steadfastly refused to allow herself bitter feelings towards the bombers. "I've never wanted to come face to face with them but I forgave them. There is no anger in my heart. It is too heavy a burden for the person who feels it."

A Presbyterian born in Dublin, Ronnie held a similarly loving philosophy. "Catholic, Protestant, it was all the same to him," said Noreen. "Long before there was much talk about cross-community work, Ronnie was working with Catholic teachers, bringing the two sides together.

"He believed young people should be educated to know the other side hadn't horns and that everyone should grow up together, respecting each other."

Noreen and Ronnie met at a church social in Kilkeel, Co Down, in the early 1950s and spent six years in Africa as missionaries before moving to Enniskillen.

"He was devoted to his pupils and family. He was very interested in sport and used to coach rugby, football and cricket."

Ronnie proved his devotion when Noreen became ill with cancer about two years before the bombing and underwent intensive chemotherapy and radiotherapy. She would have been at the war memorial with him that fateful morning had she not been feeling unwell. She believes it was God's will that she made a full recovery and was able to care for him.

Ronnie spent four years in Erne hospital but then Noreen gave up her house in Enniskillen and bought a nursing home in Holywood, Co Down, which she helps to run with some of her family.

Her children, Avril, Marilyn, Siobhan and Keith, are a comfort to her, as are the six grandchildren Ronnie never met.

Noreen intends to stay on in the nursing home where she will help look after 16 elderly residents. "The eldest is 90, and they need me, too."

webTitle: Galapagos tortoises dragged into fishing war

fields.headline: Galapagos turmoil
fields.standfirst: Tortoises dragged into fishing war
fields.trailText: Tortoises dragged into fishing war.
fields.body:
The normally tranquil Galapagos islands have become the scene of a struggle between conservationists and fishermen, who have taken giant tortoises hostage in their fight for bigger quotas.

In recent months fishermen on the archipelago where Charles Darwin developed his theories of evolution have also ransacked a research station and harassed tourists.

The dispute centres on fishing for sharks and sea cucumbers and the islanders' wish to use modern techniques banned in Galapagos waters.

"We are resentful of the authorities because they don't let us fish," said Vincent Torres, a resident of Isabela island, the largest in the chain. "They come and tell us that now we cannot do the same things we have done for a lifetime."

But conservationists are afraid that increased fishing will devastate one of the world's best-preserved areas of marine life. The archipelago, 600 miles west of the Ecuadorean mainland, has species of plants and animals, including the giant tortoise, not found elsewhere.

Much of the turmoil stems from a 1998 law which gave residents more political autonomy but also set up a marine reserve extending 40 miles offshore. Within the reserve, only tourism and local small-scale fishing are permitted.

The problem is also a consequence of the increasing population of the islands and the difficulty many face in trying to survive. In 1950 there were 1,000 islanders. Now there are 16,000, and the number is rising by 6% a year, despite efforts to curb it.

The fishermen have powerful allies in Ecuador's commercial fishing industry.

"I am in agreement with the demonstrations of discontent by the fishermen, because it is tourism and the increased population on the islands that are harming the ecosystem," said Cesar Rohon, president of Ecuador's national chamber of fishing trade.

"To administer fishing one must understand it, and the government does not know what resources are available in the Galapagos," he added.

"The ecologists, who have international support, don't know what to do with those resources."

Fernando Espinoza, executive director of the Charles Darwin Foundation research centre, said wider commercial interests were behind the protests.

"We know there are people who have offered to buy entire catches of lobster, sea cucumbers and shark fins from the fishermen of the Galapagos islands. It is a tremendous business," he said.

It is a business that has attracted more fishermen from Ecuador's mostly poor mainland population. This year 939 took part in the Galapagos lobster catch - almost double the number registered a year earlier.

The increase not only depleted the lobster population at a dangerous rate, it also decreased annual earnings for each fisherman, the Darwin Centre said. It also made other catches on the islands, including shark fins and sea cucumbers, more attractive.

Shark fins are a delicacy in many Asian countries and fetch as much as £66 a kilo. The fishermen can sell the sea cucumbers, which are crucial to the shallow water ecosystem, for 60p a piece.

"Fishermen who can get a couple of thousand sea cucumbers are doing as well as a dope dealer selling cocaine on the mainland," said John McCosker, chairman of aquatic biology at the California Academy of Sciences.

Last month, under pressure from the fishermen, the government raised the lobster limit from 50 to 80 tonnes.

Environmentalists said it was "institutionalising blackmail".

Mr McCosker said: "It's tragic, the short-term gain of a few fishermen versus the long-term survival of the Galapagos. They are killing the golden goose."

webTitle: Euro campaign champs at the bit

fields.headline: Euro campaign champs at the bit
fields.standfirst: Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: The Britain in Europe campaign is to pile pressure on the government to join a single currency by staging its own assessment of the Treasury's five economic tests.
fields.body:
The Britain in Europe campaign is to pile pressure on the government to join a single currency by staging its own assessment of the Treasury's five economic tests.

But the group - which has close links with Downing Street - has agreed to lay off hard campaigning on the currency until after the general election.

It has agreed with pro-Europe ministers and trade unionists on what is being described as a flyover strategy for the election itself.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, has said he will make the Treasury's assessment of the five economic tests soon after the election, but has not set a date.

With some economists claiming the tests are largely subjective, there has been a suspicion that if the government felt a referendum could not be won, the Treasury would conclude the tests had not been met.

Some ministers believe the authority of a second term Labour government would be exploded if it went for a referendum and lost.

Britain in Europe's decision to set up a panel of economists to assess the tests will unnerve the Treasury. The conclusions of any such panel are bound to be taken seriously. If it said the tests were met, a Labour government's ability to recommend rejection would be much more difficult.

The five tests ask whether membership would be good for jobs and investment, and whether the British and European economies have reached long term sustainable convergence.

Throughout its short life, the business-backed campaign has been under pressure from Downing Street not to demand that a Labour government take sterling into the euro. This has led to tensions with pro-European Conservatives, such as Michael Heseltine and Kenneth Clarke.

Instead the campaign has a platform for Britain to join a successful single currency when the time is ripe. Its senior members are determined to abandon their self-restraint after the election.

In a sign of intent, its chief economist, Kitty Ussher, claimed yesterday that the volatility of sterling outside the euro was a factor in 41,262 job losses this year - a figure representing the sum of all announcements of manufacturing job losses in Britain in which volatility between the pound and the euro was cited as a factor behind the decision.

If the effect on the supply chain were taken into account, as many as 66,000 jobs could have been lost in 2000, wholly or partly due to sterling's position outside the euro.

fields.headline: Ghanaian opposition leads in poll
fields.trailText: The Ghanaian opposition leader, John Agyekum Kuffuor, had a strong lead in partial results announced yesterday in the runoff to elect a successor to the longstanding president, Jerry Rawlings.
fields.body:
The Ghanaian opposition leader, John Agyekum Kuffuor, had a strong lead in partial results announced yesterday in the runoff to elect a successor to the longstanding president, Jerry Rawlings.

With ballots counted in 109 of the 200 constituencies, Mr Kuffuor, a British-trained lawyer and veteran politician, had 60% of the vote and John Atta Mills, the vice-president and Mr Rawlings' choice as his successor, had 40%.

Nearly 11m voters were registered for Thursday's ballot, but the turnout was not immediately announced.

The elections mark the end of an era for Ghana, where President Rawlings leaves office on January 7, after his elected second term. The charismatic former fighter pilot won multiparty elections in 1992 and 1996, but is barred by the constitution, which he approved, from standing for another four-year term.
AP

fields.headline: Funny ha ha
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... the comedy of (Guardian) errors
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... the comedy of (Guardian) errors.
fields.body:
No one who reads the daily corrections column in the Guardian regularly could be in much doubt about its serious intent. It recounts sad tales of libels, misquotations, distortions and occasional plagiarisms. These fall above a line I imagine dividing them from corrections dealing with less serious errors which often have an intrinsic humour.

I shall digress. I once took a photo of poet Vernon Watkins, on the cliffs near his home on the Gower. The landscape was perfectly sharp but he was slightly fuzzy. I sent him a copy and received a note back saying, "The photograph's fine but I seem to have got in the way." I feel like that about the comedy in our corrections. Who am I to stand in the way?

Many readers seem to share the opinion that the world is not so perfect that its burdens do not need lightening by a laugh. Indeed, I sometimes wonder if there is any length to which they would not go. For example, towards the end of November David Austin's cartoon on the letters page of the Guardian offered a droll comment on Lady Thatcher's attack on Mr Blair for his commitment to a European rapid reaction force. It showed a military man, in front of a briefing board, demonstrating the Mark 1 Handbag.

This brought a postcard from a reader - anonymous, alas - with the comment, "No! Not the Mark 1." On the other side, a griffin-demon from the 9th century BC, one of the protective gods carved on the walls of the royal palace of Assurnasipal II at Nimrud, Assyria, carrying something just like Margaret Thatcher's trademark handbag.

I shall digress again on the subject of handbags. When working for the BBC in Broadcasting House, where I used to write the news, a certain newsreader used the intercom from the studio where she was reading it to demand her handbag. A frantic search started as the tape being played neared its end and she screamed one last request for "my handbag". At that moment I found it and dashed in with it. "You fool," she hissed, "I said my hand-back" (a piece of paper bearing the words, "And now back to so and so in the such and such programme"). In the words of a favourite cartoon from the New Yorker - a prophet of doom tramping the streets with a revised placard: "Hey! Everybody makes mistakes."

It has been suggested that, commendable though it may be to mock our own pretensions, there is something cruel in it since someone, living and breathing, made the boob that causes us such merriment. To all my colleagues whose labours have been lost in laughter, I offer the following quotation from Herman Melville's great book Moby Dick:

"A good laugh is a mighty good thing, and rather too scarce a good thing; the more's the pity. So, if any one man, in his own proper person, afford stuff for a good joke to anybody, let him not be backward, but let him cheerfully allow himself to spend and be spent in that way. And the man that has anything bountifully laughable about him, be sure there is more to that man than you perhaps think for."

In this spirit I announce the following as the winner of the readers' editor's personal prize for the year 2000, a correction we published just over a month ago:

"In a report headed Stranger than Fiction, pages two and three, G2, about Florida and its way with elections, we said 'a man in south-central Florida was charged with shooting his dog because he suspected it of being gay'. The reporter who covered the case [Rick Cundiff of the Ocala Star-Banner] says the dog, a neutered Yorkshire terrier-poodle cross, was not shot but struck on the head with a plastic piece of a vacuum cleaner, because the owner believed he was attempting an unnatural act with a Jack Russell terrier. The blow fractured the dog's skull and a local veterinary surgeon put the dog down. The dog's owner was sentenced to six months in prison, a term now nearing its end. Finally, Ocala is in north-central Florida, rather than south-central."

As the editor of the Guardian remarked the day the correction was published, "I'm glad we cleared that up."

The runner-up is a correction which shows the fallibility of memory and the advantages of research: "The Idlewild album reviewed on April 21, is called 100 Broken Windows, not 200 Broken Mirrors."

Finally, perhaps I should quote one of the corrections of corrections; or better still, the correction of a correction of a correction that appeared in 1998 after attempts on two previous days to get right the name of Charles Darwin's house and village. Perhaps not, that would be too masochistic (even with the solace of Melville).

A happy, and not too pedantic, new year to you all.
