fields.headline: Prosperous old capital strains against its boundaries
fields.standfirst: Following MPs' warnings that prosperity creates problems, Guardian reporters investigate two cases
fields.trailText: Following MPs' warnings that prosperity creates problems, Guardian reporters investigate two cases.
fields.body:
Unemployment has fallen to an all-time low. House prices are soaring, with prime city centre properties fetching over £1m. Developers are queuing for every available piece of land to accommodate new businesses and a fast-expanding population.

While most British and some European cities are shedding people and jobs, Edinburgh is out-performing them all to become the fastest growing centre in the UK, topping most quality of life surveys.

So successful has the city become in attracting financial and high technology companies that, in common with south-east England, it is experiencing a shortage of workers.

New figures show that Donald Anderson, Labour leader of Edinburgh council, can boast that in many respects the city's economy is healthier than London's.

Unemployment, at 2.7%, is half the London level, down by three-quarters in four years. Mr Anderson recently reported that youth unemployment, the plague of other cities, is no longer a problem in Edinburgh. In the 16-24 age group, only 27 had been out of work for more than a year.

Buoyed by the prestige of a parliament and a strengthening financial centre second only to the City of London, the Scottish capital is poised for its biggest expansion since the creation of its 18th century Georgian new town, with its elegant terraces and circuses.

With its population projected to rise by 50,000 to 490,000 in the next 14 years - and the likelihood of 25,000 new jobs in the next four years alone - land in a redesignated green belt has been earmarked for a 21st century "new town".

The wedge between the Craigmiller housing scheme and Dalkeith, Midlothian, a joint venture between the city council and a local developer, could house 20,000 by 2020. With schools, shopping centre and modern transport links to the city, the 1,400 hectare (3,500 acre) area underlines the pressure facing the city.

Edinburgh is designated a world heritage site and thus protected from rash development, so there is precious little building land left. As a result, demand is growing for the release of more green belt. "There is not a patch of land which developers do not have an option on, so we are trying to consolidate expansion to protect the rest of the city," said Mr Anderson.

"We don't want to lose the big attraction of Edinburgh that you can be in open countryside after driving just 10 minutes from the city centre."

To maintain a level of prosperity which has brought Edinburgh a new financial district in its west end - helping to swell funds under management to £350bn - the city will increasingly have to look beyond its borders for workers.

Last month plans were unveiled to reopen part of a railway line linking Edinburgh with the Scottish Borders - emerging commuter territory - which closed 30 years ago. Councillors hope the line could reopen by 2008, under a public-private partnership, after the Scottish parliament passes a special order.

While talk of a Scottish "home counties" might be premature, businesspeople and councillors in Edinburgh believe more commuting will be needed to service the growing economy. Many people are being priced out of the housing market, while 20,000 are on the council waiting list for rented homes.

Simon Fairclough, marketing director of the Edinburgh Solicitors Property Centre, said: "Builders are selling off the drawing board." Some properties in the new town go for over £1m.

Ray Perman, chief executive of Scottish financial enterprise, said many big institutions were moving to Edinburgh. "They have seen overheating in London, and the difficulty of getting good quality people...English money is moving up here."

Pressures build for rich and poor alike in the new boom towns
fields.bodyText: Unemployment has fallen to an all-time low. House prices are soaring, with prime city centre properties fetching over £1m. Developers are queuing for every available piece of land to accommodate new businesses and a fast-expanding population. While most British and some European cities are shedding people and jobs, Edinburgh is out-performing them all to become the fastest growing centre in the UK, topping most quality of life surveys. So successful has the city become in attracting financial and high technology companies that, in common with south-east England, it is experiencing a shortage of workers. New figures show that Donald Anderson, Labour leader of Edinburgh council, can boast that in many respects the city's economy is healthier than London's. Unemployment, at 2.7%, is half the London level, down by three-quarters in four years. Mr Anderson recently reported that youth unemployment, the plague of other cities, is no longer a problem in Edinburgh. In the 16-24 age group, only 27 had been out of work for more than a year. Buoyed by the prestige of a parliament and a strengthening financial centre second only to the City of London, the Scottish capital is poised for its biggest expansion since the creation of its 18th century Georgian new town, with its elegant terraces and circuses. With its population projected to rise by 50,000 to 490,000 in the next 14 years - and the likelihood of 25,000 new jobs in the next four years alone - land in a redesignated green belt has been earmarked for a 21st century "new town". The wedge between the Craigmiller housing scheme and Dalkeith, Midlothian, a joint venture between the city council and a local developer, could house 20,000 by 2020. With schools, shopping centre and modern transport links to the city, the 1,400 hectare (3,500 acre) area underlines the pressure facing the city. Edinburgh is designated a world heritage site and thus protected from rash development, so there is precious little building land left. As a result, demand is growing for the release of more green belt. "There is not a patch of land which developers do not have an option on, so we are trying to consolidate expansion to protect the rest of the city," said Mr Anderson. "We don't want to lose the big attraction of Edinburgh that you can be in open countryside after driving just 10 minutes from the city centre." To maintain a level of prosperity which has brought Edinburgh a new financial district in its west end - helping to swell funds under management to £350bn - the city will increasingly have to look beyond its borders for workers. Last month plans were unveiled to reopen part of a railway line linking Edinburgh with the Scottish Borders - emerging commuter territory - which closed 30 years ago. Councillors hope the line could reopen by 2008, under a public-private partnership, after the Scottish parliament passes a special order. While talk of a Scottish "home counties" might be premature, businesspeople and councillors in Edinburgh believe more commuting will be needed to service the growing economy. Many people are being priced out of the housing market, while 20,000 are on the council waiting list for rented homes. Simon Fairclough, marketing director of the Edinburgh Solicitors Property Centre, said: "Builders are selling off the drawing board." Some properties in the new town go for over £1m. Ray Perman, chief executive of Scottish financial enterprise, said many big institutions were moving to Edinburgh. "They have seen overheating in London, and the difficulty of getting good quality people...English money is moving up here." Related story: Pressures build for rich and poor alike in the new boom towns

fields.headline: Nice weather for ducks
fields.standfirst: From Anthea Turner to overpaid birds,  Arthur Smith  looks back on his year
fields.trailText: From Anthea Turner to overpaid birds, Arthur Smith looks back on his year
fields.body:
Book of the year

I'm not sure who wrote it - the author has left their name off the novel - but my guess is it may be Will Self. Anthea Turner: Fools Rush In is a comic masterpiece, remorselessly exposing the dangerous vacuity of "celebrity". The central character tells us about her journey, from "humble beginnings to the heart of Planet Fame", in prose so cleverly bland and cliched that you almost believe Anthea really exists. I particularly loved the Flakegate episode, in which our heroine discovers she has become embroiled in a scandal involving her wedding photos, OK magazine and a bar of chocolate. "I couldn't even face leaving my room at the game reserve for a couple of days, my eyes were so puffy from crying." The other three people who bought the book will, I'm sure, agree with me.

Proper book of the year

When a writer dies you get a higher standard of obituary. When the writer is Malcolm Bradbury, who inspired a generation of novelists, eloquence abounds. I can't compete with Ian McEwan or David Lodge, but I too have a fond memory of the former pipeman of the year. I wasn't on the creative writing course but I was an undergraduate at the University of East Anglia and Bradbury was called upon to mark a play I had written. He'd seen me camping it up in a student revue and wrote, "B minus. Best stick to comedy." He was right. Years later I accompanied him, on behalf of Radio 4, to Indiana University, where his papers and manuscripts were being archived. It must have been strange for him to see these fragments of his life preserved under glass, but he charmed everyone within range. I can't remember three days when I laughed so much, drank so much and learned so much. I haven't read To the Hermitage yet, but my friend Simon, who reads everything, tells me it's wonderful. And so was Malcolm Bradbury.

Film of the year

Er, not much. Magnolia? But that was last year.

Photographer of the year

Martin Parr produced an unlikely hit in 1999 with his anthology Boring Postcards. His latest collection, Autoportrait, is made up of pictures taken by studio photographers, street snappers, anyone with a camera and a living to earn, everywhere in the world. The subject is always Martin Parr. We see him leaning into painted sunsets, squatting in front of the Parthenon, posing in a grass skirt, and generally doing what the photographer says - except that he never smiles. The backdrops may be lurid and sentimental, the headgear preposterous, but always at the centre is the inscrutable face of Martin Parr. He is a Magnum photographer, and yet in neither of these two books has he deigned to press the shutter once. What a class act.

TV programme of the year

I have already come out as a Sopranos fancier, and Dom Joly's surreal outdoor japes made me laugh, but the programme that pleased me most was in fact an entire channel. The obscure TV Travel Shop is devoted to selling package holidays. The format is simple: stock footage of a resort, followed by two smiling people in holiday shirts telling you the prices, repeated without end. This sounds soul-witheringly boring, and indeed is, until you have watched it for a few hours. You slowly realise that every holiday is exactly the same. It might be in Spain, the Caribbean, Thailand or the Maldives, but what is on offer is identical. You become mesmerised as, every six minutes, you hear the mantra: "There is a poolside bar, serving drinks all day!" My exclamation mark is deliberate: the presenters say it as though the poolside bar is the most revolutionary notion. Occasionally the presenters are replaced by similar models with different coloured shirts. Once you've watched half a day's worth of this you break into a new dimension. Then you must go to bed.

Play of the year

I nominate The Far Side of the Moon, by and starring Canada's greatest import since Leonard Cohen, Robert Lepage. I do this largely to show off that I have seen something in New York before it comes to Britain but also because, like all Lepage's work, it is original and extraordinary. The last scene is hardly more than Lepage rolling around the stage but it is thrilling. You'll have to see it to find out why when it comes to Newcastle, Glasgow and London in the new year.

Silly PR stunt of the year

I had a meeting with Mark Borkowski, who is more conceptual artist than PR man, to discuss how we might publicise a show I was doing. Under intense interrogation I revealed that in an early version of the piece I had booked a live duck, but had fired it when it turned out to cost £250 a performance. Within two days this fact, suitably embroidered, was in every newspaper, on radio and TV, and I found myself quoted saying: "It's disgraceful that we live in a world where a duck is worth six times more than a human actor." The story was last heard across the Atlantic in the New York Times.

Season of the year

Last winter was unmemorable, spring made little impact, summer, unless you're Scottish, was a no-show. There was essentially no weather for the first nine months of the year. It was an embarrassment for the elements. Then, like streaming cavalry, came autumn. October and November redeemed the preceding months with a sensational downpour. Weather was back, big time. And if I can only take one of my choices to the desert island, Sue, I'll choose the rain; because, as Camille Paglia says, "society is our fragile barrier against nature", and in the end all artistic endeavour, like its human creators, will burn in the great cosmic meltdown.

And a Happy New Year to you all.

fields.headline: Natural lawman
fields.standfirst: His groundbreaking TV dramas attacked police brutality, yet he believes that victims of crime, prejudice and ill-health did something to deserve it in previous lives. His work once prompted questions in parliament, but is the pioneering writer and producer going soft?  Simon Hattenstone  reports
fields.trailText: His groundbreaking TV dramas attacked police brutality, yet he believes that victims of crime, prejudice and ill-health did something to deserve it in previous lives. His work once prompted questions in parliament, but is the pioneering writer and producer going soft? Simon Hattenstone reports
fields.body:
Gordon Frank Newman trawls back half a century. He was six years old, walking home, his shirt stuffed with pears. "I had been given them by a man further up the road who had trees in his garden, and I was actually going past an orchard when a policeman came down the lane and stopped and said: 'What've you got there?' and I said: 'Nothing'. He called me a liar and clomped me round the ears and took the pears and got back in his car and went. I danced across the road, saw stars. I suppose that is where it started."

Newman didn't know the blow had left him deaf in his right ear. He didn't even tell his parents about the incident. The boy who turned into the man who has spent four decades exploring injustice within the justice system, simply got on with life. "Looking back on those circumstances, you see that police do that all the time. Jump to conclusions."

GF Newman first gained recognition for his crime novels. The first, Sir, You Bastard, sold 200,000 copies. But he really made his name with a landmark television series in the late 1970s. Its title couldn't have been a more literal statement of his concerns. Law and Order changed the landscape both of cop shows and British TV. It wasn't so much a drama as an exposé. The performances and mood of the four films, directed with spartan vigour by Les Blair, made you think it had to be real, had to be documentary. A new word was invented to describe Law and Order - faction. Just as radical as the style was the subject matter - Newman showed a police force identical to the criminals they trailed but for the badges.

Young Newman was a bright lad, enthusiastic for life, inquisitive, slightly dyslexic, bored by school. His background was comfortable; dad a structural engineer, mum a housewife. He lived his childhood in his head, fantasising about making a difference, saving the world, being the Superman of St Mary Cray in Kent. "I was the person who'd go in to change the situation and, having righted it, would move on."

He spent a good deal of time bunking off school, smoking with friends when they should have been in class. At 16, he decided to be a movie star and went to a Stanislavsky acting school in Chistelhurst, but it didn't really have time for stars. It was more interested in observation, character, immersion than celebrity. At drama school he wrote a script that was accepted for a cop series.

It wasn't until two decades after the pear incident that Newman again came into contact with the police. He was 24, living in Mayfair, London, and the anti-Vietnam demonstrators were marching past his home near Grosvenor Square. He was as curious as he was naive. "It was jam packed, heaving and the police were charging the crowd on horses. Yet the crowd were equally outrageous because a lot of them had weapons and were stabbing the flanks of the horses. I wasn't aware of animal rights then, but I was outraged."

Newman sits at his BBC desk in White City, back straight, arms crossed, one hand buried in his pocket, the other bearing a red band round his wrist. "It's red energy, red always draws energy, so if you're feeling tired put on a red shirt," he says. He looks smart in a pristine way - cotton suit, white shirt. To his side is a neat row of tangerines, a couple of apples and tomatoes, and a carton of organic apple juice - lunch. He is tall, and his face, his stance, his whole demeanour suggest an ascetic life.

The actor Martin Shaw remembers the first time he met him: "I was startled by him, his physical presence is startling. It was 1989, and he was completely bald, and it wasn't commonplace then. He had these extraordinary piercing blue eyes, and a candour and directness bordering on the alien. His mental frame is echoed by his physical frame - he's as straight as you can get." Shaw, who starred in Newman's For the Greater Good and is the eponymous hero of his new TV drama, Judge John Deed, calls him an extraordinarily good man, and apologises if he sounds pious. "He has a blazing integrity, in his care for people, his humanity - towards people and animals."

That blazing integrity certainly emerged in Law and Order. What was most astonishing about the series of films was Newman's sense of process, of how things were done. Many people asked how Newman knew so much about the law. Most presumed that he was an insider. Ken Campbell, who appeared in Law and Order, says that throughout the filming he never met Newman. "There were lots of rumours that he was an ex-copper, that he had lost an arm, all types of things. Some time later I met him and I was so surprised. I was expecting him to be some kind of heavy, a big Bob Hoskins. But he was so charming, so lightweight, so caring. He's a vegan isn't he?"

The Newman mythology was partly self-created. At a question and answer session at the National Film Theatre after Law and Order was screened, he told the audience that he had been a detective for 14 years and had served 12 years in prison for corruption. He was barely 30 at the time, though his long straggling beard did its best to hide his age. "I thought I was being clever, and that they would just do some smart arithmetic and realise that would have made me about 78. It came back to haunt me."

This was not the only time he has fictionalised his life. Like Len Deighton, he created different characters for the author of his books. One time he was a father of seven, another time a pimp. "I was inventing the expert who had the authority to write this book."

In truth, Newman was simply a writer who knew the value of research. His writing was as complex, at times as wordy, as the law itself. Les Blair says that the first time he read the script he thought it was over the top. "I thought this can't be true. I'd hardly ever spoken to a policeman and was reading all this stuff about the process of law and how the wheels were greased, and I was shocked by it."

Newman introduced him to contacts in the police and the underworld. They went out drinking, talked about scams, learned the tricks of the trade. "We'd go out on pub crawls on alternate nights, with villains and policemen. I ended up pouring a lot of booze into potted plants because I couldn't keep up with either of them," Blair says. "It really was an eye opener. "That's when I learned that coppers were sensible villains, and villains didn't have the sense to be coppers."

Officers were offered about a tenner a go, says Blair, to pretend to arrest the set designer and bring him to Scotland Yard so he could recreate it convincingly.

Law and Order duly caused an outcry. Questions were asked in the House of Commons. How could the BBC show our decent police to be so corrupt? asked the right. How are we going to tackle this shocking corruption? asked the left.

Newman's partner, Rebecca Hall, who writes about animal rights, converted him to vegetarianism in the 70s. He'd bought himself a little farm in Ireland, was friendly with the local farmer and his calves, and noticed how every six months a truck would call for them and take them away. It was Rebecca who told him they were going off for slaughter. He'd not worked it out for himself? "I'd never really thought where they went. I suppose like so many people I just blanked it out." Newman and Rebecca have been together for 27 years. She has two grown-up children, one a barrister who writes and the other an archaeologist who also writes. He helped bring them up as his own.

Hall and Newman divide their time between London and Hereford, where he bought a former school which he converted into flats. He keeps a huge chunk of it and the land for himself, his family and the animals - at one point they had 16 cats, five dogs and a couple of horses. His radicalism has always been allied to a good business sense: as a young man, he made money doing a variety of jobs, (including working for his father as a talented, if untrained, engineer). He used the money to buy himself a Mayfair flat, sold that and made himself a nice profit. His philosophy is simple: "Business is simple. You buy a piece of cloth, cut it in half and sell each piece for the same price you bought the original for."

He has continued to research his stories tirelessly. When he wrote The Nation's Health, again filmed by Les Blair, he worked for months in several hospitals as a trainee nurse, trailing doctors on ward rounds, in admin, in the kitchens. Blair had begun to see a change in him. By now Newman was an ardent follower of John Todd Ferrier, a minister who married Christianity with vegetarianism and a spiritualism usually allied to eastern religions. Like Ferrier, Newman believed in the concepts of reincarnation and karma. Blair was surprised to find that Newman had written a drama which offered new age solutions. "I knew him as the guy who had written Law and Order, and now he was talking about this healing thing. He was only mildly messianic with me. I think the way he operated with me was that he thought there were certain truths and he assumed other people would recognise them, rather than him running around trying to persuade me."

By the 80s, Newman had become a militant vegan. "I'd pick arguments.I'd walk into butcher's shops and berate people. I'd pull across trucks carrying chickens to slaughter. I'd go to the airfields when they were flying veal to Europe." He told people that if they didn't respect the rights of animals, it was as bad as not respecting the rights of women, children and black people. He still believes that, and condemns the Christian church for compartmentalising compassion. "It says you can exploit the animals on the one hand and be a Christian, be compassionate, on the other. You can't do that, though. It's what the Nazis were doing to the Jews and the gypsies and the homosexuals. They were slaughtering them in the morning and going home in the afternoon and pretending to be loving parents. And that's just not possible. Compassion is all consuming." He often compares the killing of animals to the Holocaust. When he talks about vegetarianism he lectures and harangues. He believes it is his duty to do so.

Most people presumed Newman was a hard-line leftwinger. But he has always claimed he wasn't interested in left and right. He doesn't even vote. "If I were to think that Tony Blair or William Hague or whoever runs the Liber als were the solution then I'd be totally lost. The political structure just does not deliver. All politicians are self-seeking." But a ballot ignored can deliver genocide. Would he have voted against Hitler? He says he's not sure, turns back to the "animal genocide" that surrounds us, and repeats that it is crass to prioritise one form of genocide over another.

Somehow it takes a while to notice Newman's left hand. Perhaps because it spends a good deal of time in his pocket. Part of the palm and two and a half fingers are missing. "I just used to make bombs," he says casually. "I was about 11 I think... it was quite shocking. I was making them in the garden shed." This must have been another defining moment in his childhood. Certainly an event that turned him away from violence. Why was he making bombs? "I wish I had an answer to that. I expect I was curious and destructive." The fingers were in pieces, splattered on the shed walls. He didn't cry because he couldn't feel anything. The shock numbed him.

Ruth Caleb, his executive producer, says what attracted her to him was his integrity, the moral principle that underlines everything he does. But it has also very nearly been his undoing after he started to produce his own work so he could dictate the catering. In 1996 there was mutiny on the set of Black and Blue, another exploration of police corruption. "The nemesis came a week and a half into the shoot when the troops had had enough of the vegetarian food. They wanted a choice."

Newman remembers getting a call from Caleb pleading with him to compromise. "She said: 'You've got to have meat', and I said: 'Well, fuck, I don't do the show'." Newman rarely swears. "I was prepared to walk out."

After all, he says, if he was having people round to his house, he would not serve meat or fish. As producer, he was buying the food, in effect playing host, so why should he betray his vegetarianism? The tabloids had a riot. The Sun compared him to Goebbels. In the end Newman steamed up to Liverpool to argue his case.

"He spoke to everyone, said you've all agreed to the food, reinvigorated them, and we carried on with the vegetarian shoot," Caleb says. "In another life I think Gordon would have been a prophet or a disciple. No, he would have definitely been a prophet."

Ken Trodd, who produced For The Greater Good, says Newman has become more and more controlling over the years. "I love Gordon, but it's so hard not to sound comic when talking about him." He recalls the time when Newman received his Bafta's writer award. "Gordon called me, and said I take it there will be at least one vegan table. I said I'm sure that'll be fine. Next thing I get a call from him asking whether the whole event couldn't be vegan. I suppose there's a hubristic sense of always asking for one more thing, however outrageous it may seem - not that it seems outrageous to Gordon. There is a sense of his wanting to control the world he has access to." After the Bafta food, came the speech. The event was live, and Bafta organisers were worried that Newman would may go on for ever. They asked Trodd to have a quiet word in his ear. "So I told Gordon there was some concern about how long he was going to speak. He told me not to worry because he'd been working on it and he'd managed to get it down to 13 minutes." He says that's typical Newman.

Is working with Newman really such a nightmare? Ruth Caleb says: "I look at it the other way round. You have a talented writer, a bit of a legend, who is also an individual as a producer. God knows there are few enough individuals around, and I think the crew are fortunate to be able to work with a writer who cares so passionately about things. And if they really wanted bacon butties they could have brought their own."

"As long as they didn't eat them near me," Newman says.

He admits there were times when he became overly aggressive. Not only did he refuse to share a table with meat-eaters but he became much more evangelical about his spiritual beliefs. This apparently gentle, compassionate man started to say things that sounded anything but compassionate. He believes that in this life, as in every life, we are paying off a debt. In short, and at its most simplistic, victims of crime, prejudice, ill health, even - by implication - police brutality, must have done something in a previous existence to deserve it. In one interview, he seemed to suggest that victims of the Holocaust were partly to blame because they had a victim mentality. Not surprisingly, many people took offence.

Newman stands by his karma. "There is always some connection between the victim and the victimiser, otherwise why is it that person? I can't tell you what that connection is, but there is a connection. Everything is cause and effect. It's a huge subject and if I had all the answers wouldn't it be wonderful? I believe we're all working off karmic debt through our actions and accumulating more debt in this life." He takes as an example illness - there's always a cause. Newman has not been to a conventional doctor for 25 years. In that time, he says, he has suffered only colds, and one persistent headache that was cured by the application of rice water.

But he can understand why people were upset by what he seemed to be saying about Holocaust victims. "I did take issue with the person who wrote that article because I didn't actually say that. It looked like I was saying they were to blame." So how did it misrepresent him? "Because it's so deeply unkind. Writing off six million people in a very unkind sentence. I can't say they deserved that, that's outrageous." So what had he actually said? "I can't remember."

Martin Shaw says one of the reasons he gets on so well with Newman is that they share so many beliefs, both spiritual and political. Although Newman may deny it, Shaw sees him as instinctively coming from the left. Like Newman, Shaw has also been vegetarian for 30 years. He is also in sympathy with Newman's views on reincarnation. "Now this is a very difficult, emotive subject. As Glenn Hoddle found out, you can't deal with it in one sentence, and if you do you're asking to be pounced upon. I agree with both Glenn and Gordon. But this is the paradox that the western mind finds so hard to reconcile - that it is simultaneously possible to know that everything is destined and has a balance and a reason because of everything that's happened in a previous life, but we have to behave as though we have control over our destiny. People in the west find it difficult to accept that both conditions can be true. I think Gordon is one of the most well adjusted and clear people I've met."

Newman insists that his beliefs are not a recipe for inaction, but the opposite. It is our duty, he says, to help people, to do our best, because that is the way we pay off our debt.

Newman eventually realised he was losing friends. "For a large part of the 80s I didn't go out to dinner." Not surprising - he must have been terrible company. "That's right, that's right." Did it upset Rebecca that his intolerance was destroying their social life? "Well it did, yes. She said, you know you might have more influence on these people by being with them." He says Rebecca has always been a steadying influence on him. "I just realised I was shutting out a lot of my life, a lot of people. And sometimes wisdom best testifies in silence. It's better to be quiet and just be an example."

When he made Black and Blue, which showed police officers cooking live villains in the local crematorium, some of his supporters argued that he had gone too far. But, of course, this wasn't the first time that had been said about his work. "Why do people find it easy to believe that policemen in South Africa or South America kill people, but that they'd never do it here? What makes us so special?" He claims it was a detective who told him about the cremations.

There were other problems, not least when he was sued by the freelance investigative journalist Duncan Campbell [not the Guardian reporter] over his portrayal of a cross-dressing, kleptomaniac hack in his TV drama Here is the News. Newman has always insisted the journalist was not based on Campbell, but it cost the BBC £100,000.

In recent years Newman has fallen out of fashion. Television no longer has space for serious dramas, especially ones riddled with complex argument. Back in the 70s he, Alan Bleasdale and Dennis Potter were the television dramatists. Today, the man on reception at the BBC doesn't seem to have heard of GF Newman. Some people are surprised he is still alive.

Les Blair says: "People are not interested in that kind of dynamic anymore. People just don't like investigative drama. There's no place for it in the BBC, which is a great shame."

Martin Shaw thinks this is more true of the TV executives than the population at large. "It's not the public's fault. Their ability to understand hasn't changed, but television is now run by accountants who take no risk. Excellence is judged by ratings, not how good the product is. Not by how innovative or how challenging or how informative it is, but simply by how much we beat the other side."

In the late 80s Newman cast the film-maker Michael Winner in The Greater Good as a businessman trying to convince the home secretary to let him run private prisons. "It was beautifully written, and if I say so myself I was incredibly good in it," Winner says. It was his first serious acting role. "That was like a fantasy in those days, but it came to be true; they did privatise prisons. And that's one of Newman's great qualities - he puts his finger on where things are going politically." Winner, not a man renowned for adhering to Reithian principles, believes that the BBC has dumbed down considerably since then. "You'd be hard pressed to get three hour-long episodes of a political drama on TV now."

Newman knows he's not as popular as he was, but he never trusted it when he was flavour of the day. Nothing has really changed, he says. He used to plough a lonely furrow and still does. "I never needed popularity to validate my existence." So he can still get the programmes made that he wants to? "No, is the truth. I've had shows that haven't gone for whatever reason, and I always presumed it was because they weren't good enough, but you look at some of the stuff on the television and think well I don't know..." He says these days TV is more schematic, pure sensation. "I'm not admiring of what I see around me, I'm not saying 'Gosh, I wish I'd made that'." Occasionally he sees films at the cinema - The Insider, say, or Shine - that he wishes he'd written.

But Newman has not given up. Next week, Judge John Deed, a pilot for a commissioned series, will be shown on BBC1. Again, it stars Martin Shaw, and once again the subject is law and order. John Deed is a a good man doing his best not to be corrupted by a conflict of interest. It's entertaining, warm and rather soft for Newman. There will be no questions asked in the house about Judge John Deed.

Martin Shaw loves the character he plays, but still has reservations. "I think Gordon will forgive me if I say we had vehement discussions. I would have wanted him to be his old radical self. I think there are areas where he has made it too easy for the audience, too mainstream. When you have Gordon Newman's name on something you have a genre expectation and I think with John Deed he has pulled back slightly from that expectation. Actually it's not so much to do with the radical nature, more to do with over-explaining - what we'd call dumbing down. I thought there were areas where we could have been more grown up, not nannied the audience so much." Meanwhile, Newman says Judge John Deed is not about dumbing down, it's about his personal evolution. There was a time when he simply wanted to expose foul play, now he wants solutions. He says he has become more aspirational over the years.

"I would like people to look at John Deed and think 'Gosh, if I ever got into trouble and ended up in court I'd like to be in front of this man'." And that, he says is a change in his writing and a change in himself. "One has to change, bringing the light to the areas of darkness. First you go behind the closed doors into the secret rooms of the police and hospitals, you open them up and shine some light in. Then the next stage is taking the people on the journey from wanting to be in the dark, to the light; from bad to good."

Life at a glance: Gordon Frank Newman

Born: May 22 1946.

Education: Edgbury secondary, Chistlehurst. Stanislavsky Studio.

Partner: Rebecca Hall, (two sons).

Novels: Sir, You Bastard; You Nice Bastard; You Flash Bastard; Law and Order, The Nation's Health, Circle of Poison.

Plays: Operation Bad Apple

Television plays: Law and Order, The Nation's Health, For the Greater Good, The Healer, Black and Blue, Judge John Deed

Awards: Bafta Writer's award (1992), Bafta for The Healer (best play, 1996). Golden Knight, Malta for directing short film Woe to the Hunter.

fields.bodyText: Gordon Frank Newman trawls back half a century. He was six years old, walking home, his shirt stuffed with pears. "I had been given them by a man further up the road who had trees in his garden, and I was actually going past an orchard when a policeman came down the lane and stopped and said: 'What've you got there?' and I said: 'Nothing'. He called me a liar and clomped me round the ears and took the pears and got back in his car and went. I danced across the road, saw stars. I suppose that is where it started." Newman didn't know the blow had left him deaf in his right ear. He didn't even tell his parents about the incident. The boy who turned into the man who has spent four decades exploring injustice within the justice system, simply got on with life. "Looking back on those circumstances, you see that police do that all the time. Jump to conclusions." GF Newman first gained recognition for his crime novels. The first, Sir, You Bastard, sold 200,000 copies. But he really made his name with a landmark television series in the late 1970s. Its title couldn't have been a more literal statement of his concerns. Law and Order changed the landscape both of cop shows and British TV. It wasn't so much a drama as an exposé. The performances and mood of the four films, directed with spartan vigour by Les Blair, made you think it had to be real, had to be documentary. A new word was invented to describe Law and Order - faction. Just as radical as the style was the subject matter - Newman showed a police force identical to the criminals they trailed but for the badges. Young Newman was a bright lad, enthusiastic for life, inquisitive, slightly dyslexic, bored by school. His background was comfortable; dad a structural engineer, mum a housewife. He lived his childhood in his head, fantasising about making a difference, saving the world, being the Superman of St Mary Cray in Kent. "I was the person who'd go in to change the situation and, having righted it, would move on." He spent a good deal of time bunking off school, smoking with friends when they should have been in class. At 16, he decided to be a movie star and went to a Stanislavsky acting school in Chistelhurst, but it didn't really have time for stars. It was more interested in observation, character, immersion than celebrity. At drama school he wrote a script that was accepted for a cop series. It wasn't until two decades after the pear incident that Newman again came into contact with the police. He was 24, living in Mayfair, London, and the anti-Vietnam demonstrators were marching past his home near Grosvenor Square. He was as curious as he was naive. "It was jam packed, heaving and the police were charging the crowd on horses. Yet the crowd were equally outrageous because a lot of them had weapons and were stabbing the flanks of the horses. I wasn't aware of animal rights then, but I was outraged." Newman sits at his BBC desk in White City, back straight, arms crossed, one hand buried in his pocket, the other bearing a red band round his wrist. "It's red energy, red always draws energy, so if you're feeling tired put on a red shirt," he says. He looks smart in a pristine way - cotton suit, white shirt. To his side is a neat row of tangerines, a couple of apples and tomatoes, and a carton of organic apple juice - lunch. He is tall, and his face, his stance, his whole demeanour suggest an ascetic life. The actor Martin Shaw remembers the first time he met him: "I was startled by him, his physical presence is startling. It was 1989, and he was completely bald, and it wasn't commonplace then. He had these extraordinary piercing blue eyes, and a candour and directness bordering on the alien. His mental frame is echoed by his physical frame - he's as straight as you can get." Shaw, who starred in Newman's For the Greater Good and is the eponymous hero of his new TV drama, Judge John Deed, calls him an extraordinarily good man, and apologises if he sounds pious. "He has a blazing integrity, in his care for people, his humanity - towards people and animals." That blazing integrity certainly emerged in Law and Order. What was most astonishing about the series of films was Newman's sense of process, of how things were done. Many people asked how Newman knew so much about the law. Most presumed that he was an insider. Ken Campbell, who appeared in Law and Order, says that throughout the filming he never met Newman. "There were lots of rumours that he was an ex-copper, that he had lost an arm, all types of things. Some time later I met him and I was so surprised. I was expecting him to be some kind of heavy, a big Bob Hoskins. But he was so charming, so lightweight, so caring. He's a vegan isn't he?" The Newman mythology was partly self-created. At a question and answer session at the National Film Theatre after Law and Order was screened, he told the audience that he had been a detective for 14 years and had served 12 years in prison for corruption. He was barely 30 at the time, though his long straggling beard did its best to hide his age. "I thought I was being clever, and that they would just do some smart arithmetic and realise that would have made me about 78. It came back to haunt me." This was not the only time he has fictionalised his life. Like Len Deighton, he created different characters for the author of his books. One time he was a father of seven, another time a pimp. "I was inventing the expert who had the authority to write this book." In truth, Newman was simply a writer who knew the value of research. His writing was as complex, at times as wordy, as the law itself. Les Blair says that the first time he read the script he thought it was over the top. "I thought this can't be true. I'd hardly ever spoken to a policeman and was reading all this stuff about the process of law and how the wheels were greased, and I was shocked by it." Newman introduced him to contacts in the police and the underworld. They went out drinking, talked about scams, learned the tricks of the trade. "We'd go out on pub crawls on alternate nights, with villains and policemen. I ended up pouring a lot of booze into potted plants because I couldn't keep up with either of them," Blair says. "It really was an eye opener. "That's when I learned that coppers were sensible villains, and villains didn't have the sense to be coppers." Officers were offered about a tenner a go, says Blair, to pretend to arrest the set designer and bring him to Scotland Yard so he could recreate it convincingly. Law and Order duly caused an outcry. Questions were asked in the House of Commons. How could the BBC show our decent police to be so corrupt? asked the right. How are we going to tackle this shocking corruption? asked the left. Newman's partner, Rebecca Hall, who writes about animal rights, converted him to vegetarianism in the 70s. He'd bought himself a little farm in Ireland, was friendly with the local farmer and his calves, and noticed how every six months a truck would call for them and take them away. It was Rebecca who told him they were going off for slaughter. He'd not worked it out for himself? "I'd never really thought where they went. I suppose like so many people I just blanked it out." Newman and Rebecca have been together for 27 years. She has two grown-up children, one a barrister who writes and the other an archaeologist who also writes. He helped bring them up as his own. Hall and Newman divide their time between London and Hereford, where he bought a former school which he converted into flats. He keeps a huge chunk of it and the land for himself, his family and the animals - at one point they had 16 cats, five dogs and a couple of horses. His radicalism has always been allied to a good business sense: as a young man, he made money doing a variety of jobs, (including working for his father as a talented, if untrained, engineer). He used the money to buy himself a Mayfair flat, sold that and made himself a nice profit. His philosophy is simple: "Business is simple. You buy a piece of cloth, cut it in half and sell each piece for the same price you bought the original for." He has continued to research his stories tirelessly. When he wrote The Nation's Health, again filmed by Les Blair, he worked for months in several hospitals as a trainee nurse, trailing doctors on ward rounds, in admin, in the kitchens. Blair had begun to see a change in him. By now Newman was an ardent follower of John Todd Ferrier, a minister who married Christianity with vegetarianism and a spiritualism usually allied to eastern religions. Like Ferrier, Newman believed in the concepts of reincarnation and karma. Blair was surprised to find that Newman had written a drama which offered new age solutions. "I knew him as the guy who had written Law and Order, and now he was talking about this healing thing. He was only mildly messianic with me. I think the way he operated with me was that he thought there were certain truths and he assumed other people would recognise them, rather than him running around trying to persuade me." By the 80s, Newman had become a militant vegan. "I'd pick arguments.I'd walk into butcher's shops and berate people. I'd pull across trucks carrying chickens to slaughter. I'd go to the airfields when they were flying veal to Europe." He told people that if they didn't respect the rights of animals, it was as bad as not respecting the rights of women, children and black people. He still believes that, and condemns the Christian church for compartmentalising compassion. "It says you can exploit the animals on the one hand and be a Christian, be compassionate, on the other. You can't do that, though. It's what the Nazis were doing to the Jews and the gypsies and the homosexuals. They were slaughtering them in the morning and going home in the afternoon and pretending to be loving parents. And that's just not possible. Compassion is all consuming." He often compares the killing of animals to the Holocaust. When he talks about vegetarianism he lectures and harangues. He believes it is his duty to do so. Most people presumed Newman was a hard-line leftwinger. But he has always claimed he wasn't interested in left and right. He doesn't even vote. "If I were to think that Tony Blair or William Hague or whoever runs the Liber als were the solution then I'd be totally lost. The political structure just does not deliver. All politicians are self-seeking." But a ballot ignored can deliver genocide. Would he have voted against Hitler? He says he's not sure, turns back to the "animal genocide" that surrounds us, and repeats that it is crass to prioritise one form of genocide over another. Somehow it takes a while to notice Newman's left hand. Perhaps because it spends a good deal of time in his pocket. Part of the palm and two and a half fingers are missing. "I just used to make bombs," he says casually. "I was about 11 I think... it was quite shocking. I was making them in the garden shed." This must have been another defining moment in his childhood. Certainly an event that turned him away from violence. Why was he making bombs? "I wish I had an answer to that. I expect I was curious and destructive." The fingers were in pieces, splattered on the shed walls. He didn't cry because he couldn't feel anything. The shock numbed him. Ruth Caleb, his executive producer, says what attracted her to him was his integrity, the moral principle that underlines everything he does. But it has also very nearly been his undoing after he started to produce his own work so he could dictate the catering. In 1996 there was mutiny on the set of Black and Blue, another exploration of police corruption. "The nemesis came a week and a half into the shoot when the troops had had enough of the vegetarian food. They wanted a choice." Newman remembers getting a call from Caleb pleading with him to compromise. "She said: 'You've got to have meat', and I said: 'Well, fuck, I don't do the show'." Newman rarely swears. "I was prepared to walk out." After all, he says, if he was having people round to his house, he would not serve meat or fish. As producer, he was buying the food, in effect playing host, so why should he betray his vegetarianism? The tabloids had a riot. The Sun compared him to Goebbels. In the end Newman steamed up to Liverpool to argue his case. "He spoke to everyone, said you've all agreed to the food, reinvigorated them, and we carried on with the vegetarian shoot," Caleb says. "In another life I think Gordon would have been a prophet or a disciple. No, he would have definitely been a prophet." Ken Trodd, who produced For The Greater Good, says Newman has become more and more controlling over the years. "I love Gordon, but it's so hard not to sound comic when talking about him." He recalls the time when Newman received his Bafta's writer award. "Gordon called me, and said I take it there will be at least one vegan table. I said I'm sure that'll be fine. I suppose there's a hubristic sense of always asking for one more thing, however outrageous it may seem - not that it seems outrageous to Gordon. There is a sense of his wanting to control the world he has access to." After the Bafta food, came the speech. The event was live, and Bafta organisers were worried that Newman would may go on for ever. They asked Trodd to have a quiet word in his ear. "So I told Gordon there was some concern about how long he was going to speak. He told me not to worry because he'd been working on it and he'd managed to get it down to 13 minutes." He says that's typical Newman. Is working with Newman really such a nightmare? Ruth Caleb says: "I look at it the other way round. You have a talented writer, a bit of a legend, who is also an individual as a producer. God knows there are few enough individuals around, and I think the crew are fortunate to be able to work with a writer who cares so passionately about things. And if they really wanted bacon butties they could have brought their own." "As long as they didn't eat them near me," Newman says. He admits there were times when he became overly aggressive. Not only did he refuse to share a table with meat-eaters but he became much more evangelical about his spiritual beliefs. This apparently gentle, compassionate man started to say things that sounded anything but compassionate. He believes that in this life, as in every life, we are paying off a debt. In short, and at its most simplistic, victims of crime, prejudice, ill health, even - by implication - police brutality, must have done something in a previous existence to deserve it. In one interview, he seemed to suggest that victims of the Holocaust were partly to blame because they had a victim mentality. Not surprisingly, many people took offence. Newman stands by his karma. "There is always some connection between the victim and the victimiser, otherwise why is it that person? I can't tell you what that connection is, but there is a connection. Everything is cause and effect. It's a huge subject and if I had all the answers wouldn't it be wonderful? I believe we're all working off karmic debt through our actions and accumulating more debt in this life." He takes as an example illness - there's always a cause. Newman has not been to a conventional doctor for 25 years. In that time, he says, he has suffered only colds, and one persistent headache that was cured by the application of rice water. But he can understand why people were upset by what he seemed to be saying about Holocaust victims. "I did take issue with the person who wrote that article because I didn't actually say that. It looked like I was saying they were to blame." So how did it misrepresent him? "Because it's so deeply unkind. Writing off six million people in a very unkind sentence. I can't say they deserved that, that's outrageous." So what had he actually said? "I can't remember." Martin Shaw says one of the reasons he gets on so well with Newman is that they share so many beliefs, both spiritual and political. Although Newman may deny it, Shaw sees him as instinctively coming from the left. Like Newman, Shaw has also been vegetarian for 30 years. He is also in sympathy with Newman's views on reincarnation. "Now this is a very difficult, emotive subject. As Glenn Hoddle found out, you can't deal with it in one sentence, and if you do you're asking to be pounced upon. I agree with both Glenn and Gordon. But this is the paradox that the western mind finds so hard to reconcile - that it is simultaneously possible to know that everything is destined and has a balance and a reason because of everything that's happened in a previous life, but we have to behave as though we have control over our destiny. People in the west find it difficult to accept that both conditions can be true. I think Gordon is one of the most well adjusted and clear people I've met." Newman insists that his beliefs are not a recipe for inaction, but the opposite. It is our duty, he says, to help people, to do our best, because that is the way we pay off our debt. Newman eventually realised he was losing friends. "For a large part of the 80s I didn't go out to dinner." Not surprising - he must have been terrible company. "That's right, that's right." fields.headline: The last word on   Intoxication
fields.standfirst: Only the first bottle of wine is expensive  -  French proverb
fields.trailText: Only the first bottle of wine is expensive - French proverb
fields.body:
Many will feel like partying especially hard this New Year's Eve, on the grounds that it marks the true millennium. By at last closing the bloodstained and breathless 20th century, it ushers in a new era, one that - unless we master increasingly resistant diseases, environmental degradation and the spread of weapons of mass destruction into fundamentalist hands - could be mankind's most difficult yet.

It should not be surprising that people choose to mark significant occasions by getting intoxicated - which is to say: by inducing temporary but often profound changes in their usual selves - for history teaches that people have always had special reasons for doing so. Past societies regarded it (and some still do) as a way of communing with the gods and as revealing people to one another and themselves. It gave people a holiday from themselves and from the usual constraints of life. Indeed, the importance of allowing people to have "moral holidays" was so widely recognised that all dispensations had their licensed feast days and seasons of revelry, even - as with the feast of the Lord of Misrule - allowing the social world to be turned upside down for a day, with the king serving the clown.

Alcohol was not the only door to divinity or self-release. Most basic forms of drugs have long been familiar to mankind, and their remarkable properties gave them a central and valued role in community life. The substances capable of effecting such transformations belonged to the same ancient pharmacopoeia as medicine, and when more austere religions started to fear their anarchic power, the people who produced them came to be demonised - into witches, wizards, and devil's familiars. As societies have grown more numerous and complex, so the effort to control the availability and use of intoxicants has grown, the chief reason being that their effects make people ungovernable.

As the name implies, an intoxicant is a substance that poisons the human body and by doing so alters states of feeling and perception. The brain tries to defend itself against the disruptive effect of most chemicals by shielding itself behind a "blood-brain barrier", but intoxicants are precisely those substances capable of penetrating the barrier, thereby disturbing the normal delicate chemical marinade of the brain and disrupting its functions.

One advantage of alcohol is that its effects are proportional to quantity. A little alcohol serves as a relaxing social lubricant, helping fellow guests to warm to one another, but (even at legal levels) making the imbiber a menace behind a steering wheel; larger quantities vanquish his muscular control and inhibitions; and quantities larger still can kill him. "The vine bears three kinds of grapes," wrote the Scythian philosopher Anacharsis, "the first of pleasure, the second of intoxication, the third of disgust."

Admonishers in the days before drink-driving (a kind of murder waiting to happen) focused on alcohol's indiscretion. "What a sober man has in his heart," says the Danish proverb, "the drunk has on his lips."

They also pointed at the destructive effect of systematic drinking on family life and individual health. Alcohol dependency was then thought to be an exclusively moral failure, but is now recognised as a social and - more to the point - medical problem. It is a measure of alcohol's centrality to life that it has resisted (in the days of Prohibition, at enormous cost) every effort to criminalise it, unlike other drugs. Alcohol marks the limits of government, one might say.

Certainly it marks the limits of self-government. "Drink never made a man better," says Dunne's sage Mr Dooley, "but it has made many a man think he was." The observation applies generally. The self-same Mr Dooley held that many couples would never have arrived at the altar together had it not been for drink. "It's the wise man who stays home when he's drunk," said Euripides, perhaps thinking the same thing.

But these wary remarks will influence few new year revellers, who will prefer Lord Byron's view that "Man, being reasonable, must get drunk; the best of life is but intoxication."

Who could disagree - if he meant intoxication by art, letters, music and love.

As societies have grown more numerous and complex, so the effort to control the availability and use of intoxicants has grown, the chief reason being that their effects make people ungovernable. As the name implies, an intoxicant is a substance that poisons the human body and by doing so alters states of feeling and perception. The brain tries to defend itself against the disruptive effect of most chemicals by shielding itself behind a "blood-brain barrier", but intoxicants are precisely those substances capable of penetrating the barrier, thereby disturbing the normal delicate chemical marinade of the brain and disrupting its functions. One advantage of alcohol is that its effects are proportional to quantity. A little alcohol serves as a relaxing social lubricant, helping fellow guests to warm to one another, but (even at legal levels) making the imbiber a menace behind a steering wheel; larger quantities vanquish his muscular control and inhibitions; and quantities larger still can kill him. "The vine bears three kinds of grapes," wrote the Scythian philosopher Anacharsis, "the first of pleasure, the second of intoxication, the third of disgust." Admonishers in the days before drink-driving (a kind of murder waiting to happen) focused on alcohol's indiscretion. "What a sober man has in his heart," says the Danish proverb, "the drunk has on his lips." They also pointed at the destructive effect of systematic drinking on family life and individual health. Alcohol dependency was then thought to be an exclusively moral failure, but is now recognised as a social and - more to the point - medical problem. It is a measure of alcohol's centrality to life that it has resisted (in the days of Prohibition, at enormous cost) every effort to criminalise it, unlike other drugs. Alcohol marks the limits of government, one might say. Certainly it marks the limits of self-government. "Drink never made a man better," says Dunne's sage Mr Dooley, "but it has made many a man think he was." The observation applies generally. The self-same Mr Dooley held that many couples would never have arrived at the altar together had it not been for drink. "It's the wise man who stays home when he's drunk," said Euripides, perhaps thinking the same thing. But these wary remarks will influence few new year revellers, who will prefer Lord Byron's view that "Man, being reasonable, must get drunk; the best of life is but intoxication." Who could disagree - if he meant intoxication by art, letters, music and love.

webTitle: I am a few of my favourite things

fields.headline: I am a few of my favourite things
fields.trailText: A week in radio
fields.body:
This year's turkey-free Christmas specials had a rather manic, strange quality to them. I think only Graham Fellows as John Shuttleworth intended this. On Shuttleworth's Christmas Special (Radio 4, on longwave because of Harry Potter Day), he gave us a tribute to Betty Turpin of Coronation Street. Andy Williams's Christmas Favourites (Radio 2) brought the best anecdote about Pavarotti I've heard, Bruce Forsyth (Radio 2) taught us how to spell his wife's name, and Chris Tarrant, on Capital Radio's Christmas Day breakfast show, left me speechless.

As a musical way to set yourself up for Christmas Eve, Williams's show was nigh-unbeatable. There was the dementedly happy The Most Wonderful Time of the Year crooned by Williams, a demonically fast Jingle Bells sung by the Williams Brothers and Tony Bennett's engaging wish-list, These Are a Few of My Favourite Things ("whiskers of kittens and long knitted mittens"). "Tony Bennett is a good friend of mine," Williams added, not long after telling us that "Robert Kennedy was a good friend of mine."

Williams - a man untethered by modesty - made his Christmas favourite pretty clear: it's himself. We got a potted history of his Christmas television shows ("Once I was flown in beneath a kite!"), some art criticism of Bennett's paintings ("beach chairs and very strong colours"), a mother-in-law gag ("She times all her meals with a smoke detector"), and a reminder wherever possible that he, and not the big guy in the red outfit, is Mr Christmas.

This self-regarding waffle was saved by the Pavarotti anecdote. Pavvers, he said with a laugh, is a "formidable" tennis player with whom Williams has enjoyed a set or two over the years. "The balls just bounce off him," he added, sounding like the tears were rolling down his permatanned cheeks.

Forsyth was an altogether more humble creature on Christmas Day, praising others (at length, with an edge of unstoppability) and peppering the show with affectionate little references to special people. Sammy Davis Jnr, who once requested a meeting with Brucie at 3am, was a "lovely little black guy", and his wife, "W-I-N-E-L-I-A", is a "mouthful but a lovely lady".

He talked about the stars but as a fan, telling us he once sat in a Los Angeles lounge for five hours listening to Erroll Garner. Just this once, I even forgave the interminable golfing anecdotes.

You are safe from such tedium with Shuttleworth all year round, but especially on his Boxing Day special, capturing the Christmas-morning atmosphere at the home he shares with his wife Mary. Despite a busy schedule ('Got to go and spin the lettuce for the running buffet"), Shuttleworth found time to make coffee for visitors on his new "caffeytiery" and to play ditties on his organ. He ended the festivities with a cheering rendition of a new song, We Hurtle Towards the Grave, but the highlight, to a salsa backing track, was his tribute to the Hotpot Queen. "We see Betty Turpin only when she's working," he began, all strained and warbly with emotion. "It's not right."

Driving an 84-year-old great aunt and a six-year-old niece to lunch on Christmas Day, I tuned in to find Chris Tarrant pretending one of his team (male) had given him a naked photograph of himself as a gift. "You'll [guffaw] never [hee-hee] win the pole vault [splutter]." Great Aunt Maude looked puzzled, the tiny tot even more so, and then they both looked at me. Time to phone a friend, methinks.

fields.headline: In search of Peter's friends
fields.trailText: Last night's TV
fields.body:
Sleepless in South London (BBC2) is a very BBC2 programme. It takes the premise of Sleepless in Seattle - a single parent's offspring should choose them a date - and turns it into a bit of a gentle game show. Three women were pitted against each other for the affection of Peter, a musician. In choosing from them a suitable date for their father, Hannah, Joe and Andrew asked the women involved questions ("Do you know any jokes?"), had a nosy round their houses ("She's very tidy"), and went off for an outing with them. Presented by the sweet but sharp Mel Giedroyc, this was Blind Date with added social awareness (and less of a budget for the final date, which took place in a curry house in south London).

Caroline, 37, was a human resources manager whose ideal man was Tony Hadley. Either she gargled gravel in her spare time or smoked 80 Marlboro Red a day. She also mixed dark colours with light ones in her washing, much to Mel's horror. After smelling her perfume ("very strong"), Mel concluded Caroline might be a bit bossy. Martine, 43, was a nurse whose kitchen cupboards were lined with paper and neatly arranged. She kept her clothes colour-coordinated in her wardrobe and took the children to a climbing wall. This perhaps wasn't a good choice of outing since Andrew was only six and didn't want to climb very high (Martine might have been hoping to branch into paediatrics when he tumbled to a broken leg, thus impressing Peter). Mel thought Martine was nice but slightly anally retentive.

Kirstin was German and an IT manager. She had met most of her recent dates on the internet, while her ideal man was Kevin Costner. Amazingly, with all these factors working against her, the children liked her the most and chose her for their dad. They even enjoyed going to a ceramics painting session with her. "Judging by them," Kirstin said of the children, "their father must be lovely." Mel thought Kirstin had a nice house (though her carpeted bed seemed unhygienic to me). Peter and Kirstin's date went well, despite the presence of a camera, but Mel didn't seem too genuine in her delight. I think she was harbouring a secret desire for Peter herself.

Like Vanessa Feltz, polar bears are dangerous, especially when hungry. Unfortunately, none made a lunge at either of the Vets in the Wild (BBC1). In Churchill, Canada, the polar bear capital of the world, Trude and Steve were helping locals to keep hungry bears away from juicy tourists as well as giving them routine health checks (the bears, not the tourists). This meant wandering around snowy scenes with tranquiliser guns and endearing woolly hats.

Hats seem to be a theme of Vets in Practice (BBC1). In the Christmas special - in between cats having their diaphragms sewn back together and a lumpy horse - Emma the vet bought herself a hat for "a treat" since Joe, her partner, had slipped off to France to go snowboarding. A hat? How about a night of passionate love with a complete stranger during which he laps champagne off her naked body? A hat indeed. Some people haven't a clue how to have fun.

In One Man and His Dog (BBC2), they never go to mow. Even in what was a national competition, there was no grand synchronised grass-cutting. That was a shame since such a sight would be quite arresting and everyone could sing along as all the men went to mow, went to mow a meadow. As it was, we got Clarissa Dickson-Wright in her wellies (not concrete, malheureusement, and not on a river bed) marvelling at the joys of the countryside. At least it keeps her out of the kitchen, one supposes.

Perhaps in an attempt to persuade da kids that Channel 4 is even more funky and cool than they had previously imagined - in advance of the launch of their new entertainment channel, E4, and not in a cynical way at all - two hours of Spice Girls coverage started with a fairly bog-standard documentary culled from MTV, Biorhythm: The Spice Girls (Channel 4), before Robbie Williams's Videodrome (Channel 4) gave the bloke from Stoke an hour of free advertising for his albums. Available in all good record stores, apparently.

fields.headline: Snowdonia
fields.trailText: A Country Diary
fields.body:
It was one of those magic mornings. Soon after sunrise, the last cloudlet dissolved and every summit pierced an azure sky. Frost etched the valley crags and a kestrel circled the high spaces. We headed directly up the moor from Capel Curig, over the leat that carries water unnaturally from the Llugwy valley, round to the head of lonely Llyn Cowlyd. Here were the heather tufts "looking to flowering time, with now no other blossom but dead snow".

It's a steep and steady climb up this southern side of Pen Lithrig-y-wrach, the conical hill that's so conspicuous to travellers heading west on the Holyhead road just beyond Capel Curig. Its name means "the slippery hill of the witch" which reminds me that it's exactly 45 years ago yesterday that we went up this way to the summit by the light of the full moon. All Carneddau was draped in frozen snow, or was lit by that big moon diffused through a veil of high cloud. It was bitterly cold, I remember, but there was no wind and we were up and down in little more than two hours. It was a simple business to kick steps in the snow crust, right up to the 2,621-ft summit.

On this shining morning, we had a super view from the top, out over the highest Carneddau and down on to sullen Llyn Cowlyd where a pair of ravens flapped by like some portent of doom. Down there, high on the hill's south-east ridge, is the compact cliff where Peter Harding and Tony Moulam put up the first route (called "Staircase") exactly 10 years before our nocturnal Christmas foray. They were pioneers on this particular Welsh peak.

The sky remained cloudless and highest Carneddau beckoned so we went down to the north-west, crossing Bwlch y Tri Marchog and up the long, broken east ridge of Pen yr Helgi Du. You get a fine view from the crest of this ridge, right down the length of Cwm Eigiau and out to the imagined green spaces of the lower Conwy Valley, hidden now by the foothills below the broken impounding wall of Llyn Eigiau.

The traverse of the airy ar te beyond brought us to the long climb up to Carnedd Llewelyn. Across to our right stood the walls and buttresses of Craig yr Ysfa, one of the great crags of Snowdonia, where the heather "scratch their bare stalks and listen for the spring".
