fields.headline: The white stuff
fields.standfirst: Austrian Karl Fuchs and his English wife Eileen were the first to bring skiing to Scotland. But it was a difficult and sometimes distressing ascent.  John Samuel  traces their ups and downs...
fields.trailText: Austrian Karl Fuchs and his English wife Eileen were the first to bring skiing to Scotland. But it was a difficult and sometimes distressing ascent. John Samuel traces their ups and downs...
fields.body:
If any man could claim to be the father of modern Scottish skiing and ski-racing it was Karl Fuchs. Even now, as the Cairngorm ski area he did so much to further is building a new £14m funicular railway serving up to 20 runs, many who ski there will recall the start they were given from the Struan House Hotel at nearby Carrbridge. The first ski hotel in Scotland, it was set up by this extraordinary man - Austrian dissident, Iron Cross-holder, Olympic-class skier, and pioneer, with his English wife Eileen, of much that is best in Scottish skiing.

Not that there was anything "best" when Fuchs arrived in 1954. British Alpine climbers of the Victorian era used skis only as an adjunct to climbing - they may have learned their skills on Britain's many challenging rock faces, but not on its ski slopes, because these simply did not exist.

Conditions in the Scottish Highlands were very different from those in the continental European ski resorts. A contemporary noted: "Snow slopes in Scotland take on a most puzzling kind of surface glare which defies the most hawk-eyed of skiers and reduces the short-sighted runner, with moisture on his glasses to a state of dithering funk... with uncertain snow, heather, rocks, windswept ice and all kinds of bunkers placed in the most awkward and trying positions, fast running is mere folly."

But there was a Scottish Ski Club, made up of "skiers afraid of nothing", according to one continental visitor, "just as long as there is a little snow buried beneath the grass." But when the second world war intervened, winter training took on a darker purpose. Lord Hunt of Everest fame recalled the fierce blizzards suddenly whipping in from the Arctic. "On one occasion, fighting the way up to Loch Etchachan in the teeth of a gale, I watched [Frank] Smythe lifted by some gust and deposited 40ft below the track in a snow drift."

After the war, people began to think again about Scotland's possibilities, but until Karl and Eileen Fuchs arrived there was no exact commercial focus, no person of sufficient charisma and credibility to make things happen on a scale that could ensure Aviemore and the Cairngorms became the first Scottish ski destination centre.

It was in late 1954 that Fuchs pulled up the blinds of the overnight train from Euston and, for the first time, observed the Cairngorm mountains capped by winter snow. So much snow and only early November! There would not always be this much snow, but he wasn't to learn this until later. Fuchs was born in 1924 in Steiermark, Austria. His father was a steelworker, a man of the Schutzbund, or left, bitterly at odds with the nationalistic Heimwehr. After one particularly bloody street battle, the 10-year-old Karl was left desperately seeking his father among the dead and injured. It proved to be a memory that would stay with him his whole life - though his father did escape abroad, only to be imprisoned on his return until the end of the second world war.

But there was no escaping the wartime call-up for Fuchs. He avoided fighting in Stalingrad and spent time in Yugoslavia. The Iron Cross came with his part in the demolition of a bridge, but after this, he and a few companions discarded their uniforms, lived off the land and made it back home in 1945.

Eileen Knowles, the daughter of Maurice, a first-world-war RAF pilot, met Fuchs on an Austrian ski slope after the war. An honours history graduate from Newnham College, Cambridge, she had performed wartime civil service functions.

Studying German in Vienna was not the most obvious post-war relief for Eileen, but her father was also learning the language in Austria while becoming one of the earliest guides to Major Walter Ingham, the Alpine tour operator.

Karl's fluency of manner and ski style won over Eileen. She could speak German to him. He, initially, understood only one word in 10 of English. For the remainder of his days, Fuchs would speak what became known throughout the skier Highlands as "Scotstrian". So, "I kop sex bindle stick" meant he had carried six bundles of slalom poles up the mountain.

By 1947 Fuchs had achieved minor fame as Austria's police ski champion and as a member of his country's training squad for the 1948 St Moritz Winter Olympics. Suddenly, with a crash on a Zugspitze training course, his ambitions were in ruins. His leg was so badly fractured he spent most of the next nine months in hospital. Skiing, though, was in his blood and when Eileen met him he had become one of the first to qualify from a new, nationally approved instructors' course.

The pair quickly set their minds on a ski hotel, but motorcycle expeditions into the mountains from their apartment in Bruck found no suitable place at a price they could afford. Finally their thoughts turned to Britain. With Maurice as guide, and camping in two small tents, they found Snowdonia compelling, but with snow too uncertain for Britain's first ski school. Disappointed, they drove north to the Lake District to hear the same story.

The Scottish Council for Physical Recreation suggested three areas - Glencoe, Ben Lawers and the north-facing Cairngorms, close to the village of Aviemore. The last proved to be first. In the late summer sunshine, all were enchanted by the beauty of Loch Morlich. Fuchs took out his binoculars and saw a steep, narrow corridor running to the left of the 4,084ft Cairngorm peak. A filling of snow and what a brilliant intermediate run it would make. The search was over.

Or nearly. The Euston-Inverness railway ran beside the River Spey and the narrow B9152, which led from the A9 to the village of Aviemore - one big hotel and a few houses - and the even smaller village of Carrbridge. There they hit upon the Struan House Hotel, once a substantial double-fronted house with small, tower-like features, and, pricelessly, an annexe. And it was for sale, at £5,000. It was like their own first encounter, love at first sight. In November, 1954, they bought it. Scotland's first ski hotel was born, and with it the Austrian Ski School.

They were little aware of what they were getting into."Horizontal" weather, wind-whipped Arctic sleet, can pierce a conventional ski anorak like grapeshot. Equally, the mist will lift or winds ease, and a day's sublime skiing follow.

The Fuchs' fortunes were not dissimilar. Karl was always in the forefront of the fight for key amenities, but there were many schisms, battles and setbacks. Yet the visitors kept coming.

In the 60s and 70s the Cairngorm upgrades proceeded slowly, its public still mostly from Scotland. London and the south-east were sniffy, and closer, in any case, to the Alps, but Manchester and the Midlands were catching on.

In 1960, the all-important road to the ski area was opened; in 1961, the chairlift and the Sheiling and Ptarmigan lodges. The White Lady tow gave access to a fine slalom slope. Then, not of Fuch's making, but a bonus for its publicity - the Coylumbridge Hotel skating rink. A T-bar to Coire Cas followed, opening up more ski territory. Next, the Aviemore Centre - hotels, ski shops, pin tables and go-carts. Then an internationally recognised slalom race course and, in 1967, the British championships.

On a sunny Saturday, more especially in late-season, when Scottish snow is often at its best, there were suddenly 6,000 skiers on Cairngorm: sleek and adept as contemporaries in Verbier or Val d'Isére. Today there are up to 20 runs to choose from, and Aonoch Mor beneath Ben Nevis, near Fort William has come to join the Cairngorms as a serious destination, along with the less built-up areas of Glencoe, Glenshee and the Lecht.

Not least of Fuch's achievements in a heavily Presbyterian environment was the installation of his bar. Beyond the bar counter Struan encouraged people to do adventurous things. On hundreds of occasions when there was no hope of skiing because of the weather, Fuchs would conduct a birdwatching ramble round, say, Loch an Eilein.

One instructor, Dieter Bartsch, became head of the Austrian ski team, then the Swiss women, then the Norwegian men and recently the Swiss men. The world of skiing was amazed that from these Scottish roots he could help propel Konrad Bartelski and Fuchs's own son, Peter, into the top 20 of the 1974 World Championships at St Moritz.

But in 1980, Peter died, tragically young at 24, in a car accident.

The Fuchs worked on for four years, but the sparkle had gone from Struan. The frostbitten foot of Fuchs's war years deteriorated and in 1984 the hotel was sold. Three years later, Maurice died at the age of 94. There was one more emotional visit to Austria, in 1990, then for the Fuchs it was back to the croft they had made their home, next door to which their daughter, Lisi, and son-in-law, Davie, built a restaurant. On September 30 1990, Karl Fuchs died in his sleep, loyal to his adopted Cairngorms to the last. Eileen survives him, helping to administer the Karl and Peter Fuchs Memorial Fund for the benefit of young Speyside skiers, proud of the memorial plaque to Karl that now sits prominently on Cairngorm, weathering all the storms.

 Richard Brown's Struan, the Extraordinary Story of Karl and Eileen Fuchs, is available from Right Words, 14 Bedford Road, St Albans, Herts AL1 3BQ, at £9.95.

Even now, as the Cairngorm ski area he did so much to further is building a new £14m funicular railway serving up to 20 runs, many who ski there will recall the start they were given from the Struan House Hotel at nearby Carrbridge. The first ski hotel in Scotland, it was set up by this extraordinary man - Austrian dissident, Iron Cross-holder, Olympic-class skier, and pioneer, with his English wife Eileen, of much that is best in Scottish skiing. Not that there was anything "best" when Fuchs arrived in 1954. British Alpine climbers of the Victorian era used skis only as an adjunct to climbing - they may have learned their skills on Britain's many challenging rock faces, but not on its ski slopes, because these simply did not exist. Conditions in the Scottish Highlands were very different from those in the continental European ski resorts. A contemporary noted: "Snow slopes in Scotland take on a most puzzling kind of surface glare which defies the most hawk-eyed of skiers and reduces the short-sighted runner, with moisture on his glasses to a state of dithering funk... with uncertain snow, heather, rocks, windswept ice and all kinds of bunkers placed in the most awkward and trying positions, fast running is mere folly." But there was a Scottish Ski Club, made up of "skiers afraid of nothing", according to one continental visitor, "just as long as there is a little snow buried beneath the grass." But when the second world war intervened, winter training took on a darker purpose. Lord Hunt of Everest fame recalled the fierce blizzards suddenly whipping in from the Arctic. "On one occasion, fighting the way up to Loch Etchachan in the teeth of a gale, I watched [Frank] Smythe lifted by some gust and deposited 40ft below the track in a snow drift." After the war, people began to think again about Scotland's possibilities, but until Karl and Eileen Fuchs arrived there was no exact commercial focus, no person of sufficient charisma and credibility to make things happen on a scale that could ensure Aviemore and the Cairngorms became the first Scottish ski destination centre. It was in late 1954 that Fuchs pulled up the blinds of the overnight train from Euston and, for the first time, observed the Cairngorm mountains capped by winter snow. So much snow and only early November! There would not always be this much snow, but he wasn't to learn this until later. Fuchs was born in 1924 in Steiermark, Austria. His father was a steelworker, a man of the Schutzbund, or left, bitterly at odds with the nationalistic Heimwehr. After one particularly bloody street battle, the 10-year-old Karl was left desperately seeking his father among the dead and injured. It proved to be a memory that would stay with him his whole life - though his father did escape abroad, only to be imprisoned on his return until the end of the second world war. But there was no escaping the wartime call-up for Fuchs. He avoided fighting in Stalingrad and spent time in Yugoslavia. The Iron Cross came with his part in the demolition of a bridge, but after this, he and a few companions discarded their uniforms, lived off the land and made it back home in 1945. Eileen Knowles, the daughter of Maurice, a first-world-war RAF pilot, met Fuchs on an Austrian ski slope after the war. An honours history graduate from Newnham College, Cambridge, she had performed wartime civil service functions. Studying German in Vienna was not the most obvious post-war relief for Eileen, but her father was also learning the language in Austria while becoming one of the earliest guides to Major Walter Ingham, the Alpine tour operator. Karl's fluency of manner and ski style won over Eileen. She could speak German to him. He, initially, understood only one word in 10 of English. For the remainder of his days, Fuchs would speak what became known throughout the skier Highlands as "Scotstrian". So, "I kop sex bindle stick" meant he had carried six bundles of slalom poles up the mountain. By 1947 Fuchs had achieved minor fame as Austria's police ski champion and as a member of his country's training squad for the 1948 St Moritz Winter Olympics. Suddenly, with a crash on a Zugspitze training course, his ambitions were in ruins. His leg was so badly fractured he spent most of the next nine months in hospital. Skiing, though, was in his blood and when Eileen met him he had become one of the first to qualify from a new, nationally approved instructors' course. The pair quickly set their minds on a ski hotel, but motorcycle expeditions into the mountains from their apartment in Bruck found no suitable place at a price they could afford. Finally their thoughts turned to Britain. With Maurice as guide, and camping in two small tents, they found Snowdonia compelling, but with snow too uncertain for Britain's first ski school. Disappointed, they drove north to the Lake District to hear the same story. The Scottish Council for Physical Recreation suggested three areas - Glencoe, Ben Lawers and the north-facing Cairngorms, close to the village of Aviemore. The last proved to be first. In the late summer sunshine, all were enchanted by the beauty of Loch Morlich. Fuchs took out his binoculars and saw a steep, narrow corridor running to the left of the 4,084ft Cairngorm peak. A filling of snow and what a brilliant intermediate run it would make. The search was over. Or nearly. The Euston-Inverness railway ran beside the River Spey and the narrow B9152, which led from the A9 to the village of Aviemore - one big hotel and a few houses - and the even smaller village of Carrbridge. There they hit upon the Struan House Hotel, once a substantial double-fronted house with small, tower-like features, and, pricelessly, an annexe. And it was for sale, at £5,000. It was like their own first encounter, love at first sight. In November, 1954, they bought it. Scotland's first ski hotel was born, and with it the Austrian Ski School. They were little aware of what they were getting into."Horizontal" weather, wind-whipped Arctic sleet, can pierce a conventional ski anorak like grapeshot. Equally, the mist will lift or winds ease, and a day's sublime skiing follow. The Fuchs' fortunes were not dissimilar. Karl was always in the forefront of the fight for key amenities, but there were many schisms, battles and setbacks. Yet the visitors kept coming. In the 60s and 70s the Cairngorm upgrades proceeded slowly, its public still mostly from Scotland. London and the south-east were sniffy, and closer, in any case, to the Alps, but Manchester and the Midlands were catching on. In 1960, the all-important road to the ski area was opened; in 1961, the chairlift and the Sheiling and Ptarmigan lodges. The White Lady tow gave access to a fine slalom slope. Then, not of Fuch's making, but a bonus for its publicity - the Coylumbridge Hotel skating rink. A T-bar to Coire Cas followed, opening up more ski territory. Next, the Aviemore Centre - hotels, ski shops, pin tables and go-carts. Then an internationally recognised slalom race course and, in 1967, the British championships. On a sunny Saturday, more especially in late-season, when Scottish snow is often at its best, there were suddenly 6,000 skiers on Cairngorm: sleek and adept as contemporaries in Verbier or Val d'Isére. Today there are up to 20 runs to choose from, and Aonoch Mor beneath Ben Nevis, near Fort William has come to join the Cairngorms as a serious destination, along with the less built-up areas of Glencoe, Glenshee and the Lecht. Not least of Fuch's achievements in a heavily Presbyterian environment was the installation of his bar. Beyond the bar counter Struan encouraged people to do adventurous things. On hundreds of occasions when there was no hope of skiing because of the weather, Fuchs would conduct a birdwatching ramble round, say, Loch an Eilein. One instructor, Dieter Bartsch, became head of the Austrian ski team, then the Swiss women, then the Norwegian men and recently the Swiss men. The world of skiing was amazed that from these Scottish roots he could help propel Konrad Bartelski and Fuchs's own son, Peter, into the top 20 of the 1974 World Championships at St Moritz. But in 1980, Peter died, tragically young at 24, in a car accident. The Fuchs worked on for four years, but the sparkle had gone from Struan. The frostbitten foot of Fuchs's war years deteriorated and in 1984 the hotel was sold. Three years later, Maurice died at the age of 94. There was one more emotional visit to Austria, in 1990, then for the Fuchs it was back to the croft they had made their home, next door to which their daughter, Lisi, and son-in-law, Davie, built a restaurant. On September 30 1990, Karl Fuchs died in his sleep, loyal to his adopted Cairngorms to the last. Eileen survives him, helping to administer the Karl and Peter Fuchs Memorial Fund for the benefit of young Speyside skiers, proud of the memorial plaque to Karl that now sits prominently on Cairngorm, weathering all the storms.  Richard Brown's Struan, the Extraordinary Story of Karl and Eileen Fuchs, is available from Right Words, 14 Bedford Road, St Albans, Herts AL1 3BQ, at £9.95.

fields.headline: Long to reign over US
fields.standfirst: When John Norton lost his fortune, there was only one thing to do - declare himself the Emperor of the United States.  Sarah Burton  on the life of the man who abolished the presidency and issued edicts from a bedsit
fields.trailText: When John Norton lost his fortune, there was only one thing to do - declare himself the Emperor of the United States. Sarah Burton on the life of the man who abolished the presidency and issued edicts from a bedsit
fields.body:
The American election of 1876 was a close race. After 16 weeks of dispute over voting returns, the contested votes were awarded to Republican Rutherford B Hayes, only three days before the scheduled inauguration. His opponent, Democrat Samuel J Tilden, had won the popular vote.

Throughout the controversy, one man remained unconcerned. Joshua Norton knew who was really running the country.

Four years later on January 10 1880, a funeral cortege two miles long made its way through the streets of San Francisco. Estimates put the size of the crowd lining the route at between 10-30,000. Flags all over the city hung at half-mast. Businesses were closed out of respect. Many citizens had wept openly the previous day, when the San Francisco Chronicle had run the banner headline: 'Le roi est mort'. The silver plate on the rosewood coffin to which all eyes were turned read: "Joshua A Norton. Died January 8, 1880. Aged about 65."

Although Joshua Abraham Norton was given a funeral worthy of a king - the most elaborate the city had ever seen - his estate was worth less than $6. A stranger could never have guessed that the eccentrically dressed tramp who had collapsed and died on a rainy pavement was in fact Norton I, Emperor of the United States of America.

The man who ruled America for more than 20 years had been born in London on Valentine's Day, 1819, the son of an entrepreneur. The family moved to South Africa where John Norton prospered in shipping, leaving on his death a small fortune to his son. Joshua arrived in the city of San Francisco on the November 23 1849, carrying his $40,000 legacy in a trunk and opened a general store. He imported commodities such as coal, bricks, coffee, tea, flour and beef, held them until they were in great demand, then sold at a huge profit. As a result of his speculating and shrewd real-estate deals, Norton had accumulated a fortune of a quarter of a million dollars by 1853.

Flushed by success, he next endeavoured to corner the market in rice. Anticipating a shortage, he used his entire fortune to buy all the rice he could lay his hands on. The shortage never materialised - instead, the market was glutted. In 1857 Norton was declared bankrupt. Stunned and disorientated, he left his elegant town house for a shabby room in a seedy boarding house and, ironically, a job in a rice factory.

For the next two years little is known of Norton's movements. But while he wrapped himself in a cocoon of obscurity, an inner metamorphosis was taking place. When he finally emerged, the transformation was complete.

On the evening of September 16 1859, Norton called on the editor of the San Francisco Bulletin and gave him a document in which his intentions were clearly laid out. So extraordinary and impressive was his bearing that the editor not only accepted it, but printed it on the front page. Next day the people of San Francisco read it over breakfast.

"At the peremptory request and desire of a large majority of the citizens of these United States, I, Joshua Norton... declare and proclaim myself Emperor of these United States; and in virtue of the authority thereby in me vested, do hereby order and direct the representatives of the different states of the Union to assemble... to make such alterations in the existing laws of the Union as may ameliorate the evils under which the country is laboring, and thereby cause confidence to exist, both at home and abroad, both in our stability and in our integrity."

The statement was signed Norton I, Emperor of the United States and Protector of Mexico.

While the people of San Francisco were still absorbing this news, Norton issued a second edict, also published by the Bulletin, which enlarged on his motives: "It is represented to us that the universal suffrage, as now existing through the Union, is abused; that fraud and corruption prevent a fair and proper expression of the public voice, that open violation of the laws are constantly occurring, caused by mobs, parties, factions and undue influence of political sects . . ."

He went on to abolish Congress and, incensed when nobody took any notice, dissolved the Republic. Eventually he entirely lost his patience with Washington's disobedience, and went the whole hog, abolishing the office of president, and announcing that, henceforth, he would rule personally. (He was later to cast off his title of Protector of Mexico in response to the disconcerting news of the execution of his fellow emperor, Maximillian, by rebels.)

While all this legislation occupied much of Norton's time, there are many testaments to the serious dedication which characterised his approach to his new station in life. He immersed himself in the lives and preoccupations of his subjects, his diverse business involving the critical study of bus timetables, the inspection of sewers, drains and construction sites and the discussion of the crime rate with local police.

His determination to rule even-handedly caused him to attend a different religious service each week in order to avoid giving rise to sectarian jealousy. Born a Jew, Norton subsequently ordered the amalgamation of all faiths into one "Universal Religion". This was around the time of, and philosophically consistent with, his abolition of the Republican and Democrat parties. He disdained the trappings of majesty and walked, cycled or used public transport, showing himself daily in the streets in order to remain accessible and in touch with his subjects.

This stocky, bearded man, whose occupation was listed both in the census and in the city directory as "Emperor", cut a dignified if somewhat eccentric figure, striding about the city streets in a pale blue army officer's uniform with gold-plated epaulettes and brass buttons, topped by a tall black beaver hat with a bright green plume and a rosette. A pair of outsize boots was slit at the sides to accommodate his corns. A heavy sabre, donated by a local blacksmith, clanked at his heels, and he was never without both a walking-stick and a garish Chinese umbrella. The Emperor's regal air was further enhanced by a fresh rose in his buttonhole, if not by his constant retinue of his two famously well-behaved mongrel dogs, Lazarus and Bummer.

What was more astounding than the Emperor's appearance and behaviour, however, was the affection and deference shown to him by the citizens of San Francisco. People he met in the street bowed and curtsied. He was invited to arbitrate in local disputes, and faith in his judgment led to his frequently being com pared with Solomon. He invariably ate out, often at fashionable restaurants, and was rarely embarrassed by the presentation of a bill. Establishments he had patronised were entitled to post a sign: "By Appointment to His Imperial Majesty, Joshua Norton I", an endorsement guaranteed to attract customers. He rode free of charge on public transport and had complimentary seats for the theatre, where, upon his entrance, the audience always respectfully rose to its feet. Throughout his reign newspapers published all his royal decrees free of charge.

Despite his exalted status, the Emperor continued to rule America from his humble quarters in the lodging house. One commentator writes: "The Emperor held court in a shabby, rented room furnished with a camp bed, a table and chair, a faded rug and a broken washstand. His regalia hung on nails knocked into the walls, and pictures of Queen Victoria and the Empress Eugenie covered damp patches on the wallpaper." Norton had taken steps to procure more appropriate accommodation, as an edict of September 1870 shows: "Whereas our friends and adherents are dissatisfied that we are not better lodged, and hold that we ought to have had a suitable palace years ago;

"Whereas the treasonable proscriptive acts of some of the hotel keepers of this city have kept us out of decent rooms for our accommodations...

"Now, therefore, we do hereby command the proprietors of the Grand Hotel to forthwith furnish us with rooms, under penalty of being banished."

The Grand Hotel evidently complied, but soon found housing an emperor too exacting, forcing him to announce:

"Whereas the Grand Hotel, hitherto our headquarters, is in rebellion; now, therefore, we, Norton I, so hereby command the water companies to close down on them, and the gas company to give them no light, so as to bring them to terms."

He returned to the boarding house, and while friends continued to pay his rent and his travel and dining expenses were taken care of, there remained the problem of the imperial wardrobe. The day came when his eclectic ensemble became unacceptably tatty, whereupon another of his edicts appeared: "We, Norton I, have heard serious complaints that our wardrobe is a national disgrace..." The city's board of supervisors took the hint, and, with much ceremony, appropriated money for a new one, while the city's tailors vied for the honour of creating a replacement ensemble. Emperor Norton showed his appreciation by elevating all the city supervisors to noble rank.

"The Emp", as he was called by his intimates, dealt with the remaining expenses of daily life by issuing his own currency, or Bonds of Empire, designed and printed by himself and illustrated with his own portrait. The bonds promised to repay the bearer the full amount, plus 25% in 20 years' time and were accepted all over the city.

Despite the fact that Norton I was so well-known that visitors to San Francisco took home statuettes and postcards depicting his image, and he was generally paid his due respect, he would from time to time encounter subjects unaware of his identity and status. On one such occasion an ignorant employee of the Central Pacific Railroad refused him a free meal aboard one of its trains; the Emperor had no option but to abolish the company. Similarly, when a river boat captain ordered Norton off his boat for not paying his fare he retaliated by ordering the US navy to blockade all the company's vessels. In the face of this threat, the board of directors immediately apologised and presented the emperor with a lifetime free pass.

In 1867, an over-zealous policeman was sufficiently foolish to arrest him with the aim of subjecting him to "involuntary treatment for a mental disorder". Public opinion was so outraged that, fearing a riot, police chief Patrick Crowley went in person to release him from custody, and issued a full public apology. The Emperor accepted this with characteristic graciousness and urbanity, but newspapers angrily denounced the offence against his "imperial majesty", approvingly quoting a judge's opinion that: "He has shed no blood, robbed nobody, deprived nobody of his country, which is more than can be said for most fellows in the king line." The city of San Francisco endeavoured to make matters up to the Emperor by granting him free board and lodging for life.

Norton was a great correspondent, writing regularly to other heads of state with messages of sympathy or advice. He bombarded Bismarck with ingenious strategies during the Franco-Prussian war and, at the outbreak of the civil war in 1861, sent letters to President Lincoln and Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy, summoning them to San Francisco so that he could mediate. Undaunted by the absence of responses he threw in his lot with Lincoln, pledging his political and military allegiance. Lincoln wrote back politely declining to take up this generous offer.

Like many public figures, Norton was subject to interference in his life by complete strangers. False proclamations were sometimes concocted by journalists in order to boost newspaper sales, and bogus telegrams were a favourite ploy. One wag attempted to arrange a marriage for Norton with the widowed Queen Victoria. Telegrams of congratulations on the proposed match purported to come from Tsar Alexander, Disraeli and Ulysses S Grant.

San Francisco citizens' desire to promote the city as a friendly metropolis which tolerates - indeed celebrates - all kinds of eccentricity has been suspected of enlarging and enhancing the myth of Emperor Norton. Some have reasonably cast doubt on the extent to which Norton's lifestyle was good-naturedly subsidised by the people of the city, while others have suspected the notion of the general compliance of banks and others with Norton's currency. (We do know for certain that the First National Bank refused to honour one of Norton's cheques for $100 in 1869, because he responded by ordering the confiscation of the bank's assets.)

We may smile at the widely cited "fact" that three seats were always reserved for the Emperor at the opening night of any theatrical entertainment in the city (the other two were for Lazarus and Bummer), and also at the claim that thousands of people showed up at his dog's funeral because the Emperor was so upset. If this seems fanciful, it is certainly the case that when Bummer died in 1865, the royal pooch was sufficiently famous for journalist Samuel Clemens to publish his epitaph.

Was Joshua Norton mad? Those who knew him personally stated categorically that apart from his insistence that he was an emperor, he was "perfectly reasonable and highly intellectual. He was regarded without sarcasm as an honest, noble, intelligent man. People respected him because he respected them". It seems likely that, as some claim, he suffered a nervous breakdown following his bankruptcy, and that this experience opened the door somehow to what followed. The self-made man had gone down the pan, and Norton re-invented himself, this time as a self-made emperor - in that now well-worn phrase - "in people's hearts".

And if he was crazy, just how crazy was he? He anticipated a civil war in America as early as July 1860 and also called for funding for research into the potential of "aerial machines" - both barmy ideas at the time. As far as his ideas for global peace went, he was sufficiently unhinged to call upon other world leaders to join him in creating a "League of Nations" where international disputes could be resolved peacefully. Locally, he had the distinctly unusual idea of filling in parts of San Francisco Bay in order to create more space for development. But more preposterous than any of his other notions was his proposal for "a suspension bridge to be built from Oakland Point to Goat Island, and thence to Telegraph Hill." This was at a time when the only suspension bridges in existence were in remote parts of Africa.

Half a century later the Bay Bridge (or Golden Gate) was constructed exactly as Norton had suggested and it still bears a plaque commemorating his "prophetic wisdom". His memory also lives on where he now lies, at Woodlawn Memorial Park in Colma. His red granite tombstone reads: Norton I, Emperor of the United States, Protector of Mexico, Joshua A Norton, 1819-1880. There are no quotation marks.

 Sarah Burton's book Impostors: Six Kinds of Liar, published in hardback by Viking (£15.99) will be published by Penguin (£7.99) in March.

He bombarded Bismarck with ingenious strategies during the Franco-Prussian war and, at the outbreak of the civil war in 1861, sent letters to President Lincoln and Jefferson Davis, president of the Confederacy, summoning them to San Francisco so that he could mediate. Undaunted by the absence of responses he threw in his lot with Lincoln, pledging his political and military allegiance. Lincoln wrote back politely declining to take up this generous offer. Like many public figures, Norton was subject to interference in his life by complete strangers. False proclamations were sometimes concocted by journalists in order to boost newspaper sales, and bogus telegrams were a favourite ploy. One wag attempted to arrange a marriage for Norton with the widowed Queen Victoria. Telegrams of congratulations on the proposed match purported to come from Tsar Alexander, Disraeli and Ulysses S Grant. San Francisco citizens' desire to promote the city as a friendly metropolis which tolerates - indeed celebrates - all kinds of eccentricity has been suspected of enlarging and enhancing the myth of Emperor Norton. Some have reasonably cast doubt on the extent to which Norton's lifestyle was good-naturedly subsidised by the people of the city, while others have suspected the notion of the general compliance of banks and others with Norton's currency. (We do know for certain that the First National Bank refused to honour one of Norton's cheques for $100 in 1869, because he responded by ordering the confiscation of the bank's assets.) We may smile at the widely cited "fact" that three seats were always reserved for the Emperor at the opening night of any theatrical entertainment in the city (the other two were for Lazarus and Bummer), and also at the claim that thousands of people showed up at his dog's funeral because the Emperor was so upset. If this seems fanciful, it is certainly the case that when Bummer died in 1865, the royal pooch was sufficiently famous for journalist Samuel Clemens to publish his epitaph. Was Joshua Norton mad? Those who knew him personally stated categorically that apart from his insistence that he was an emperor, he was "perfectly reasonable and highly intellectual. He was regarded without sarcasm as an honest, noble, intelligent man. People respected him because he respected them". It seems likely that, as some claim, he suffered a nervous breakdown following his bankruptcy, and that this experience opened the door somehow to what followed. The self-made man had gone down the pan, and Norton re-invented himself, this time as a self-made emperor - in that now well-worn phrase - "in people's hearts". And if he was crazy, just how crazy was he? He anticipated a civil war in America as early as July 1860 and also called for funding for research into the potential of "aerial machines" - both barmy ideas at the time. As far as his ideas for global peace went, he was sufficiently unhinged to call upon other world leaders to join him in creating a "League of Nations" where international disputes could be resolved peacefully. Locally, he had the distinctly unusual idea of filling in parts of San Francisco Bay in order to create more space for development. But more preposterous than any of his other notions was his proposal for "a suspension bridge to be built from Oakland Point to Goat Island, and thence to Telegraph Hill." This was at a time when the only suspension bridges in existence were in remote parts of Africa. Half a century later the Bay Bridge (or Golden Gate) was constructed exactly as Norton had suggested and it still bears a plaque commemorating his "prophetic wisdom". His memory also lives on where he now lies, at Woodlawn Memorial Park in Colma. His red granite tombstone reads: Norton I, Emperor of the United States, Protector of Mexico, Joshua A Norton, 1819-1880. There are no quotation marks.  Sarah Burton's book Impostors: Six Kinds of Liar, published in hardback by Viking (£15.99) will be published by Penguin (£7.99) in March.

fields.headline: Self obsession
fields.standfirst: Wouldn't it be funny if those on the streets pitied us for our inability to be happy without getting smashed, despite all our comforts?
fields.trailText: Wouldn't it be funny if those on the streets pitied us for our inability to be happy without getting smashed, despite all our comforts?
fields.body:
Resolution. Even the word I don't like. It sounds like revolution, then sneaks away with a weasly ssss. And, of course, it's the opposite of revolution - it won't change anything. Sure, it'll make you feel like the hero of your own story, but isn't that a bit of a sad desire to start with?

Attach the word to New Year's, of course, and you've got a recipe for true cretinism. Is there still anyone over the age of 12 who makes New Year's resolutions? If I've learned anything from 41 years of being on this planet, it's that uttering the words "I'm never going to (insert pet vice here) again" make you look about as worldly as Tom Kitten. Yes, you will, and yes, your words will come back to haunt you, making your defeat all the more poignant. Then you'll end up saying, "Well, I'm strong enough now to give into temptation just the once", and before you know it you're doing tricks for bottle tops in Cardboard City.

I am of the opinion that interfering in people's self-destructiveness, or even in their mild hell- raising, actually makes the situation far worse. The three great addiction stories of the year were those of Robbie Williams, Daniella Westbrook and Will Self, and the various fates of these famous addicts carried an interesting lesson. Self has taken many cures for heroin addiction, administered both by himself and by alleged professionals. But despite a lot of hypocritical cant from Mr Dictionary-Swallower over the years, he had never been truly drug-free for more than five minutes in the past 30 years or so until earlier this year: suddenly, while wrapping a huge slab of dope in a perfume-drenched cloth in order to take it to America to get him through a reading tour, he suddenly got this overview of himself and looked down at this fortysomething father of three indulging in this terminally undignified activity. That was what got him clean, he swears; not the expensive therapy or the self-loathing, but the sheer inappropriateness of it all.

The simple difference between Self, who did give up, and Williams and Westbrook, both of whom fall off the wagon more often than cheap sound systems, is that Self was almost twice their age and had therefore done loads more drugs.

There comes a day when intoxication, like anything else, becomes boring, and a clean-up undertaken under these circumstances would seem to stand a whole lot more chance of sticking than one that is tried because society doesn't approve or you might get the sack from a soap opera. Vitally, Westbrook and Williams are young and beautiful - she still looks better with just the one nostril than most of us do with two - and there is nothing like being young and beautiful to make you feel immortal.

Over Christmas and the New Year, all of our shabby double standards about intoxication come into play. As we reel from party to party, well-fed and employed, we are meant to heed the words of the Homeless Tsar - and in this case how appropriate that title is, tsars being a byword for treating oppressed people very badly in a cold climate - and not give as much as a spare 50p piece to the poor youngster on the blanket outside the bank in case he or she spends it all on drink! But if being homeless at Christmas or the New Year doesn't deserve a drink, what does? Wouldn't it be funny, though totally understandable, if those who live on the streets looked at us and pitied us for our inability to be happy without getting smashed, despite all the comforts we have?

While reminding us that every junkie started out on a puff of marijuana and therefore we can't be trusted to try it without being punished by law (and at the same time condemning the nanny state), the curtain-twitching Tory press will contrive both to egg us on and rein us in where drink is concerned, this year as all others.

Do these hacks actually get paid for reminding us to drink one glass of water for every glass of alcohol? Does everyone not know by now that this is wise? And does anyone actually do it? But if you think about it, the Alternate Glass Of Water theory is to the liver what the Marquess of Queensbury rules are to fighting; that is, they don't actually protect the body in the long run, but just enable it to take punishment for longer without switching off, as it would if left to itself while being drowned in alcohol or hit around the head.

In both cases, something that is obviously very bad for people is encouraged by "sensible" precautions, which simply add up to more profits for drinks manufacturers and boxing promoters alike.

Having said that, I certainly plan to spend another happy New Year insensible with drink, because that's the kind of crazy guy I am. But I do so in the knowledge that I am as much a drug abuser as the sweet-faced junkie in the street, and, like him - but unlike your self-deluding "sensible" drinker - I won't be boring friends with tales of my hangovers or swearing never to do it again. Once you're hooked, you're hooked, and then all that matters is carrying off your addiction with a certain self-aware dignity until such time as it becomes that worst of all things, a bore, to you. Then, and only then, can you really think seriously about getting and staying clean.

If old Alanis Morissette was here, I bet she'd say that this next thing was ironic, but nevertheless: it is sad and strange that even though we may behave bestially when intoxicated, what separates us from our animal friends is the knowledge that we are all going to die. And if that isn't the scariest, creepiest thing you've ever heard, then you're a cooler customer than me, Gunga Din. Mankind drinks and drugs himself insensible because he knows he's not around for long, and that, not some highfalutin heraldry, is what elevates us above the rest of the natural world. "By making a beast of himself man forgets the pain of being human," said no less than Sam Beckett.

So, next time you see some disgusting drunk - be he suited and booted and reeling home from the City, or sitting on the pavement with piles and a pet rat called Satan - just think: maybe the reason he's like that is because he's simply more sensitive than sensible, social-drinking, Chardonnay-sipping you. Maybe you're the brute, and that's why he's there and you're here, reading the Guardian like a civilised human being. Happy New Year!

fields.headline: How to...
fields.standfirst: Wear glasses
fields.trailText: Wear glasses
fields.body:
The world can be divided into two kinds of people: those who wear glasses, and those who think they don't need glasses. You can spot the first group because they're wearing glasses. People in the second group are also easy to spot because they walk past you in corridors, park on your front lawn and screw up their eyes when you ask them if they can see the bus in front of them.

Once you decide to get glasses, you need to choose which type. Generally, there are two kinds of glasses you'll need: the ones you need for reading and the ones you need to find the ones you need for reading. Avoid bifocals, however: these have a nasty line halfway up the lens that gives the impression that your head is half full. Bifocals mean you can't read anything higher than your chest or see anything coming lower than your chest. They're a nightmare for short people reading timetables at bus stops and looking for the bus coming up the hill. Varifocals, meanwhile, mean you can focus on anything as long as you keep your head permanently in motion.

You can repair your own glasses. If the bridge breaks, simply wind a yard of Sellotape around it. Similarly, if one of the ear struts goes, keep your glasses on your head with a thick piece of elastic. Remember, personality is more important than looks. People with limited personality buy cool, trendy frames - the rule is that the straighter the frame, the cooler you are, and the rounder the squarer.

But red-framed glasses are not cool, have never been cool and will never be cool. Red glasses suit nobody. Everyone in the world knows this, apart from a very small number of people who buy glasses with red frames.

There's an old saying that men don't make passes at women with glasses. That's generally because women with glasses can see what's on offer and make themselves scarce. Some older women wear glasses that hang from gold chains around their necks. This is code for, 'I am open to suggestion of sexual practices involving chains and bondage.' Ask them about it next time you're in the library.

The most bizarre thing about buying glasses is that you go into an optician with lots of lovely frames, you pick a pair you like, slip them on, go to the mirror and realise you can't see a bloody thing.

But once you've got glasses, you actually look rather clever - especially if, before you got them, you spent a lot of time walking face first into lamp-posts and off the edge of cliffs.

webTitle: Alexander Chancellor: Abstinence makes the heart grow fonder

fields.headline: Abstinence makes the heart grow fonder
fields.trailText: Bush is not only heir to a rather unattractive constitutional dynasty, but he has all the right instincts for a constitutional monarch.
fields.body:
I hope you have all had a very happy Christmas and are feeling ready for the challenges of the New Year. The pedants say that 2001 is, in fact, the first year of the new millennium, but luckily we have ignored them and got the thing over with already. The Millennium Dome is now history, a memorial to the greatest act of folly of Tony Blair's first term.

The only useful purpose that the Dome is ever likely to serve is to be a powerful anti-Labour image for William Hague to put on his election posters. But even that will not suffice to get him elected. Blair will get the second term he craves, for most voters, even conservative ones, would cheerfully sacrifice even their national independence and their monarchy to keep little baldie out of Number 10.

So this is going to be a good year for Blair, whatever it may be like for the rest of us. We will continue to submit to being modernised, devolved and having the countryside strewn with hideous new housing so that he may enjoy all the trappings of office for another few years. Then he will probably be ousted by the "New Conservatives" under a reforming new leader, perhaps Kenneth Clarke. Clarke, it seems to me, personifies the Conservatives' only hope of re-election, a fact that the party will come to accept, even if it hates him for his love of things European.

This will also, of course, be a good year for George W Bush Jr, who after 40 years of doing nothing much except drinking and another eight doing nothing much except killing people in Texas, will ascend to the presidency of the US on January 20. We may, with the Guardian's encouragement, be starting down the road to republicanism in this country, but Dubya will turn out to be America's first monarch since King George III. He is not only the heir to a rather unattractive dynasty, like his Hanoverian predecessor, but he seems to have all the right instincts for a constitutional monarch. His court will be peopled by family retainers, and Dick Cheney will serve as his prime minister and run the government. Meanwhile, he will perform the ceremonial functions of the head of state.

He might do that rather well. He seems to be of a lazy but amiable disposition, appropriate to monarchs without power. I write before the details of the inauguration ceremony have been announced, but I would be surprised if he didn't put on a show to rival that of President Kennedy in 1960. It will be interesting to see if he wears a top hat and tail coat when he takes the oath of office on the steps of the Capitol.

His successor in four years' time could easily be Senator Hillary Clinton, for whom this is also going to be a bumper year. She has been through a lot, the poor woman. But it's all coming right now. The $8m advance she has been promised for her memoir of her White House years is said to be the second-largest book advance ever, exceeded only by the Pope's $8.5m advance in 1994.

The Clintons are not at all rich, and they owe a great deal of money to lawyers. But they won't be poor for long. Monica Lewinsky has seen to that. The huge advance is attributed to Hillary having guaranteed that she will unburden herself on the matter of husband's behaviour with the White House intern. Bill Clinton, in his turn, is expected to get almost as large a book advance for public hand-wringing about his adultery. Only Monica is looking like a bit of a loser.

Bill, incidentally, seems to have exercised great influence over America's teenagers, nearly a third of whom regard oral sex as "abstinent behaviour". This is what Bill was also clearly thinking when he insisted that he had not had "sexual relations" with "that woman". In 1996, Congress allocated $50m to give to states that promised to teach "abstinence from sexual activity outside marriage as the expected standard for school-age children". That would have been all right if the young hadn't had their own ideas of what abstinence means.

A survey of American boys between the ages of 15 and 19 has shown that half of them have received oral sex from a girl without generally regarding it as "sex". Research has also shown that there is no consensus among teenagers as to what constitutes abstinence. It is a pity, this, because medical experts insist that oral sex, while it won't make a girl pregnant, can transmit sexual diseases of most kinds, including Aids.

I used to hate talk of "challenges" as sounding altogether too challenging, but now I rather like the word for bestowing an aura of accomplishment on the performance of routine tasks such as paying bills and writing columns for the Guardian. Next year should be full of such challenges, and I am rather looking forward to them. I hope you are, too.

fields.headline: Floods and tears
fields.trailText: Yes - I, too, was once a glamorous bastard. But I've paid for it since
fields.body:
'I first smelled a rat when he started to go to t'ai chi three times a week." Elaine is lamenting the departure of treacherous Tom, who has bunked off to Italy with Francesca. I remember Francesca. She was already in the picture, luring him off on Tuscan hols, "with a group of people", years ago when Tom and I had our little scene.

"I realise now," sobs Elaine, "it's been going on for months. He's treated me like a doormat. The bastard!"

Uneasily aware that my little scene with Tom also went on for months. Yes - I, too, was once a glamorous bastard. But I've paid for it since. Now the gods have stapled my nose to a doormat as wide as Wembley.

"Now that I know what a bastard Tom was," muses Elaine, "I realise that poor old Gordon wasn't as bad as all that, after all. At least he didn't betray me."

Whereas he did betray me, of course - with Elaine, though she is too distraught to remember. Tempted to deliver stinging reminder, but know full well that, if I did, she would burst into tears for the fourth time this morning, and I'd have to spend the rest of the day dissuading her from suicide.

And where is Gordon? Having his post-yuletide migraine, which he is artfully prolonging in order to avoid his families. I was on the point of having a migraine myself, but the bastard got in first. "A bit like President Clinton, then," I suggest.

Elaine looks blank. "What?"

"You know - now we've seen what the next lot's like, Clinton doesn't seem so bad after all."

"Oh yes. That's right." She delivers this line in a tired, offhand tone. How dare I change the subject from her sacred dilemma? I must know by now that Elaine has no interest whatever in politics. But her salvation is in sight. Aunt Elspeth comes in, awash with the milk of human kindness and proffering a small bottle.

"Elaine, dearrr, this is my Ignatia. It's a homeopathic rrremedy for grrrief and loss. It might be worrrth a trrry." Elaine accepts it gratefully. She is sucking up to the aunt as if her life depends on it. "I wonderrr, dearrr, if we ought to get anotherrr surveyorrr to take a look at your poorrr house?"

"Oh, I can't bear to go back there at the moment, Auntie," sighs Elaine. How dare she call Elspeth auntie? She's had my husband, she's had my lover, now she wants my bleeding Great Aunt. Although Elspeth isn't strictly speaking my aunt, either. And though I saw her through her urinary crisis in Swindon, aunt may be starting to regret she gave me that large cheque recently.

Elaine has a trump card, you see: Little Sandy, who creeps into the room and kneels down beside Aunt Elspeth's chair. He plays with his cars on her lap. "The surveyors will all be on holiday for another two weeks, I bet," I point out, getting up briskly and hoping for a moment to myself. "I'll go and put the kettle on."

"Mum?" Harriet enters the kitchen looking puzzled. "My radiator's gone cold." Oh God! The oil's run out - I knew there was something vital we'd forgotten.

Aunt enters, looking grave. "Dulcie, dearrr, we must do something to help poorrr Elaine." Just as long as it doesn't involve that £50,000 you gave me, Auntie.

fields.headline: The questionnaire
fields.standfirst: Simon Morley
fields.trailText: Simon Morley
fields.body:
Simon Morley, 33, and fellow Australian, David Friend, devised Puppetry Of The Penis, a show in which they manipulate their genitalia into various shapes, objects and landmarks. They took the act, which started as a party trick, to the 1998 Melbourne Comedy Festival, and a tour of Australia followed. They appeared at Edinburgh this year, and currently can be seen at the Whitehall Theatre, London.

What is your idea of perfect happiness?

To be healthy, with too much money, a wife and children, in a tropical climate.

What is your greatest fear?

Being unable to control my bodily functions on stage.

Which living person do you most admire and why?

Muhammad Ali - he broke ground as a sportsman, entertainer and an ambassador for equality.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?

One of my first performances of the show - no one laughed. I was asked to put my pants on and leave.

What is your greatest extravagance?

Fine wine and food.

What objects do you always carry with you?

What else but the tools of my trade.

What is your favourite smell?

Bacon frying.

What is your favourite fantasy?

Bit of a pattern emerging here: in the sun with beautiful women pouring me wine and feeding me bacon.

What makes you depressed?

Wars and financial woes.

Should the royal family be scrapped?

No, just confined to their quarters.

Do you believe in capital punishment?

No, people should live with their crimes.

Do you believe in monogamy?

Yes, but it's not for everybody.

What or who is the greatest love of your life?

My mother.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?

Haven't we all?

What is your greatest regret?

Can't say I have one - it's all a learning experience.

How often do you have sex?

Not nearly enough.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?

More sex.

What would your motto be?

You can't die wondering.

Do you believe in life after death?

Yes - I just hope they have bacon.

How would you like to be remembered?

I don't think I have much choice - it'll be as The Penis Man.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?

Be thankful for what you have.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Slimming with salsa
fields.trailText: Slimming with salsa
fields.body:
The subject Coming soon to your kitchen: the Calorie Tsar, ordering you to shed the visible signs of festive excess. The Knowledge's Liberator: salsa. Not the terpsichorean type, but an all-purpose flavouring of rare distinction.

The basics Overeating is the prevailing Seasonal Affection Disorder, and in two days we'll be trying to undo the damage. You are entitled to do your undoing with painful self-denial. The Knowledge prefers to rely on salsa, one of the few consumables that tastes as good without fattening ingredients as with them.

The details Salsa is a relish of sorts, ubiquitous in Mesoamerica and common enough in Italy - and in Indian and Middle Eastern cooking, though they don't use that name. Beginner's fundamentals: chopped parsley and onion. Pepper and a little salt. Enough lemon juice and/or vinegar to moisten the melange. Mix briefly. Result: something that's inexpressibly delicious on any form of animal, vegetable, cereal or leguminous chow. Variations: confer glorious variety with capers, other fresh herbs, anchovies, chillies, other alliums, tomatoes (in season), lime, innumerable spices, diced capsicums, etc. If you're not worried about calories, a little extra virgin olive oil will sit here happily. And even with oil, salsa's calorie count still makes cottage cheese look fattening.

Where to buy Supermarkets charge an arm and a leg for plastic coffins containing a few sprigs of fresh herbs. Use your legs to hunt down a greengrocer selling big, loose bunches, and your arms to carry them home. The other basics: available anywhere, but why not make a new year's resolution to give less money to PLCs and more to FLTs (Friendly Local Traders)? They need you.

The easy way out When you see a jar of something calling itself salsa, turn around and walk away.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Malcolm Gluck recovers from Christmas and seeks out more booze
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer, if media reports of its recent problems are to be believed, may not be in the party mood, but for those of you who are, then there is no better place from which to acquire the wine. Gold Label Sparkling Chardonnay (16 points out of 20, £5.99), from France, is an excellent opener, for both this column and the party. It is a dry, subtly fruity bubbly that offers elegance and classic tailoring at a third of the price of a comparable champagne.

Two further splendid M&S wines, a red and a white, both in limited distribution, are Chateau de Landure Cuvée de l'Abbé Frégouse Minervois 1998 and McLean's Farm Semillon 1999, from Australia. The red is one of those wines of which people will think as they regard it on the table, 'Oh! How quaintly Gothic and expensive-looking', and when you reveal its provenance will then refuse to believe that you bought it from a high-street purveyor of underwear. This disbelief will be enhanced when they taste the fantastic fruit - chocolate, pears and blackcurrants - and superb lingering tannins. The after-taste? Pure Venezuelan chocolate - rich, dark, exotic. A stunning wine, rating 18 points and costing £7.99. The white carries hints of straw and burnt butter - deliciously vegetal and toasty - which haunt the rich melon fruit that has undertones of raspberry and lemon. A beautiful wine, it, too, costs £7.99 and rates 17 points.

At Majestic there is the truly exceptional Champagne Oeil de Perdrix, a non-vintage blend rating 16 points and on offer at £12.75 if you buy two bottles or more before January 29. It has an onion-skin, or partridge's eye, hue and is extremely dry and well-wrought. There is also, at this retailer, a rather terrific Cava: Freixenet Cuvée DS 1996 (16.5 points, on offer at £9.59 if you buy six bottles or more before January 29). There is stunning complexity and crispness here, and for the money it knocks Krug into a hatted cock (sorry, old joke of my history teacher).

At Morrisons there is Castillo de Molina Reserve Chardonnay 1998 (16 points, on offer for a fiver until January 7). It is a gorgeous butter and strawberry/ melon/lemon construct. Winter Hill Red Vin de Pays d'Oc 1999 (14 points, two bottles for a fiver until January 7) is packed with bargain bonny fruit. Penfolds Koonunga Hill Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, on offer at £3.99 until January 7) is one of this brand's best vintages for years. A beautifully couth Aussie fruit of texture, style and controlled lushness, it is deliciously succulent. Villa Montes Cabernet Sauvignon 1999 (15.5 points, on offer at £3.99 until January 7), from Chile, is very ripe, severely plummy, very entertaining, and has overt tannins to give it balance and character. Rosemount Chardonnay 1999 (16 points, normally £6.99, down to a fiver until January 7) is one of the most stylish Australian whites in the country.

Another Aussie, Lindemans Bin 65 Chardonnay 2000 (16.5 points, on offer at £3.99 until January 7), has acquired a nutty undertone in this vintage. It is still up there as one of the Aussie's best-value chardonnays at £4.99, but with a quid off it's a fantastic bargain.

At Oddbins there is Pierre Gimonnet et Fils 'Cuis 1er Cru' Blanc de Blancs Brut Champagne (16 points, £14.99), which is hugely elegant and civilised and beats many a grande marque bubbly costing three times more. At Tesco there is Valdivieso Sparkling Merlot 1998 (16 points, £5.99, 30 branches only, 0800 505555 for details), from Chile, and what an exuberant red bubbly it is. Mellow, ripe, rich, hugely fruity and great with spicy goings-on (it was a triumph with my vindaloo), as well as eccentric and vividly entertaining.

Waitrose has its own-label non-vintage Cava Brut (15.5 points, £4.99), a palate-teasing blend of local grapes that produces individuality and bite. It's on offer until January 7: buy two bottles and you save £1.50 on the aggregated price.

Booths has Concerto Lambrusco 1998 (16 points, £6.49), from Italy, another sparkling red. But Lambrusco , you say? Bury, please, all snobbish thoughts. This is the real thing, as drunk in Modena or Parma with charcuterie or a robust stew.

fields.headline: Revival of the fittest
fields.standfirst: New millennium - new interiors opportunities? Hardly, says Charlotte Abrahams. Instead of looking forward and embracing the future with open arms, 2000 meant pinching ideas from the past. But at least only the good ones got through
fields.trailText: New millennium - new interiors opportunities? Hardly, says Charlotte Abrahams. Instead of looking forward and embracing the future with open arms, 2000 meant pinching ideas from the past. But at least only the good ones got through
fields.body:
Well, we didn't end up living in pure white space stations, after all. In fact, it seemed that by the time the future became the present, we didn't really like it. We spent 1999 planning for the millennium year, but when it arrived it was a disappointment. There was Peter Snow on millennium eve ready to chart the devastating spread of the Y2K bug, but nowhere got sick. The Dome, hyped as the globe's most exciting attraction, was a disaster. The Millennium Bridge opened to great acclaim but promptly closed again due to a wobble. Even the London Eye, now, along with Tate Modern, hailed as one of the few successes, failed to open in time for the big night. No wonder we found ourselves looking back.

In the home, we took inspiration from the recent past: 70s suburbia was hip again, and suddenly orange was cool, green was in and anyone who was anyone was doing shagpile (albeit renamed Flokati). The 80s staged a comeback, too. Not as brash as first time around, but there was a bit of glamour and a lot of shiny black, no doubt as a reaction against the pure white minimalism of the 90s.

We were keen to stay close to home, as well. Having travelled the globe in search of interior styles, this year we decided to see what Britain itself had to offer. Traditional became cool again as true British companies took themselves in hand. Wedgwood employed one hot modern designer after another, including Nick Munro, who took the signature blue-and-white Jasperware and relaunched it in smooth black-and-white. Thomas Goode signed up Paul Smith, Dartington Crystal called in Nigel Coates, Burberry got hip and even Peter Jones got itself a new image.

The home-with-office-space became an increasingly popular target for designers. Working at home has its advantages - no commuting, no boss monitoring your calls, and it works well with family life - but it has disadvantages, too: such as where to put everything. Designers and that new breed of personal therapist, the storage consultant, threw themselves into the task of solving the problem. Books rolled out full of photographs of streamlined home offices and tips on how we could get the look, while ingenious computer desks, shelving systems and even an office-in-a-cupboard appeared in stores. The message was clear: to get ahead, get an efficient desk system.

Organic was a buzzword in 2000, and not just for food. Organic living was the in thing; a look characterised by the heavy use of wood and grasses. I don't know if anybody bought one, but the interiors press went crazy for a block of oak that was turned by hip young designers Twelve into an incense burner-cum-stool. It was rustic, it was earthy and it looked great with white concrete.

Bamboo, which is not only organic but also very Zen (another key look for 2000), was huge. We bought it as furniture, as flooring and as a garden plant. Easy to grow, it took over from more traditional plants. And if you were really with it, you got it in black. Logically, for a nation anxious to get back to nature, gardens were hip again. But not traditional gardens with patches of lawn surrounded by beds of marigolds - 2000 gardens were outdoor rooms and 2000 gardeners wouldn't be seen dead digging out and potting on. No, modern gardening is all about vast concrete walls, steel sculptures, paint, decking and the odd tropical plant. And while flowers might not have been much in evidence outside, inside they were everywhere. Florists were smart and flower prints were cool again, as modern girls realised they could like pretty things and still be successful. Of course, not everyone wanted to bring back the chintz: there were plenty of people who were more than happy in their dead plain homes. But plain was just not on. So they went geometric. Stripes came first, then circles - everything from polka-dot beakers to target tiles, then abstract and vaguely futuristic shapes championed by DNA, a Birmingham-based design company that dominated the cushion scene.

Print also reappeared on the walls as paper returned as a credible wall covering. At least, it returned to the mocked-up homes of the style mags, which were full of Sharon Elphick's urban images, Neisha Crosland's prints and Ottilie Stevenson's traditional-meets-modern stripes and flowers. It remains to be seen if the prize of fresh, interesting walls will be enough to persuade us to go back to cutting and pasting.

Tired of sanding, waxing and cold feet, we did not need persuading to give carpet another go, however. The boldest homeowners had a brief flirtation with patterned stuff, but it didn't take off. Years of wooden floors had made us appreciate the space-enhancing qualities of plain flooring, so swirls were out. Out, too, were carpets woven from rough grasses - they were uncomfortable and impossible to clean.

Comfort was important, you see, and we also chose our furniture accordingly. Day beds were everywhere. Those with an interest in art and who had lots of cash went for Rachel Whiteread's version, originally made for an exhibition but later put into production by SCP; the rest of us made do with Habitat's clever brand of cheapish modern chic or went for the other style of laid-back seating, the lounger. Last seen on a crazy paving patio, loungers were this time meant to be used inside as well. The best ones were made of the kind of plastic that didn't need a foam-filled cushion to stop it sticking to your skin.

But then, plastic was the designer's material of choice. Chairs made by everyone from Jasper Morrison to Ikea piled off production lines and into our homes, where they looked cool and wore well. The design world liked them, too: this year's 100% Design/Blueprint manufacturing award went to Magis, makers of Morrison's moulded plastic Air Chair.

The year's other big design gong, the Peugeot Design Award, went to an unknown bloke called Hector Serrano for his fabulously tactile light, Super Patata. It was the obvious choice: this was the year of the light, and Super Patata - basically a salt-filled latex balloon that can be moulded to different shapes - represented everything that is exciting about modern lighting design.

But it was a high point in what turned out to be rather a disappointing start to the third millennium. On the high street, everything looked much the same, with the exception of Habitat, which, with designers such as Matthew Hilton on the team, seemed to do little wrong, and Muji, which continued to expand, bringing its distinctive no-brand Japanese goods to the British people. At the other end, 100% Design, Britain's version of the Milan furniture fair, was slick but rather dull. Still, look on the bright side. No great innovations means no great change. So, if you didn't get a plastic chair and a sensual interactive light for 2000, you can always get one for 2001
