Organic living was the in thing; a look characterised by the heavy use of wood and grasses. I don't know if anybody bought one, but the interiors press went crazy for a block of oak that was turned by hip young designers Twelve into an incense burner-cum-stool. It was rustic, it was earthy and it looked great with white concrete. Bamboo, which is not only organic but also very Zen (another key look for 2000), was huge. We bought it as furniture, as flooring and as a garden plant. Easy to grow, it took over from more traditional plants. And if you were really with it, you got it in black. Logically, for a nation anxious to get back to nature, gardens were hip again. But not traditional gardens with patches of lawn surrounded by beds of marigolds - 2000 gardens were outdoor rooms and 2000 gardeners wouldn't be seen dead digging out and potting on. No, modern gardening is all about vast concrete walls, steel sculptures, paint, decking and the odd tropical plant. And while flowers might not have been much in evidence outside, inside they were everywhere. Florists were smart and flower prints were cool again, as modern girls realised they could like pretty things and still be successful. Of course, not everyone wanted to bring back the chintz: there were plenty of people who were more than happy in their dead plain homes. But plain was just not on. So they went geometric. Stripes came first, then circles - everything from polka-dot beakers to target tiles, then abstract and vaguely futuristic shapes championed by DNA, a Birmingham-based design company that dominated the cushion scene. Print also reappeared on the walls as paper returned as a credible wall covering. At least, it returned to the mocked-up homes of the style mags, which were full of Sharon Elphick's urban images, Neisha Crosland's prints and Ottilie Stevenson's traditional-meets-modern stripes and flowers. It remains to be seen if the prize of fresh, interesting walls will be enough to persuade us to go back to cutting and pasting. Tired of sanding, waxing and cold feet, we did not need persuading to give carpet another go, however. The boldest homeowners had a brief flirtation with patterned stuff, but it didn't take off. Years of wooden floors had made us appreciate the space-enhancing qualities of plain flooring, so swirls were out. Out, too, were carpets woven from rough grasses - they were uncomfortable and impossible to clean. Comfort was important, you see, and we also chose our furniture accordingly. Day beds were everywhere. Those with an interest in art and who had lots of cash went for Rachel Whiteread's version, originally made for an exhibition but later put into production by SCP; the rest of us made do with Habitat's clever brand of cheapish modern chic or went for the other style of laid-back seating, the lounger. Last seen on a crazy paving patio, loungers were this time meant to be used inside as well. The best ones were made of the kind of plastic that didn't need a foam-filled cushion to stop it sticking to your skin. But then, plastic was the designer's material of choice. Chairs made by everyone from Jasper Morrison to Ikea piled off production lines and into our homes, where they looked cool and wore well. The design world liked them, too: this year's 100% Design/Blueprint manufacturing award went to Magis, makers of Morrison's moulded plastic Air Chair. The year's other big design gong, the Peugeot Design Award, went to an unknown bloke called Hector Serrano for his fabulously tactile light, Super Patata. It was the obvious choice: this was the year of the light, and Super Patata - basically a salt-filled latex balloon that can be moulded to different shapes - represented everything that is exciting about modern lighting design. But it was a high point in what turned out to be rather a disappointing start to the third millennium. On the high street, everything looked much the same, with the exception of Habitat, which, with designers such as Matthew Hilton on the team, seemed to do little wrong, and Muji, which continued to expand, bringing its distinctive no-brand Japanese goods to the British people. At the other end, 100% Design, Britain's version of the Milan furniture fair, was slick but rather dull. Still, look on the bright side. No great innovations means no great change. So, if you didn't get a plastic chair and a sensual interactive light for 2000, you can always get one for 2001

webTitle: Patience is a virtue in the garden

fields.headline: Patience is a virtue
fields.standfirst: What can a veteran gardener learn from a year outdoors? While some things will never change, such as daffodils in spring, never plan too far ahead, says Christopher Lloyd. Better to take unpredictable mother nature a day at a time
fields.trailText: What can a veteran gardener learn from a year outdoors? While some things will never change, such as daffodils in spring, never plan too far ahead, says Christopher Lloyd. Better to take unpredictable mother nature a day at a time
fields.body:
Gardeners look fore and aft at the turn of the year. We learn from past mistakes - or think we shall - and we plan that this time it will all be different. I wrote to a friend in Australia on August 16 that Fergus and I (and we are self-critical) felt that the garden at Great Dixter had never looked better. The summer had been cloudy and cool, which had suited most plants admirably; nothing had scorched and the dry spells had not been exacerbated by heat.

We had had an early spring again - our daffodil orchard was already looking its best by March 23, I noted - and were lucky to escape an April frost. Magnolias were especially magnificent. But then, in April and May, it was wet; the daffodil foliage succumbed to fungal disease and I know perfectly well that, as a consequence, next spring's display will, on the whole, be very weak. Nothing I can do about that.

Fergus and I were far too late in planting up our Exotic Garden with all the really tender stuff that we'd grown under glass and that was kept waiting for too long. It caught up in the end, but we'd wasted a whole month. I had taken a couple of weeks off in Scotland, in the middle of June, and what with catching up with all the arrears of work on my return, this was fairly disastrous.

So, we have made a resolution. I shall not go north until October next year (it's lovely to see the birches changing colour). Both Fergus and I will keep our diaries free of engagements for one whole week in the middle of June and really get to grips with that subtropical planting. We shall be out there at 6.30 each morning (he would have liked it to be earlier still) and can get in a couple of hours' work before the day's inevitable interruptions begin - telephone, mail, staff requiring attention, visitors and all that. At this distance in time, it looks a wonderful plan; perhaps some of it will work out.

Then we had that fantastically wet tail end to the year. If October hadn't been by far the wettest month we (in East Sussex) have endured since we started keeping records in 1913, then November would have been. The ground is one big squelch. Thank goodness that way back in the 1460s we were sited on a hill. We look down on a lake, which is the Rother valley, and are at a safe distance. Yet I have no doubt there will be periods of drought in 2001, as in every other year.

Really, your garden needs to be prepared for all sorts of weathers. In some departments, it will fail; in others, it will turn up trumps. In general, I am a gardening optimist. This means, inevitably, that there will be disappointments, but I also have the useful fall-back of forgetting failures extremely quickly.

I get fed up with the killjoys who, if a fine, warm spell turns up early in the year, shake their heads and say, "We shall pay for it later; you just see". They cannot enjoy the present because of their wretched hypothetical future. However, I do admit that, if a fine sunny day arrives in February, it is unwise to sow masses of seeds whose progeny you will be quite unable to keep happy during the weeks and months that must elapse before it is safe, or you have the space ready, to plant them out.

On the whole, I don't think we do a lot of planning ahead, or, if we do, we find in the end that half our schemes go by the board. Either something fails, or another plan overtakes the first one. It is no bad thing to be pragmatic and to await developments before making decisions. That said, we shall definitely make plans when deciding which seeds to order - something you may well have done already, but which we not infrequently leave until as late as February. Not on principle, certainly, but because there seem to be so many other demands on our time. Who said that winter was a slack season?

I do not believe in change for the sake of change. There should be a more deep-seated urge, if any. I speak of a garden - mine, and very likely yours, too - that already has a good bone structure and, therefore, doesn't need to be changed. As for taking on new areas, consider first whether you are making the best use of the old. It may be better to renovate than to yield to the lure of greener grass on the other side of the fence.

I have so often seen gardens in which areas, even quite close to the house, have ceased to be thought about creatively, and all the effort has been concentrated on some new area that seems to represent a new life. Personally, I can always find satisfaction in adjustments. Most established gardeners could make a useful start by clearing away or cutting back old hulks of overgrown and no longer contributive trees and shrubs. Then you can admire the cleared area and go from there. Most shrubs deserve only a limited amount of space. When they become really bulky, they are covering a greater area than their value warrants.

The seed catalogues make us plan on a smaller scale. "Wouldn't it be nice to grow such-and-such again next year?", we think. And that is quickly followed by, "Where shall we plant it, and what will go well with it?" Planning has many aspects and ramifications

fields.headline: Make mine a ...
fields.standfirst: Drambuie Cream
fields.trailText: Drambuie Cream
fields.body:
Drambuie Cream is the kind of drink that barmen come up with when someone asks for 'something sweet and sticky for the lady'. Mind you, Drambuie itself is pretty sweet, too - and, apparently, it is drunk mainly by fellas. And Greeks of both sexes.

But Drambuie Cream - 'an unashamedly luxurious fusion of 15- to 17-year-old Scotch malt whiskies, fresh dairy cream and heather honey' - is beyond sweet. Even with ice, downing a glass is like wolfing a box of Milk Tray at one sitting. So who drinks it? According to www.chilledfusion.com, surprisingly fashionable people such as the Beeb's Shaker Maker, Ben Reed, who has invented the Drambuccino, a tooth-rotting combination of espresso, Drambuie Cream, butterscotch schnapps andice, which he weirdly recommends 'for elevenses or a mid-afternoon pick-me-up' (I thought Coke was the mid-afternoon pick-me-up of choice among the chattering classes). If you nevertheless fancy a wee dram to see in the new year, it's £12.99 at Sainsbury's, Bottoms Up and Wine Rack.

fields.headline: The way we wore
fields.standfirst: Jess Cartner-Morley looks back on the year in fashion in which we ripped the waistbands from our jeans, raided auntie's wardrobe for her newly cool Burberry and took a step back to the 70s for our most glamorous moments
fields.trailText: Jess Cartner-Morley looks back on the year in fashion in which we ripped the waistbands from our jeans, raided auntie's wardrobe for her newly cool Burberry and took a step back to the 70s for our most glamorous moments
fields.body:
January

The third millennium dawns, and what are we wearing? Disappointingly, there isn't a silver space boot or temperature-controlled jumpsuit to be seen. The patchouli scent of Ali MacGraw hangs in the air, designers having decreed that 70s West Coast campus chic is where it's at. In designer wardrobes, Fendi patchwork jackets and Alberta Ferretti folksy milkmaid pieces rule; long, stripey scarves are swiftly adopted by the fashionable masses as a cheap, chic alternative. Meanwhile, the year's first street-generated micro trend kicks off: brightly coloured karma bead bracelets appear on wrists around town - true love and fashionability for only £3.

February

It may be winter, but in the shops it's spring: the new collections have arrived. The buzz is all about Prada. Those who consider themselves part of fashion's ruling class love a sartorial challenge, the chance to show the world that they can look good in the most unpromising of outfits. And the pussycat bows, pleated skirts and lemon-yellow sweaters that Miuccia Prada has produced are nothing if not challenging. The high-street stores that have copied her lead hold their breath to see if the public will bite. At New York fashion week, the ever-more-ostentatious use of fur brings animal rights protesters on to the catwalk. Back in London, Top Shop wins a well-deserved award for high-street design. Hussein Chalayan is named Designer Of The Year - and uses his acceptance speech to rail against a celebrity-obsessed media more interested in pop star models than in innovative design. In Milan the following week, fashion shows concede priority to the eminently pressing need to stock up on woven leather bags from newly fashionable label Bottega Veneta.

March

Those pussycat bow blouses are still with us - it seems the office angels look is failing to capture the public's imagination. But the Charlie's Angels look is catching on months before the film's release. Flick hairstyles and tight 70s pop T-shirts turn up everywhere. Denim is rapidly becoming more fashionable than it has been since Nick Kamen took off his 501s: bleach-splashed and bleached-out emerge as successors to ubiquitous indigo Earl Jeans. And though it's still raining, the Burberry switchboard is jammed with fashionistas eager to get their hands on the year's poolside must, a check string bikini.

April

Last year's diamanté heart glasses having proved a little too easy for the high street to reproduce, Stella McCartney's Chloe has come up with a more elaborate design this year - smoky brown glasses with embossed gold tiger heads. Can you see out of them? No one cares. The vintage pop T-shirts that seemed so cool last season are starting to feel a bit tired, so someone has the bright idea of ripping off the sleeves and slashing the neckline. Customising goes mega and a new style of dressing is born.

May

The silly season comes early. Unconfirmed sightings of grown men on push-along scooters mushroom into a full-blown trend. The female population, not quite stupid enough to risk life and limb on a folding silver scooter but still suckers for a pointless summer trend, take inspiration from Mariah Carey, an R&B song- stress not known for her innate elegance. Suddenly, a pair of jeans isn't fit to be seen in public until you've ripped off the waist band to reveal an extra inch of tummy. Can't come out tonight, we're doing sit-ups.

June

After a spring of LK Bennett slingbacks, our lust for ever-prettier shoes can now be satisfied only by sequinned flip-flops, selling like hot cakes for a storming £35 a pair. But never mind, because fashion is enjoying a rich moment: at the Celine show, one of the hits of the season, models were told to walk as if they were "the sexiest, richest woman in St Tropez. Make them jealous!" All things luxe and logo-ed are in. But as £300 handbags are out of the reach of most, a roaring trade in fake, blackmarket Louis Vuitton is inevitable.

July

A new style icon claims her throne: the air hostess, as idealised in TV adverts of old. Chiffon scarves, shiny patent bags the colour of love-heart sweets and itsy-bitsy wheel-along vanity cases are the height of chic. But only the very daring take the Louis Vuitton look all the way and wear coloured plastic sun visors, a look stolen from Florida tourists and suddenly, bizarrely, fashionable.

August

With the imminent arrival of both baby Rocco and album Music, Madonna is queen of pop culture again. The cover of the single, showing her in blonde ringlets and stetson, crystallises a mood that has long bobbed around the edge of style consciousness: the rodeo girl. Usually, a trend is credible and becomes naff; Madonna takes a naff trend and makes it credible. Stetsons have been the predictable uniform of Miss Selfridge-clad clubbers for two summers, but by kitsching them to the max with full make-up and rhinestone-studded cowgirl shirts, Madge makes us realise we love them.

September

Watching fashion types sweat in their autumn wardrobe while it's still warm is usually good for a laugh: but the arrival of autumn in June makes wearing cosy clothes in September entirely sensible. At the New York shows, the 40s look beats the 80s hands down. Anna Wintour's outfit of the week is a raspberry tweed skirt suit with ribbon belt. The return of proper skirts and shoes heralds a hosiery revival, with nude fishnets and outsize lobster nets the new accessory of choice: Jonathan Aston is the name on everyone's lips. In London, the 80s revival trundles on, with Footloose-style off-the-shoulder batwing sweaters (the kind once sold in Pineapple studios) on almost every catwalk.

October

Milan, and the dizzying time-travel of the fashion world takes another leap, this time to the 50s. Anna Molinari's show for Blumarine sets the scene with full skirts and ponytails. With the luxury fashion industry booming, there are snazzy new flagship stores to visit each day: Armani's takes up a whole block and has a Nobu upstairs, while Pucci's (the latest label poised for a major comeback) is resplendent with curving walls and signature swirly prints. In Paris, the show circuit ends with what is billed as the highlight of the fashion year: Tom Ford's debut for Yves Saint Laurent. While the Le Smoking jackets are a hit, Paris fashion editors sniffily declare that no foreigner can capture the true elegance of YSL.

November

Ruched boots, a toned-down version of the scrunched pixie boots that were a revelation on the Bottega Veneta catwalk in February, appear on the shelves of Marks & Spencer. How fast fashion moves: a trend goes from cult idea to mass-market product in one season. Likewise, Burberry, red-hot at the beginning of the year, has already detected signs of burn-out in the popularity of the check, and moved the high-end label away from the signature beige, black and red.

December

Christmas is a time when taste is suspended: how else would the institution of the Yuletide jumper have survived? True to form, fashion's festive season turns into a gaudy celebration of the glitziest colour of all: gold. From Vogue's Gold issue to the gold fishnet socks that are pictured on all fashionable feet but that no one can find in the stores, showing off is deemed de rigueur. It's all rather more chichi than the downbeat winter of 1999. Perhaps this is the real millennium, after all.

webTitle: It's been a very strange old year...

fields.headline: So what was that all about?
fields.standfirst: All things considered, it has been a very strange old year, reckons Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: All things considered, it has been a very strange old year, reckons Matthew Fort
fields.body:
Remember those pictures of Mr Blair entertaining M Chirac to a pie and a pint down at his local? Did you notice how Chirac lowered the level of the beer in his glass pretty radically before breaking off for some cheerful pleasantry, while our own PM gingerly took a sip of bitter and then looked as if he had swallowed something vaguely unpleasant and wholly unfamiliar? Very telling, that.

Let's face it, the public discomfort of our elected servants apart, there hasn't been a hell of a lot to laugh at this year. There has been a dreary familiarity about the headlines: the words BSE, ban and crisis did the rounds again, only this time it was not our BSE, ban and crisis, but theirs - the French, the Germans and the Spanish. It is difficult not to allow the smallest scintilla of schadenfreude to flicker across the mind. The only thing preventing a full outbreak of gloating is the feeling that there appears no escape from this particular foul disease, and the suspicion that there might be something just as nasty lurking in our own lamb pen, pigsty or chicken run just waiting to come out.

BSE isn't the only subject that kept coming up, as it were. There have been the usual jeremiads about the state of our kids' eating habits; the dreadful diet of the Scots; the food in motorway service stations; the fat and salt content of hamburgers; standards of hygiene in food outlets (179,897 of the 381,617 premises inspected by environmental health officers were deemed unacceptable); shortages of everything from oysters (storm damage) and ostriches (fraud) to caviar (Russian mafia and Iranian marketing policy).

Novelty items, such as those about hard-up police turning to pizza delivering to make ends meet, and the prawn sandwiches distracting some spectators from the action on the pitch at Old Trafford (thank you, Roy Keane, for that public service), brought little respite, and spirits plummeted further when Ben & Jerry's, those flagbearers for caring capitalism and full-fat ice cream, turned out to care even more for the companionship of Unilever. So, when kennel owner Jean-Louis Lacoste in France was fined £300 for eating his charges, there was darkness at noon. Here he would have got a life sentence, provided he hadn't been strung up before he got to court. How can we trust their beef when they show so little consideration for the sanctity of dogs?

Talking of courts, there was our old friend, Marco Pierre White, defending his reputation with customary vigour. The New York Times and International Herald Tribune both alleged that he was flying on drugs and drink when he stormed his way to the top of the culinary ladder a few years back, before he became a simple businessman. The allegations were, of course, nonsense. Who needs coke, or even rum and Coke, when you have an ego like Marco's?

There have been the usual giddy "scientific" stories about olive oil staving off bowel cancer (research at Hospital Universitari Germans Trias i Pujol outside Barcelona; Spain ranks second among the world's olive oil producers, by the way); chocolate staving off heart attacks (research sponsored by Mars); and the search for the perfect chip (research at the National Technical University of Athens; no known commercial affiliations).

A year that marked more debate over the role of alcohol in social violence even witnessed a spot of bother at a tea dance: a 77-year-old grandfather sent a 71-year-old rival to hospital with a broken wrist, broken nose and cuts after being accused of interfering with the ladies. The would-be pugilist was given a suspended sentence, but left court defiant, saying, "I am a gentleman and, anyway, I'm impotent."

No, nothing much has changed in 800 years, so why should we now? After all, we still believe that we are superior to any other nation on the face of the earth in matters of cleanliness, honesty and endeavour, while all the evidence says that we're dirty, dishonest, lazy and violent.

We spend less on food than we did in 1968 - 17% of the household budget, down from 26% in 1968 - and less than anyone else in Europe. Translated, that means we are the canniest of shoppers, although we seem singularly slow to pick up on the fact that cheap food means bad food - which means BSE, listeria, salmonella and E coli, but that is by the by. Also, the younger we are, the lazier we are when it comes to food. According to research, the UK's 11.5m 15-29 year olds will have spent £5.5bn in restaurants and takeaways in the current year; 89% will go to burger bars, 68% to chippies, 61% to pizza and pasta outlets; 51% will head for a Chinese takeaway; 39% a fried chicken palace; and 36% will tuck into an Indian takeaway. So now you know.

It has not all been ghastliness, however. It seems that strawberries taste sweeter when picked in the dark. One Anthony Newton has discovered a new use for Twiglets - as a hold-up weapon - and is currently serving four years for his cheek. Our chocolate bar manufacturers won a 27-year battle to get the EU to recognise our right to call our favourite nibbles "chocolate", despite the fact that they contain almost no chocolate. We have discovered that there's more to taste than salt, sweet, bitter and sour; there's umami, too. Now there's a magic word for you. Actually, it's our old friend monosodium glutamate, which was first identified as a separate taste in 1908 in Tokyo. But it took 21st-century technology to identify the molecule on the tongue that responds to it, so confirming its existence.

Most of all, let us take heart from Italy, where a campaign has united the Catholic church, communists, trades unionists, environmentalists, gourmets and bar owners. In the Catholic newspaper Avvenire, Massimo Salani, a lecturer at the centre for theological studies in Pisa, called on all good Italians to begin a crusade against McDonald's and the eat-and-run culture it represents. Such eating habits, declared Signore Salani , are "not Catholic. It completely forgets the holiness of food." Fast food is fit only for Lutherans. "To reduce everything to zero, to eliminate conversation for the sake of speed," agreed Monsignore Domenico Sigalini, "is to lose the sense of family."

We'll ignore for a moment the British trend to abandon the concept of family at the first opportunity. The principle is the thing. It is time that we all adopted the rallying cry of the anti-McDonaldisti of Italy: "Better a day of tortellini than 100 days of hamburgers."

If God is with us, who can be against us? Who, indeed?

fields.trailText: What a year
fields.body:
It is tempting, when stock-taking the year's news, to find an individual who can encapsulate the whole thing - a villain or a hero or a victim who can tie it all up, such as OJ or Diana or Monica Lewinsky did these past years. But 2000 was different. This was a year defined not by a person but by crowds of people - or, more often, by mobs of people.

Parents encouraged their children to smash in paedophiles' cars this year. Parents and children chanted, "Sex case! Sex case! Hang him! Hang him!" Portsmouth mobs attacked local paedophiles, and Gwent mobs got their words mixed up and attacked a local paediatrician. Then there was Portsmouth North's MP, Syd Rapson, admitting on TV that the violence consuming his neighbourhood frightened him. "The house next door to me was firebombed. Then a nice person rang me and said they had made a mistake. It should have been my house that was set on fire."

There were mobs, too, baying for Nasty Nick's expulsion from the Big Brother house and yelling "Whore!" and "Slut!" and "Prick-tease!" at his fellow housemate, Mel, the flirty one. There were telephone mobs: 300,000 Sun readers rang to protest the life sentence handed down to a Norfolk farmer who had murdered a 16-year-old burglar. The fuel protesters rose as popular heroes and fell as a mob. They went a little crazy. They said they were going to starve the country out. They prophesied Armageddon. This was a PR miscalculation.

There were mobs that turned out to exist only in our collective imagination. For a time, Londoners envisaged themselves invaded on the tube by hordes of Romanian Gypsy women, even though they were hardly ever spotted in packs of more than one and a baby. In the Middle East, the Israelis tried to convince the outside world that the Palestinians were a mob, but the outside world was unsure.

And there was the most outrageous mob of all - the one that utilised fake pomposity and intimidation to fix an election, that yelled and screamed and chased election officials down stairwells while their leaders went on TV mawkishly to praise their Greatest Of All Democracies. Most years hurl up some shifty individual who has the effrontery to declare himself winner of a tin-pot election, who elbows his way into power in a coup d'état thanks to a boorish mob. But it doesn't happen very often in the United States.

And the year had begun so gently. A man blew a conch at sunrise on the tiny island of Kiribati, and a new millennium dawned. Nelson Mandela lit a candle inside his old cell at Robben Island. The citizens of Bangkok listened to a jazz composition by their king, Bhumibol Adulyadej. Palestinians released a flock of doves into the firework-lit skies over Bethlehem's Manger Square; admittedly, many of the doves flew straight into the fireworks and were instantly killed.

There had been stirrings of panic beforehand. The citizens of Las Vegas emptied the shelves of the gun shops: one simply could not buy a gun in Vegas over the millennium period. But the Y2K bug failed to materialise. Had the world been duped by unscrupulous computer technicians?

Although home secretary Jack Straw announced a week into the new year that the English had a "propensity to violence", January remained basically mob-free. There were, of course, ample opportunities for the crowds to turn bloody - specifically, the non-appearance of the River of Fire and the queues for the Body Zone at the Millennium Dome. The pyrotechnicians later explained that the River of Fire had actually gone according to plan but, travelling as it had at the same pace as earth and time, the human race was not advanced enough to see it. This was either a very inventive lie or the 21st century's first great philosophical conundrum. If the River of Fire was not seen, could it be said to have existed?

Downriver that same night, the nation's glitterati, alongside various raffle winners and unsung heroes, queued for three long hours to board trains bound for the Dome. The Dome chief, Lord Falconer, a close friend of the prime minister, later apologised to "the VIPs and the ordinary people". The phrase "close friend of the prime minister" became 2000's most trenchant term of abuse.

"The trouble with queuing," wrote the Guardian's Polly Toynbee in the year's first major Dome savaging, "is that expectations rise exponentially with every minute queued. If you stand outside the Body Zone for an hour, it had better be worth it, but all you get is seven minutes of nothing much." The Body Zone had been billed as "an intellectually accessible exploration into the most fascinating object in the world, the human body". This turned out to be essentially true. It was intellectually accessible: a hollowed-out lump of Perspex surrounding an escalator that led to a hunk of throbbing rubber - the human heart.

Most wounding for the Dome was the single-word headline in the London Evening Standard on February 1 underneath a photograph of the Millennium Wheel. That word was: "Fabulous."

In April, a Norfolk farmer, Tony Martin, was jailed for life for shooting a 16-year-old burglar, Fred Barras, as he tried to escape from his home. The boy was killed by an illegal, pump-action shotgun. He was shot twice in the legs, once in the back. Although Barras had 29 prior convictions for robbery, the burglary of Martin's farm was to be his big break into the criminal mainstream. Barras's final words, having been shot by Martin, were, "Give over, give over. I'm sorry, I'm sorry." Then he said, "Mum ..." and died. There was widespread anger at the murder conviction. Up to 300,000 Sun readers rang the paper to protest. "Plagued by thieving pykies," wrote the Sun, "Martin was let down by the police - there was no bobby in his village - and by toothless courts, leaving repeat offenders free to prey on decent hard-working people." Conservative leader William Hague assured Martin's supporters that under a Tory government the law would favour householders defending themselves.

Martin had, for 18 months before the shooting, worked himself into a frenzy. He had sealed his windows, patrolled his property with a loaded gun and yelled at passers-by, "I'll blow the heads off thieves and machine-gun Gypsies." But as a metaphor he became a downtrodden rural Englishman protecting his castle against the worst sort of foreign invader, a Gypsy.

Hague assured the Gypsy-haters that under a Tory government the "floods of Kosovars and Romanian Gypsies swamping soft-touch Britain" would be locked in detention centres. It was unappealing, like the rest of Hague's catalogue of soundbites in 2000. When he told GQ that he used to drink 14 pints a day, the PR man Max Clifford summed up his image problem: "It doesn't actually matter whether it's true or not. You don't look at him and see a 14-pint man."

In May, Tony Blair might well have become the first serving Labour prime minister to vote Tory in an election. Of course, he refused to say for whom he cast his second preference vote in London's mayoral poll, but Downing Street was so transfixed in its belief that only Steven Norris could stop the man bent on reducing London to ashes that the odds are the prime minister did put his cross in that most bizarre of boxes.

Ken Livingstone was an issue that stretched liberal commentators almost to breaking point. Even the Guardian fleetingly contemplated supporting Norris, to the horror of some staff members. The editor, Alan Rusbridger, pointed out that, in October 1951, the Manchester Guardian advised, "For the next few years, a Churchill government is, it seems to us, the lesser evil." In the end, the Guardian supported nobody. It was, anyway, a foregone conclusion. "Londoners," wrote Geoffrey Wheatcroft in the Guardian, "are going to the polls like schoolchildren who know they are doing something naughty to tease the grown-ups."

On July 1, police were called to investigate the disappearance of a little girl from a country lane near her grandparents' home in West Sussex. The girl had been playing with her sister and brothers, but decided to return home on her own. Initial police reports were optimistic. Sarah Payne was probably just hiding in the fields. But the search parties found nothing. Sarah's parents appeared on TV every day, raging helplessly against what was becoming increasingly obvious.

On July 3: "We need her home now, today. She is the most important thing in our lives. She is our life. We have a family name for her, our little princess. She is soft, gentle, likeable. She has not got a horrible vein in her body."

On July 4: "Just drop Sarah somewhere she can be found. Let her walk away from you."

On July 5: "We are coming. I know we are taking our time. Hang in there, girl, because we are coming for you."

There was hope on July 9. At Knutsford services a woman approached a frightened little girl and asked her name. "Sarah," she said.

On July 15: "We know that Sarah is still alive. It is a gut instinct. We are certain of it."

Sarah's body was found on the 17th. She had been murdered during the first weekend in July. Grief quickly turned into something else. "NAMED SHAMED" read the headline in the News of the World. "If you are a parent you must read this. There are 110,000 child sex offenders in Britain. The murder of Sarah Payne has proved police monitoring of these perverts is not enough. So we are revealing WHO they are and WHERE they are, starting today." The News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, called for "vigilance not vigilantism". The vigilante attacks, of course, began within hours. In Manchester, a 300-strong mob surrounded the home of Ian Armstrong, who was mistaken for a paedophile because he shared a surname with a man named by the News of the World. They backed a six-year-old boy down his garden path and shouted, "Do you want this one?"

Once the misunderstanding had been cleared up, the News of the World scored a bizarre victory by parading Armstrong at a press conference. "I support the News of the World's campaign to name and shame paedophiles," he quivered.

The residents of the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth drew up a "mental list" of the 20 most likely paedophiles in their neighbourhood. They set about attacking the homes of those on the list. They admitted to suspecting one man because he lived alone and talked about how much he loved his mother. A 17-year-old boy was included because his girlfriend was 15. The protesters paraded their children for the cameras. A three-year-old held up a sign as if she was supporting her village fete. It read: "Kill Paedophiles!" Five innocent families fled the estate, terrified of their neighbours. The campaign's self-proclaimed leader, Katrina Kessell, declared that if they felt compelled to run away because of guilty thoughts then it was their own fault. It was during one of her many TV interviews that Kessell's three-year-old son was found wandering near a busy road half-a-mile from their home. Social services was alerted.

From time to time, the mobs succeeded in their goal of targeting actual paedophiles. A gang attacked the home of James White, who had pleaded guilty to three indecent assaults on young girls. They threw missiles and informed him that they would come back later and firebomb his house. White worried about his wife and children. He drove to a service station on the M61 and took a massive overdose of the tranquilliser, Diltiazen. One of White's neighbours, a mother-of-four, said: "He was an animal and he probably got off lightly taking his own life like this."

Hague assured the rioters that under a Tory government Britain's most dangerous paedophiles would be jailed for life. "The protesters' emotions," he said, "are strong and understandable."

It turned out that the majority of the names on the Portsmouth "mental list" were indeed convicted paedophiles, a disproportionate number of whom had been re-housed on the Paulsgrove estate, many within yards of the local school.

The summer weather was bad. Leeds had only 12 minutes of sunshine during the first eight days of July. On July 14, 10 people were locked into a house in London's East End, with 25 cameras following their every move. Some of the housemates immediately stripped naked and covered themselves in clay. The critics united in predicting a giant flop. "Big Brother is deeply dull," wrote the Daily Telegraph. "When the winner is announced in nine weeks, will anybody care?" The contestants were deemed vacuous and one-dimensional. And then one of them, Nick Bateman, began to behave oddly. A graduate of Gordonstoun, Bateman befriended his housemates and craftily set them against each other. He built himself an immunity from eviction with made-up stories of a harrowing past. His first love was, he falsely announced, killed in a car crash on their honeymoon in Australia. There were gasps of sympathy from his housemates. The nation was gripped. Was there a psychopath in the Big Brother house? The broadsheet intelligentsia went into hyperdrive.

"His deviousness has a Shakespearean breadth to it," wrote Emma Brockes in the Guardian. "You can imagine him as Edmund in King Lear, standing on the lawn at midnight and shaking his fist at the moon: 'Thou, nature, art my goddess; to thy law my services are bound.' "

The Sun launched a "Kick Out Nick" campaign. Nick was kicked out; 28 British papers put him on their front cover that day. The Sun signed him up. Like a comic pastiche of the anti-paedophile riots occurring simultaneously across the country, Channel 4 viewers swarmed the Big Brother set every Friday night to cheer or boo the evicted housemates. "It's history, isn't it?" said one viewer. "It's like watching Neil Armstrong on the moon or Diana's funeral." By the end of the year, it was as if we were collectively embarrassed by our fleeting devotion to the show. "It's Fame Over For Big Bruv Craig," laughed the Daily Star. The housemates were like victims of a one-night stand, wondering what they'd done wrong, why we didn't like them any more, especially when things were going so well.

The man charged with the murder of TV star Jill Dando turned out not to be a Serb hitman, nor a revenge-obsessed criminal unmasked on Crimewatch, not even an obsessive Dando fan. He was a Freddie Mercury fan. What could be said about that?

The music impresario Jonathan King was charged with a crime dating back 30 years - the same charge that had destroyed Oscar Wilde's life: the buggering of a teenage boy. The trials of King and the Dando suspect are still pending.

George Harrison's attacker was simply on the wrong medication. When he was put back on to the right medication, he apologised profusely. The London nailbomber, it turned out, represented nothing but his own lonely, hateful insanity.

Sarah Payne's murderer remained faceless, uncaught, as invisible as a wisp of air. As did the year's other dreadful killer. In Bridgend, during the millennium celebrations, a woman called Karen Beavon began to complain of a bad back. She felt depressed. A few weeks later she asked her husband if it was true that a family of Australians was living in their house. She started making the imaginary Australians cups of tea. But she couldn't get the tea right. The cups were full of cold water. She thought the Australians were staying upstairs. When her husband pointed out to her that they lived in a bungalow, she became agitated. She accused her husband of trying to murder her.

Karen went blind, and then deaf. She was 37 when new-variant CJD killed her, on July 15, seven months after she had first complained of a bad back.

The disease claimed its youngest life three months later. Microscopic holes had formed in the brain of 14-year-old Zoe Jeffries, whose two great loves were cheeseburgers and Leonardo DiCaprio. "It's as if someone had stuck a knife in her body," said her mother. "I really do think she has been murdered." But she blamed herself, too. She said she felt guilty for not buying Zoe more expensive hamburgers. October's 14,000-page BSE report refused to point fingers. No one was blamed. It failed to provide conclusions. It just told us what we already know: that we know very little.

In Gaza, a 12-year-old boy, Mohammed al-Durrah, went out with his father to buy a second-hand car on a Saturday morning. They blundered into the path of Israeli soldiers. The boy hid behind his father's back for safety and was killed, a clean shot. The spinning began in earnest. The Israeli army said that the boy and his father couldn't have "been there by accident. They were there like the others throwing stones, and throwing Molotovs." They added that the boy was probably killed by "his fellow rioters". This false claim backfired. The Israelis did their best to regain the high ground by announcing that the Palestinians were cynically dispatching their own children to die for the cameras. But even if this was true, why were the Israelis so keen to kill them? The martyring of one's own children no longer seemed like the crazy behaviour of an otherworldly people. It suddenly seemed human instead. The Israelis appeared to the world like old-fashioned monsters: like a mob.

A series of posters appeared overnight across London and the Midlands, calling for the death of Jews. Omar Bakri Mohamed, of Tottenham's Al Muhajiroun, denied circulating them, even though his mobile telephone number was printed at the bottom. He said he had been framed by unknown forces (possibly the Zionist-controlled British media). In Stamford Hill, a Jewish student was brutally stabbed on a bus while reading the Talmud.

That same week, a Saudi airliner bound for London was politely seized by - in the hijackers' own words - "Saudi people subjugated to American hegemony". It was a low-key hijack. The passengers only realised things were askew when, upon landing, they looked out of the windows to see an airport that was clearly not Heathrow. "It was a small airport, and there were signs in Arabic," said hostage Chris Fowler from Newport. "It was then that I knew something was up."

It was Saddam International Airport. The hijack had, it transpired, coincided with the launch of Iraqi Tourism Week. The instantly released hostages were put up for the day at the five star Al-Rashid hotel, which was covered in an enormous banner of Saddam wearing a ski-suit and goggles. They were laden with glossy brochures extolling the attractions of Baghdad and sent back to London the same day. "Come again," the Iraqi officials told them. "Next time for a holiday."

Saddam suddenly didn't seem quite so bad after all, and our foreign secretary Robin Cook, with Iraq under sanctions, appeared curmudgeonly when he refused to thank him for resolving the crisis so speedily. "I would not thank any government for carrying out its clear international obligation to stop a terrorist hijack," he explained.

"It's all a bit too slick," added one diplomat. "The speed with which the negotiations were completed - it all resolved itself remarkably quickly." So, was the whole thing a set-up, a spin, a magic trick, designed to promote Iraqi Tourism Week? Whatever, the spectre of the Islamic world beating the west at its own game by engaging in successful PR was a whole new concept for 2000.

The Weird Hijack proved to be one of the year's most enduring mini-themes. Back in February, an Afghan plane on an internal flight was seized and diverted to London Stansted where, the Telegraph reported, the hijackers were given a cushy time. "They have been offered fizzy drinks, hot towels, and muffins for tea." This outrage, compounded by the collective memory of economy flights, where muffins and hot towels are something to be only dreamed of, paled against the theory that followed: were the hijackers and passengers in cahoots? Was it all an elaborate ruse for the 170 on board to obtain political asylum? When the crisis was resolved, it transpired that 81 of those on board immediately returned home, 14 were charged with kidnapping, and the rest currently have pending asylum applications.

Neither hijack was quite as odd as the one perpetrated by Augusto Lakandula in May. A Philippine airbus was minutes from landing at Manila when Lakandula leapt to his feet and explained to the 278 passengers on board that his wife was having an affair with a policeman. He then ran up and down the aisle grabbing cash and valuables from passengers. He tied a home-made parachute to his back. It was made of string and bed sheets. He ordered a stewardess to open the door. She obliged. Unfortunately, his backpack was bulging so profusely from his hoarded valuables that he got stuck in the doorway. So the stewardess pushed him out.

"If he survived that jump with that parachute," a Philippine Airlines spokesman later said, "he deserves to keep all the money because that would be the miracle of the century." Lakandula's body was found submerged in mud outside Manila the next day. His unopened parachute lay next to his body.

All three hijacks had been resolved without any passengers losing their lives, which is more than can be said for Qantas's September 30 flight from Sydney to London. Emma Christoffersen, a Marks & Spencer sales assistant from Newport, was returning home from a three-week trip to Australia. It was a 20-hour flight. She flew economy. There was inadequate leg-room. A blood clot formed in a vein in her leg. It travelled to her heart. She collapsed in the Heathrow arrivals lounge and died minutes later. It wasn't terrorism that killed Christoffersen. It was business.

August saw the unfolding of that most tragic of tales - the boy trapped down the well. In this instance, there were 118 boys, the well was the Kursk submarine. Russia's premier, Vladimir Putin, dithered for days over whether to accept foreign offers of help, even though his navy had no deep-sea-diving team. The country's government refused to publish a list of the trapped sailors. Finally, a Russian journalist bribed a navy official. He slid the equivalent of £440 into his pocket. The official handed over the list. This was how the sailors' mothers discovered that their children were dead or dying in the submarine.

Putin's government chose old-fashioned means to stifle what they perceived to be a mob of devastated mothers. One woman began yelling at a deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov. "They are there in a tin can!" she screamed. "Do you have children? Surely not!" She was grabbed by men in suits, injected with some kind of sedative and carried out. She was later paraded at a press conference. "I am glad they sedated me because I have a heart condition and I may have died without the sedative," she said. A note later found in the pocket of one of the corpses on board the submarine revealed that some of the crew died slowly. The Russian authorities only allowed a few lines of the note to be published. "I'm writing blind ... There are 23 of us here ..." The rest was considered too tragic, or too politically sensitive, to be known: fragments of fragments, written in the dark at the bottom of the sea.

On September 7, in a livestock market in North Wales, a softly-spoken farmer - wounded by the BSE crisis and rising fuel prices - was about to bring Britain to a shuddering halt. "If you're not with us then leave now," said Brynle Williams to the 150 gathered farmers and hauliers. "No one will think the worse of you." It had taken Williams just 10 minutes to organise his protest. There was no headed paper, no website, no infrastructure, just 150 rural working people with mobile phones, alienated by what they saw as an urban, cosmopolitan (Labour) government.

Within days, all of Britain's refineries were barricaded by Williams's men. Blair learned of the blockades while staying at the Sheffield Hilton. He was due to visit a local school early the next morning. Frantic calls were made between Sheffield and London. How could the prime minister return to London without being photographed? A dash to the capital would have looked terrible in the press - as if there were a crisis. So a plot was hatched. Nobody would tell the school that Blair wasn't going to show up. Instead, he'd sneak to Sheffield station, hide on a train, and be smuggled out of a side door at St Pancras.

It was a triumph. At 8.50am, while the groomed and excited Sheffield schoolchildren were all lined up and the photographers at the ready, Blair was zipping unchronicled back to London. For all the uncertainty that gripped Britain during the fuel crisis, one thing wassure: the prime minister knew how to avoid being photographed looking panicky. Ninety per cent of the British public supported the protests, and it was nice to see some old- fashioned solidarity to a cause, even if cheap fuel was not the noblest of crusades. But then the People's Fuel Lobby went power-crazy. They labelled themselves the New Jarrow Crusaders and prophesied Armageddon if their demands were not met: "This is a historic crusade. People can live without fuel but they cannot live without food."

fields.bodyText: It is tempting, when stock-taking the year's news, to find an individual who can encapsulate the whole thing - a villain or a hero or a victim who can tie it all up, such as OJ or Diana or Monica Lewinsky did these past years. But 2000 was different. This was a year defined not by a person but by crowds of people - or, more often, by mobs of people. Parents encouraged their children to smash in paedophiles' cars this year. Parents and children chanted, "Sex case! Sex case! Hang him! Hang him!" Portsmouth mobs attacked local paedophiles, and Gwent mobs got their words mixed up and attacked a local paediatrician. Then there was Portsmouth North's MP, Syd Rapson, admitting on TV that the violence consuming his neighbourhood frightened him. "The house next door to me was firebombed. Then a nice person rang me and said they had made a mistake. It should have been my house that was set on fire." There were mobs, too, baying for Nasty Nick's expulsion from the Big Brother house and yelling "Whore!" and "Slut!" and "Prick-tease!" at his fellow housemate, Mel, the flirty one. There were telephone mobs: 300,000 Sun readers rang to protest the life sentence handed down to a Norfolk farmer who had murdered a 16-year-old burglar. The fuel protesters rose as popular heroes and fell as a mob. They went a little crazy. They said they were going to starve the country out. They prophesied Armageddon. This was a PR miscalculation. There were mobs that turned out to exist only in our collective imagination. For a time, Londoners envisaged themselves invaded on the tube by hordes of Romanian Gypsy women, even though they were hardly ever spotted in packs of more than one and a baby. In the Middle East, the Israelis tried to convince the outside world that the Palestinians were a mob, but the outside world was unsure. And there was the most outrageous mob of all - the one that utilised fake pomposity and intimidation to fix an election, that yelled and screamed and chased election officials down stairwells while their leaders went on TV mawkishly to praise their Greatest Of All Democracies. Most years hurl up some shifty individual who has the effrontery to declare himself winner of a tin-pot election, who elbows his way into power in a coup d'état thanks to a boorish mob. But it doesn't happen very often in the United States. And the year had begun so gently. A man blew a conch at sunrise on the tiny island of Kiribati, and a new millennium dawned. Nelson Mandela lit a candle inside his old cell at Robben Island. The citizens of Bangkok listened to a jazz composition by their king, Bhumibol Adulyadej. Palestinians released a flock of doves into the firework-lit skies over Bethlehem's Manger Square; admittedly, many of the doves flew straight into the fireworks and were instantly killed. There had been stirrings of panic beforehand. The citizens of Las Vegas emptied the shelves of the gun shops: one simply could not buy a gun in Vegas over the millennium period. But the Y2K bug failed to materialise. Had the world been duped by unscrupulous computer technicians? Although home secretary Jack Straw announced a week into the new year that the English had a "propensity to violence", January remained basically mob-free. There were, of course, ample opportunities for the crowds to turn bloody - specifically, the non-appearance of the River of Fire and the queues for the Body Zone at the Millennium Dome. The pyrotechnicians later explained that the River of Fire had actually gone according to plan but, travelling as it had at the same pace as earth and time, the human race was not advanced enough to see it. This was either a very inventive lie or the 21st century's first great philosophical conundrum. If the River of Fire was not seen, could it be said to have existed? Downriver that same night, the nation's glitterati, alongside various raffle winners and unsung heroes, queued for three long hours to board trains bound for the Dome. The Dome chief, Lord Falconer, a close friend of the prime minister, later apologised to "the VIPs and the ordinary people". The phrase "close friend of the prime minister" became 2000's most trenchant term of abuse. "The trouble with queuing," wrote the Guardian's Polly Toynbee in the year's first major Dome savaging, "is that expectations rise exponentially with every minute queued. If you stand outside the Body Zone for an hour, it had better be worth it, but all you get is seven minutes of nothing much." The Body Zone had been billed as "an intellectually accessible exploration into the most fascinating object in the world, the human body". This turned out to be essentially true. It was intellectually accessible: a hollowed-out lump of Perspex surrounding an escalator that led to a hunk of throbbing rubber - the human heart. Most wounding for the Dome was the single-word headline in the London Evening Standard on February 1 underneath a photograph of the Millennium Wheel. That word was: "Fabulous." In April, a Norfolk farmer, Tony Martin, was jailed for life for shooting a 16-year-old burglar, Fred Barras, as he tried to escape from his home. The boy was killed by an illegal, pump-action shotgun. He was shot twice in the legs, once in the back. Although Barras had 29 prior convictions for robbery, the burglary of Martin's farm was to be his big break into the criminal mainstream. Barras's final words, having been shot by Martin, were, "Give over, give over. I'm sorry, I'm sorry." Then he said, "Mum ..." and died. There was widespread anger at the murder conviction. Up to 300,000 Sun readers rang the paper to protest. "Plagued by thieving pykies," wrote the Sun, "Martin was let down by the police - there was no bobby in his village - and by toothless courts, leaving repeat offenders free to prey on decent hard-working people." Conservative leader William Hague assured Martin's supporters that under a Tory government the law would favour householders defending themselves. Martin had, for 18 months before the shooting, worked himself into a frenzy. He had sealed his windows, patrolled his property with a loaded gun and yelled at passers-by, "I'll blow the heads off thieves and machine-gun Gypsies." But as a metaphor he became a downtrodden rural Englishman protecting his castle against the worst sort of foreign invader, a Gypsy. Hague assured the Gypsy-haters that under a Tory government the "floods of Kosovars and Romanian Gypsies swamping soft-touch Britain" would be locked in detention centres. It was unappealing, like the rest of Hague's catalogue of soundbites in 2000. When he told GQ that he used to drink 14 pints a day, the PR man Max Clifford summed up his image problem: "It doesn't actually matter whether it's true or not. You don't look at him and see a 14-pint man." In May, Tony Blair might well have become the first serving Labour prime minister to vote Tory in an election. Of course, he refused to say for whom he cast his second preference vote in London's mayoral poll, but Downing Street was so transfixed in its belief that only Steven Norris could stop the man bent on reducing London to ashes that the odds are the prime minister did put his cross in that most bizarre of boxes. Ken Livingstone was an issue that stretched liberal commentators almost to breaking point. Even the Guardian fleetingly contemplated supporting Norris, to the horror of some staff members. The editor, Alan Rusbridger, pointed out that, in October 1951, the Manchester Guardian advised, "For the next few years, a Churchill government is, it seems to us, the lesser evil." In the end, the Guardian supported nobody. It was, anyway, a foregone conclusion. "Londoners," wrote Geoffrey Wheatcroft in the Guardian, "are going to the polls like schoolchildren who know they are doing something naughty to tease the grown-ups." On July 1, police were called to investigate the disappearance of a little girl from a country lane near her grandparents' home in West Sussex. The girl had been playing with her sister and brothers, but decided to return home on her own. Initial police reports were optimistic. Sarah Payne was probably just hiding in the fields. But the search parties found nothing. Sarah's parents appeared on TV every day, raging helplessly against what was becoming increasingly obvious. On July 3: "We need her home now, today. She is the most important thing in our lives. She is our life. We have a family name for her, our little princess. She is soft, gentle, likeable. She has not got a horrible vein in her body." On July 4: "Just drop Sarah somewhere she can be found. Let her walk away from you." On July 5: "We are coming. I know we are taking our time. Hang in there, girl, because we are coming for you." There was hope on July 9. At Knutsford services a woman approached a frightened little girl and asked her name. "Sarah," she said. On July 15: "We know that Sarah is still alive. It is a gut instinct. We are certain of it." Sarah's body was found on the 17th. She had been murdered during the first weekend in July. Grief quickly turned into something else. "NAMED SHAMED" read the headline in the News of the World. "If you are a parent you must read this. There are 110,000 child sex offenders in Britain. The murder of Sarah Payne has proved police monitoring of these perverts is not enough. So we are revealing WHO they are and WHERE they are, starting today." The News of the World's editor, Rebekah Wade, called for "vigilance not vigilantism". The vigilante attacks, of course, began within hours. In Manchester, a 300-strong mob surrounded the home of Ian Armstrong, who was mistaken for a paedophile because he shared a surname with a man named by the News of the World. They backed a six-year-old boy down his garden path and shouted, "Do you want this one?" Once the misunderstanding had been cleared up, the News of the World scored a bizarre victory by parading Armstrong at a press conference. "I support the News of the World's campaign to name and shame paedophiles," he quivered. The residents of the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth drew up a "mental list" of the 20 most likely paedophiles in their neighbourhood. They set about attacking the homes of those on the list. They admitted to suspecting one man because he lived alone and talked about how much he loved his mother. A 17-year-old boy was included because his girlfriend was 15. The protesters paraded their children for the cameras. A three-year-old held up a sign as if she was supporting her village fete. It read: "Kill Paedophiles!" Five innocent families fled the estate, terrified of their neighbours. The campaign's self-proclaimed leader, Katrina Kessell, declared that if they felt compelled to run away because of guilty thoughts then it was their own fault. It was during one of her many TV interviews that Kessell's three-year-old son was found wandering near a busy road half-a-mile from their home. Social services was alerted. From time to time, the mobs succeeded in their goal of targeting actual paedophiles. A gang attacked the home of James White, who had pleaded guilty to three indecent assaults on young girls. They threw missiles and informed him that they would come back later and firebomb his house. White worried about his wife and children. He drove to a service station on the M61 and took a massive overdose of the tranquilliser, Diltiazen. One of White's neighbours, a mother-of-four, said: "He was an animal and he probably got off lightly taking his own life like this." Hague assured the rioters that under a Tory government Britain's most dangerous paedophiles would be jailed for life. "The protesters' emotions," he said, "are strong and understandable." It turned out that the majority of the names on the Portsmouth "mental list" were indeed convicted paedophiles, a disproportionate number of whom had been re-housed on the Paulsgrove estate, many within yards of the local school. The summer weather was bad. Leeds had only 12 minutes of sunshine during the first eight days of July. On July 14, 10 people were locked into a house in London's East End, with 25 cameras following their every move. Some of the housemates immediately stripped naked and covered themselves in clay. The critics united in predicting a giant flop. "Big Brother is deeply dull," wrote the Daily Telegraph. "When the winner is announced in nine weeks, will anybody care?" The contestants were deemed vacuous and one-dimensional. And then one of them, Nick Bateman, began to behave oddly. A graduate of Gordonstoun, Bateman befriended his housemates and craftily set them against each other. He built himself an immunity from eviction with made-up stories of a harrowing past. His first love was, he falsely announced, killed in a car crash on their honeymoon in Australia. There were gasps of sympathy from his housemates. The nation was gripped. Was there a psychopath in the Big Brother house? The broadsheet intelligentsia went into hyperdrive. "His deviousness has a Shakespearean breadth to it," wrote Emma Brockes in the Guardian. "You can imagine him as Edmund in King Lear, standing on the lawn at midnight and shaking his fist at the moon: 'Thou, nature, art my goddess; to thy law my services are bound.' "It's history, isn't it?" said one viewer. "It's like watching Neil Armstrong on the moon or Diana's funeral." By the end of the year, it was as if we were collectively embarrassed by our fleeting devotion to the show. "It's Fame Over For Big Bruv Craig," laughed the Daily Star. The housemates were like victims of a one-night stand, wondering what they'd done wrong, why we didn't like them any more, especially when things were going so well. The man charged with the murder of TV star Jill Dando turned out not to be a Serb hitman, nor a revenge-obsessed criminal unmasked on Crimewatch, not even an obsessive Dando fan. He was a Freddie Mercury fan. What could be said about that? The music impresario Jonathan King was charged with a crime dating back 30 years - the same charge that had destroyed Oscar Wilde's life: the buggering of a teenage boy. The trials of King and the Dando suspect are still pending. George Harrison's attacker was simply on the wrong medication. When he was put back on to the right medication, he apologised profusely. The London nailbomber, it turned out, represented nothing but his own lonely, hateful insanity. Sarah Payne's murderer remained faceless, uncaught, as invisible as a wisp of air. As did the year's other dreadful killer. In Bridgend, during the millennium celebrations, a woman called Karen Beavon began to complain of a bad back. She felt depressed. A few weeks later she asked her husband if it was true that a family of Australians was living in their house. She started making the imaginary Australians cups of tea. But she couldn't get the tea right. The cups were full of cold water. She thought the Australians were staying upstairs. When her husband pointed out to her that they lived in a bungalow, she became agitated. She accused her husband of trying to murder her. Karen went blind, and then deaf. She was 37 when new-variant CJD killed her, on July 15, seven months after she had first complained of a bad back. The disease claimed its youngest life three months later. Microscopic holes had formed in the brain of 14-year-old Zoe Jeffries, whose two great loves were cheeseburgers and Leonardo DiCaprio. "It's as if someone had stuck a knife in her body," said her mother. "I really do think she has been murdered." But she blamed herself, too. She said she felt guilty for not buying Zoe more expensive hamburgers. October's 14,000-page BSE report refused to point fingers. No one was blamed. It failed to provide conclusions. It just told us what we already know: that we know very little. In Gaza, a 12-year-old boy, Mohammed al-Durrah, went out with his father to buy a second-hand car on a Saturday morning. They blundered into the path of Israeli soldiers. The boy hid behind his father's back for safety and was killed, a clean shot. The spinning began in earnest. The Israeli army said that the boy and his father couldn't have "been there by accident. They were there like the others throwing stones, and throwing Molotovs." They added that the boy was probably killed by "his fellow rioters". This false claim backfired. The Israelis did their best to regain the high ground by announcing that the Palestinians were cynically dispatching their own children to die for the cameras. But even if this was true, why were the Israelis so keen to kill them? The martyring of one's own children no longer seemed like the crazy behaviour of an otherworldly people. It suddenly seemed human instead. The Israelis appeared to the world like old-fashioned monsters: like a mob. A series of posters appeared overnight across London and the Midlands, calling for the death of Jews. Omar Bakri Mohamed, of Tottenham's Al Muhajiroun, denied circulating them, even though his mobile telephone number was printed at the bottom. He said he had been framed by unknown forces (possibly the Zionist-controlled British media). In Stamford Hill, a Jewish student was brutally stabbed on a bus while reading the Talmud. That same week, a Saudi airliner bound for London was politely seized by - in the hijackers' own words - "Saudi people subjugated to American hegemony". It was a low-key hijack. The passengers only realised things were askew when, upon landing, they looked out of the windows to see an airport that was clearly not Heathrow. "It was a small airport, and there were signs in Arabic," said hostage Chris Fowler from Newport. "It was then that I knew something was up." It was Saddam International Airport. The hijack had, it transpired, coincided with the launch of Iraqi Tourism Week. The instantly released hostages were put up for the day at the five star Al-Rashid hotel, which was covered in an enormous banner of Saddam wearing a ski-suit and goggles. They were laden with glossy brochures extolling the attractions of Baghdad and sent back to London the same day. "Come again," the Iraqi officials told them. "Next time for a holiday." Saddam suddenly didn't seem quite so bad after all, and our foreign secretary Robin Cook, with Iraq under sanctions, appeared curmudgeonly when he refused to thank him for resolving the crisis so speedily. "I would not thank any government for carrying out its clear international obligation to stop a terrorist hijack," he explained. "It's all a bit too slick," added one diplomat. "The speed with which the negotiations were completed - it all resolved itself remarkably quickly." So, was the whole thing a set-up, a spin, a magic trick, designed to promote Iraqi Tourism Week? Whatever, the spectre of the Islamic world beating the west at its own game by engaging in successful PR was a whole new concept for 2000. The Weird Hijack proved to be one of the year's most enduring mini-themes. Back in February, an Afghan plane on an internal flight was seized and diverted to London Stansted where, the Telegraph reported, the hijackers were given a cushy time. "They have been offered fizzy drinks, hot towels, and muffins for tea." This outrage, compounded by the collective memory of economy flights, where muffins and hot towels are something to be only dreamed of, paled against the theory that followed: were the hijackers and passengers in cahoots? Was it all an elaborate ruse for the 170 on board to obtain political asylum? When the crisis was resolved, it transpired that 81 of those on board immediately returned home, 14 were charged with kidnapping, and the rest currently have pending asylum applications. Neither hijack was quite as odd as the one perpetrated by Augusto Lakandula in May. A Philippine airbus was minutes from landing at Manila when Lakandula leapt to his feet and explained to the 278 passengers on board that his wife was having an affair with a policeman. He then ran up and down the aisle grabbing cash and valuables from passengers. He tied a home-made parachute to his back. It was made of string and bed sheets. He ordered a stewardess to open the door. She obliged. Unfortunately, his backpack was bulging so profusely from his hoarded valuables that he got stuck in the doorway. So the stewardess pushed him out. "If he survived that jump with that parachute," a Philippine Airlines spokesman later said, "he deserves to keep all the money because that would be the miracle of the century."
