fields.headline: First aid
fields.trailText: For the pudding, it took the merest fraction of a second to suggest trifle. The response was joyous
fields.body:
From a restaurateur's selfish point of view, I have a preference for New Year's Day over the New Year's Eve shindig, which revolves around seemingly ocean-sized quantities of alcohol. Sure, there is an undeniable thrill to be had from being out and about at the stroke of midnight, all wrapped up in great layers of woollens and other cosies, but I'm usually at work on New Year's Eve, so I have no qualms in putting those particular memories behind me.

As luck would have it, an old pal phoned me a few weeks back and asked if he could come to the restaurant for lunch on New Year's Day. "Of course - I'd be delighted! It will be great to see you - and how many will you be? Two? Three?"

"About 110!" Cripes, it's the staff of our sister restaurant, Bibendum, no less. Oh God, not again, I thought, as the toe-curling feeling of dread that is the staff do came over me. Sadly, I was unable to protest too much, because when I had worked in the kitchens at Bibendum years back, we had hired Blue Print Cafe for our Christmas party.

The fact that, this year, I would be cooking for them, rather than eating with them, was not an issue, although the irony of it all was not lost on me as I sighed deeply, thinking Auld Lang Synes aplenty. But the burning question was, what to cook? A New Year's Day celebration meal is rife with potential culinary potholes, not least because of the condition of the participants after partaking of the evening before. There is also the small matter of getting hold of ingredients at a time when just about everyone is shut. Your menu ideas must be laid down and then honed to a well-conceived whole that will please and restore simultaneously.

So, to start, let's do puff pastry with plenty of porcini - mushrooms and pastry being a very good match. Even better, it can easily be made a little in advance.

To follow, a great pot of spiced lamb comes to mind - a korma, that great braise that is as satisfying as it is delicious, accompanied by a dish of potatoes, cauliflower and spinach made fragrant with spice.

As for the pudding, it took only the merest fraction of a second for me to suggest a trifle. The response was joyous. Quite right, too.

All recipes serve six.

Jalousie des cepes

Jalousie is French for a Venetian blind, and sounds a lot better than 'puff'.

100g dried cèpes
30g unsalted butter
6 shallots, finely chopped
4 cloves garlic, finely chopped
1 small glass white wine
30g flour
400ml milk
1 blade mace
1 bayleaf
lemon, zest grated
50g Parmesan, grated
1kg puff pastry
1 handful flat-leaf parsley, picked
2 fresh eggs, beaten
Sea salt and black pepper

Pre-heat the oven to 200C/400F/gas mark 6. Soak the dried mushrooms in enough tepid water to cover them, and leave to reconstitute for 20 minutes or so. Fry the shallots and garlic gently in the butter until softened. Infuse the milk with the mace and bayleaf. Squeeze the soaked cèpes of as much water as possible, then chop them up and fry until all trace of liquid has gone and they have darkened a little. Tip in the wine, cook until this liquid, too, has evaporated, then repeat the process with the strained cèpe soaking liquid. Stir in the flour, and cook gently for five minutes or so, until the whole has darkened somewhat. Pour a little of the infused milk through a sieve and into the pot, stir until the mixture is smooth, and repeat until all the milk is incorporated. Stir the sauce continuously until simmering, then for a further five minutes. Remove the sauce from the heat and cover to prevent a skin from forming. Once it has cooled, add the lemon zest, Parmesan, parsley, all but a spoonful of the beaten eggs, salt and pepper. Leave to cool.

In the meantime, prepare the pastry. Depending on the size of your oven and/or baking sheets, roll out two or three large rectangles of pastry and two or three smaller pieces. Lay the smaller pieces on the baking sheets, leaving plenty of space between each, and divide the cèpe filling equally among them. Spread the mixture over the pastry, leaving a 2.5cm border around the entire edge. On the remaining larger pastry rectangles, lightly mark out the perimeters of the stuffing, then cut across the sheet's breadth, making numerous incisions to emulate the slats of a Venetian blind. Brush a little beaten egg around the border of the pastry rectangle, then lay it on top of the smaller ones so that the slats sit comfortably on the stuffing, and press down to seal. Brush a little more beaten egg over the surface of the packages, and place in the fridge for an hour or so (though preferably overnight) before baking. Bake in the hot oven for five to seven minutes, then reduce the heat to 175C/350F/gas mark 4 for 15 minutes, then to 150C/300F/gas mark 2 for a further 15 minutes to ensure that the base is cooked. By this time, the jalousies should be puffed and golden atop. Serve warm.

Lamb korma

This beautiful dish is from Madhur Jaffrey, and is as pleasurable to prepare as it is to eat.

8 tbsp ground coriander
3 tbsp ground cumin
3 tbsp desiccated unsweetened coconut
12 onions
20 cloves garlic
4 thumb-size pieces fresh ginger
1 small tin plum tomatoes
2 tsp ground turmeric
Vegetable oil
12 whole cardamom pods
6 whole cloves
20 whole black peppercorns
4 bayleaves
1 whole cinnamon stick
3 dried hot chillies
4kg shoulder and leg of lamb (mixed, but get more neck as it is much tastier), cut into 2.5cm cubes
5 tbsp plain yoghurt
3 tsp salt
2 tsp garam masala

To finish

2 green chillies, sliced thin
2 tbsp coriander leaves, chopped

Heat a heavy-bottomed frying pan and put in the coriander, cumin and coconut, stirring constantly to roast until coloured evenly. Put to one side. Peel and coarsely chop the onions, garlic and ginger, pop them in a liquidiser, along with the tomatoes, and whizz to a paste. Heat a big, heavy-based pot (or two), pour in three or so tablespoons of oil and wait until it begins to shimmer. Drop in the cardamom, cloves, peppercorns, turmeric, bayleaves, cinnamon and chillies, stirring all the while. Begin browning the meat in small batches. Place each batch in a bowl, and repeat until all the lamb is done. Tip the spices into the meat bowl along with the final batch.

Add three to four tablespoons of oil to the pot, add the paste, keeping your face averted as it may spit alarmingly. Stir continuously while the paste thickens, then reduce the heat and add the merest splash of water to prevent it from scorching. Tip in the roasted spices, cook for another five minutes, then add the yoghurt a little at a time, stirring continuously. Return the meat to the pot, add salt and enough water barely to cover the lamb, cover tightly with a lid andgently simmer for an hour.

Once the meat is tender, if the sauce is still very liquid, raise the heat and reduce carefully until it coats the lamb. Stir in the garam masala, cook for another five minutes or so, then remove any visible whole spices before serving, if desired. Sprinkle with chillies and coriander and serve with plain boiled rice and the following vegetable dish.

Potatoes and cauliflower, fennel seeds and spinach

A fantastic combination.

4 medium cauliflowers
1kg waxy potatoes
10 tbsp vegetable oil (or ghee)
tsp fenugreek seeds
3 tsp fennel seeds
4 tsp whole cumin seeds
2 whole red dried chillies
1 tsp ground turmeric
4 tsp ground coriander seeds
3 tsp salt
Plenty of black pepper
200ml cold water
300g spinach
2 tsp garam masala

Break the cauliflower into florets and place in a bowl of cold water for half an hour. Peel the potatoes and cut into 2cm squares. Rinse the potato thoroughly, then leave to soak in cold water for half an hour also. Drain the vegetables and dry thoroughly.

Heat a large, heavy-bottomed pot and pour in 10 tablespoons of oil. Tip in the fenugreek, fennel, cumin and chillies. Stir just once, then tip in the cauliflower and potatoes, stirring all the while to coat them in the spices. Reduce the heat, add the turmeric, coriander, salt and pepper, and fry gently for 10 minutes or so. Pour in the water, put a lid on the pot and cook gently for 10-15 minutes, until the vegetables are cooked but not collapsed. Shred the spinach and add to the pot, along with the garam masala, stirring them in carefully. Return the lid to the pot, and cook for a further five minutes, stirring occasionally. Serve hot.

Trifle

This year's favourite pudding is, apparently, trifle. It just goes to show that you cannot keep a good pudding down.

For the everlasting syllabub

250ml white wine
5 tbsp brandy
2 lemons, juiced and rind pared
80g caster sugar
750ml double cream

For the trifle

2 vanilla pods
tsp freshly grated nutmeg
1.3 litres whipping cream
8 fresh eggs
3 tbsp caster sugar
1 2.5cm deep by 16cm wide sponge
Apricot jam
24 macaroons
70ml good white wine
70ml madeira
30g whole almonds, roasted
Crystallised fruits

First, prepare the syllabub. Put the wine, brandy, lemon juice and rind into a bowl, cover and leave overnight. Strain the liquid, dissolve the sugar therein, then slowly whisk in the cream until thickened and cloud-like.

Split the vanilla pods, scrape out the seeds, and add the pods, seeds and nutmeg to the whipping cream in a saucepan. Place the pot over a high heat. Whisk together the eggs and sugar, stir in a little of the infused cream, and tip the lot into the cream in the pot. Stir the custard over a gentle heat until it thickens and a bubble appears on the surface. Remove from the heat, and pour through a sieve into a wide bowl, to extract the vanilla pod and any lumps. Leave to cool.

Slice the sponge through the middle, spread each half with apricot jam and cut into smaller pieces. In a big bowl, place the sponge pieces with the macaroons, then pour over the wine and madeira. Pour in the custard, cover and put in the fridge for an hour or so. Spoon the syllabub on top and scatter with whole almonds. Cut the crystallised fruit into shards and scatter among the almonds. Chill thoroughly, preferably overnight, before serving

 Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, Butlers Wharf, London SE1.

Sure, there is an undeniable thrill to be had from being out and about at the stroke of midnight, all wrapped up in great layers of woollens and other cosies, but I'm usually at work on New Year's Eve, so I have no qualms in putting those particular memories behind me. As luck would have it, an old pal phoned me a few weeks back and asked if he could come to the restaurant for lunch on New Year's Day. "Of course - I'd be delighted! Oh God, not again, I thought, as the toe-curling feeling of dread that is the staff do came over me. Sadly, I was unable to protest too much, because when I had worked in the kitchens at Bibendum years back, we had hired Blue Print Cafe for our Christmas party. webTitle: No room at the inn, innit

fields.headline: No room at the inn, innit
fields.standfirst: Adrian Mole, aged 33
fields.trailText: I sat next to Mohammed, whose daughter Raki was in the cast playing a glue-sniffer running away from an arranged marriage
fields.body:
Friday, December 22, Ashby-de-la-Zouch

Another night out! This time at Neil Armstrong Comprehensive, my alma mater, to see Glenn in The Holiday Play. In my day, it was simply called the Nativity play. In the 1982 performance, Pandora was a mesmeric Mary. Several men in the audience fainted during Jesus's protracted forceps delivery. I sat next to Mohammed, whose daughter Raki was in the cast playing a glue-sniffer running away from an arranged marriage. To my considerable consternation, Glenn had been cast as a homeless abuser of alcohol. The production was confused, because the children had not been given lines or told where to stand or, in fact, when to take their entrances and exits. This led to severe overcrowding on the stage at times, and necessitated Mr Billington, the young drama teacher, to issue loud instructions that could clearly be heard above the horrible din of the school orchestra.

Roger Patience, the headmaster, sat next to the stage with his head in his hands. The action apparently took place in a night shelter. A pregnant female called Marie turned up with her "partner" Joe and asked the social worker in charge for sanctuary. What Marie actually said was, "I gotta lie down coz I'm 'aving a kid an' the filth is after me for nickin' a swaddlin' cloth outta the everythin's a pound shop." To which the social worker/innkeeper in turn replied, "Ya gotta be jokin', ain't ya? There ain't no bleedin' room, it's holiday time, you shoulda booked." Here, Joe intervened: "Don't dis my chick, man". Then Glenn made his entrance and proceeded to give an alarmingly realistic depiction of a man who had consumed several bottles of methylated spirits.

A female derelict/angel came on and shrieked, "I just seen a bright star appear in the east. It weren't there before. It done my 'ead in." Mohammed's daughter then entered sniffing on a tube of Bostick (empty, I hope). I felt Mohammed shift uncomfortably in his seat. I lost track of the dramatic events after that and turned my attention to the programme. I noticed that Pamela Pigg had been credited with "facilitating research on the homeless".

When I next looked back at the stage, Raki was giving an improvised speech about the difficulties of being a radical feminist growing up in a fundamentalist Muslim household. Mohammed muttered, "If she thinks she's gettin' them Timberland boots for Christmas, she's gotta nuther think comin'." Mr Billington gave a speech at the end thanking the children for their "enthusiastic grasp of improvisational techniques". He wished us all a "merry holiday".

As we walked to the car park together, Mohammed said, "Moley, why don't they do a proper Nativity play no more?" I said that it was felt in some circles that it was inappropriate in a multicultural school. Mohammed laughed and said, "What kinda circles? Crop?"

We went for a Christmas drink at the Kings Head. I asked for a cheese roll, but was told that they only do Thai food now. I didn't fancy slurping on a bowl of noodles as I drank, so I ate nothing. As a consequence, I felt slightly drunk when I got home and phoned Pamela Pigg and asked her out. She accepted eagerly, saying, "I've longed for this moment." After putting down the phone, I cursed the two pints of shandy I had consumed earlier.

Monday, December 25

Christmas Day has been blighted. A tragedy has befallen my family. Last night, my mother was arrested and charged with GBH. The tableau of Becks, Posh and Brooklyn in her front garden drew huge crowds of gawpers. Bail was refused because she gave a policeman a Chinese burn on his wrist when he tried to dismantle Brooklyn's crib. The policeman is undergoing trauma counselling, and is expected to be on sick leave for two months.

webTitle: Resolutions to avoid at all costs

fields.headline: Resolutions to avoid at all costs
fields.trailText: Six disasters waiting to happen
fields.body:
Grow a moustache The sinister cult of upper lip upholstery is gaining advocacy around the bars of the former garment district north of Oxford Circus. Some may have it that a dapper 'tache is just the very latest thing amid the chicanery of the Heavenly Social, but all such sorcery must be resisted. Only Sir Gerald Nabarro, Salvador Dali and 'Bob' from Blackadder have pulled it off with anything approaching aplomb. Give the muzzy a miss.

Hold a car boot sale It seems to make sense, doesn't it? A glut of unwanted, half-wanted or replicated presents, a gang of things you've never actually found a use for and a small slew of items you haven't even glanced at in a while - none of which justifies a full-on, redemptive binning. A-ha, convert tat into cash, you think. But think how you'll feel when your nosy neighbours turn up to peruse your flotsam with barely disguised glee. Not only will you henceforth be the family that had a Breville sandwich maker. You will be ... The Family That Needed The Extra Cash.

Start up a dotcom startup The e-bubble isn't so much bursting as trumping Monsieur Creosote right now. Try this two-step wellbeing plan instead. The next time someone mentions the word Nasdaq, slap them really hard on the cheek and douse them with cold water, all the time shrieking, 'I'm doing it for you, petal!'

Commence a course of vitamins This way lies envy, paranoia, watchfulness and, ultimately, poverty. You'll have heard that St John's wort is most supremely good for you - 75% of all Germans blah, blah ... peace of mind ... blah ... clarity of thought, etc. So you trundle along to your inevitably cat-infested natural remedy shop, which is run by some terrifying 63-year-old hippy who asks if you were born within five miles before she'll agree to sell to you. She proceeds to charge you £7.95. Whatever you want, it's £7.95. Then you notice that the toned and upbeat young mum next to you is buying echinacea and damiana, and the old geezer with the clever, sparkling eyes has cod liver oil capsules to hand. So that's you, done up like a yellow kipper, hooked on wellness enhancers for life. And you'll be skint. Eat an orange instead.

Write a novel Inspired by David 'Dave' Eggers, you spend the holiday period pouring heavily autobiographical notes into your PC, only mildly deterred by the American standard spell-check that wants all words to consist of fewer letters. You get down 80-plus pages of sprawling, chaotic and immodest memoirs before it dawns on you that you, unlike Eggers, have no genius to fall back on. Your work is published by the A-Line Press of Bicester, titled A Mind Numbing Yarn Of Stupefying Banality. Go for a walk instead.

Join a gymnasium If you haven't set foot in a fitness room in some years, be warned. People have no class any more. They just are not shy, at all. Direct eye contact and unabashed smiling outbursts are commonplace. If someone, for example, thinks you've got a fine and robust backside, they will approach you without a hint of embarrassment and say: 'Neat buns'. Or worse, they might go: 'Good glutes', just like that. It just isn't worth the discomfort of having to spurn their offers of friendship. Gyms - don't join them.

fields.headline: Coming to a shelf near you
fields.standfirst: Predicting a fertile 2001,  Alex Clark  rounds up the titles she is looking forward to
fields.trailText: Predicting a fertile 2001, Alex Clark rounds up the titles she is looking forward to
fields.body:
Before they have been published, and through the glorious filter of the catalogue or press release, all books sound fascinating. A skilfully constructed editor's blurb, like a good foundation garment, can disguise flabbiness and impart shape; a glamorous author photograph or seductive strapline can momentarily distract from a hackneyed idea or far-fetched plotline. The contemplation of next year's vast crop of books, then, is a tricky affair, and some of the books featured in this sneak preview may well turn out to be dodos. Nonetheless, much of what is coming our way in 2001 does sound tempting - and here is a brief survey of those volumes most likely to charm the money out of your wallet.

Arguably, fiction is the area most prone to "proof of the pudding" syndrome: past form is not a failsafe guide to future performance, and hyped first novels yield as many cringing disappointments as they do exciting discoveries. Next year, apart from the seasoned campaigners mentioned opposite, veteran authors Anita Brookner, Bernice Rubens, Russell Hoban and Margaret Drabble all publish new work, but perhaps the most eagerly awaited appearance will be from V S Naipaul, whose new and as yet untitled novel will come out in September. For my money, though, Iain Sinclair's first novel for eight years is well worth looking out for: set in a valley bordering England and Wales rather than Sinclair's home turf of London and peopled by conspiracy theorists, utopians and lunatics, it sounds characteristically extraordinary. Landor's Tower will be published by Granta in March at £15.99.

In a completely different vein, one pudding I have already tasted is Laurie Graham's The Future Homemakers of America (June, Fourth Estate, £9.99). It's delicious. Graham is a peculiarly overlooked novelist, despite her surefire comic touch and wayward invention. Her last novel was set in an East End sink estate; her new offering whisks us off to the Fens, where a group of US Airforce wives are grimly sitting out their post-war postings. Occasionally compared to Alan Bennett, Graham exhibits precisely the same blend of toughness and sentiment, and deserves a far greater measure of recognition.

Among the highlights of imported fiction, a new novel from Marie Darrieussecq continues her obsession with fractured lives. Her last, My Phantom Husband , revolved around an abrupt disappearance; Breathing Underwater (May, Faber, £9.99) also features a protagonist who simply ups sticks. More unpredictable comings and goings are at the heart of Haruki Murakami's Sputnik Sweetheart (May, Harvill, £12): his tale of frustrated teachers will doubtless please his growing number of British fans.

In the world of non-fiction, biography and history continue to prove themselves publishing's most fertile ground: alongside those mentioned opposite, lives of Lutyens, David Trimble, Maria Callas, Gwen John and James Miranda Barry will all grapple for coverage. One of the most intriguing subjects is Richard Dadd, the fantastical fairy-painter who, in a fit of delusion, murdered his father. Patricia Allderidge examines his life - much of it spent in an asylum - in The Parricide's Story (July, Cape, £18.99). Andrew Hussey's The Game of War (June, Cape, £18.99) sees another odd bloke getting the treatment - this time situationist, soixante-huitard and suicide Guy Debord.

History tends to divide neatly into "big picture" books - the panoramic views of the Schamas, Fergusons and Cannadines - and the exact opposite: episodic and faintly quirky works of "narrative non-fiction" spawned by Longitude . In the second camp, this season boasts Selkirk's Island by Diana Souhami (Weidenfeld, May, £20), about the real-life Robinson Crusoe, and Sarah Bakewell's The Smart (April, Chatto, £17.99), a slice of life that provides more evidence of the apparently inexhaustible appeal of 18th-century London.

Quirkiness is not confined to the historical; a distinct sub-genre in sports writing has emerged in which whimsy is a prerequisite. Books of famous men writing about their enthusiasms - in this case Al Alvarez in Poker (March, Bloomsbury, £20) and Mordecai Richler in On Snooker (April, Yellow Jersey, £10) - serve the dual purpose of conferring gravitas and excitement on the pastime in question and reminding us that writers are not boring recluses with limited experience of vibrant popular culture. It doesn't always work, but might in these distinguished cases.

Many - if not most - books don't fit into discrete categories, which is why writers often complain of having come across their work in the travel, humour or erotica sections of inept bookshops. The most eye-catching of the odds and ends include Adam Phillips's Houdini's Box (April, Faber, £9.99), in which the eclectic psychotherapist examines escapologists - not just the self-proclaimed kind like Houdini, but more subtle cases of a little girl obsessed with hide and seek, poet Emily Dickinson and an analysand preoccupied with flight. Meanwhile, Stanley Williams really did escape - from an erupting volcano that engulfed his companions. His horrifying story is told in Surviving Galeras (April, Little, Brown, £16.99). And finally, one for the paranoid: Crypto by Steven Levy (January, Allen Lane, £18.99) preys on all our anxieties about the digital age. It also boasts a supremely inventive subtitle - "Keepers of Secrecy, Warriors of Privacy and Celebrants of Anarchy in the New Code War". Can you afford to be without it?

Fiction

Seasoned campaigners

Thinks ... by David Lodge (March, Secker, £16.99). A middle-aged man is tempted by another woman. Hmm.

The Rotters' Club by Jonathan Coe (March, Viking, £14.99). Coe turns his satirical eye on the 1970s.

Border Crossing by Pat Barker (April, Viking, £16.99). A child psychologist is confronted by one of his former patients.

Breaking through

Lust by Geoff Ryman (Feb, Flamingo, £9.99). What would happen if fantasies came to life.

Sheepshagger by Niall Griffiths (Feb, Cape, £10). The title says it all: second novel from the Welsh Irvine Welsh.

Number9dream by David Mitchell (March, Sceptre, £10.99). Japanese odyssey from the author of Ghostwritten.

Pages for You by Sylvia Brownrigg (April, Picador, £12). A young woman's account of a love affair.

Daring debuts

Smashing People by Michael Fishwick (Jan, Cape, £14.99). Into the heart of the 1980s media world.

The Death of Vishnu by Manil Suri (Feb, Bloomsbury, £16.99).

Much-touted first novel from a mathematician.

Mary George of Allnorthover by Lavinia Greenlaw (March, Flamingo, £12.99). The first foray into fiction by the acclaimed poet.

The Oversight by Will Eaves (March, Picador, £12). Childhood cruelty and a mysterious Victorian writing box.

The Execution by Hugo Wilcken (May, Flamingo, £9.99). First novel by a writer billed as the new Camus.

American graffiti

The Body Artist by Don DeLillo (Feb, Picador, £13). Latest novel by the author of Underworld.

Licks of Love by John Updike (March, Hamish Hamilton, £16.99). It's a grim title, but contains Rabbit Remembered.

Hotel Honolulu by Paul Theroux (April, Hamish Hamilton, £16.99). Chaucer set in Hawaii. Apparently.

A Day Late and a Dollar Short by Terry Macmillan (May, Viking, £16.99). Family life by the author of Waiting to Exhale.

Big hitters

Five Quarters of the Orange by Joanne Harris (April, Doubleday, £12.99). First chocolate, then wine, now citrus fruit.

How To Be Good by Nick Hornby (May, Viking, £16.99). In which one master of lad lit impersonates a woman ...

One For My Baby by Tony Parsons (May, HarperCollins, £14.99)

... and another meditates on the fragility of relationships.

He Kills Coppers by Jake Arnott (May, Sceptre, £10.99). Murder and football from the author of The Long Firm.

Non-fiction

Life studies

John G by Sheridan Morley (May, Hodder, £20). The likely-to-be-definitive biography of Gielgud.

Indira: A Life of Indira Nehru Gandhi by Katherine Frank (March, HarperCollins, £19.99).

The public and private life of India's assassinated leader.

His Invention So Fertile: A Life of Christopher Wren by Adrian Tinniswood (April, Cape, £25).

New life of the master architect.

Virtual Murdoch by Neil Chenoweth (May, Secker, £16.99).

Where Rupert goes next, by an Australian journalist.

Science diction

Rocks of Ages: Science and Religion in the Fullness of Life by Stephen Jay Gould (Feb, Cape, £14.99).

How to reconcile two apparently opposed belief systems.

Rivals: Conflicts as the Fuel of Science by Michael White (March, Secker, £16.99). How jealousy, pettiness and feuds get things going.

The Gold Code by James Shreeve (April, Penguin Press, £18.99).

An insider's account of the race to map the human genome.

Sexual Chemistry: A History of the Contraceptive Pill by Laura Marks (April, Yale, £20). How the magic pill has affected women's lives.

History zone

Ornamentalism: How the British Saw their Empire by David Cannadine (April, Penguin Press, £16.99). How the Imperialists sought to escape an England they loathed.

SS1: The Unlikely Death of Heinrich Himmler by Hugh Thomas (Feb, Fourth Estate, £18.99). The mystery behind the Nazi's final days.

From Dawn to Decadence by Jacques Barzun (March, HarperCollins, £24.99). 500 years of Western cultural life.

The modern world

Sonic Boom: Inside the Battle for the Soul of Music by John Alderman (Feb, Fourth Estate, £9.99).

How MP3s will change our lives.

Them: Adventures with Extremists by Jon Ronson (April, Picador, £15). In which Ronson seeks out the secret rulers of the world.

Moralities: Sex, Power and Money in the Twenty-First Century by Joan Smith (May, Penguin Press, £14.99). The future of ethics.

Miscellany

The Flaneur by Edmund White (Feb, Bloomsbury, £9.99). The novelist seeks out Paris's nooks and crannies.

Houdini's Box by Adam Phillips (April, Faber, £9.99). What drives the human obsession with escape.

Buried Alive: The Terrifying History of Our Most Primal Fear by Jan Bondeson (April, Norton, £21.95). Why we fear being buried alive. Seems obvious to me.

The Pursuit of Oblivion by Richard Davenport-Hines (July, Weidenfeld, £20). A history of narcotics.

webTitle: The Saturday Poem Indolence by  Douglas Dunn

fields.headline: The Saturday Poem Indolence
fields.trailText:
The pleasure's one of its anticipation

Knowing what will happen, when, where...
fields.body:
The pleasure's one of its anticipation

Knowing what will happen, when, where,

though why -

For all my pondering - rarely gets answered.

It's the pleasure of expectedness,

Of the light breeze, birdsong,

well-gardened air,

And vapour zips in the timetabled sky.

It's quite unexceptional, perfect peace

In a domesticity of one, civilian

To the point of irenic stasis, slothful

To a fault. An industrious bee wings past

Towards its buzzing labours. Blackbirds hop

From worm to worm. I stretch my idleness

And drop a book I tried but failed to read.

A hedgehog waddles down the weeded

path.

A chaffinch, perched on a propped rake,

chirps,

Then vanishes within my blink.

I have a bird in one eye and a trout

For my supper. I'm talking to myself

In my garden of indolence where I grow

Lethargy, lilies, and sit breathing mint,

Rosemary, thyme, sage, thinking of how

I'll cook

That fine fat fish I caught in a mad moment

Devoted to dexterity and doing.

The breeze riffles the dropped

unreadable book.

Shall I have chips with it, or baby potatoes?

Salad? Green beans? Or asparagus

spears?

At this rate I'll be mentally exhausted

Before it's time to cook and eat. Aha!

I could have deep-fried bad book

... Thank God

For chairs, cushions, blue sky, and peace

and quiet.

I so much looked forward to my day off.

Now that it's here, what I looked forward to,

I realise, was doing damn all in a deckchair.

Thank God, too, for this Chablis, black

olives,

Sunshine, and all these fragile butterflies,

Busy, beautiful, and living their lives

As if there's no tomorrow. Kick the book.

That's the stuff! Boot it away. I'll leave it

Out here on the grass. I won't improve it.

All this is my property! My goods and

chattels,

Impedimenta, my but-and ben, mine own

Estate and little home, and all for me ...

Another airliner - high energy,

Sky-power, propulsion, and momentum,

Exactly what I'm doing without today

By being bum-bound on a comfy chair.

Can't I get off my butt and do something?

Well, no - frankly. It's my day off, my first

In weeks. I've done enough. It's time to do

Nothing, for controlled irresponsibility.

I'm relaxing. The bird in my right eye

Fidgets. Sun does funny things to the

leaves.

Hedgehog's back! Is it a he or a she?

It goes past me like a self-propelled handbag.

I need to pee. But if I go inside

I'll be tempted to stay. Well, it's my grass,

And there's no one about ... So here goes

water.

Deeply, I regret having pissed on the book.

Much worse, though, is I think I've doused a

daisy

Which didn't deserve it. One day, I might invent

A board or card game, but for one player -

It won't be called 'solitaire'. I'll call it

'Time on My Side', or else 'As I Like It'.

I'm lying low, but coming up for air.

My wandering mind patrols its boundaries.

There are some things I like better than this -

A walk along a beach on Bernaray,

Laughing with Lillias in the summer-house

I can't yet bring myself to call a 'gazebo'.

Or dozing in Vienna over coffee.

And other things, equally innocent ...

Some might be physical. Not one

means 'work'.

 From The Year's Afternoon by Douglas Dunn. Published by Faber and Faber price £7.99

webTitle: Review:  Intoxicating Minds  by Ciaran Regan

fields.headline: A little of what you fancy
fields.standfirst: John McCrone  on Ciaran Regan's  Intoxicating Minds,  the human habit of getting high
fields.trailText: John McCrone on Ciaran Regan's Intoxicating Minds, the human habit of getting high
fields.body:
Intoxicating Minds

Ciaran Regan

164pp, Weidenfeld, £14.99
Buy it at BOL

Could drug use be natural for humans - even something to which we have become genetically adapted? And is our preference for tobacco and alcohol over heroin and cocaine just a cultural accident, different societies making different choices about which drugs are embraced and which demonised? These are questions that Ciaran Regan, a professor of pharmacology at University College Dublin, raises yet never properly answers in an intriguing historical survey of Homo sapiens's long relationship with mind-altering substances.

Regan offers up many quirky facts about drug use. The fly agaric mushroom, with its classic red cap and white spots, has probably been producing hot flushes and visions since prehistoric times. It is so prized by modern Siberian tribespeople that one mushroom can cost three reindeer. Luckily for the impecunious, the drug can be recycled by drinking the urine of the original purchaser. The active ingredient, ibotenic acid, remains potent for four or five such "passes".

In medieval times, flying ointments were prepared from mandrake and deadly nightshade, which contain drugs that block the brain neurotransmitter, acetylcholine. When rubbed into the armpit or rectum - areas of skin with a rich blood supply - the user falls into a deep sleep with strange dreams of soaring. Cannabis was introduced to Europe by Napoleon's army returning from Egypt. In the form of a confection called dawamesc - hemp tops ground up with sugar, orange juice, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, nutmeg, musk, pistachios and pine kernels (now there's a Christmas bon bon!) - it was handed around at Le Club des Hachichins, a notorious gathering place for decadents, including the poet Charles Baudelaire.

Regan does a good job of sketching the full range of drug use, tracing the emergence of all the familiar drugs and showing how cultures often stumble upon their own local variants on a theme. So tobacco was being chewed throughout the Americas for at least the past 5,000 years. For a similar time - judging by the red-stained teeth of skeletons - people have been chewing betel nut in south east Asia, while Africans had their own nicotine equivalent in khat leaves and the Australian Aborigines chewed pituri, the extract of a shrub.

Regan also offers thumbnail sketches of the relative hazards of various drugs and the way they affect the brain. Alcohol operates by the remarkably unsubtle mechanism of inserting itself into the thin membrane walls of brain cells, dulling their ability to fire. In the early stages of inebriation, certain types of brain cell or parts of the brain are more affected than others. The feeling is good because the pathways disrupted happen to be ones to do with feelings of anxiety and inhibition, so we develop that warm, sociable glow. But at higher doses, all brain activity begins to slur and we become just blind stumbling drunk.

While the action of alcohol may present little challenge to the pharmacologist, cannabis, surprisingly, is probably the least understood drug. More than 60 psychoactive ingredients have so far been identified, and it is only very recently that researchers discovered the brain has a particular receptor for one of these molecules. That is, the brain uses a cannabis-like neurotransmitter for its own internal signalling purposes. But no one yet knows why stimulating this obscure receptor should produce a cocktail of psychological effects that include euphoria, hunger and talkativeness.

As for the hazards of drug use, Regan's basic line seems to be that all drugs are poisons and none is much better or worse than others if used with moderation. Instead, what seems remarkable is the way cultures swing to extremes of opinion about a particular substance. Tobacco or marijuana? Alcohol or cocaine? On a pharmacological cost-benefit analysis, often these drugs come out much the same, but public attitudes are always polarised. Coffee and chocolate once caused moral panic, yet the Victorians were happy to swig opium and alcohol in the form of laudanum. And they used cocaine in every form from teething drops for infants to a drink, Vin Maraini, that carried the Pope's seal of approval. All societies have had their drugs, and historical accident has apparently decided which become the socially acceptable ones.

So what is the "scientific" view on human drug use? Regan is rather taken by the possibility that Homo sapiens evolved to be a substance abuser: we have been using drugs for so long that we have become genetically adapted to them. Indeed, they may serve an evolutionarily important, mind-expanding purpose. Unfortunately, he supports this radical suggestion with only a few speculations about a puzzling adult taste for bitter, mildly stimulating brews and evidence that Europeans have extra liver enzymes for eliminating alcohol, the possible legacy of centuries of heavy boozing. More convincing data will be needed before anyone can take his voguish hypothesis too seriously.

A clearer scientific message is an anthropological observation. In history, drugs have seemed a good thing when they are used as part of a ritual, communion or other bonding activities - when the use is a social rather than an individual act. This is how we instinctively draw the moral boundaries. Drugs that promote sociability become revered, while those that isolate are treated as profoundly dangerous. However, despite setting the scene for a sharp examination of how and whether we should use consciousness-altering drugs, Regan's book tails away into the anodyne. Rather than pursue the moral argument, he rambles off on to a description of the drugs used to treat mental illness and eventually even a potted history of the field of pharmacology. An opportunity missed.

 John McCrone writes about the science of consciousness at www.btinternet.com/~neuronaut/
fields.bodyText: Intoxicating Minds Ciaran Regan 164pp, Weidenfeld, £14.99 Buy it at BOL Could drug use be natural for humans - even something to which we have become genetically adapted? And is our preference for tobacco and alcohol over heroin and cocaine just a cultural accident, different societies making different choices about which drugs are embraced and which demonised? These are questions that Ciaran Regan, a professor of pharmacology at University College Dublin, raises yet never properly answers in an intriguing historical survey of Homo sapiens's long relationship with mind-altering substances. Regan offers up many quirky facts about drug use. The fly agaric mushroom, with its classic red cap and white spots, has probably been producing hot flushes and visions since prehistoric times. It is so prized by modern Siberian tribespeople that one mushroom can cost three reindeer. Luckily for the impecunious, the drug can be recycled by drinking the urine of the original purchaser. The active ingredient, ibotenic acid, remains potent for four or five such "passes". In medieval times, flying ointments were prepared from mandrake and deadly nightshade, which contain drugs that block the brain neurotransmitter, acetylcholine. When rubbed into the armpit or rectum - areas of skin with a rich blood supply - the user falls into a deep sleep with strange dreams of soaring. Cannabis was introduced to Europe by Napoleon's army returning from Egypt. In the form of a confection called dawamesc - hemp tops ground up with sugar, orange juice, cinnamon, cloves, cardamom, nutmeg, musk, pistachios and pine kernels (now there's a Christmas bon bon!) - it was handed around at Le Club des Hachichins, a notorious gathering place for decadents, including the poet Charles Baudelaire. Regan does a good job of sketching the full range of drug use, tracing the emergence of all the familiar drugs and showing how cultures often stumble upon their own local variants on a theme. So tobacco was being chewed throughout the Americas for at least the past 5,000 years. For a similar time - judging by the red-stained teeth of skeletons - people have been chewing betel nut in south east Asia, while Africans had their own nicotine equivalent in khat leaves and the Australian Aborigines chewed pituri, the extract of a shrub. Regan also offers thumbnail sketches of the relative hazards of various drugs and the way they affect the brain. Alcohol operates by the remarkably unsubtle mechanism of inserting itself into the thin membrane walls of brain cells, dulling their ability to fire. In the early stages of inebriation, certain types of brain cell or parts of the brain are more affected than others. The feeling is good because the pathways disrupted happen to be ones to do with feelings of anxiety and inhibition, so we develop that warm, sociable glow. But at higher doses, all brain activity begins to slur and we become just blind stumbling drunk. While the action of alcohol may present little challenge to the pharmacologist, cannabis, surprisingly, is probably the least understood drug. More than 60 psychoactive ingredients have so far been identified, and it is only very recently that researchers discovered the brain has a particular receptor for one of these molecules. That is, the brain uses a cannabis-like neurotransmitter for its own internal signalling purposes. But no one yet knows why stimulating this obscure receptor should produce a cocktail of psychological effects that include euphoria, hunger and talkativeness. As for the hazards of drug use, Regan's basic line seems to be that all drugs are poisons and none is much better or worse than others if used with moderation. Instead, what seems remarkable is the way cultures swing to extremes of opinion about a particular substance. Tobacco or marijuana? Alcohol or cocaine? On a pharmacological cost-benefit analysis, often these drugs come out much the same, but public attitudes are always polarised. fields.headline: Page-turners
fields.standfirst: Ian Sansom  on diaries for 2001
fields.trailText: Ian Sansom on diaries for 2001
fields.body:
As the determined second hand once again rushes to grip the top of the clock this New Year's Eve, dumb millions across the world will doubtless join hands, turn their backs upon the darkness of the past and stare upon that bright and terrible question that forever torments our enfeebled chronological souls. Shall it be a page a day, or a page a week? Desk or pocket? Filofax or electronic organiser? Which of these egregious little modernisms will we use to chart our course through another year? How shall we write our lives? And when shall we visit the dentist?

At the beginning of a year the diary expresses optimism. At the end it's a record of defeats. Re-read your own diary for 2000 and remind yourself of what it is you've already lost: friends, places, meetings. Time. All those little dead nows, the husks of our inner lives. The diary announces great and sad news: the old self is dead. But here, upspringing, comes something new.

If I consult my own old diaries, my past appears as mysterious to me as my future. Where was "DINNER?" on Wednesday February 9? Was I really in Ireland for two weeks in April that year? Why? And on February 12 1999, did I overhear this: "Yes, I'd like to make an appointment please. It's about my ears. I was wearing these dangly earrings, and the wire cut through my lobes"? Or did I make it up? Even a recent entry, for Monday December 11 2000, already makes no sense: "Piss hot." What?

The diary is the place where our outer lives take shape, the point at which the biographical meets the structural, where we compose our narrative. There are therefore several basic requirements for any successful diary. First, there must be enough room to record appointments. This rules out The 2001 Dodo Pad, a diary which seems to have been designed for people with tiny handwriting, or tiny hands. People, apparently, like Emma Thompson, Julian Critchley, and the Hon Lady Shuckburgh, all of whom appear to swear by the Dodo. If these names alone are not enough to put you off, then the "very British and timeless sense of humour featured throughout the diary" probably will. Any diary which exhorts you to doodle is taking its whimsy too seriously.

Diaries are supposed to set the tone and tempo for the year, and since the tempo of modern life, as Norbert Elias once so elegantly put it, is "nothing other than the mani festation of the multitude of intertwining chains of interdependence which run though every single social function people have to perform, and of the competitive pressure permeating this densely populated network", then the very least one should expect is for a diary to take its responsibilities seriously. The Times Literary Supplement Diary 2001 measures up to the challenge, being one of those long, severe pocket books far too big for most pockets, unless you have a tame Savile Row tailor. It will be useful if you ever find yourself without the telephone number for, say, Princeton University Press, or the address of the literary periodical Novoye Literaturnoye Obozreniye. TLS working days are divided into hours from 8 till 6, and weekends are left free. With a nasty logo embossed in silver on its leathery cover, it might easily be mistaken for a promotional giveaway from a road-haulage company.

There's no mistaking the Waterstone's Diary 2001. It announces itself as the "ideal practical present for any book lover", although at £7.99 one suspects that most book-lovers would prefer an actual book, grainy photographs and pieces from Philip Gross, Michèle Roberts and Ben Okri being hardly sufficient to satisfy all but the most dilatory of readers. At the other end of the scale is the British Library Literary Engagement Diary 2001, so stuffed full with calligraphy and holograph reproductions as to wither all but the boldest hand. Do you really want to jot down your dentist's appointment alongside the original manuscript of Sylvia Plath's "Insomniac"?

It is sometimes lamented that there are no great diarists any more - that our lives, paced as they are by telephones and television and emails, do not allow for the opinions and distensions of a Pepys, a Klemperer, or even a young Alan Bennett. And it's true, the diary for most of us is not the place to record our innermost thoughts and convictions, or even our evenings out with Stephen Daldry and Dame Thora Hird, but rather to remind us what time we need to collect the children. Most of us don't have time to feel nostalgic for our own emotions, or to dwell for too long upon the imagined horrors of the moment.

There may be no great diarists, then, but there are still great diaries. By far the best is the legendary Redstone Diary, the thinking man's Pirelli calendar. Now in its 11th year, it comes themed and edited by Julian Rothenstein and Mel Gooding. 2001 is "Odysseys and Other Journeys". Waterstone's may have a specially commissioned poem by Carol Ann Duffy, but here we find an "Application Form For a Kingdom of Heaven Passport", Richard Long's "Spring Walk", photographs of Che Guevara in disguise, the room in the Baykonur Cosmodrome, Kazakhstan, in which Yuri Gagarin spent the night before he travelled into space, and a stamped certificate of a pilgrimage to Santiago de Compostella. The typography is neat and unobtrusive, the dates are clear, and the sturdy ring-binding allows you to tear out the nice pictures when you've finished.

In the midst of one's self-obsessions, the Redstone Diary reminds one of other worlds. And who knows, maybe this year will be the year when you no longer merely imagine another life for yourself, but decide to live it instead. Actually, in the diary of my other life I've just woken up and taken my beautiful children down to the Lower East Side to buy Nova Scotia salmon and cream cheese and pumpernickel bagels at Tannenbaum's. Plans for the retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art are coming along fine, and I've finally booked an appointment for that cosmetic dentistry. We really must meet for lunch, or a drink. No, seriously. Have you got your diary?

 The 2001 Redstone Diary is available from Redstone Press at £10.95.

webTitle: Review: The Raymond Chandler Papers: Selected Letters and Non-Fiction

fields.headline: The long goodnight
fields.standfirst: Chris Petit  reads the  mournful, insomniac letters in The Raymond Chandler Papers
fields.trailText: Chris Petit reads the mournful, insomniac letters in The Raymond Chandler Papers
fields.body:
The Raymond Chandler Papers: Selected Letters and Non-Fiction, 1909-1959
eds Tom Hiney and Frank MacShane
267pp, Hamish Hamilton, £20
Buy it at BOL

Certain authors generate the literary equivalent of merchandising: Raymond Chandler is currently one of them, fitting snugly into the overlap between popular and academic studies. This latest volume of correspondence and bits and bobs, much of it previously published, is the equivalent of the Chandler Heritage Mug with endorsement from P D James, and designed for the shelf rather than to be read.

Read through, it's OK if taken at a clip with judicious use of the index, though too much bad early stuff is included for bulk. Later letters throw up some smart observations, but not many demonstrate "the raw wit that appears in print only once or twice a century" claimed by the introduction. At best the volume is an efficient testament to the lost minor art of letter-writing.

Chandler's correspondence was essentially the result of loneliness, the bulk written or dictated during the decline of his much older wife (by 17 years), and at night because he didn't sleep and couldn't write fiction after dark. There was no family, no real friends apart from his wife and an ancient cat. Chandler is generally more forthcoming about the cat, until after his wife's death, when he writes sentimentally and movingly about her. The main drawback is that this was a professional correspondence, meaning that however fluent or conversational the letters may appear, they remain relatively formal and buttoned-up. The only loosening occurs with a late botched suicide attempt, the result of depression after his wife's death.

Chandler, like most writers, was a griper, and the moans are standard - publishers' inability to publish properly, covers, meddling copy editors unsplitting intentionally split infinitives, photos, agents, reviews (absence of or unfavourable: "While reviewing generally is not very reliable anywhere, I really do think English reviewing is getting absurd"). He can be funny and bitchy about other writers, finding James M Cain too faux-naïf, Hemingway too absurdly macho, Agatha Christie dishonest and contrived, Greene lifeless and the New Yorker "a very dull periodical".

But he admired Fitzgerald, another dapper drunk whom he probably most resembled in trajectory and phobias, and deferred to as a stylist. Like Fitzgerald, Chandler, despite his hard-boiled props, wrote principally about loss: check those titles - The Long Goodbye, The Big Sleep, Farewell, My Lovely. And like Fitzgerald, and many others of his literary generation, he suffered from the writer's main occupational hazard, drink. He was reduced to writing - pulps, then private-eye fiction - because of drink, having been fired from the oil business in his forties. In Chandler's case, writing was the last resort of a working alcoholic, confirmed by the famous story of his dismal efforts to complete a Hollywood screenplay sober in the studio offices. He was eventually allowed to finish it at home, drunk.

Chandler writing and dictating into the night is the perfect portrait of the writer as agoraphobic ghost. A natural restlessness translated into frequent moves - more than 100 addresses in all - until he ended up in La Jolla outside San Diego. Chandler, who was of Irish Quaker extraction and had been poshly educated at Dulwich, was rather down on California, which he found shallow, in his letters at any rate; there are few hints here of the fertile landscape of his fiction.

His observations tend to rely on the sort of general disgruntlement which is the writer/drunk's off-duty state. He admitted he was something of a snob and wanted to be taken seriously by the literary set. His classical education set him up well, he argued defensively, for the "semi-literate" field in which he found himself working, as it saved him from being fooled by pretentiousness, "which is what most current fiction is too full of". Predictably, he rather wearied of being asked when he was going to write a "serious" novel, but the letters betray an obsession with the distinctions between high-, low- and middle-brow.

The accumulated tone, despite attempted chipperness, is of a terrible weariness, with little of the vigour referred to by James and none of the "modern Californian shaman" of which the introduction boasts. There is little magic to Chandler - that was never his point - and not much turned him on: TV is seen as a dangerous medium.

Hitchcock gets a ratty letter for messing up his contribution to the script of Strangers on a Train. Chandler worked for several years as a Hollywood screenwriter, giving him financial security before his books became successful. But on Hollywood he has little to add to the general bulletin of writers' complaints about its crassness. A quick, brilliant sketch of a bunch of producers coming back from lunch, with their gangster walks and mannerisms, is a rare flash of insight.

Chandler had trouble writing fiction and was smart enough to eke out his fragile talent and not use the letters as notebooks or dry runs. They were time-fillers: the prose equivalent of sleepwalking.

fields.headline: Big in thrillers
fields.trailText: Chris Petit on John Major's favourite author, Robert Goddard, plus Four Hands, Cold Steel Rain, An Innocent Eye and Code to Zero
fields.body:
As you would expect from John Major's favourite author, Robert Goddard is safe hands, if old- fashioned in appeal: more soft- than hard-boiled, given to regretful titles (Borrowed Time, Beyond Recall), stiffish portraits of the Middle Englander and a retrospective air. Sea Change (Bantam Press, £16.99) is something of a liberation, then, with a historical setting loosening Goddard up. A lively mix of political intrigue and high adventure in the New Year of 1721 follows the bursting of the South Sea Bubble, a match in financial fallout for the Wall Street Crash or Lloyds scandal. A penniless mapmaker is the dupe in a story that has him chased and chasing from Amsterdam to Rome after a beautiful widow and a ledger recording the extent of high financial irregularity, with Dutch colonial rivals and recusant Jacobites keenest to view. It's especially good on the arduousness of 18th-century travel.

Buy it at BOL

Four Hands (Picador USA, $13) by the Mexican writer Paco Ignacio Taibo II - translated for the US market five years ago - is not available in the UK but should be (publishers, please note), and is worth tracking down through the internet. Any story that starts with Stan Laurel crossing the Mexican border carrying eight gin bottles for a solo binge in a hotel room, from the window of which he will witness the assassination of Pancho Villa, is no ordinary thriller. Taibo's quirkiness has earned him a raft of favourable comparisons that include Dos Passos, Richard Condon, Heller, Doctorow and Garcia Marquez - all fine, but at the risk of detracting from his singularity. Four Hands is that comparatively rare thing, a really good left-wing thriller not shackled by earnestness. It delights in the interplay of politics, US imperialism, enterprise and investigative journalism: "Century after century, professionals of power hired professionals of information, who hired professionals of curiosity, who hired legalised criminals to keep the game in play." Ridiculously inventive, baggy and gifted with a sense of the ridiculous, it makes impressively easy work of its maze of unreliable evidence, grand paranoia, shifting time zones and exquisite conspiracy.

Kenneth Abel is the author of two sharp, wintry East Coast thrillers, Bait and The Blue Wall, which had a feel of The Sopranos in their grasp of the mundanity of corruption and domestic lives. Previous authorial information was scant. However, with his third, Cold Steel Rain (Orion, £9.99), Abel owns up to being a professor of Renaissance Literature and signals this coming out with a more poetic style - blood smelling of roses - and a story of Byzantine corruption set in a super-rainy and essentially foreign New Orleans and environs, a fetid state of palpable rottenness. Interestingly damaged cast, good bruised dialogue and a way with set-piece action.

Buy it at BOL

Like number 11 buses, Philip Hook's adjectives tend to come in threes. This mannerism apart, An Innocent Eye (Hodder & Stoughton, £14.99) is an uncongested tale that draws on Hook's experience as a Sotheby's art expert. At its crux is the vexed question of looted artworks taken from Jewish owners under the Nazis and recycled into the international art market by respectable galleries. A young journalist finds himself drawn into an interesting history of rarefied hypocrisy while trying to trace the whereabouts of a Monet belonging to murdered French grandparents, an investigation that throws up its share of wriggling aesthetes. Hook's other target is the Vatican, past masters at money-laundering when it suits fundraising aims. A vivid diary of Jewish persecution in occupied Paris is never quite matched by the split contemporary narrative, though there is a nifty deconstruction of the Jesuitical mind.

Buy it at BOL

In Code to Zero (Macmillan, £16.99), Ken Follett inserts his fiction into a recorded delay in the 1958 launch of America's first satellite, when bad weather was given as the reason despite clear Florida skies. In the stand-off brought about by both Russia and the US having the bomb, the cold war had turned into a largely surrogate affair - see Frances Stonor Saunders's fascinating Who Paid the Piper? The CIA and the Cultural Cold War (Granta, £9.99) - with the space race its most expensive diversion. Follett's brisk X-Files -ish tale of amnesia is another outing for that reliable evergreen, the Manchurian Candidate scenario, with the CIA operating mind-control games. Efficient research uncovers a murky history of Ivy League scientific research turned spooky.
Buy it at BOL
fields.bodyText: As you would expect from John Major's favourite author, Robert Goddard is safe hands, if old- fashioned in appeal: more soft- than hard-boiled, given to regretful titles (Borrowed Time, Beyond Recall), stiffish portraits of the Middle Englander and a retrospective air. Sea Change (Bantam Press, £16.99) is something of a liberation, then, with a historical setting loosening Goddard up. A lively mix of political intrigue and high adventure in the New Year of 1721 follows the bursting of the South Sea Bubble, a match in financial fallout for the Wall Street Crash or Lloyds scandal. A penniless mapmaker is the dupe in a story that has him chased and chasing from Amsterdam to Rome after a beautiful widow and a ledger recording the extent of high financial irregularity, with Dutch colonial rivals and recusant Jacobites keenest to view. It's especially good on the arduousness of 18th-century travel. Buy it at BOL Four Hands (Picador USA, $13) by the Mexican writer Paco Ignacio Taibo II - translated for the US market five years ago - is not available in the UK but should be (publishers, please note), and is worth tracking down through the internet. Any story that starts with Stan Laurel crossing the Mexican border carrying eight gin bottles for a solo binge in a hotel room, from the window of which he will witness the assassination of Pancho Villa, is no ordinary thriller. webTitle: Melancholy corners of a foreign field

fields.headline: Melancholy corners of a foreign field
fields.trailText: Director's diary
fields.body:
Melancholy corners of a foreign field

December 22 2000

Dawn on the road to Folkestone with my daughter. We're driving via the Channel tunnel towards Bauvais, south of
Amiens, about 50km to the north of Paris, to a house that we have rented with three other families. The radio is
percolating away with the Today programme, which is shorn of politics because it's Christmas, and because "politics" in
Britain is apparently synonymous with parliamentary sessions and the availability and willingness of politicians to submit
to interviews. So a zoologist is talking about his study of the way penguins conserve their energy when they walk.

It's
possible, he says, that penguins will be able to give advice to pregnant women. Or is it the other way round? Male
penguins sit on their eggs for months, without moving or eating, while their partners roam freely. "It'll never catch on
with humans," says my daughter.
I grew up in a house with few books; one of them (or to be more precise two of them) was The Times History of the
Great War. Appropriately enough, the volumes were as large as tombstones and at least as melancholy. The books
strove for a diffident and unemotional style but the story that the maps, photographs and statistics told to a curious
10-year-old was a terrible litany of misery. They didn't show the victims of gas attacks or of shell-shock - those mad
eyes, robbed of their souls came to haunt me later - but fuzzy photographs of lozenge-shaped tanks lurching over
muddy crests, battalions marching to and from the front, groups of soldiers relaxing ("Indian soldiers enjoy a
cigarette") and line after regimented line of corpses marked by crosses were enough to fill my imagination.

December 23

It's a sharp, clear day as we drive through the small villages and towns whose names conjure my childhood memories of
houses and churches crumble like pie-crust by the war: Armentiers, Bapaume, Bethune, Douai, Cambrai, Arras, Vimy -
where there's a memorial to 60,000 Canadian soldiers who died defending a small lip of land that projects above a plain
that used to be dotted with coal mines. The memorial consists of two tall rectangular columns of Portland stone, with
the names of the dead soldiers inscribed around the base while a hooded weeping woman gazes out from the ridge.

It's
very simple and expressive and extraordinarily moving but less so than the trenches that have been preserved nearby.
The Canadian and German lines that faced each other are perhaps only 30m apart at their closest. Between the
opposing trenches, massive craters have been left by constant bombardment as if gouged out by giant hands, while the
land all around them is pitted and puckered. It's all grassed over now like a thin membrane over a virulent pox. On this
beautiful, cold, sunny day my daughter and I are able to see each other all too clearly across the trenches: close enough
to see a smile or a tear.

December 24

There's a thick, almost impenetrable fog and as we enter the Somme region, small handwritten signs announce perhaps
the most memorable characteristic of the region (at least for the soldiers): boue - mud. Every minor road is smeared
with thick clay, which sticks to our shoes as we step towards a monument near a small village called Azincourt. Henry
V's battlefield is marked with a menhir and a plan showing the disposition of the troops. The nimble English archers
hiding in the woods achieved victory over the French knights, who were obliged to fight on foot because of the
waterlogged fields and were bogged down in the mud in their heavy armour.
We think of the 20th century as the era that invented mass barbarity and suffering, in which whole societies were
culled by war, but 10,000 Frenchmen died at the battle of Agincourt.

The battlefield is known as La Carogne - the
Carrion, a name which might justly apply to the whole of this region in which war cemeteries are as common as orchards
in the Vale of Evesham. The stoical jocularity of the "tommy" is achingly immortalised in a British cemetery called
Blighty Valley, but alongside almost every small road there seems to be a corner of a foreign field that is forever
England, or Scotland, or Wales, Ireland, Canada, Australia, India, Africa, Morocco, even Germany, whose cemeteries
announce themselves more discreetly and whose dead are marked by plain black crosses.

Through a veil of mist and thin rain we spot the British memorial to the Unknown Soldiers. It's an appropriately
monumental monument designed by Lutyens in the imperial manner that he developed for the government buildings in
New Delhi. A vast brick-built four-sided triumphal arch towers over a stone catafalque bearing the names of 73,000
men who went missing in action.

Crowned With the Sunshine of Immortal Youth, says the inscription with appalling irony.
Lines of tombstones, the dead on parade, mark the presence of what was left of bodies that could only be identified by
the regimental flashes on their uniforms: "Soldier of the Great War/Known Unto God". On the monument are the names
of missing members of the bicycle battalion. In this cold, this fog, this wet - even today we slip and sludge through the
perfectly manicured lawns - this seems to sum up the entire lunacy; in lanes impassable to lorries, tanks, armoured
cars and even horses, a bicycle seems as much use as a teacup in a forest fire.

They say there is no condition one adapts to so quickly as war, a lesson that's been learned the hard way by the nearby
village of Thiepval, which was destroyed twice in the first war and fought over in the second. But like all the other
villages and towns we have passed through, its face is resolutely cheery - Christmas decorations in the streets, Santas
scaling the walls of the low houses.
I'm an unembarrassed Francophile of the sort brilliantly documented by Posy Simmonds: I like the language (though I
don't speak it well), the oysters in the market, the expert butchers, the choice of cheeses, the sense of place and civic
pride, boules in the town squares under the plane trees, poplars by the roadsides, the architecture (up to about 1910),
much of the landscape and many of the people.

I like too the fact that most small towns have Maisons de la Culture, and
that in a smallish town like Amiens the alternative to The Grinch and The Muppet Christmas Movie is a choice of 12
Chinese films. If there is evidence of a permanent conquest in this much fought-over part of France, it is in the
McDonald's signs which are displayed on the outskirts of every town, the huge carpet, furniture, DIY and wine
warehouses, and the nightmarishly gigantic hypermarkets. As my daughter would say, they'll never catch on with
humans.

webTitle: Honours for art, science - and student fees

fields.headline: Honours for art, science - and student fees
fields.trailText: The great and the good in science and the arts in academe are recognised in this year's honours - and so is the man who challenged the government's policy on student fees.
fields.body:
The great and the good in science and the arts in academe are recognised in this year's honours - and so is the man who challenged the government's policy on student fees.

Andrew Cubie, the Edinburgh lawyer who chaired an inquiry into student funding for the Scottish Parliament, becomes a CBE for services to business and the community in Scotland. As chairman of CBI Scotland 1995-96 he showed no enthusiasm for devolution but when called by the faltering Labour-Liberal Democrat coalition to sort out the explosive question of fees, carried the process of consultation to the Scottish public in a groundbreaking way. He has since criticised the Scottish executive for not implementing his recommendations fully but his report remains an embarrassing alternative for the Westminster government.

Two heads of higher education institutions become knights and one a dame. Professor Janet Trotter, director of Cheltenham and Gloucester College of Higher Education since its formation in 1990, started her career as a school teacher of religious studies.

Professor Christopher Frayling, Rector of the Royal College of Art, is known as a passionate advocate of the value of art college education although in a Guardian interview he confessed he was depressed by some of the "gothic shocking stuff" produced by students wanting attention. The Provost of University College London, Professor Christopher Llewellyn Smith, is honoured for his contribution to particle physics, notably as director general of CERN, the £350m a year European research establishment. He oversaw the launch of the £1.5bn Large Hadron Collider project with American and Japanese collaboration before moving to UCL last year.

Also knighted is Christopher White, former director of the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford, and professor at Yale. An expert on Dutch painters, particularly Rembrandt and Rubens, he is honoured for services to art history.

Hopes for the profitable development of bioscience are reflected in knighthoods for John Sulston, former director of the Sanger Centre for genome research at Cambridge, and to the biotechnology entrepreneur Chris Evans. The founder and director of Merlin Science Services is an honorary professor at Manchester, Liverpool and Exeter universities as well as being a big Labour party donor. Professor Grahame Bulfield. director of the Roslin Institute near Edinburgh, where Dolly the sheep was cloned, receives a CBE for services to animal genetics.

Two distinguished medical men are recognised with knighthoods for their contribution to education and training as well as research - Professor Leszek Krzysztof Borysiewicz, of Cardiff University, and Barry Jackson, president of the Royal College of Surgeons.

Professor Anna Davies, of Somerville College Oxford, an internationally respected scholar of philology and linguistics, is made a dame.

Two vice chancellors receive CBEs - Ian Graham-Bryce, former principal of Dundee, and Patrick Dowling, head of Surrey University for services to business/academic links.

fields.headline: Reach for the skies
fields.standfirst: Architecture scaled the heights this year, says  Jonathan Glancey
fields.trailText: Architecture scaled the heights this year, says Jonathan Glancey
fields.body:
Chris Smith and the Millennium Commission held a reception a fortnight before Christmas to celebrate a year of "outstanding achievement of the many diverse projects the Commission has supported" for the year 2000. The "lounge suit" do (note the dodgy 1950s dress code) was held in the Turbine Hall of Tate Modern. The Millennium Commission has contributed £50m to this hugely popular London attraction.

Pointedly perhaps, the presence of guests was not required at the Dome in Greenwich, for which the Millennium Commission has dug much deeper into the pockets of its lounge suits. Yet, in visitor numbers alone, the Tate, a modern art gallery, beat the dome, an incomprehensible theme park, hands down.

Not that there was anything particularly wrong with the design of the dome itself. Yes, it's an old-fashioned, Dan Dare-style homage by the Richard Rogers Partnership to those twin architectural icons of the 1951 Festival of Britain, Ralph Tubb's Dome of Discovery and Powell and Moya's Skylon. Yes, it's also a rather likable rogue, especially by night. Nancy Banks-Smith, the Guardian's TV critic, described it as looking like a stranded jellyfish.

The trouble with the dome - the huge sums of money wasted on the content aside - was the lack of a single good idea, the smell of burgers that wafted inside and out, the vicious and churlish behaviour of the politicians responsible for it, especially during the lead-up to its opening, the stink over its financing and management, and the frightful row over its future.

Disturbingly, the year's other major architectural project connected directly to those who like having power over us was the bloated and ugly Portcullis House, by Michael Hopkins and Partners. This visual assault stands slap-bang opposite Barry and Pugin's fairytale Palace of Westminster.

It's a shame that so much effort, money and aggressive energy was wasted on the dome, especially as the doomed-from-the-start Millennium Experience was to set the political and cultural tone for the officially designated millennium year. It cast a deep nimbus cloud over so many fascinating and truly worthwhile projects that were funded by the Millennium Commission, one of several discretionary bodies under Chris Smith's wing.

Back to the pre-Christmas Tate Modern bash. The invitation was a brave attempt to blow that cloud away. It listed in bold type the achievements of the Millennium Commission... "A million trees, eight new bridges, 100 new visitor attractions, 550 village halls and centres, 8,500 miles of paths and cycleways... almost 2,000 new open green spaces, a million books to 4,500 state schools... 600 churches with new bells." Add to these the equally impressive lists that could be typed up by the Heritage Lottery and Arts Council Lottery commissions and it's clear that the sin of the dome has been redeemed in all but the press and the popular imagination.

Without doubt there have been some very good millennium-related buildings. The conversion of the former Bankside power station into Tate Modern by the Swiss architects Herzog and de Meuron is a magnificent achievement, if a little too cool for some tastes.

There's the hugely impressive Great Court at the British Museum designed by Foster and Partners, and the handsome, castle keep-like Walsall Art Gallery by Caruso St John (their first major building and a critical triumph). In Lancaster, there's the romantic Ruskin library by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard.

In West Sussex the Millennium Seed Bank, for the Royal Botanic Gardens' outpost at Wakehurst Place, is a fine building by Stanton Williams and a superb learning experience. The American Air Force museum at Duxford is Foster at his best again, aided and abetted by a dangerously beautiful collection of US warbirds flocked around a B-52 nuclear bomber. There's Foster, a third time, with the Great Glass House at the National Botanical Garden of Wales.

Others not to miss are the Peckham library by Alsop and Stormer, the London Eye by David Marks and Julia Barfield, the Wellcome Wing at London's Science Museum by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard, and the extraordinary Eden Project in Cornwall by Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners. These hi-tech bubbles that appear to blow from a disused clay quarry look intriguing; we'll have to wait until next year to see if all the fuss has been worth it. Let's hope so.

There are buildings that don't exist but ought to by now - if the millennium suits had wanted it. I miss Zaha Hadid's opera house on Cardiff bay, even though it never left the drawing board or computer screen. It would have looked great; the project was scuppered by the Millennium Commission. I would like to have seen Daniel Libeskind and Cecil Balmond's amazing Spiral gallery, all fractals and wired-up geometric energy, completed and open at the V&A. Fortunately, Libeskind's Imperial War Museum, Salford is well on its way on the opposite side of the Manchester Ship Canal from Michael Wilford's busy new Lowry Centre.

There are plenty of other buildings I wish didn't exist. Throughout the year, British architects of another breed have been busy littering the country with a staggering number of trashy shopping malls, call centres, distribution depots, business parks, shiny offices and executive housing. Yes, we have seen some fine new buildings of which we can all be proud this year, yet these are outweighed by the junk that we somehow insist on as our right.

Equally we have watched the infrastructure of these traffic-coned isles slip and slide away into disorder. If only we could have invested some of those millennium billions into our railways and our hospitals as well as our museums and parks. Imagine if we had new main-line stations and other transport buildings designed by the likes of those who have graced our museums and art galleries.

The year did see, however, the completion of the last of the great publicly funded and publicly run transport infrastructure projects we'll see for many years: the Jubilee line extension of the London Underground between Green Park and Stratford via North Greenwich. Under the inspired and tireless architectural direction of Roland Paoletti, one amazing station has followed another. The line has become a tourist attraction in its own right. It is a truly great achievement; the sheer scale of some of the lonelier stations, such as Canada Water, suggesting future development around them in what, in parts, are still very poor areas of London.

At the same time, the principal gateways to London from overseas - with the honourable exceptions of Waterloo and Paddington stations, both beneficiaries of the design skills of Nicholas Grimshaw - remain pretty embarrassing experiences. Think Heathrow, think Gatwick, think Stansted (a fine Foster building being quickly trashed), and think the stink of horrid food. The millennium would have been a good opportunity to invest in a clear-up of these latter-day Augean stables.

On a smaller scale, two of my own best architectural investments this year have been the new edition of Norbert Schoenauer's peerless 6,000 Years of Housing (WW Norton), and the first English translation of Hermann Kern's Through the Labyrinth (Prestel). This is less a rainy afternoon book than one that could see you through a flood: a good year, then, to publish this masterly study of labyrinths and their relation to religion and architecture.
