Add to these the equally impressive lists that could be typed up by the Heritage Lottery and Arts Council Lottery commissions and it's clear that the sin of the dome has been redeemed in all but the press and the popular imagination. Without doubt there have been some very good millennium-related buildings. The conversion of the former Bankside power station into Tate Modern by the Swiss architects Herzog and de Meuron is a magnificent achievement, if a little too cool for some tastes. There's the hugely impressive Great Court at the British Museum designed by Foster and Partners, and the handsome, castle keep-like Walsall Art Gallery by Caruso St John (their first major building and a critical triumph). In Lancaster, there's the romantic Ruskin library by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard. In West Sussex the Millennium Seed Bank, for the Royal Botanic Gardens' outpost at Wakehurst Place, is a fine building by Stanton Williams and a superb learning experience. The American Air Force museum at Duxford is Foster at his best again, aided and abetted by a dangerously beautiful collection of US warbirds flocked around a B-52 nuclear bomber. There's Foster, a third time, with the Great Glass House at the National Botanical Garden of Wales. Others not to miss are the Peckham library by Alsop and Stormer, the London Eye by David Marks and Julia Barfield, the Wellcome Wing at London's Science Museum by MacCormac Jamieson Prichard, and the extraordinary Eden Project in Cornwall by Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners. These hi-tech bubbles that appear to blow from a disused clay quarry look intriguing; we'll have to wait until next year to see if all the fuss has been worth it. Let's hope so. There are buildings that don't exist but ought to by now - if the millennium suits had wanted it. I miss Zaha Hadid's opera house on Cardiff bay, even though it never left the drawing board or computer screen. It would have looked great; the project was scuppered by the Millennium Commission. I would like to have seen Daniel Libeskind and Cecil Balmond's amazing Spiral gallery, all fractals and wired-up geometric energy, completed and open at the V&A. Fortunately, Libeskind's Imperial War Museum, Salford is well on its way on the opposite side of the Manchester Ship Canal from Michael Wilford's busy new Lowry Centre. There are plenty of other buildings I wish didn't exist. Throughout the year, British architects of another breed have been busy littering the country with a staggering number of trashy shopping malls, call centres, distribution depots, business parks, shiny offices and executive housing. Yes, we have seen some fine new buildings of which we can all be proud this year, yet these are outweighed by the junk that we somehow insist on as our right. Equally we have watched the infrastructure of these traffic-coned isles slip and slide away into disorder. If only we could have invested some of those millennium billions into our railways and our hospitals as well as our museums and parks. Imagine if we had new main-line stations and other transport buildings designed by the likes of those who have graced our museums and art galleries. The year did see, however, the completion of the last of the great publicly funded and publicly run transport infrastructure projects we'll see for many years: the Jubilee line extension of the London Underground between Green Park and Stratford via North Greenwich. Under the inspired and tireless architectural direction of Roland Paoletti, one amazing station has followed another. The line has become a tourist attraction in its own right. It is a truly great achievement; the sheer scale of some of the lonelier stations, such as Canada Water, suggesting future development around them in what, in parts, are still very poor areas of London. At the same time, the principal gateways to London from overseas - with the honourable exceptions of Waterloo and Paddington stations, both beneficiaries of the design skills of Nicholas Grimshaw - remain pretty embarrassing experiences. Think Heathrow, think Gatwick, think Stansted (a fine Foster building being quickly trashed), and think the stink of horrid food. The millennium would have been a good opportunity to invest in a clear-up of these latter-day Augean stables. On a smaller scale, two of my own best architectural investments this year have been the new edition of Norbert Schoenauer's peerless 6,000 Years of Housing (WW Norton), and the first English translation of Hermann Kern's Through the Labyrinth (Prestel). This is less a rainy afternoon book than one that could see you through a flood: a good year, then, to publish this masterly study of labyrinths and their relation to religion and architecture.

webTitle: Passionate teacher who was doing something special

fields.headline: Passionate teacher who was doing something special
fields.standfirst:
Will Woodward on his meeting with Charlotte Wilson
30 December: Briton among 20 killed in ambush by Burundi rebels
fields.trailText: A few weeks ago at an Indian restaurant in Kigali I sat next to Charlotte Wilson as she translated for me the agenda of a summit she had been attending with the Rwandan government.
fields.body:
A few weeks ago at an Indian restaurant in Kigali I sat next to Charlotte Wilson as she translated for me the agenda of a summit she had been attending with the Rwandan government.

She was exasperated and mildly amused by the request that she attend. The meeting, to discuss the science curriculum in secondary schools, meant time away from teaching at her school in Shyogwe, about which she talked with bursting enthusiasm. She would rather have been with her students.

At the same time she enjoyed recounting how the summons had come from the ministry of education, via her headteacher, with the clear instruction that it would be quite wrong not to attend. So she found her way to Kigali and turned up at a meeting with precious little idea of what they were supposed to be discussing or for how long she was expected to attend.

Charlotte, like most Britons working in Rwanda for Voluntary Service Overseas, was passionate about what she did and also had no intention of carrying on schoolteaching when she returned to the UK. This was fantastic, she said, but her vocation was scientific research. She had a PhD in molecular microbiology which, she felt, was the real reason she had been invited to the meeting.

Because most of the country's educated class were among the 800,000 people wiped out in the genocide of 1994, anybody with any expertise is eagerly greeted. The government is delighted to have them. The British government, which has made support for education the centrepiece of its aid effort, is as enthusiastic about seeing them there.

And the volunteers have responded, most exhausted but unfazed by 30 or so hours of teaching a week, to classes of somewhere between 40 and 70, plus marking. The programme, under the sensitive control of Fran Roots, the director in Kigali, already seems part of the educational landscape in Rwanda. The volunteers are helped but not mollycoddled, supported when things are tough but encouraged to make their own way when things are going well.

Most find it difficult at first but most stay, learn, enjoy it and grow as people, living in local homes, travelling around by bus and making Rwandan friends. When I was there in late October the volunteers were making plans for the festive season, leaving notes on the VSO office wall. Charlotte seemed to have thrown herself into the work and the lifestyle, constantly aware that what they were doing was special. She was certainly one of its keenest advocates.

fields.headline: Watford end Taylor trauma
fields.standfirst: Barnsley 0 - 1 Watford
fields.trailText: Barnsley 0 - 1 Watford
fields.body:
Allan Nielsen last night delivered the goal that could revive Watford's First Division promotion drive.

The Denmark midfielder's fifth goal of the season arrived on 56 minutes and ended a dire run which had caused the Watford manager Graham Taylor to berate his fading side. But the Hornets richly deserved their reward for a swashbuckling performance that belied their recent fall from grace.

For the managerless Barnsley it was a miserable night as well as a bitterly cold one. The Rotherham manager Ronnie Moore, among those tipped to replace the departed Dave Bassett, was an interested spectator and would have had no trouble in compiling a dossier on the Yorkshiremen, such was their inept display.

Barnsley fans had expected their side to go for the jugular against Taylor's men, who came into the game having lost seven of their previous eight games with their confidence presumably flagging.

Yet it was Watford, once leaders of the pack chasing the champions-elect Fulham, who took charge from the off.

They would have been gifted an early lead had it not been for Steve Chettle's intended clearance hitting his own crossbar in the 15th minute. Tommy Smith's right-wing cross should have been dealt with comfortably by the experienced Chettle, but his feeble attempt at a lashed clearance sliced over his own head and clipped Kevin Miller's bar.

Barnsley were penned inside their own half for the first half, but right on the interval Mike Sheron turned superbly on the edge of the box only to make a mess of his shot, which trickled straight into the arms of the waiting Alec Chamberlain.

That came after Barnsley's Chris Morgan was forced to clear his fellow defender Chris Barker's wayward header off the line. Watford continued to call the tune, with Tommy Mooney's shot rifling over the top from all of 30 yards.

The goal that Watford had always threatened was taken with some aplomb by Nielsen 11 minutes after half-time. Mooney switched the play from left to right with a delightful ball to Smith and, when the midfielder's cross was whipped into the six-yard box, the Dane was on hand to hook home from close range.

Nielsen should have added a second but blasted wide with Miller nowhere. Chamberlain was forced into a rare save to preserve the lead, and did superbly to claw away Sheron's 16-yard snapshot.

fields.headline: Juninho back at the top
fields.trailText: The former Middlesbrough midfielder Juninho ends a triumphant first season back home this afternoon when he appears for Vasco da Gama in the Brazilian league final.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The former Middlesbrough midfielder Juninho ends a triumphant first season back home this afternoon when he appears for Vasco da Gama in the Brazilian league final.

Juninho, who arrived in Rio this summer on loan from Atletico Madrid, has been widely regarded as Vasco's most important player this season. His return to form after an unhappy second stint at the Riverside has already been rewarded with a call-up to the Brazilian national team.

"Without a shadow of a doubt Juninho will be a first-choice player for Brazil for the next international games," the Vasco coach Joel Santana said yesterday. "He is an excellent player, he has a strong character and very good technique. Football is all about the moment, and Juninho is living the best moment of his career. He has rediscovered his own football."

At Vasco, who beat Man chester United on the way to the World Club final in January, he has formed a strong partnership with Romario, who despite his 34 years has scored 73 goals this year.

Juninho - known as Juninho Paulista to differentiate him from another Juninho in the Vasco squad - has pleased fans with a flowing style they say recalls the golden era of Brazilian football.

In September, after only four matches for Vasco, he was called up to play Bolivia in a World Cup qualifier. In Brazil's next match he scored in a 6-0 thrashing of Venezuela.

In the first leg of the league decider on Wednesday Vasco and Sao Caetano drew 1-1 and, although today's second leg will be in Vasco's Sao Januario stadium, Juninho is taking nothing for granted. "At this stage of the competition home advantage counts for nothing," he said. "Whoever is better on the day will win."

Today's final caps six farcical months in the domestic game. The national league was redubbed the Joao Havelange Cup and given a byzantine structure in which the top clubs from the lower divisions played the 12 best first division teams in a knockout phase.

To the embarrassment of the organisers, second division Sao Caetano beat Fluminense, Palmeiras and Gremio of the top flight before reaching the final. If Sao Caetano win today they will have performed the bizarre feat of winning the league without having ever played in the first division.

Their team are a motley selection of players including one who spent time in a top- security prison. Seven of the team go to the same evangelical church and when they score they kneel in a line and reveal T-shirts with slogans such as "God is true" and "100% Jesus". Their coach set a less pious tone yesterday by splitting the lip of a reporter after objecting to his line of questioning.

webTitle: Why England had to get tough

fields.headline: Why England had to get tough
fields.standfirst: Daniel Taylor charts the rise of a new hooligan wave that has forced the government to act
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor charts the rise of a new hooligan wave that has forced the government to act.
fields.body:
It is 16 years since John Barnes danced through the entire Brazil defence only for his euphoria at scoring one of England's finest goals in a 2-0 victory to be swiftly trampled on by a stampede of size-10 Doc Martens.

On the onward journey from Rio de Janeiro a number of England followers travelling on the team plane abused the left winger. Instead of being treated like a hero, Barnes was dismayed to find himself being looked upon as a leper. Mark Hateley had also scored for England that night and the "fans" let it be known that, in their opinion, the score was only 1-0. The "nigger's effort" did not count.

Barnes was clever. When the bananas were being thrown and the monkey chants started polluting the air, he refused to let his emotions show. One day he turned up for a fancy-dress party organised by Liverpool's players in a Ku Klux Klan outfit. The giant banana costume, he explained, had already been hired.

Gradually the racists slunk away, their numbers dwindling and the instigators tired of being ostracised by decent football folk.

Now it seems they are coming back. According to evidence from the Home Office and the Football Supporters' Association, football violence and racism are back on the increase and spreading like a contagious disease. A new generation of xenophobic yobs is coming through the ranks and, in the most extreme cases, England's players have once again been targets for their vitriol.

Indeed the problem is becoming so bad that the government has proposed a radical shake-up of the England Members Club, after a post-Euro 2000 study revealed it to be infested with young white hooligans "determined to display offensive and distorted perceptions of patriotism".

Strong words, but as those who have followed England on a regular basis can testify, no exaggeration.

Take the game against France in Paris last September. "It may as well have been a Nuremberg rally," says Paul Thomas, a club member and the Football Supporters' Association international co-ordinator. "There were people sieg heil-ing during God Save the Queen and racist abuse throughout the match, not just directed at the French players but also the England players. I can certainly remember Sol Campbell taking some terrible abuse and one or two others as well.

"It's still a minority but, make no mistake, it's a sizeable minority and I'm sad to say the level of racism and xenophobia has definitely been getting worse over the last couple of years.

"Songs like No Surrender to the IRA are on the increase, not just with the national team but at grounds around the country. There's no disguising the fact there are some vile and unpleasant people in the members' club."

After the deaths of two Leeds United supporters in Istanbul eight months ago, it is clear that the English hooligan element sees Turkey as the new enemy. But what is perhaps most disturbing is the number of teenagers, aged 16 to 19, who have become involved.

"We have just had France 98 and Euro 2000 which have both been quite easy for young people to get to," says Thomas. "You don't see the BNP [British National Party] or Combat 18 openly organising racism but there is definitely a new generation coming through, as the game in the Stade de France showed."

John Tongue, a Bury supporter and club member since its formation, recalls England's World Cup qualifier against Italy at Wembley in 1997. "I went with three friends and afterwards two of them said they would never watch England again," he says.

"One of the distasteful things about watching England is that is there is always a percentage of racists. There is a certain level of xenophobia, rubbish like No Surrender to the IRA and all that dross, but what surprised me most that night was that we were sitting in a section designated for the members' section. Judging by some of the remarks we heard, it did not seem to make any difference whatsoever."

According to Mark Perryman, a Tottenham Hotspur fan who has followed England abroad since 1996, it is "too simplistic" to say the main problem is racism. "The problem is xenophobia rather than racism. There are people who follow England and refuse to accept anything foreign. But that's not just a football problem. You will see that on the Costa del Sol with English tourists every summer.

"The report is right to say there is a hardcore of racist and violent people in the members' club but there are also the best, most passionate supporters in the country and the government will get nowhere if it fails to realise that."

Ministers are proposing stricter implementation of laws against racist and sexist remarks at matches and there are plans to encourage a more family-oriented environment by employing accredited stewards to travel with the official members' organisation.

The report was set up in the wake of violence involving English supporters at Euro 2000 and it suggests that a revamped club would require the existing 27,000 members to be vetted again. Anyone with a criminal conviction would be barred sine die.

Thomas says the jury remains out on the government's proposals. "A revamp is necessary but it will need a package of measures. There are all sort of things to be weighed up and that will mean a long hard struggle."

Until then, England's away matches will continue to be engulfed by a dread of what may or may not happen off the pitch.

webTitle: Eriksson coming, Ferguson going the pivotal issues

fields.headline: Eriksson coming, Ferguson going the pivotal issues
fields.standfirst: 2001 will be all about managing. No change there, then
fields.trailText: 2001 will be all about managing. No change there, then.
fields.body:
And so to 2001, a space odyssey perhaps for those playing Bradford City but in general a chance for English football to declare that the 21st century really begins here. For let's face it, the new millennium has so far seen little except a series of false starts.

Once nothing symbolised the grandeur of the nation's most popular sport so much as the Wembley silhouette. Now those twin towers, far from being the Castor and Pollux of the English game, represent the bluster and cock-up of what was being planned to replace them.

Remember how the year began? England were going to win the Fifa vote and host the next World Cup but one. In the meantime Kevin Keegan's team would defy critical pessimism and make a decent showing in the 2000 European Championship.

Then came the water cannons of Charleroi followed by Claudia Schiffer, Germany's secret weapon, the beauty of the latter finishing off what was left of England's (and South Africa's) 2006 bid after the ugliness of the former. All right, the vote was going to be lost anyway, but at least the English would have gone home with dignity.

Then again nobody could dispute that 2001 will see the England football team making one of its more novel reawakenings. What remains to be seen is whether revolution brings revival.

Though it was hardly necessary to be Old Moore to predict Keegan walking out on the England job before the year was up, few could have foreseen 12 months ago that the team would now be awaiting a foreign coach. The coming of Sven Goran Eriksson promises to be the pivotal moment of 2001 once, that is, the precise moment of his arrival has been ascertained.

Not that anything could have been more predictable than the events that have ensued since the Football Association announced the Swede's appointment from next July 1. Eriksson got the job because of success at club level but if he takes up the post before the agreed date it will be only because his present season with Lazio has continued to go badly wrong.

The FA wants its man installed sooner rather than later and ideally in good time for England's World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March. But what price Eriksson's chances with the media and public opinion if he makes his entrance against a background of uncertainty bordering on the hostile?

Already the studious Swede knows that the xenophobic branch of the fourth estate is waiting to pounce. After Euro 2000 and the disappointment of the early World Cup qualifiers - the home defeat by Germany which brought Keegan's resignation and the numbed draw in Finland under Howard Wilkinson - the FA was entitled to search far and wide for an accomplished coach, but in some quarters the idea of a foreigner picking the national team still galls.

Already it looks as if the best England can hope for in qualifying for the 2002 World Cup in Japan and South Korea is a play-off as one of the group runners-up. A failure to qualify would be a serious blow not only for players and supporters but for the restructuring of the English game at all levels.

Regular tournament experience is essential if England are to have any chance of their youngsters maturing as successfully as those of France in the 90s. And it is important that the likes of Manchester United, Liverpool, Arsenal, West Ham and Ipswich are able to leaven their established teams with a healthy crop of developing English players.

webTitle: Winter freeze lays waste to league programme

fields.headline: Winter freeze lays waste to league programme
fields.trailText: The big winter freeze has had a devastating effect on the weekend's fixtures. More than 30 matches have been postponed in England and Scotland with more likely to follow after pitch inspections this morning.
fields.body:
The big winter freeze has had a devastating effect on the weekend's fixtures. More than 30 matches have been postponed in England and Scotland with more likely to follow after pitch inspections this morning.

The biggest casualties so far have been a trio of Premiership matches, with Aston Villa-Leicester, Everton-Leeds and Bradford-Liverpool all falling victim to the weather. Newcastle, Middlesbrough and Southampton will all decide this morning whether their pitches are playable.

Villa decided to call off the match with Peter Taylor's side yesterday morning because, although the Villa Park surface remains playable because of a pitch cover and undersoil heating, conditions in and around the stadium are dangerous. Villa's safety and operations manager Graham Hodgetts said: "You can't even stand up in some places and for me it was an easy decision."

The First Division games at Gillingham, Grimsby and Wimbledon have also been postponed and more than half the games in the Second and Third are casualties.

In the Second Division the matches at Bristol Rovers, Cambridge, Oxford, Rotherham, Swansea, Swindon and Wrexham are off. In the Third Division the matches at Blackpool, Carlisle, Cheltenham, Lincoln City, Plymouth and Rochdale are postponed.

Celtic and Rangers will have the weekend off after their games were among the victims of the weather and only three top-flight Scottish matches are on: Dundee-Dunfermline, Hibernian-Dundee United and St Johnstone-Hearts.

Outside the Scottish Premier League only two games have so far survived: Partick Thistle-Berwick and Peterhead-Brechin.

fields.headline: Gregory eats humble pie
fields.trailText: John Gregory has used up another of his managerial lives at Aston Villa by apologising to the chairman Doug Ellis for his damning and personal criticisms of him.
fields.body:
John Gregory has used up another of his managerial lives at Aston Villa by apologising to the chairman Doug Ellis for his damning and personal criticisms of him.

Gregory s apology, issued by his solicitor Julian Middleton, followed a long clear-the-air meeting between the pair at Villa Park late yesterday.

Villa's manager had accused the 76-year-old Ellis in a Sunday newspaper of being "stuck in a time warp" and "talking big but acting small", remarks Gregory now claims he regrets making public.

"I wish to publicly apologise to the chairman Mr Ellis if he felt my recently reported remarks were no more than a personal attack on him," Gregory said.

"My remarks were born out of my frustration and perhaps should have been discussed in private than aired publicly.

"I wish to apologise to Doug personally for the remarks I made. I am still totally committed to Aston Villa Football Club, and myself and the board will be working a lot closer together in the future to achieve the success supporters expect of this great club."

By contrast, Ellis maintained a discreet silence. But it is a significant silence. By refusing to confirm the pair had made up, Ellis sent a clear message that the outspoken Gregory had been forced to climb down.

So Gregory has escaped the fate suffered by six of his predecessors: the sack. Yet it is unlikely Ellis, a proud man who does not take to being crossed, will either forgive or forget.

Despite Gregory's apology, Ellis is understood to feel betrayed and the chances are that the team's results will not have to dip much, or Gregory to stray too far out of line, for the manager to be dismissed.

Lazio's assistant coach Roberto Mancini yesterday made clear he wants to bring Paolo di Canio back to the Italian champions from West Ham.

The 32-year-old, who played with Lazio early in his career, had said it would be "fantastic" to appear again for the club led by the England-bound Sven Goran Eriksson.

Mancini said: "Lazio need to hire a player in the January transfer window. Di Canio is one of my favourite players and he can play in the Champions League.

"In my list, No1 is Barcelona winger Marc Overmars - but he can't play in the Champions League - and No2 Di Canio."

Meanwhile West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp also has to consider a £3.5m offer for his captain Steve Lomas from Manchester City.

Joe Royle, who yesterday completed the signing of Darren Huckerby from Leeds for £3.2m, is keen to take Lomas back to City, the club he left for Upton Park three years ago.

But Redknapp is delaying any deal until the crowded festive programme is over. In any case he said: "City are very interested in signing Steve, but I am not keen to lose him . . . Until Steve comes and tells me he wants to go, I want to keep him."

Preston have paid a club-record fee - "in excess of £1.5m" - for the Manchester United striker David Healy.

The 21-year-old made his sole league appearance for United as a substitute only last Saturday against Ipswich. He has spent part of this season on loan at Port Vale and has already broken into the Northern Ireland side.

Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce last night agreed a 10-year contract. He has been a target of Wolves and several other clubs but will stay at the Reebok stadium after three months of talks.

Michael Knighton is selling his 93% stake in Carlisle after eight years at the helm. The new owners will be a consortium headed by a Scottish businessman, Stephen Brown.

webTitle: Wenger the avenger aims to repair opening day crash

fields.headline: Wenger the avenger aims to repair opening day crash
fields.standfirst: Form and placings indicate a close run thing at Highbury today
fields.trailText: Form and placings indicate a close run thing at Highbury today.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger must be putting it mildly when he describes his visit to Sunderland on the opening day of the season as "a nightmare". Arsenal lost, Patrick Vieira was sent off and Wenger was involved in a tunnel incident with the fourth official that landed him a 12-game touchline ban he is still trying to overturn.

When Sunderland Part II hits Highbury today, Wenger will hope for an afternoon less eventful and more successful. As he says, not much more could have gone wrong at the Stadium of Light and this is a match Arsenal need to win. "It's as simple as that." Not just to pursue Manchester United but to keep Sunderland, one place behind in third, off their backs.

The chances of avoiding more rising on-pitch temperatures may be helped by the fact that Darren Williams is likely to be on Sunderland's bench. He was elbowed by Vieira as he tried to haul the French man back, seemed to be accused by Arsenal players of cheating and was said by Wenger to have been close to a serious post-match incident with Thierry Henry in the tunnel.

Not that Arsenal's manager expects Sunderland to arrive intent on goading Vieira. "I never go into a game with suspicious ideas about anything," he said. "I just try to see my team doing well and I can't imagine Sunderland will come down and just try to wind up Patrick. That would not be fair. I'm sure it will be committed physically, but a fair game."

In any case Wenger insists that the presence of Peter Reid's team will not stir bad memories of his post-match problems with the fourth official Paul Taylor, against whom he was found guilty by the Football Association of using "threatening behaviour and physical intimidation".

"It was nothing to do with Sunderland," he said. "It was with Mr Taylor." His appeal against the touchline ban, which had been due to start in late October, has yet to be heard - "it's planned for 2003," he joked - and Taylor is facing suspension himself for comments allegedly made to the Notts County striker Sean Farrell while refereeing a game in October.

Relations between Wenger and Reid have never been anything other than frosty, and they hardly thawed yesterday when Reid said: "Patrick Vieira's sending-off was a controversial incident, according to their manager. It's not as if I sent Williams on to kick Vieira - he's too small for that."

The 23-year-old Williams may need minor nose surgery at the end of the season after Vieira's foul, which tends to back Reid up. "The controversy came from Mr Wenger and had nothing to do with me," the Sunderland manager added.

It did not prevent Reid praising Wenger's side. "They're brilliant," he said. "They've got strength in Tony Adams, Martin Keown and Lee Dixon, strength I've tried to instil here. Vieira is a world-class player and Thierry Henry, when he is at full tilt, is frightening."

The French striker's hat-trick against Leicester reinforced Reid's fear, even if Sunderland boasted the same Boxing Day feat, thanks to Kevin Phillips. The visitors can only hope their striker has finally rediscovered the form of last season.

Sunderland have risen almost unnoticed. Whispers of European nights are spreading across Wearside.

"There's nothing wrong with being confident because we're playing well at the moment," Reid said. "We are the third-best team in the country. If we can get something at Arsenal, people will start to sit up."

fields.headline: It only takes a minute...
fields.standfirst: What can you say in a 60-second film?  Jonathan Romney  makes his own miniature contribution to cinema
fields.trailText: What can you say in a 60-second film? Jonathan Romney makes his own miniature contribution to cinema
fields.body:
No one in their right mind would actively encourage a critic to make films, but I've made one anyway. It's mercifully short: exactly one minute, and that's the length of my entire oeuvre to date. That makes me a micro- (possibly a nano-) auteur.

These things are always relative, and so is the length of a minute. In the average feature, it's barely enough time for the golden stars to revolve round the peak of Paramount mountain. But 60 seconds to get in and out - that's tight. The last time I saw it done was in a centenary-of-cinema compilation that challenged leading directors to hand-crank a facsimile of the Lumière brothers' cinematograph for roughly 53 seconds, the duration of the brothers' original strips of film. Wim Wenders filmed two actors smiling sweetly, David Lynch created a sci-fi comic-strip that must have taken months to set up, and Abbas Kiarostami, if memory serves, fried an egg.

But what if you have exactly 60 seconds to make your point? Stop For a Minute is a series of shorts commissioned by Dazed and Confused magazine together with FilmFour Lab, made by an eclectic bunch of directors, artists, designers, et al. The diversity is extraordinary. I've sat through enough shorts programmes at festivals to know that, given five, 10, 12 minutes, people more often than not end up doing much the same thing. But give them 60 seconds, and the possibilities seem endless - animation, portraiture, essays, documentaries, frozen moments. And invariably, whether it's explicit or not, the minute itself becomes the subject.

Michael Stipe recites all the things you can do in 60 seconds. Simon Pummell mounts a concise demonstration on relativity, showing what a minute means to a baby and to his great-grandmother. Harriman Steel give us 480 minutes - a night's sleep.

Yet no two films feel as if they last the same time. Some feel as if they're over as soon as you've registered them - not so much Stop For a Minute as Blink and You'll Miss It. With others, you can feel every second passing - and for once, that's by no means a bad thing. Some films cram in as many cuts as possible, while others take the minute as an unbroken stretch.

Roman Coppola folds his minute in two in a witty reverse-time gag. Breda Beban crams her entire life story into a single shot of the palm of her hand. In View, photographer Michael Cleary turns voyeur culture on its head by pulling back slowly from a blurry close-up of a single window, which as it gains in clarity, disappears in the mass of a city nightscape.

In more than a few cases, a film's whole meaning is placed in its ending, not so much by way of a twist, more in terms of retroactively reshaping what you've just seen - for example, US film-makers Ariel Rogers and A Kaufman with their seemingly banal slowed-down moment, given poignant new significance by the closing image.

Some films play on the fact that these films will initially be seen online, notably Plowman and Davis' pixillated rant against dotcommery, with its neat one-in-the-eye punchline. Others work a single striking image or technique: in Alnoor Dewshi's witty Shush, three speakers' faces are digitally mutated to make an unsettling commentary on language and lies.

My minute - which premieres online on January 12 - is a gag, a man-goes-to-the-doctor joke done in a single shot that lasts exactly 60 seconds from the first word to the last image. At least that was the theory, although I wouldn't bet your stopwatch on it. The actors, Lynda Steadman and Rupert Procter, produced some wonderful takes, then gamely went through another, then another, because they were a couple of seconds under or over.

In fact, at the topping-and- tailing stage of post-production, there was a bit of leeway for cheating - the last image is held for two frames. And there's a bit of digital tweaking. Put it this way, it wasn't done by the Dogme book.

I'm not sure if I learned much about directing, except that it's amazing what you can get away with if you have a terrific cast and crew and a producer who doesn't suffer fools gladly but might just tolerate a critic with delusions. I think I've pretty much mastered the technique of stroking my chin, though.

One thing I definitely learned was the importance of.... (pause, consults wristwatch)... timing.

 Stop For a Minute goes online on January 2 at www.stopforaminute.com and is on FilmFour from January 3.

fields.body:
Rob Grant created, co-wrote and co-produced the first six series of the BBC science fiction comedy Red Dwarf. His latest book, Colony, is published by Viking.
Buy Colony at Amazon.co.uk

"Science fiction comedy, per se, is a very underpopulated field. I'm not quite sure why: there's a natural link in that both SF and comedy deal in the same currency - both look at the world from odd angles. Still, here's my stab at a top 10 of SF comedy novels, in no particular order. Naturally, modesty prevents my including my own books..."

1. The Hitch-hiker's Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams
The obvious choice, really. The first three books are the best - bright, witty and chock full of brilliant concepts. Though some of the references (Mr Adams's irrational loathing of digital watches, for instance) seem dated now, it's still guaranteed to amuse.

2. The Stainless Steel Rat by Harry Harrison
Harry Harrison's work spans the whole of SF: comedy, hard SF, fantasy, you name it. All of it is worth reading. The Stainless Steel Rat series is not, on the whole, laugh-out-loud comedy, but it is funny. If you haven't tried any, ignore the gaudy covers and buy one. They're all good. Then read Captive Universe which is not a comedy book, but it will make you go out and buy the rest of his work.

3. Discworld by Terry Pratchett
There are dozens of books in the Discworld series. Technically, they're science fantasy, involving dragons and other mythical creatures. If you're a fantasy fan, Mr Pratchett certainly delivers a good laugh consistently. If you haven't read any of them yet, where have you been?

4. A Scanner Darkly by Philip K Dick
Mr Dick's work has been the source of a number of major movies: Blade Runner and Total Recall among them. A Scanner Darkly is a bizarre and often hysterically funny novel about an undercover drugs cop who finds himself on his own trail. Compulsory.

5. Slaughterhouse Five by Kurt Vonnegut Jr
A unique and original talent, Mr Vonnegut dislikes being pigeon-holed as an SF writer. The fact remains, though, that he's responsible for a lot of classic and extremely funny writing in this genre. Slaughterhouse Five is his masterpiece, and it veers from incredibly funny to as black as it gets, centred as it is around the firebombing of Dresden (at which the young author was present). Once you've read it, you'll want to rush out and buy Breakfast of Champions and Player Piano and Cat's Cradle and ... well, everything else he's written.

6. Venus On The Half-Shell by Kilgore Trout
A curiosity, this one. Kilgore Trout is a fictional science fiction writer invented by Kurt Vonnegut jr, who often used him as a way of making personal appearances in his own novels. However this book was written by Philip Jose Farmer, using Vonnegut's alter-ego character as a nom-de-plume, to break him out of a writer's block. Interesting.

7. Riverworld by Philip Jose Farmer
Again, not out-and-out comedy. The whole of humankind finds itself reincarnated on the banks of an enormous river. It's a big concept, spanning several volumes, and tremendous fun, the main heroes being the author's own favourite historical personages, including Tom Mix (the early cowboy movie actor in the 10 gallon hat), Mark Twain and a bizarrely reformed Herman Goering. Don't miss it. The series begins with To Your Scattered Bodies Go and ends with The Dark Design.

8. Ringworld by Larry Niven
Once again, not a drop dead funny comedy, but great, original characters and fantastic concepts with a wry sense of fun. A must-read. The sequel's just as good, too.

9. Colony by Rob Grant
All right, I've caved in. But then how can I provide a definitive top 10 without including this sparkling gem of the genre?

10. Backwards by Rob Grant
Outrageously, I've mentioned myself twice. Astonishing...
